description:
Cosmic Messengers 1 (Theory) [AST-3870/ AST-4870/ PHY-3870/ PHY-4870] [AST-3870/ AST-4870/ PHY-3870/ PHY-4870-1]

Faculty Name
Kandaswamy Subramanian [kandaswamy.subramanian@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Instructor: Kandaswamy Subramanian

This course introduces to the student how cosmic objects can be studied using various messengers, such as electromagnetic waves at a wide variety of bands,  gravitational waves and various energetic particles.  The course describes how these different signals originate, how they are detected, what information they carry and how to interpret them.

------

Syllabus: 

Overview of Cosmic messengers: Electromagnetic radiation-Neutrinos-Gravitational waves-Cosmic rays-Atmospheric limitations-Ground based versus Space observatories-Coherent versus incoherent detection.

Radiative transfer-Black Body radiation- Optical telescopes-detectors-noise and statistics-photometry-X-ray and Gamma-ray telescopes- Observations of Stars, galaxies, GRBs incontinuum.

Bohr Model-Hydrogen atom-Lyman and Balmer series-Optical spectroscopy-Probing star formation, high redshift galaxies-absorption line systems.

 Radiation from moving charges - Bremsstrahlung, Synchrotron and Compton processes-Thermal vs non-thermal radiation - Acceleration of relativistic particles - polarization from Synchrotron emission and Compton scattering - selfabsorption

Radio telescopes-Single dish-Radio interferometers-aperture synthesis-image reconstruction-Probing radio galaxies, quasars, black holes, CMB-coherent emission from pulsars- 21 cm line from galaxies and the EOR- Molecular lines and cold gas

Neutrino detection-Solar and supernova neutrinos-neutrino oscillations-cosmic neutrinos from early universe

Cosmic Ray detectors-highest energy cosmic rays-origin?

Gravitational wave detectors-Quadrupole formula-LIGO detections-detecting black holes and neutron star mergers-Stochastic backgrounds as probe of supermassive black holes and early universe
 

Learning Outcomes

The student will learn to appreciate the messengers and tools astronomers use to observe and understand the diverse phenomena that occur in the universe. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Pre-requisites: PHY/AST-2850: “Physics of the Universe” [desirable]; exposure to Electricity and Magnetism and basic Quantum Theory.

Recommended Reading:

1. Astrophysical Techniques, C.R. Kitchin, IoP publishing
2. Astronomy Methods, Hale Bradt, Cambridge University Press
3. High Energy Astrophysics, Malcolm Longair, Cambridge University Press
4. Radiative Processes in Astrophysics, G.W. Rybicki and A.P. Lightman, Wiley
5. Gravitational Waves vol I, Theory and Experiments, M. Maggiore,  Oxford University Press
6. Physics of the Interstellar and Intergalactic Medium, B.T. Draine,  Princeton UniversityPress

 

Grading Rubric

3 assignments of totalling 50 marks, 1 mid term of 20 marks and end exam of 30 marks
 

Attendance Policy

Attendance of 80% of classes is minimum

CourseTitle: Introduction to Biology 3: Molecular Genetics and Molecular Biology
description:
Introduction to Biology 3: Molecular Genetics and Molecular Biology [BIO-2201] [BIO-2201-1]

Faculty Name
Kasturi Mitra [Kasturi.mitra@ashoka.edu.in] ,Laasya Samhita [laasya.samhita@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

How is an organism’s structure and function regulated? The answer to this question lies within the inherited DNA and myriad interactions within the cellular milieu. Genetics has evolved phenomenally since Mendel first introduced the concept of genes during the mid-1800s. Today genetics is used in all phases of life from food to medicines, new discoveries tend to manipulate genetics not only to diagnose and find better cure for deadly diseases like cancer but also to design smart plants and microbes to enhance the quality and quantity of food and secondary metabolites such as biofuel. Hence a thorough knowledge of genetics is an absolute requirement for biologists to comprehend the complexity of life. 

Specifically, you will learn in detail the structure and function of chromosomes and genes. We will then move on to study the key areas of genetic variation and molecular genetics and focus on model organisms used for genetic studies. Subsequently we will learn more about the molecular mechanisms that underlie the genetic code and details about how it si decoded (transcritpion, translation, regulation of gene expression). This course will provide both basic and advanced understanding of the concepts and tools that are used in molecular genetics and molecular biology. Then we will discuss how to evaluate and design key cutting-edge research in the field of molecular biology.

Learning Outcomes

Ability to solve problems in genetics involving two or more sets of alleles

Basic understanding of the structure and function of a gene

Relationships  between DNA, RNA and protein and key factors that enable functions of each one

Basic principles of transcription and translation

Be able to explain at least two kinds of gene regulation with examples

Basic understanding of DNA repair and its exploitation in gene manipulation techniques

 

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prerequisites: Only students who have completed Genetics and evolution (BIO1200) course can enroll in this course.

Textbooks and resources:

1. Molecular Cell Biology. Lodish H, Berk A, Kaiser CA, Krieger M, Bretscher A, Ploegh H, Amon A and Scott MP. 7th edition. New York: W. H. Freeman and Company.

2. Molecular Biology of the Cell, Bruce Alberts, Alexander Johnson, Julian Lewis, David Morgan, Martin Raff, Keith Roberts, and Peter Walter. 6th edition. New York: Garland Science.

3. If required some printed material will be provided in the class.

4. If required electronic references will be provided for some classes.

Grading Rubric

 The course will be taught by two instructors, and there will be two written exams as well as assignments that feed into the final mark. grading could be absolute or relative. Instructors will inform students about the precise grading break up closer to the date. The exam could consist of short answer, problems and/or multiple-choice questions. It will be based on the content covered in the class and the readings from the textbooks. 

Standard Ashoka grading rubric. Conversion from percentage of total marks as below

90 – 100 A; 80 – 89.9 A-; 70 – 79.9 B+; 60 – 69.9 B; 55 – 59.9 B-; 50 – 54.5 C+; 45– 49.9 C; 40 – 44.9 C-; < 40 F

Attendance Policy

Attendance at theory and examinations are mandatory. At least 75% attendance is required to appear for the final exam. If you miss any theory class, you must find out what you missed and make sure you understand it. If you need help regarding the course, please contact the instructors or TA during office hours by prior appointment. No cell phone use is allowed during the class.  Please silence your cell phones during the class. Laptops and tablets are allowed but strictly for note taking.

CourseTitle: Introduction to Biology II: Cell Biology
description:
Introduction to Biology II: Cell Biology [BIO-2214] [BIO-2214-1]

Faculty Name
Anup Padmanabhan [anup.padmanabhan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Divyashree A N [divyashree.AN_phd19@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Cells are the fundamental unit of life. It carries out all (well… almost all!) the physiological processes essential for its survival and propagation. Within the cell, each of these processes is accomplished by molecular-machines. What are these processes and how do these mini machines carry out cellular functions? How do these cellular machines know the right place and the right time to carry out appropriate functions? In this introductory Cell Biology course, we will start by exploring some of the essential processes at the cellular level and understand how the relevant molecular machines manage to carry out these processes with such amazing fidelity and efficiency. The primary focus of this course will be on eukaryotic cells, but as and when needed we will draw comparisons with prokaryotic cellular processes to appreciate their similarities and distinctness.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this course, the participant is expected to

  • have a good conceptual grasp of basic cellular mechanisms, the molecular machinery involved, and their functional regulation within a cell.
  • develop a deeper appreciation of how individual components come together to carry out various physiological processes in a cell.

Course Contents

  • Eukaryotic and Prokaryotic Organisms - Cellular Architecture & Organization (1 L)
  • Cellular Structures (7 L)
    • Organelles
    • Membrane bound Organelles (1 L)
      • Nucleus and Nuclear Dynamics
      • Endoplasmic Reticulum
      • Mitochondria , chloroplasts, and Peroxisomes
    • Cytoplasm
    • Membrane less organelles (1 L)
      • Centrosomes
      • Cell Cortex
      • Ribo-nucleoproteins
  • Emergent Structures 
    • Cytoskeleton
      • Prokaryotic (1L)
        • FtsZ, MreB, ParM
      • Eukaryotic (3 L)
        • Actin, myosin and actomyosin regulators
        • Microtubule dynamics and Motors
        • Intermediate and Septin Filaments
    • Lamellipodia, filopodia, podosomes
    • Cellular Macromolecules (5 L)
      • Proteins
        • Protein Synthesis
        • Post Translational modifications
        • Protein Degradation 
        • Lipid-Protein Interactions 
        • DNA-Protein interactions
        • Ribo-nucleoprotein Interactions (eg - p-granules ; germ cell specification during development)
  • Cell Signaling (1 L)
    • Plasma Membrane Receptors
    • Secondary Messengers
  • Cellular Phenomena (9 L)
    • Endocytosis (1L)
    • Cell Cycle
      • Prokaryotic  (1L)
      • Eukaryotic (3L)
        • Mitosis
          • Closed and Open mitosis
          • Dynamics of Mitosis - spindle ; 
        • Cytokinesis - Role of actomyosin 
        • Meiosis - Haploid & Diploid 
    • Cell Motility & Migration (2L)
      • Prokaryotic 
      • Eukaryotic ( unicellular ; multicellular, organism development)
    • Cell Adhesion (2L)
      • Microbial - biofilm 
      • Multicellular Organism  
    • Cell-cell adhesion ( Cadherin ; Ephrin; Nectins, Tight Junctions ..)
      • Cell substrate adhesion  (Integrin based)
    • Cell Death (1L)
      • Programmed Cell Death - Apoptosis
      • Necrosis
      • Pyroptosis
      • Autophagy
  • Experimental approaches in Cell Biology (2 L)
    • Fractionation
    • Reconstitution 
    • Pulse Chase 
    • Microscopy
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)
  • The contents and discussions in this course go beyond the subject covered in any one textbook. Hence attending and class participation goes a long way in preparation.
  • Reference for the context is taken from the following sources
    1. Textbooks  - 
      • Molecular Biology of the Cell -  Alberts et al
      • Molecular Cell Biology - Lodhish et. al
      • other cell biology textbooks available in the library
    2. www.ibiology.org
Grading Rubric

Assessment & Grading 

  • The course is divided into 4 quarters. Each quarter will culminate in a quiz There are four written quiz sessions, each 90 minutes long.  Quiz sessions may be ‘open book*’.

*Open book =  you may bring in only handwritten notes—no textbooks / no laptops / No printed matter. 

  • The three best scores (out of 4) will be counted toward the final grading. Due to the course format, the schedule is extremely tight. So if you miss a quiz, there will NOT be any retest (or other forms of assessment) for examinations under any circumstances.
  • We will follow absolute grading.
  • Note that 10 points will be awarded for class participation and discussions throughout the course.

IMPORTANT - 

  • The prescribed syllabus will require significant reading effort from the students.
  • Lecture slides are not comprehensive material for your preparation for assessment. Lecture slides are merely pointers for me to discuss concepts in class.
  •  
  • This course is intended to develop an independent line of thinking and reasoning toward understanding cell biology concepts. Academic Integrity happens to be the most essential ingredient in achieving that. Any student guilty of, aiding or abetting any form of Academic Dishonesty will score a ‘zero’ in the relevant assessment. Repeat offenders will attract a ‘Fail’ grade. All steps will be taken in strict adherence to the Ashoka Academic Integrity Policy. 
  • Every student will be free to ask questions and express their views (s) in a class discussion. Those might or might not align with some other idea. In any case, we will follow a zero-tolerance policy towards any behavior that is offensive or discriminatory based on ability, gender, race, ethnicity, color, religion, age, marital status, or sexual orientation.

Grading rubric

80 – 90 A- 3.7

75 – 79 B+ 3.3

70 – 74 B 3.0

65 – 69 B- 2.7

60 – 64 C+ 2.3

55 – 59 C 2.0

50 – 54 C- 1.7

45 – 49 D+ 1.3

45 – 49 D 1.0

40 – 44 D- 0.7

< 40 F 0

Attendance Policy

A lot of discussions happen beyond the lecture slides, which maybe included in formulating quiz questions.

Hence attendance, while not mandatory, is strongly encouraged.

Microbiology [BIO-2411/ BIO-6411] [BIO-2411/ BIO-6411-1]

Faculty Name
Laasya Samhita [laasya.samhita@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Microbiology is the study of the microbial world. In this course, we will explore various aspects of microbial genetics, evolution, lifestyle and diversity. Starting with a basic understanding of microbial biology in the first half, we will move on to their interaction with humans in the second half. We will delve into how both prokaryotic and eukaryotic microbes have served as model organisms furthering human understanding of basic biological processes at the molecular level. By recent estimates, the human body houses roughly the same number of bacterial as human cells. We will explore human-microbial interactions starting with infectious diseases and going on to the microbiome. Under biotechnology, we will look at how microbes are harnessed by humans in the food and medicine industrial sectors. While this is primarily a theory course, there will likely be 2 lab sessions to improve understanding of concepts learnt in class. We will also have a guest lecture by an expert in one of the sub-areas we discuss, and use audio-visual support to better our understanding of the subject.

Learning Outcomes

Understand and explain why we still do not know the full extent of microbial diversity

Note how bacteria, viruses, archaea and fungi are different from each other

Note what technical insights/advances helped humans to identify, grow and observe microbes, and what advances we still need

Explain how bacteria propagate

Explain why viruses differ from most other microbes

Describe any one fundamental biological advance made possible with a microbial model system

Mention the causative agents of at least two infectious diseases along with their mechanism of infection

Explain briefly why resistance to drugs is a major health problem today

Describe at least two industrial processes that rely on microbes

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

This is a 2000 level course. UG students in or post their 2nd years as well as ASP students interested in pursuing basic, applied or molecular microbiology and/or biotechnology should plan on taking this course. Masters students who have had no prior exposure to microbiology could also consider taking this course. reading material will consist of textbooks as well as some class hand outs.

Recommended textbooks:

Microbiology by Pelczar, Chan and Krieg (5th edition onwards)

Brock biology of microorganisms, (13th edition onwards)

 

Grading Rubric

Standard Ashooka grading scale. Course assessment will be done using grading (absolute or relative based on final class performance), in-class quizzes, assignments and or an exam, and group presentations. This is tentative and can be changed based on the instructor’s discretion.

Attendance Policy

Attendance is strongly encouraged. Peer discussions in class are an important component of the overall learning experience. There will be pre-announced spot quizzes as part of the overall assessment and grading. Those who miss these without a valid excuse given before class starts (eg: a doctor’s note) will miss the corresponding mark. The questions will be sourced from concepts taught in the classroom as well as common textbook content. Please note that late class entries will not be allowed. If you are more than 10 min late, please do not come in that day. It is distracting both to the instructor and your colleagues in class.

This microbiology elective is designed for a holistic introduction to the fascinating field of microbes and their behaviour. The course is intended for those who want to pursue a future career in the biological sciences, be it in academia, industry, science communication, policy or other related areas. It requires a substantial effort both in terms of thinking and reading from students. Slides may be shared post class but will in no way be sufficient for preparation towards assignments or exams. These are only intended as a broad guide to the instructor and students. Assignments, exams and their deadlines are to be taken seriously. Again, missing one without prior information or with insufficient justification (to be decided case by case at the instructor’s discretion) will mean missing the corresponding mark.

Use of phones during lectures is not allowed. Any student whose behaviour disrupts functioning may be asked to leave the classroom.

Academic dishonesty (eg: cheating, plagiarism, fabrication) will not be tolerated. Such instances will be dealt with strictly and according to university guidelines.

Evolutionary Genetics [BIO-3456/ BIO-6456] [BIO-3456/ BIO-6456-1]

Faculty Name
Sudipta Tung [sudipta.tung@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Evolutionary thinking is rather pervasive. Its applications are not only limited to all subdisciplines of biology, but also across a range of fields outside biology, from cosmology to town building. Evolutionary computation is a distinguished field now enabling solutions to inherently complex systems.

In this course I plan to lay a firm foundation of evolutionary theory with the help of basic principles of genetics along with the tools of mathematics and computation. This will be followed by connecting those concepts to the essence of modern omics techniques, human health and evolutionary medicine.

This course does not need any pre-requisite, except for 10th standard mathematics. All other necessary concepts will be taught during the course itself. However, an introduction to genetics, 12th-grade Mathematics, a basic knowledge of coding in any programming language and will be helpful (but not essential) for this course.

Learning Outcomes

Strong foundational knowledge of the principles behind evolutionary thinking and experimentation.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

There is no prescribed textbook for this course. Suitable reading materials will be shared after the lectures. Interested students may go through the following books for additional reading.

  • Rice, S., 2004. Evolutionary theory: mathematical and conceptual foundations.
  • Freeman, S. and Herron, J.C., 2007. Evolutionary analysis.
  • Hartl, D.L., Clark, A.G. and Clark, A.G., 1997. Principles of population genetics (Vol. 116).
Grading Rubric

There are four grading components. Their relative weights are given below.

Exam (best 2 out of 3): 40%

Classroom assignments 30%

Review & synthesis seminar/poster: 20%

Class participation: 10%

At the end of the course, a letter grade will be given based on the overall percentage marks as per the scheme below.

80 – 89 A-
75 – 79 B+
70 – 74 B
65 – 69 B-
60 – 64 C+
55 –59 C
50 – 54 C-
45 – 49 D+
40 – 44 D
<40 F

  2. If you decide to attend a class you should maintain general classroom norms.
  3. If you have a genuine reason to miss one of the exams (with approval from OAA), inform me at the earliest so that I can schedule a makeup exam.

Introduction to Mandarin Level - 1 [CHI-1101] [CHI-1101-1]

Faculty Name
Shao Chin [shao.chin@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Introduction to Mandarin is a beginner’s language course, specifically designed for students with no exposure to Modern Standard Chinese (putonghua 普通話). The course will introduce students to the Chinese language and culture and focus on basic speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. This includes an introduction to phonetics, basic vocabulary, and expressions of daily use. The course will prepare the students to attain a certain level of understanding and proficiency in Chinese language through interpretive, interpersonal, and presentational modes. It will integrate Chinese culture into language learning through both written and audio-visual means to familiarize students with the culture and language. At the end of the class, students will be able to read and comprehend Chinese texts on various topics moderately without the aid of pinyin and tone marks. They will be able to give presentations in Chinese on a prepared topic and write short paragraphs and compositions on a limited range of topics and situations.

This course is part of a two-semester sequence building towards a TOCFL Novice certification at the end of the Spring semester.

There will be two sections of Introduction to Mandarin Level 1 offered in Monsoon 2022:

CHI 1101-1 M/W/F 10:10–11:40 (taught by Shao Jhe Chin Laoshi)

CHI 1101-2 M/W/F 15:00–16:30 (taught by Hsu Weili Laoshi)

Homework, regular short quizzes, attendence,midterm/final exam.

Two points are deducted for each absence.

* If you fail to attend more than 8 classes, you will not be allowed to continue the course.

Daoist and Buddhist Apocalypses [CHI-2003/ SOA-2238] [CHI-2003/ SOA-2238-1]

Faculty Name
Daniel Murray [daniel.murray@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

When is the end of the world coming? Who will survive? What horrors await us?

This course offers an alternative history of religion in China by focusing on visions of the end of the world in Chinese Buddhist and Daoist thought and practice. These ideas often developed on the margins of society or in direct opposition to the state. How did these groups conceive of time and space? What experiences did members of these movements have? What did they gain from participation in them? By moving these groups to the center of Chinese history, we may then be able to reconsider how we think about Chinese society and culture. In each unit, we will discuss and analyze historical and ethnographic cases in relation to broader anthropological and sociological theories to see how they may or may not apply.

Unit one overviews ideas about the apocalypse in general and conceptions of time in China and early Buddhism. Unit two covers the early developments in organized Daoism and Chinese Buddhism and their apocalyptic visions. Unit three jumps forward in time to late imperial China to discuss a variety of sectarian religious movements with millenarian beliefs. Finally, unit four considers the modern qigong movement Falun Gong and their conception of salvation.

Concepts in Organic Chemistry [CHM-1101] [CHM-1101-1]

Faculty Name
Deepak Asthana [deepak.asthana@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

About the course:

Chemistry teaches the art of creating new molecules, new materials, compounds that never existed. Everything around us is a product of some sort of chemical/biochemical reaction. Fate of any reaction is largely controlled by the some very basic molecular properties that affect the rate and mechanism of interactions leading to formation of the product.    

This course offers an introductory level understanding of the various processes which influence the stability and reactivity of intermediates and the end products. Course structure is designed to refresh your chemistry knowledge from your school and to prepare you for your journey towards becoming an expert. It will provide comprehensive account of all the key concepts that you may require to solve the puzzles of chemical bonding and reactions.

The world of chemistry, and especially organic chemistry, looks scary. However, if fundamental rules and some basic principles are understood, most things start becoming obvious events which could be planned and designed to follow the desired reaction pathway. Concept of electronegativity, resonance, conjugation, hybridisation, and aromaticity are key in explaining the number of complexities found organic chemistry.   

The first question that one might ask is why atoms form molecules, and once they have come close to each other, what keeps them intact. How strong is the force that keeps them held in a molecule? Why certain molecules are linear, many others have non-planar three-dimensional shapes? What are the factors that decide the path and the fate of any chemical reaction?  

We all know that carbon has tendency to form multiple bonds and that is why it may form very large chain of bonded atoms resulting in production of vast number of different compounds. The number of known organic compounds today is humongous. Generally, compounds are given some names based on their properties or behaviour. Such names reflect no information about its compositions. If there is no unified naming system in in existence, it will be impossible to handle such a huge database of existing compounds. In this course we will practice the international nomenclature system (IUPAC) too and learn naming some of the structurally very complex molecules e.g., cyclic/poly-cyclic systems.

The purpose of this course is to make sure that your journey into the realm of organic reactions and all those rules & exceptions is more enjoyable!

Course Contents/Topics:

  • Structure and bonding: Ionic, Covalent, Coordinate and Hydrogen bonds, The octet rule,  Formal charge, Sigma (σ-) and pi (π-) bonds,  Hybridisation, , Inductive effects, Hyperconjugation, Mesomeric effects, Steric effect,  Acidity and basicity, Acids, Bases  
  • Aromaticity: Hückel’s rule and characteristics of aromatic compounds benzenoid and non-benzenoid compounds, Alternant and nonalternant hydrocarbons, Annulenes, Anti-aromaticity, Homo-aromaticity and Nomenclature of aromatic compounds. 
  • Nomenclature:  Functional groups, IUPAC Nomenclature of aliphatic organic compounds: Alkanes, Alkenes, Alkynes, Alcohols, Amines, Carboxylic acids, Ethers, Halides, and nitriles.
  • Stereochemistry: Representation of stereostructures: Fischer, Newmann, and Sawhorse Projection formulae and their interconversions.
  • Conformational analysis: Butane and cyclohexane (mono and disubstituted) and their relative stability and energy diagrams.
  • Configurational analysis: Geometrical isomerism: cis–trans, syn-anti, and E/Z notations with C.I.P rules.
  • Optical isomerism: Chirality, Enantiomers, The Cahn–Ingold–Prelog (R and S) nomenclature, The D and L nomenclature, Diastereoisomers (or diastereomers), Diastereoisomers,  Mesomer Racemic mixture,  resolution of racemic mixtures

In case you want to discuss more about the course structure and learning outcomes, feel free to reach me in AC 03, Office 311. My e-mail: deepak.asthana@ashoka.edu.in

Learning Outcomes
  • Students will develop understanding about various types of bond formations. Will learn about the factors that decide the preference of one type of bonding over others and also the stability of molecules which are ionic or covalnet. Will also learn about hydrogen bonds and its importance in supramolecular systems.   
  • Electronic and steric factors basically control the behaviour of a molecule in any chemical reaction. A clear understanding of electronic and steric effects enables us to predict a number of chemical properties.  
  • Will learn the international nomeclature system for organic systems. 
  • Will study the fact that why some system exist in a particular conformation. What makes a specific geometric arrangement more stable than the other.  
  • Concept of aromaticity and basic principles will be explained.
  • Chiral systems, enantiomers and nomenclature of chiral mole cules will be taught.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

This course is suitable to all who have studies science a school levels and is interested in knowing more about chemical processes.

Suggested Reading/Books:

Organic Chemistry by Jonathan Clayden, Nick Greeves and Stuart Warren.

Advanced Organic Chemistry: Part A: Structure and Mechanisms  by Francis A. Carey  and Richard J. Sundberg.

Stereochemistry of Organic Compounds: E. L. Eliel and S. H. Willen

Interested in studying more about atomic orbitals: Principles of Atomic Orbitals by N. N. Greenwood

Grading Rubric

Assignments: 30%

Mid-term Exam: 30%

Final-term Exam: 40%

Attendance Policy

Minmum 80%

CourseTitle: Organic chemistry from nature to laboratory
description:
Organic chemistry from nature to laboratory [CHM-1104] [CHM-1104-1]

Faculty Name
Sourav Chatterjee [sourav.chatterjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The course is designed for Monsoon 2023 semester undergraduate students. This course will address advance knowledge for chemistry students elucidating reaction mechanisms, concepts of different reactions and their pathway through understanding making and breaking chemical bonds.

Learning Outcomes

Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

1. Learn about notations and significance of different types of arrows involved depicting stability of chemical structures, chemical reactions. Arrows notation to show movement of electrons in chemical reactions.

2. Explain stability of intermediates formed in breaking covalent bonds in terms of the nature of the atoms, or group of atoms, attached to the carbon atom.

3. Understand mechanism of different chemical reactions.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Books to be followed: Organic Chemistry (T. W. Graham Solomons, Craig B. Fryhle, Scott A. Snyder), Organic Chemistry (Jonathan Clayden), Organic Chemistry (Arun Bahl).

Course Description is outlined below:

Language of arrows: straight arrow, curved arrow, half headed arrows and double headed arrows

Bond cleavage: Homolytic & Heterolytic bond

Reaction intermediates formation, stability, and reactivity: Carbocation, Carbo anion, Free radicals, Carbene, Nitrene, Benzyne

Type of Reagents: Electrophile & Nucleophiles, General types of reaction

Addition reactions:  Electrophilic & Nucleophilic addition, Markonikoff & Anti Armónicos Rule

Elimination reactions: E1, E2 and E1CB, Factors affection elimination reaction, Energy profile diagram

Substitution reactions: SN1 and SN2, SNi, Factors affection substitution reaction Energy profile diagram, Anchimeric Assistance, Substitution reaction in aromatic compounds

Condensation reactions: Aldol condensation, Dieckmann condensation, Claisen condensation, Enamine and Imine formation

Pericyclic reactions:  Woodward Hoffman Rule and Molecular Orbital Theory Diels Alder reaction

Rearrangement reactions: Carbocation, Carbanion, Free radicals, Carbene, Nitrene intermediates

Assignment: 30%

Quiz: 20%

Final Exam: 50%

60%

Overview

Dual behavior of light and particle, elementary concepts of operator, eigenfunctions  and  eigenvalues, commutation of operators, commutator and uncertainty relation, Postulates of quantum mechanics, particle in a box, extension of  the problem to two or three dimensions and concept of  degenarate energy levels, angular momentum, rigid rotor, simple harmonic oscillator, concepts of classical  turning points, tunneling, hydrogen atom,  concepts of molecule (MO and VB theory), rotational spectra, and vibrational spectra.

 

Learning Outcomes

Learning Outcomes

1. The limitations of classical mechanics at molecular length scales
2. The differences between classical and quantum mechanics

5. How molecular phenomena can be related to model problems
6. How to interpret spectra

Programming Language Design and Implementation [CS-1319] [CS-1319-1]

Faculty Name
Partha Pratim Das [partha.das@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Starting 1950’s (FORTAN & LISP) innumerable programming languages have been designed, implemented, deployed, and re-engineered. Some are targeted for specific domains while many serve to be ‘general purpose’ and cross-domain. Yet all of them have one thing in common - the ability to express the computational needs for some real world problem, to act as a bridge between the man and the machine. In this evolution, several paradigms of computing emerged – functional, procedural, object-oriented, generic (meta programming), logic – to name the major few. And languages have been functional (LISP), procedural (C), logic (Prolog), or simply multi-paradigm (C++).

Programming Languages are living entities of CS. They are born (designed and implemented), grow in their use, and fade out to others. Hence, long serving languages need regular re-births and / or repurposing (C++98 -> C++11 -> C++14 -> …). Understandably lot of languages (actually most) die when they stop serving their computing role. And a few are resurrected (like LISP), when we rediscover their worth after decades.

PLDI will introduce you to the dynamics of programming language design in the context of evolving requirements and trade-offs concerning syntax, semantics, pragmatics, and paradigms. You have been developers in languages. PLDI will give you the perspective of being creators of them. For this understanding, you will need to master two aspects in depth.

First, how languages are implemented. How to deal with their syntax, semantics, and pragmatics – traditionally known as ‘Compilation Techniques’. This will cover lexical and syntax analysis, memory management, runtime behaviour of programs, translation to machine code, and optimization. Some background material like fundamentals of automata and formal languages will be covered if you are not already aware of them.

Second, how languages are designed. Design is a complex process involving the understanding of requirements of the target users on one hand and the constraints of the syntax, semantics, and pragmatics that is necessary for its implementation on the other. A good designer like Niklaus Wirth of Pascal, Dennis Ritchie of C, Bjarne Stroustrup of C++, or Guido van Rossum of Python works out a best match between the two. You will be exposed to the parameters a designer has to juggle with including Name scoping and binding; Programming elements – expressions, control flow, procedures, exception, and concurrency; Data types and abstraction - polymorphism; Type Systems; Computing elements – iteration, recursion, and calculus; Paradigm choice; and Domain specific languages

In the process, you may hope to pick up a few interesting languages.

The course is practice orieneted. So you will need to write a complete compiler for a tiny language.

Learning Outcomes
  • You will learn to be a designer of your own language and be able to implement it. You will also develop deep understanding for why the programming languges are designed the way they are.
  • You will learn to implement a complier with end-to-end features using the nanoC language and compare it will gcc.
  • You will also learn the basic language translation techniques and a few interesting languages from different paradigms.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)
  • Compilers : Principles, Techniques and Tool, Aho, Lam, Sethi, Ullman, 2nd Edition. (Dragon Book)
  • Concepts of Programming Languages, Robert W. Sebesta, 11th Edition. (Sebesta)
  • In addition, presentation slides will include several open references.

  2. Quizzes: 20%
  3. Mid-term Test: 20%
  4. End-term Test: 30%

  • No extension given on assignments on any ground except for medical if certified by Infirmary at Ashoka.
  • No special consideration for representating Ashoka in events outside the University. If you miss, you lose marks.
  • Best 3 of 4 quizzes will be taken.
  • If mid-sem is missed, Q4 will be the place holder for it.

Introduction to Critical Thinking [CT-0001] [CT-0001-12]

Faculty Name
Raginee Sarmah [raginee.sarmah@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The Introduction to Critical Thinking course is grounded in the building of proficiency through focussed attention on the basic tasks that develop a critical mind: reading, writing, speaking, listening. It considers these vital acts – of reading a text closely, of making connections between different subjects, of participating in an ongoing conversation, of being discerning about source material – as essential habits that can be strengthened through repetition. The course provides space in which you can engage with a variety of source materials and understand how to ask questions that extend and enrich your understanding – of situations, texts, institutions and people. It is also intended to be an induction into the distinct practices of academic research and writing within a university. By the close of the course, you will have a keener sense of your own processes of learning, thinking and writing, and a more robust sense of what it means to be ‘scholar’ in an active knowledge community constituted by your peers.

Learning Outcomes

Reading:

1. Breaking down texts into identifiable parts.

2. Making patterns and connections across texts

3. Building reading stamina and the ability to select texts

4. Understanding textual context, genre and source material

Writing: 

1. Developing the craft of outlining, revising, editing

2. Applying form, voice, style, tone to affect writing

3. Developing logical, coherent, structured writing

4. Using explanatory, narrative and justificatory writing

Thinking:

1. Practising converting thoughts into words

2. Narrowing down a curiosity or thought into a question

3. Constructing and developing a reasoned argument

4. Engaging meaningfully with multiple perspectives

Speaking+Listening:

1. Aiming for confidence, clarity, coherence 

2. Practising and harnessing audience engagement 

3. Developing active and respectful listening  

4. Engaging meaningfully with ongoing discussions

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

You need no specific training in order to credit an ICT course. Nor is an ICT course geared towards preparing you specifically for a career in a particular subject or field. Rather, you can expect it to guide you in the transition out of how you approached academic work in school to how you might approach it in a university setting, and to sharpen your understanding of what it means to be critical, questioning and deliberate in your approach to the world. 

ICT is writing-intensive. You can expect to work on longer assignments (the mid-term and the end-term essays) over multiple rounds of feedback, as well as shorter assignments through the semester. You will also need to rehearse regular habits of reading (of academic texts and wider materials) and responding (to prompts, or given materials). Finally, as the ICT is a small cohort-oriented course, you can expect it to have a strong participation and interaction component, and also expect to work on projects both individually and in collaboration with your coursemates.

Grading Rubric

The ICT will be graded on a number of elements. Your final assessment will account for your participation and performance in writing components primarily, and also a host of non-writing components. The rubric will assess both formative work (building towards a bigger piece, or continuing a specific ‘habit’) and summative work (producing a final output).

Attendance Policy

For this course, you are allowed three unexcused absences (for which you do not need permission from the instructor) and two excused absences (for which you do need permission from the instructor). The penalty for any absence beyond these five will be decided by the ICT instructor on a case-by-case basis. Please note that a consistent pattern of non-attendance may include discretionary penalties such as grade cuts.

If you are absent, the responsibility for making up for what has been missed – by looking at class notes and/or speaking to classmates – is yours. The responsibility for finding out about any homework that has been set for future classes is yours too.

Introduction to Critical Thinking [CT-0001] [CT-0001-14]

Faculty Name
Dibyangee Saha [dibyangee.saha@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The Introduction to Critical Thinking course is grounded in the building of proficiency through focussed attention on the basic tasks that develop a critical mind: reading, writing, speaking, listening. It considers these vital acts – of reading a text closely, of making connections between different subjects, of participating in an ongoing conversation, of being discerning about source material – as essential habits that can be strengthened through repetition. The course provides space in which you can engage with a variety of source materials and understand how to ask questions that extend and enrich your understanding – of situations, texts, institutions and people. It is also intended to be an induction into the distinct practices of academic research and writing within a university. By the close of the course, you will have a keener sense of your own processes of learning, thinking and writing, and a more robust sense of what it means to be ‘scholar’ in an active knowledge community constituted by your peers.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

You do not need to have any specific kind of training in order to do an ICT course. Nor is any ICT course geared towards preparing you specifically for a career in a particular subject or field. Rather, you can expect it to guide you in transition out of how you approached academic work in school to how you might approach it in a university setting, and to sharpen your understanding of what it means to be critical, questioning and deliberate in your approach to the world. 

ICT is writing-intensive. You can expect to work on longer assignments (the Mid-Term and the End-Term essays) over multiple rounds of feedback, as well as shorter assignments through the semester. You will also need to rehearse regular habits of reading (of academic texts and wider materials) and responding (to prompts, or given materials). Finally, as the ICT is a small cohort-oriented course, you can expect it to have a strong participation and interaction component, and can expect to work on projects both individually and in collaboration with your coursemates. 

Readings and Theme:

In this section of the ICT, we will be working with multimedia; our course material includes podcasts, films, music, graphic novels, literary fiction, poems, alongside academic texts. This curation encourages you to:

a) Engage all your five senses as critical thinking tools
b) Re-evaluate how to read sensory perceptions — as empirical knowledge, political action, and as culturally produced meanings.  

Our discussions will not only examine the role of five senses in building knowledge systems, but also where they place us as readers and writers within and without the canon. As a class, we are most interested in the business of academic writing. Our exercises will, thus, focus on synthesizing authorial voices, using language as a critical tool, formulating arguments, and developing a critical lens for research.

Listed below are prospective readings for the course: 

1. Berger, John. Ways of Seeing. Penguin uK, 2008.
2. Descartes, René. Meditations on first philosophy. Broadview Press, 2013.
3. Lee, Joel. "Odor and order: how caste is inscribed in space and sensoria." Comparative Studies of South Asia, Africa and the Middle East 37.3 (2017): 470-490.
4. Joyce, James. “Araby.” Dubliners. OUP Oxford, 2008.
5. Hazarika, Bhaskar. Aamis. Signum Productions, 2019
6. Baudrillard, Jean. The Gulf War did not take place. Indiana University Press, 1995.

Grading Rubric

1. Mid-term Assignment (20% of total grade)

a) 15% for Synthesis Paper
b) 5% for Peer Review

2. End-term Assignment (40% of total grade)

a) 30% for Academic essay
b) 10% for Annotated Bibliography

3. Group Presentation (15% of total grade)

4. Course Engagement (25% of total grade)

a) 15% for class participation and continuous assessment 
b) 10% for turn-it-in assignments

Attendance Policy
  • You are expected to excuse yourself from class in case you cannot attend it
  • You will be notified if/when 3 absences are recorded.
  • The penalty for more than five absences will be decided by the ICT instructor on a case-by-case basis. A consistent pattern of non-attendance may include discretionary penalties such as grade cuts.
  • If you are absent, the responsibility for making up for what has been missed — by looking at class notes and/or speaking to classmates — is yours. An excused absence does not excuse you from take-home assignments.

Introduction to Critical Thinking [CT-0001] [CT-0001-4]

Faculty Name
Kundan Sen [kundan.sen@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course introduces students to critical thinking and writing through an emphasis on close reading, attention to detail, and a slow, deliberative articulation of logical arguments. Students will undertake a reading and writing intensive coursework in which readings will be organised around a meditation on ‘the Self’, that goes beyond disciplinary constraints and attempts to understand the self as an emergent phenomenon with a relationship to space, time, and media, each of which will be an area of investigation. 

The first section aims to move away from the universalising language that one encounters in utterances such as ‘the unmarked citizen’ or ‘the rational individual’. The readings in this section aim to help one understand the self as a complex and multidimensional entity, which emerges relationally with others, as a ‘presentation’, and narratively as a ‘construct’. The second section then looks at how the self is an inherently ‘spatialised’ entity with readings that speak to the relationship between space and selfhood through cultural concepts such as ‘place-making’, and ‘lifeworlds’. In this, we will also be interested in exploring the ways in which such spatialised, cultural expressions of selfhood get articulated through an engagement with and in various forms of media, especially internet mediated social-media that pervades our ordinary lifeworlds. The course provides space in which you can engage with a variety of source materials and understand how to ask questions that extend and enrich your understanding -- of situations, texts, institutions and people. It is also intended to be an induction into the distinct practices of academic research and writing within a university.

Learning Outcomes

Reading:

1. Breaking down texts into identifiable parts.

2. Making patterns and connections across texts

3. Building reading stamina and the ability to select texts

4. Understanding textual context, genre and source material

 

Writing 

1. Developing the craft of outlining, revising, editing

2. Applying form, voice, style, tone to affect writing

3. Developing logical, coherent, structured writing

4. Using explanatory, narrative and justificatory writing

 

Thinking

1. Practising converting thoughts into words

2. Narrowing down a curiosity or thought into a question

3. Constructing and developing a reasoned argument

4. Engaging meaningfully with multiple perspectives

Speaking, Listening

1. Aiming for confidence, clarity, coherence 

2. Practising and harnessing audience engagement 

3. Developing active and respectful listening to others 

4. Engaging meaningfully with ongoing discussions

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

You do not need to have any specific kind of training in order to do an ICT course. Nor is any ICT course geared towards preparing you specifically for a career in a particular subject or field. Rather, you can expect it to guide you in transition out of how you approached academic work in school to how you might approach it in a university setting, and to sharpen your understanding of what it means to be critical, questioning and deliberate in your approach to the world. 

Students can expect to undertake reading and short writing assignments each week, with a longer mid-term writing assignment and a final end-term research paper. 

Short-Writing Assignments: These are the elementary blocks of the course aimed at performing crucial habit-building around the act of writing. Students will be required to produce short pieces of writing (around 500 words) each week based on the reading they would have undertaken in the preceding week. Students will ideate about their thoughts and opinions on the readings and class discussions and articulate them in these short pieces. These will be due before class each Monday. 

Long-Writing Assignments: These will comprise the mid-terms assignment (800-1000 words) and the end-semester research paper (1500-2000 words). Students will be evaluated on the basis of their critical thinking skills as well as their writing skills in reference to the grading rubric that students shall be familiarised with. 

In addition to writing, this course is focused on developing an extensive reading habit among students and as such, students shall be required to undertake reading tasks each week, from a range of articles, academic essays, anthologies, and books. The writings assignments shall be based on students reading of these texts and therefore emphasis shall be placed on close reading and attention to detail and a careful dissection of ideas presented in each text. (The reading list shall be updated in consultation with the cohort).  

Grading Rubric

The ICT will be graded on a number of elements. Your final assessment will account for your participation and performance in writing and non-writing components, and in formative work (building towards a bigger piece, or continuing a specific ‘habit’) and summative work (producing a final output). 

 

The components are below. 

 

1. Participation (in classes, meetings and peer work)

2. Regular Assignments 

3. Presentation 

4. A mid-term assignment of 800-1500 words involving the synthesis of multiple sources

5. An end-term Academic essay of 1500 - 2500 words

6. Improvement over the course

A standard Ashoka rubric will be used in your eventual ICT grade, wherein the highest possible grade is ‘A’ and the lowest possible grade is ‘F’.In general, grades in the ‘A’ range demonstrate that you have consistently exceeded the expectations of the course; grades in the ‘B’ range indicate that you have met the expectations for the course; grades in the ‘C’ range and below, demonstrate that you have fallen short of the expectations for this cours

Attendance Policy

For this course, students are allowed three unexcused absences (for which you do not need permission from the instructor) and two excused absences (for which you do need permission from the instructor). The penalty for any absence beyond these five will be decided by the ICT instructor on a case-by-case basis. Please note that a consistent pattern of non-attendance may include discretionary penalties such as grade cuts.

Introduction to Critical Thinking [CT-0001] [CT-0001-5]

Faculty Name
Kundan Sen [kundan.sen@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course introduces students to critical thinking and writing through an emphasis on close reading, attention to detail, and a slow, deliberative articulation of logical arguments. Students will undertake a reading and writing intensive coursework in which readings will be organised around a meditation on ‘the Self’, that goes beyond disciplinary constraints and attempts to understand the self as an emergent phenomenon with a relationship to space, time, and media, each of which will be an area of investigation. 

The first section aims to move away from the universalising language that one encounters in utterances such as ‘the unmarked citizen’ or ‘the rational individual’. The readings in this section aim to help one understand the self as a complex and multidimensional entity, which emerges relationally with others, as a ‘presentation’, and narratively as a ‘construct’. The second section then looks at how the self is an inherently ‘spatialised’ entity with readings that speak to the relationship between space and selfhood through cultural concepts such as ‘place-making’, and ‘lifeworlds’. In this, we will also be interested in exploring the ways in which such spatialised, cultural expressions of selfhood get articulated through an engagement with and in various forms of media, especially internet mediated social-media that pervades our ordinary lifeworlds. The course provides space in which you can engage with a variety of source materials and understand how to ask questions that extend and enrich your understanding -- of situations, texts, institutions and people. Introduction to Critical Thinking [CT-0001] [CT-0001-6]

Faculty Name
Jasleen Kaur Bagga [jasleen.bagga@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The Introduction to Critical Thinking course is grounded in the building of proficiency through focussed attention on the basic tasks that develop a critical mind: reading, writing, speaking, listening. It considers these vital acts – of reading a text closely, of making connections between different subjects, of participating in an ongoing conversation, of being discerning about source material – as essential habits that can be strengthened through repetition. The course provides space in which you can engage with a variety of source materials and understand how to ask questions that extend and enrich your understanding -- of situations, texts, institutions and people. It is also intended to be an induction into the distinct practices of academic research and writing within a university. By the close of the course, you will have a keener sense of your own processes of learning, thinking and writing, and a more robust sense of what it means to be ‘scholar’ in an active knowledge community constituted by your peers.

Learning Outcomes

Reading:

1. Breaking down texts into identifiable parts.

2. Making patterns and connections across texts

3. Building reading stamina and the ability to select texts

4. Understanding textual context, genre and source material

Writing 

1. Developing the craft of outlining, revising, editing

2. Applying form, voice, style, tone to affect writing

3. Developing logical, coherent, structured writing

4. Using explanatory, narrative and justificatory writing

Thinking

1. Practising converting thoughts into words

2. Narrowing down a curiosity or thought into a question

3. Constructing and developing a reasoned argument

4. Engaging meaningfully with multiple perspectives

Speaking,Listening

1. Aiming for confidence, clarity, coherence 

2. Practising and harnessing audience engagement 

3. Developing active and respectful listening to others 

4. Engaging meaningfully with ongoing discussions

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

You do not need to have any specific kind of training in order to do an ICT course. Nor is any ICT course geared towards preparing you specifically for a career in a particular subject or field. Rather, you can expect it to guide you in transition out of how you approached academic work in school to how you might approach it in a university setting, and to sharpen your understanding of what it means to be critical, questioning and deliberate in your approach to the world. 

 

ICT is writing-intensive. You can expect to work on longer assignments (the Mid-Term and the End-Term essays) over multiple rounds of feedback, as well as shorter assignments through the semester. You will also need to rehearse regular habits of reading (of academic texts and wider materials) and responding (to prompts, or given materials).Finally, as the ICT is a small cohort-oriented course, you can expect it to have a strong participation and interaction component, and can expect to work on projects both individually and in collaboration with your coursemates. 

Grading Rubric

The ICT will be graded on a number of elements. Your final assessment will account for your participation and performance in writing and non-writing components, and in formative work (building towards a bigger piece, or continuing a specific ‘habit’) and summative work (producing a final output). 

 

The components are below. 

 

1. Participation (in classes, meetings and peer work)

2. Regular Assignments 

3. Presentation 

4. A mid-term assignment of 800-1500 words involving the synthesis of multiple sources

5. An end-term Academic essay of 1500 - 2500 words

6. Improvement over the course

A standard Ashoka rubric will be used in your eventual ICT grade, wherein the highest possible grade is ‘A’ and the lowest possible grade is ‘F’.In general, grades in the ‘A’ range demonstrate that you have consistently exceeded the expectations of the course; grades in the ‘B’ range indicate that you have met the expectations for the course; grades in the ‘C’ range and below, demonstrate that you have fallen short of the expectations for this course.

Attendance Policy

For this course, you are allowed three unexcused absences (for which you do not need permission from the instructor) and two excused absences (for which you do need permission from the instructor). The penalty for any absence beyond these five will be decided by the ICT instructor on a case-by-case basis. Please note that a consistent pattern of non-attendance may include discretionary penalties such as grade cuts.

 

If you are absent, the responsibility for making up for what has been missed -- by looking at class notes and/or speaking to classmates -- is yours. The responsibility for finding out about any homework that has been set for future classes is yours too.

In this course, you will develop and rehearse the habits that are essential to the development of a critical mind: reading, writing, speaking, listening and - of course - thinking. Reading for Writing [CW-1005] [CW-1005-2]

Faculty Name
Arunava Sinha [arunava.sinha@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is an intensive immersion in reading as preparation to be a writer. It involves reading about 10 novellas and novels, participating in discussions, writing short papers, and making a presentation. The objective is to read in a way that will inform your writing subsequently.  

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Haruki Murakami: Drive My Car
Alessandro Barricco: Silk
Annie Zaidi: Prelude to a Riot
Han Kang: The Vegetarian
KR Meera: Qabar
Anushka Jasraj: Radio Story
Adrian Tomine: ‘Amber Sweet’ from Killing and Dying
Vivek Shanbhag: Ghachar Ghochar
Sally Rooney: Conversations with Friends
Aravind Jayan: Teen Couple have Fun Outdoors
Perumal Murugan: One Part Woman
Meg Mason: Sorrow and Bliss
Jerry Pinto: Em and the Big Hoom

Grading Rubric

20%: Class participation (including attendance)
60%: Four pieces of 500 words each on one selected work from the readings, to be submitted at the end of weeks 3, 6, 9, 12
20%: A presentation on a chosen book-length text from outside the readings

Attendance Policy

You are permitted TWO absences in a semester for non-health/non-emergency reasons.

Beyond this there will be half a grade cut (from class participation and attendance) for each

subsequent missed class.

Craft of Writing (Translation) [CW-2011] [CW-2011-1]

Faculty Name
Arunava Sinha [arunava.sinha@ashoka.edu.in] ,Vyshnevi Satheesh [vyshnevi.satheesh_ug24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In this course, students will develop the basic skills of translation by working on a variety of short texts as well as one medium-sized text. The short exercises will be aimed at practising different genres and facets of translation, including prose, poetry, and dialogue. At this stage they will learn about making choices and the elements of the original text that need to be carried over into the translated text. The second half will involve translating a medium-sized text of the student's choice from their mother tongue (or any other language of choice) into English, applying the earlier learnings. The course is aimed at preparing students to translate full-length texts.

Students should have completed the Introduction to Creative Writing Course.

Learning Outcomes

First steps towards being a literary translator.

Grading Rubric

Assignments 
- 300 words to be translated every week from one or more languages into English in the first half of the semester, leading to the break 
- The best 3 assignments to be graded 
Submission 
- 5000 words of one text into English by the end of the semester. 
We will workshop these submissions in the second half of the semester, after the break. So everyone needs to post at least 500 words every week to be workshopped. 
Grading 
- 30%: 3 best assignments 
- 20% class participation, in terms of classwork, assignment submission and workshop feedback 
- 50% end of semester submission 

Attendance Policy

You are permitted TWO absences in a semester for non-health/non-emergency reasons.

Beyond this there will be half a grade cut (from class participation and attendance) for each subsequent missed class.

Statistics for Economics [ECO-1400/ CS-1207] [ECO-1400/ CS-1207-1]

Faculty Name
Ashwini Deshpande [ashwini.deshpande@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is compulsory for all Economics Majors, PPE as well as Economics Minor. This course introduces students to the probability and statistical methods necessary for the study of economics at the undergraduate level. In particular, the course will cover random variables, probability distribution, joint probability distribution, interval estimation and hypothesis testing. 

Learning Outcomes

The course will introduce students to the statistical method, viz., deducing the characteristics of a population from observing characteristics of a sample. The main objective of the course is to convey to the students why we need to understand statistics for scientific inference.  

This will introduce students to the concept of random samples, random variables, their distributions which will be needed to move from properties of a sample to that of an underlying population. This will be preceded by a quick recap of probability theory.

The second half of the course will introduce students to methods of statistical inference, testing the significance of sample characteristics. 

Students will be given problem sets regularly throughout the semester for problem solving practice. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

1.Ross, Sheldon M.2004.   "Introduction to Probability and Statistics for Engineers and Scientists", Third Edition, Elsevier Press. (Ross, henceforth)

2. Peck, Roxy, Olsen, Chris and Devore, Jay. 2012 "Introduction to Statistics and Data Analysis", Fourth Edition, Brooks/Cole Cengage Learning (POD, henceforth)

3. We will also refer to Ross, Sheldon. A First Course in Probability, 8th Edition. (Ross 2, henceforth)

Other material, including online resources, might be introduced during the semester. Whether the new readings are compulsory or optional will be announced. 

Grading Rubric

Student grades have four components: final exam (50% weightage), first mid-term  (20% weightage),  second exam (25% weightage), and the total score in all problem sets combined (5% weightage). The final exam would be a 100 marks, 2-hour assessment on the entire syllabus. The syllabus for the first and second mid-term exams will be announced in class and on AMS/Moodle. 

The instructor does not entertain marks obsession.  Students should make use of office hours for any extra help or resources they require. 

The Ashoka grading scheme:

A letter grade = outstanding. Students know the mathematical techniques and have the ability to apply them in novel problems. 
B letter grade = good. Students have expertise in most of the mathematical techniques taught in the course. They may lack creativity in problem solving but are well trained to do well in any mathematical or applied course. 
C letter grade = adequate. Student knows enough. If s/he tries to revise the course content, s/he shall do well in any application of the course content. 
D letter grade = barely satisfactory. Student knows little. S/he requires guidance and then s/he would be able to apply the courses’ concepts. 
F letter grade = unsatisfactory. Student knows less than 40% of the course content. S/he has not achieved the minimum standards for this course

Attendance Policy

Attendance policy: you can miss 6 classes over the semester with no penalty. There is no need to provide a justification for missing classes. If you miss between 7-10 classes, you will be downgraded one grade (e.g., if your final grade was B, you would be given B-). If you miss 11 or more, you get a straight F. 

Remember that you can’t predict with accuracy the various illnesses and emergencies (your own, your families’) that will occur towards the end of the semester. If you “use up” your 10 absences early on, no matter how serious the reason that causes you to miss more classes later in the semester, YOU WILL GET AN F. 

Attending a class means sitting in the classroom for the full 90 minutes. Repeated entry and exit from the class will not be allowed. This means that once you exit the class before the class ends, you will not be allowed to re-enter and will be marked absent. Please take care of restroom and food/beverage needs before entering the classroom. 

If students are late in entering the class by more than 5 minutes, they would be marked absent.

2. Peck, Roxy, Olsen, Chris and Devore, Jay. 2012 "Introduction to Statistics and Data Analysis", Fourth Edition, Brooks/Cole Cengage Learning (POD, henceforth)

3. We will also refer to Ross, Sheldon. A First Course in Probability, 8th Edition. (Ross 2, henceforth)

Other material, including online resources, might be introduced during the semester. Whether the new readings are compulsory or optional will be announced. 

Grading Rubric

Student grades have four components: final exam (50% weightage), first mid-term  (20% weightage),  second exam (25% weightage), and the total score in all problem sets combined (5% weightage). The final exam would be a 100 marks, 2-hour assessment on the entire syllabus. The syllabus for the first and second mid-term exams will be announced in class and on AMS/Moodle. 

The instructor does not entertain marks obsession.  Students should make use of office hours for any extra help or resources they require. 

The Ashoka grading scheme:

A letter grade = outstanding. Students know the mathematical techniques and have the ability to apply them in novel problems. 
B letter grade = good. Students have expertise in most of the mathematical techniques taught in the course. They may lack creativity in problem solving but are well trained to do well in any mathematical or applied course. 
C letter grade = adequate. Student knows enough. If s/he tries to revise the course content, s/he shall do well in any application of the course content. 
D letter grade = barely satisfactory. Student knows little. S/he requires guidance and then s/he would be able to apply the courses’ concepts. 
F letter grade = unsatisfactory. Student knows less than 40% of the course content. S/he has not achieved the minimum standards for this course

Attendance Policy

Attendance policy: you can miss 6 classes over the semester with no penalty. There is no need to provide a justification for missing classes. If you miss between 7-10 classes, you will be downgraded one grade (e.g., if your final grade was B, you would be given B-). If you miss 11 or more, you get a straight F. 

Remember that you can’t predict with accuracy the various illnesses and emergencies (your own, your families’) that will occur towards the end of the semester. If you “use up” your 10 absences early on, no matter how serious the reason that causes you to miss more classes later in the semester, YOU WILL GET AN F. 

Attending a class means sitting in the classroom for the full 90 minutes. Repeated entry and exit from the class will not be allowed. This means that once you exit the class before the class ends, you will not be allowed to re-enter and will be marked absent. Please take care of restroom and food/beverage needs before entering the classroom. 

If students are late in entering the class by more than 5 minutes, they would be marked absent.

Anuradha Saha [anuradha.saha@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is compulsory for all Economics Majors. This course introduces students to the probability and statistical methods necessary for the study of economics at the undergraduate level. In particular, the course will cover random variables, probability distribution, joint probability distribution, interval estimation and hypothesis testing.

  • The first objective will be to learn simple data collection, presentation and analysis skills.

Grading Rubric

Student grades have three components: final exam (35% weightage), class probes (25%), take-homes (20%) and project (20%). The final exam is a 100 marks, 2.5 hours assessment on the entire syllabus. Students should exhibit expertise in initial topics and in-depth knowledge of the latter ones discussed in the course. Class probes are monthly problem-solving sessions (about 3 in a semester). These sessions would give students an opportunity to apply recently learnt concepts to new problems and expose them to more interesting ones in a limited time frame. The take-homes are fortnightly problem sets to be solved at home (about 5 in a semester). Students have to do three group projects, once a month.

Macroeconomic Theory I [ECO-2201] [ECO-2201-5]

Faculty Name
Ronit Mukherji [ronit.mukherji@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is a compulsory Economics course offered by the Department of Economics at Ashoka University. This course builds upon the fundamentals of macroeconomics from the introductory courses and introduces students to the macroeconomic fundamentals of the economy, which is crucial for policy-making. It also creates a bedrock for economic analysis and teaches students how to use these concepts to make policy recommendations. By the end of the
course, students should be able to relate much of what economic policies they would have been exposed to, and to critically evaluate the actions of the government and the monetary authority, the two bodies responsible for macroeconomic policies.

Decision Theory [ECO-3105] [ECO-3105-1]

Faculty Name
Abhinash Borah [abhinash.borah@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The objective of the course is a thorough engagement with the rationality project as understood in economics using the methodological perspective of decision theory. Setting up the exercise in decision-theoretic terms has the advantage of disciplining us to make our claims in terms of observable behavior. The course will begin by laying out the substantive content of rationality in neo-classical economics, along with an appreciation of the “genealogy” of this concept. This discussion will also focus on the Bayesian paradigm and the foundations of subjective probabilities that are fundamental organizing principles when discussing rationality in uncertain environments. Our thorough engagement with decision-making under risk and uncertainty, including the hugely influential expected utility theory, will allow you to understand better the central role that the principle of consequentialism plays in decision-theoretic reasoning. After that, we will look at some leading criticisms of classical decision theory. We will focus on a set of topics proposed as responses to some of these criticisms. Right through the course, we will focus on applications of these insights and ideas in economics and other fields like finance and politics.

Industrial Organisation [ECO-3600] [ECO-3600-1]

Faculty Name
Saish Vijay Nevrekar [saish.nevrekar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Overview:

The Industrial Organization course at the bachelor's level provides students with a comprehensive understanding of how firms and industries function in a competitive market. Through theoretical frameworks, students explore topics such as market structure, pricing strategies, entry and exit barriers, and the role of government policies in shaping industry dynamics. By examining real-world case studies and conducting practical exercises, students develop critical thinking skills to analyze market behavior and make informed decisions. This course equips students with the knowledge and tools necessary to navigate the complexities of the modern business environment and contribute to strategic decision-making within organizations.

Course organization and syllabus: 

Every week will consist of two lectures: a theory lecture followed by an assignment lecture. For the assignment sessions,  you are expected to solve all the exercises before the class. During the lecture, only select problems will be solved. Any queries regarding the remaining questions will be entertained. 

Week of Week Theory (Monday) Assignment (Wednesday)
28-Aug 1  Introduction+Monopoly  
04-Sep 2  Multi-product Monopoly  Monopoly
11-Sep 3  Price Discrimination  Price Discrimination
18-Sep 4  Bundling and Tying  Bundling and Tying
25-Sep 5  Cournot and Stackelberg  Cournot and Stackelberg
02-Oct 6  Holiday (Gandhi Jayanti)  Mid-term Exam
09-Oct    Monsoon break  
16-Oct 7  Barriers of Entry  Barriers of Entry
23-Oct 8  Bertrand Model  Bertrand Model
30-Oct 9  Collusion  Collusion
06-Nov 10  Capacity Constraints  Capacity Constraints
13-Nov 11  Horizontal Differentiation        (on Wednesday)  Mid-term exam  (on Saturday)
20-Nov 12  Hotelling Model  Hotelling Model
27-Nov 13  Salop Model (on Wednesday)  Salop Model (on Saturday) 
04-Dec 14  Vertical Differentiation  Revision/Missed Lecture
11-Dec    Final Exam  

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Main textbook: Tirole, J. (1988). The theory of industrial organization. MIT press.

Other readings will be updated soon. 

Grading Rubric

Grading will be based on the final exam (60%) and continuous evaluation through mid-term exams (20%+20%). 

The exams will take place in assignment sessions of weeks 6th, 11th, and 14th. The mid-term exams will last 1 hour and will test all topics taught in the respective block. These exams will have a similar structure and difficulty as the problem sets. The final exam will last for 1.5 hrs and will test all topics taught till the date of the exam. 

The final grade will be computed as the weighted average: 40% mid-term exams and 60% final exam. The necessary condition for passing is to secure at least 35% in the final exam. The sufficient condition is secure at least 40% across the weighted average of final and mid-term exams.

Pricing Theory and Public Policy [ECO-3602] [ECO-3602-1]

Faculty Name
Sneha Bakshi [sneha.bakshi@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will focus on pricing: its theory in different market structures like monopoly, oligopoly, and competitive markets, between different demand segments in the form of price discrimination, and price collusion; a behavioral economics approach to pricing, discounts and promotions; the particulars of pricing in some specific industries; and will explore the application of price as a policy instrument: to correct market failures and to create markets where none exist to improve resource allocation, and to provide support or incentive for target products, suppliers or consumers.

Learning Outcomes

The first part of this course aims to enable students to understand the considerations on which pricing decisions are theoretically based in various types of markets, and to learn how to apply them to different industries, cases, and problems. The second part of the course will help students get familiar with the use of price as a policy instrument and help them explore and analyze how governments and institutions do this to improve upon non-existent and imperfect markets.

Class Participation: Attendance 5points, In-class surprise Quizzes 12points

Take home Assignment (on Moodle): 15points

Total points: 100

Environmental Economics [ECO-3700] [ECO-3700-1]

Faculty Name
Kavita Sardana [kavita.sardana@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The first part of the course will focus on showing how neoclassical welfare theory forms the basis of the normative criteria that are used to distinguish market and policy-influenced outcomes for the provision of environmental goods and services. From a theoretical perspective, most contemporary topics in environmental economics characterize the failure of the first welfare theorem, missing markets, externalities, and the nature of public goods in the provision of environmental goods. In this context, the interventionist approach using the Pigouvian paradigm, in contrast to the non-interventionist Coasian paradigm will be discussed to achieve efficient allocation of resources. Additionally, a simple analytical model describing pollution damages in monetary units, the cost of pollution prevention, and the characteristics of an efficient allocation of pollution emissions will be used to describe the menu of environmental policy instruments (such as tradable permit schemes) and their comparative properties.
The second part of the course will focus on conceptual and pragmatic understanding in discussing the current dialogue on environmental protection and restoration. Mass movement following the constitution of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and the formal meeting of the UNFCC parties (Conference of the Parties, COP) for environmental protection (based on the targets of adaptation and financing) is anchored in the understanding of environmental valuation techniques that provide input into national accounts and policy reforms that are required to channel funds for environmental protection. The focus will be on learning the environmental valuation techniques in general and revealed preference methods and stated preference methods in particular. Practicals in the second part of the course will be conducted with datasets from the field of environmental valuation with the learning objectives and outcomes of making the students adept at using valuation techniques. The analysis will be conducted using STATA software.

Learning Outcomes

1. Understanding theory of environmental policy for provision of environmental good

2. Understanding conceptual and practical applications of  environmental valuation techniques 

3. Understanding the current mandate and dialogue of environmental protection and restoration

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Main Readings

Textbooks

Phaneuf, D. J., & Requate, T. (2016). A course in environmental economics: theory, policy, and practice. Cambridge University Press.

Haab, T. C., & McConnell, K. E. (2002). Valuing environmental and natural resources: the econometrics of non-market valuation. Edward Elgar Publishing.

Grading Rubric

Mid-term exam (50%) and final group project presentation (50%)

Attendance Policy

Mandatory
