Decision Theory [ECO-6105] [ECO-6105-1]

Faculty Name
Abhinash Borah [abhinash.borah@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

We will focus on two prominent areas of decision-theoretic research: (i) theories of behavioral choices; and (ii) decisions under uncertainty.

For the first topic, we will begin by setting up the foundations of rational choice theory and then look at the case against it. We will focus on a set of topics that will respond to rational choice theory’s descriptive (and at times normative) limitations. Amongst them will be prospect theory and the theme of reference-dependent preferences; sequential choice procedures featuring multiple rationales; choice theories featuring limited consideration; theories of temptation and self-control. We will also focus on stochastic choices. 

For the second topic, we will examine the foundations of subjective probabilities and Bayesianism. We will study the classic approaches of De Finetti, Savage, and Anscombe-Aumann to this question. After that, we will focus on the large and impressive literature on decision-making under ambiguity that has emerged in the last three decades or so. Ambiguity, here, refers to decision settings in which a decision-maker perceives “uncertainty about probability, created by missing information that is relevant and could be known” (Frisch and Baron, 1988). That such decision settings exist was pointed out by Ells- berg (1961). His work showed how ambiguity represents a normative criticism of the subjective expected utility framework of Savage (1954) and, by extension, of the Bayesian paradigm. David Schmeidler’s work in the late 1980s revived interest in this area of research. We will cover important models like Schmeidler’s Choquet expected utility, Gilboa and Schmeidler’s maximin expected utility, Klibanoff, Marinacci, and Mukerji’s smooth ambiguity model, and Siniscalchi’s vector expected utility. Before getting to all this, though, we will first look at a few landmark models of decision-making under risk like vNM expected utility and rank-dependent utility.

Econometrics 2 [ECO-6402] [ECO-6402-1]

Faculty Name
Kanika Mahajan [kanika.mahajan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is a graduate-level econometrics course focusing on causal identification. The course begins with a discussion of the Rubin-Causal model, and randomized controlled trials – the pinnacle for causal econometric designs. Subsequently, it moves to selection on observable designs, and the use of fixed effects to control for select unobservables. The second half of the course focuses on three key empirical techniques for causal identification: namely differences-in-difference, regression discontinuity designs, matching and instrumental variables. The course will focus mainly on the intuition behind causal identification and applying them in practice. A critical component of the course would be reading empirical academic papers. This would provide students with some context in the application of the empirical methods introduced in class.

This course will focus on both theoretical knowledge as well as implementation of theory through software applications like STATA and real datasets.

Learning Outcomes

Students should be able to understand and implement various methods of causal identification in econometrics.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Angrist, J.D and Pischke, J.-S. Mostly Harmless Econometrics, Princeton University Press, 2008. (MHE)

Jeffrey M. Wooldridge, Introductory Econometrics: A Modern Approach, 4th or 5th edition (JMW)

Wooldridge, J. Econometric Analysis of Cross Section and Panel Data, 2nd ed., MIT Press, 2010. (CSPD)

Cameron, A.C. and Trivedi, P.K. Microeconometrics using Stata, 2nd ed., Stata Press, 2010

Abadie and Cattaneo’s paper titled “Econometric Methods for Program Evaluation”, published in the Annual Review of Economics in 2018.

NBER Summer Lectures from 2007, titled “What’s New in Econometrics”. (Optional)

Greene, W.H., Econometric Analysis, (7th edition), Pearson, 2012 (Optional)

Grading Rubric

Homeworks:  25%

End Term exam:  25%

Replication:  25%

Class paper presentation: 15%

Class participation: 10%

 

Homework problems will generally be based on data. Homework assessments will be submitted individually. Group discussions are allowed but plagiarism will be dealt with a fail grade on the assessment and on the course for repeated violation. STATA based assessments should be accompanied with proper outputs and explanations. Assignments must be submitted in time on google classroom. Late submission will not be graded. Cheating will be dealt with by a fail grade on the course.

Class Presentation: Students (in groups of 2-3 depending on enrollment in the course) will present and lead the class-discussion of an assigned paper. In addition to summarizing the paper, a key portion of the presentation will focus on “critiquing” the paper and considering possible extensions.

Class Participation: while there is no attendance requirement, class participation comprises a key part of the course. Students are expected to contribute to discussions on the assigned papers.

Replication:  Students will be required to work in teams of 2 or individually (depending on enrolment). You need to select a paper from any of these journals: American Economic Review (AER), the American Economic Journals (AEJ: Applied Economics, Economic Policy), Quarterly Journal of Economics (QJE), Journal of Development Economics (JDE), American Journal of Political Science. You can choose papers from other journals too if the datasets are available online. Their websites host data files for recent years and also the computer programs for the results obtained in the papers. Each team will need to select a paper and download the associated files to replicate the main regression models. The “do” and the “log” files will be required to be submitted by each team. Two teams cannot work on the same topic (so first come, first served will be the criteria). The teams will under replication analysis/results and present it in a 15-minute presentation about the paper and how the results were replicated will be answered by the team members.

Attendance Policy

Marks will not be based on attendance but past experience shows that it is highly correlated with final grade

Introduction to Literary Theory [ENG-1002] [ENG-1002-2]

Faculty Name
Madhavi Menon [menon@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Addressing the self-reflexive imperative that lies at the root of “theory,” this class will step back from individual texts of fiction to think through bigger questions about literature. What counts as literature? What is the role of history in the production of literature? Does literature reflect reality or create it? Does gender play a role in the kind of literature we read and write? Why do we desire to read? What do we read when we read? Theory not only reads the whats and whys and hows of texts, but it also asks to be read itself as a text. In this class, therefore, we will undertake that double session of reading and writing about texts that think about reading and writing.

Learning Outcomes

To read widely in schools of literary theory and develop the ability to navigate the complexity of their arguments

To be able to articulate in your own words the pith of a theoretical argument and associate it with fiction and culture

To write clearly and confidently about theory

Grading Rubric

A-F. Your final grade for the semester will depend equally – 50% each – on your class participation (including your presentations, productive participation in class discussions, and online summaries), and final essay assignment.

Attendance Policy

Full attendance required

CourseTitle: Introduction to the Progressive Writers’ Movement
description:
Introduction to the Progressive Writers’ Movement [ENG-2313] [ENG-2313-1]

Overview

Faculty : Prof. Fuzail Siddiqi

Simply put, postcolonial literature is writings by people from erstwhile colonies about the
encounter and experience of colonialism and its lingering effects in the post-colonial world.
What exactly does postcolonial literature aspire to represent? Can a writer accurately and
faithfully put forth their ideas of their culture and ways of being, which have been shaped by the
colonial enterprise? What are the similarities and differences between writers that come under
the rubric of postcolonial literature? While Emily Apter argues about the untranslatable nature of
literatures from the non-West into a language that is accessible to the West, Graham Huggan
suggests that contemporary postcolonial literature is specifically marketed for what he calls an
‘alterity industry’. In between these two kinds of readings, the untranslatability thesis and the
market-oriented world of publishing, the course will endeavour to engage with issues of race,
gender, identity, and exploitation that works of postcolonial literature attempt to highlight. The
course aims first to survey the early works of postcolonial studies, including Edward Said, Frantz
Fanon, Gayatri Chakravorty Spivak, and Ashish Nandy and move to more recent theories of
Robert Young, Graham Huggan, Vivek Chibber, and others. These will be read in consonance
with the works of postcolonial writers, including but not limited to Ngũgĩ wa Thiong’o, Chinua
Achebe, V.S. Naipaul, Derek Walcott, J.M. Coetzee, Arundhati Roy, and others.

2000-level Elective-The Progressive Writers’ Movement: Fuzail Asar Siddiqi
The Progressive Writers’ Movement, one of the largest literary movements in South Asia,
attempted to shed light on inequality, injustice, and exploitation widespread in South Asia from
the early 1930s to the middle of the 1950s through their literature. They aimed to create a just
and fair society by highlighting the ills prevalent in contemporary life. This course will aim to
study the works of the Progressive Writers and focus on how their writing endeavoured to think
of the task of literature as oriented towards social reform and not merely for aesthetic purposes.
Can literature be only about aesthetics and not about the social? Or are the social and the
aesthetic inexorably intertwined in literature? Is literature supposed to have a socially useful
function? Moreover, who or what is qualified to be the subject of literature, and are there any
requirements to be an author? This course will think about such questions by focusing on novels,
short stories, and poetry of some of the exponents of the Progressive Writers’ Movement,

including but not limited to Saadat Hasan Manto, Ismat Chughtai, Faiz Ahmed Faiz, Kaifi Azmi,
Sajjad Zaheer, Rashid Jahan, and Ahmed Ali.

Postcolonial Literatures [ENG-3001/ ENG-5301] [ENG-3001/ ENG-5301-2]

Overview

Faculty: Prof. Fuzail Siddiqi

In this course, our attempt will be to engage with questions and concerns broadly categorised as "postcolonial" across the world. This includes thinking about the nature of anticolonial struggle and nationalism, the so-called "moment" of decolonisation and the formation of a sovereign state, the relationship between settlers and "indigenous" inhabitants in the ex-colony, and the relationship between the colonial enterprise and the natural environment in the colony. Our discussions will primarily be about the postcolonial novel from three different "postcolonial" contexts of India, South Africa, and Canada. We will thus engage closely with Mahasweta Devi's Mother of 1084 (1974), J.M. Coetzee's Disgrace (1999), and Margaret Atwood's Surfacing (1972). Our reading of these three novels will be supplemented with discussion about related critical work by the likes of Gayatri Chakravorty Spivak, Edward Said, Homi K. Bhabha, Derek Attridge, David Attwell, and Sara Ahmed.

Apparitions of Macbeth [ENG-4203] [ENG-4203-1]

Faculty Name
Jonathan Gil Harris [jgharris@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Macbeth stands unsurpassed among Shakespeare’s works for its capacity to frighten.  It is not just that it features scary Witches who predict the future in riddles, or a murderous tyrant who strikes terror into every corner of his kingdom.  Much of the power of the play derives from its staging of eerie, prophetic apparitions – a floating dagger, a bloody ghost, a series of visions that emerge from a cauldron.  Even the name of the play has acquired a legendary apparitional power: merely to mention it in a playhouse is supposed to conjure unspeakably bad luck.  What is behind the play’s ability to scare the heck out of us?  This seminar will scrutinize Macbeth and its terrifying apparitions.  As we will see, these apparitions are not just plot points or theatrical special effects.  They are also emblematic of the spectral power of matter to conjure untimely possibilities and impossibilities – to make us feel, as Lady Macbeth says, “the future in the instant.”  We will consider how Macbeth’s apparitions have eerily predicted subsequent apparitions of the play, in theory (Sigmund Freud’s account of psychological attachment, Michel Foucault's theory of dreams, Helene Cixous's study of co-dependent crime, Stanley Cavell's reflections on crises of knowledge, Terry Eagleton’s analysis of capitalist reification, Michel Serres’s imagining of human-non-human assemblages) and in cinema (Welles's Voodoo Macbeth, Polanski’s Macbeth, Kurosawa’s Throne of Blood, Bhardwaj’s Maqbool, Bhattachatrya's Mandaar).  In the process, we will treat the “apparitional” as a theoretical lens that helps us think about the temporalities of political conflicts involving tradition and modernity, indigeneity and cosmopolitanism, globalisation and planetary turmoil, violent tyranny and resistance.

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Macbeth (Folger edition)

various theoretical and critical texts

Grading Rubric

A-F

Attendance Policy

Attendance required; all absences need to be notified for in advance

Caribbean Literature [ENG-4350] [ENG-4350-1]

Overview

Faculty: Prof. Shalini Puri 

What do our postcolonial solidarities invite us to learn about places in the global south other than India? How might we situate our scholarship in dialogue with such places and with their cultural and intellectual histories? How can thinking about the specificities of place deepen our theoretical generalizations? And how does postcolonial studies itself change if we think from the perspective of islands and archipelagoes rather than subcontinents and continents?  

 

We will address these questions by exploring the environmental imaginations of Caribbean literature as it responds to the inextricably linked (post)colonial histories of extractivist, environmental, and epistemic violence. Caribbean writers have found extraordinarily inventive and wide-ranging ways to navigate both archival erasures and dominant representations of the Caribbean as a picturesque paradise or as place of tragedy or disaster.  We will study their environmental manuevres across several different genres and forms––from realism to speculative fiction to epic to satire, from theater to literary essays to allegory to “small” forms such as the vignette, the fragment, patwa proverbs and creole voicings, short ekphrastic poems, and postcards. We will explore the affordances of each genre for framing and resolving environmental considerations: What vocabularies for environmental witnessing and repair do particular genres offer?  How do they approach problems of representation, knowledge, agency, and political desire? For example, how might the politics of water be treated differently in a realist novel, a found poem drawn from a newspaper article, a postcard, and a visual poem?  

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

 

Our readings will focus on the Anglophone Caribbean, Puerto Rico, Haiti, the Atlantic, and the Caribbean diaspora. Writers will likely include Nobel laureate Derek Walcott; Jamaican poet laureates Lorna Goodison and Olive Senior; Kei Miller; Marlene NourbeSe; Jacques Roumain; and Aliyah Khan. Our theoretical interlocutors include Michel-Rolph Truillot, Rob Nixon, Isabel Hofmeyr, Elizabeth deLoughrey, Yarimar Bonilla, Deborah Thomas, Veena Das, Saidiya Hartmann, and Christina Sharpe. Assignments will include a presentation; exploratory, academic, and public writing; and short writing exercises in different genres.

Violence and South Asian Literature [ENG-4410] [ENG-4410-1]

Faculty Name
Abir Bashir Bazaz [abir.bazaz@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sonal Dugar [sonal.dugar_asp24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

How should we be thinking about a concept as elusive as violence? What is the relation between thinking and violence? What do South Asian literary texts teach us about violence? What is nonviolence? These are some of the questions that will guide our thinking about the theme of violence in South Asian literatures. The course will introduce the students to modern South Asian literary texts that think about violence. We will focus not only on texts dealing with war, riots, torture and other forms of physical violence but also on those processes of slow—and intangible—violence that have come to define collective and individual life in South Asia. We will situate key texts, authors and genres from different regional languages in a wider historical context of political violence in South Asia. We will be reading literary texts by Intizar Hussain, Mohan Rakesh, Mahasweta Devi, Nirmal Verma, Waryam Singh Sandhu, Indira Goswami, Akhtar Mohiuddin and Michael Ondaatje. We will also be reading key theoretical texts on the question of violence by Carl Schmitt, Hannah Arendt, Walter Benjamin, Franz Fanon, M.K.Gandhi, Judith Butler and Jacques Derrida. We will also be screening and discussing films by Govind Nihalani, Gulzar and Sudhir Mishra among others.How should we be thinking about a concept as elusive as violence? CourseTitle: Dil Ka Batwara: The Cinematic Partition
description:
Dil Ka Batwara: The Cinematic Partition [ENG-4420] [ENG-4420-1]

Faculty Name
Rita Kothari [rita.kothari@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The historic and political vocabulary of Partition appears inadequate in capturing the fractured memories, separated hearts, nostalgia and sense of futility. A more affect-driven and less historic approach, partition in lower case, imbues a range of articulations: graphic novels, cinema, art, painting, and of course literature. This course is interested in navigating the terrain of affect and partition through discussions on language, space, geographies by focusing almost entirely on cinema. This provides the course focus on both the historical backdrop in the background, as well as the slow-moving processes of memory and lexicon-making that partition has affected. This course must be taken only if both things—Partition and cinema—interest students.

CourseTitle: Leadership Lessons from the Road Less Travelled
description:
Leadership Lessons from the Road Less Travelled [ENT-1007] [ENT-1007-1]

Faculty Name
Ekanto Ghosh [ekanto.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Priyank Narayan [priyank.narayan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Rashmi Bansal [rashmi.bansal@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sagar Singhal [sagar.singhal@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The primary mode of learning will be the story telling method. High achieving entrepreneurs
will speak about their life stories, how and why they started out, what were/are their
motivators, what difficulties and challenges they faced along the way, how they built their
team, how they managed to work with very little capital and so on. The course aims to enable
the participants to appreciate the various facets of leadership and the behavior and traits of
successful leaders through listening to the life stories of a dozen high achieving entrepreneurs
and interacting with them.

Leadership Lessons from Road Less Travelled - Rashmi Bansal.pdf

In Pursuit of Service Excellence [ENT-2015] [ENT-2015-1]

Faculty Name
Aditya Ghosh [aditya.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Ekanto Ghosh [ekanto.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Priyank Narayan [priyank.narayan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sagar Singhal [sagar.singhal@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The world is a graveyard of businesses that got distracted. There is an adjacent graveyard of organizations which did not change or innovate, and became increasingly irrelevant. With the growing startup culture and businesses facing unprecedented challenges such as COVID-19, it is extremely important to build businesses that are relevant and resilient. How does service excellence help to achieve this goal? What are the challenges and necessary tools to scale up an existing business/institution without compromising on the aim, values or quality? How to build customer focused businesses while also creating an employee first culture? Will the proposed strategy to scale up bring about a tremendous amount of efficiency or growth, without walking away from what is fundamental to the business? How to intertwine an organization’s internal values and external brand elements? What are some of the entrepreneurial principles that can be used in scaling up institutions and how that can be differentiated from conventional methods of scaling up? How to create a home grown brand that is widely recognized and becomes the industry standard? How can learnings from one industry such as airlines be used in a principally different sector? This course aims to teach you how to pursue excellence in organizations, communities and for an individual. The course will be taught by a seasoned business leader who has worked across industries such as aviation, lifestyle, hospitality, social impact etc. The course will use real life examples and case studies combined with sessions with industry experts and field visits.

Problem Solving using Microsoft Excel [ENT-2038] [ENT-2038-1]

Faculty Name
Ekanto Ghosh [ekanto.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Priyank Narayan [priyank.narayan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sagar Singhal [sagar.singhal@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Microsoft Excel is the most widely used spreadsheet software and is used by people across industries & organizations irrespective of their type and level. In today’s world where data is the new oil, data from multiple data sources ultimately lands up in an MS Excel file. The challenge of the professionals of tomorrow will be the ease with which they can solve business problems/questions that come their way.

Welcome to the comprehensive course – ‘Problem Solving using Microsoft Excel’. In today's digitally driven world, proficiency in Excel is an indispensable asset, whether you're a student, a professional, an entrepreneur, or someone eager to enhance their data management capabilities. This course is designed to equip you with the knowledge and practical expertise required to navigate Excel with confidence, efficiency, and finesse.

Why Excel Skills Matter?

Microsoft Excel stands tall as one of the most powerful and versatile spreadsheet applications available, and its impact spans across various industries and domains. From finance to marketing, from engineering to data analysis, Excel empowers users to organize, analyze, and visualize data in ways that drive informed decision-making. Regardless of your background or profession, Excel proficiency is a gateway to unlocking numerous opportunities and streamlining your daily tasks. It allows you to handle large datasets, automate repetitive tasks, create visually compelling charts and graphs, perform complex calculations, and more. Whether you're managing personal finances, conducting business analyses, or preparing academic reports, Excel is the go-to tool for data analysis and presentation.

Agri-food systems and sustainability [ES-2404] [ES-2404-1]

Faculty Name
Anita Pinheiro [anita.pinheiro@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Title: Agri-food systems and sustainability

Course Level: 2000 | Course Code: ES-2404

Faculty: Professor Anita Pinheiro

Time table: Mon- Wed, 3:00- 4:30 pm | Classroom: AC02-006 (TR)

Sustainability in agri-food systems is intensely debated and discussed. This course helps the students to critically analyse diverse ways by which the sustainability of agri-food systems is understood and conceptualised. The course will analyse the environmental, social and economic impacts of different agri-food systems, taking case studies from around the world.

The course will also critically engage student discussions on topics such as Green Revolution, the emerging alternative solutions, bio-nanotechnologies in agriculture, local and global oceanic fisheries, circular approaches, livestock systems, Nature-based and technology-based solutions, and dietary changes to plant-based protein sources. Using case studies, the course will help students critically analyse these aspects in Global South and Global North countries.

The classes will include lectures, documentary/video presentations, and guided group discussions. Additional background material will be provided during the lectures to supplement the readings.

Bottom of Form 

Learning Outcomes

This course will enable the students to

Have a comprehensive global overview of agri-food systems, food security, and its underlying challenges to sustainability.

Have basic understanding on the emerging concepts related to sustainable agri-food systems and critically analyse from the perspectives of Sustainable Development Goals

Explore and analyse global examples of agri-food policies that emerged in response to sustainability challenges.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Indicative reading list

1. Alam, A., & Rukhsana. (2023). Climate Change Impact, Agriculture, and Society: An Overview. Climate Change, Agriculture and Society: Approaches Toward Sustainability, 3-13. (select sections).

2. Anderson, C. R., Bruil, J., Chappell, M. J., Kiss, C., & Pimbert, M. P. (2021). Agroecology now!: Transformations towards more just and sustainable food systems (p. 199). Springer Nature. (Chapters 1 &2).

3. Chikoye, D., Gondwe, T., & Nhamo, N. (Eds.). (2017). Smart Technologies for Sustainable Smallholder Agriculture: Upscaling in Developing Countries. Academic Press. (select sections).

4. De Boer, I. J., & van Ittersum, M. K. (2018). Circularity in agricultural production. Wageningen University & Research. (select sections)

5. Djurfeldt, G., Holmen, H., Jirström, M., & Larsson, R. (2005). The African food crisis lessons from the Asian Green Revolution. Cabi. (select chapters).

6. Pyett, S. C., Jenkins, W. M. N., van Mierlo, B. C., Trindade, L. M., Welch, D., & van Zanten, H. H. E. (2023). Our future proteins: A diversity of perspectives. (select chapters).

7. Swaminathan, M. S. (2010). Science and sustainable food security: selected papers of MS Swaminathan (Vol. 3). World Scientific. (select papers/chapters).

8. Visvanathan, S., & Parmar, C. (2002). A biotechnology story: notes from India. Economic and political weekly, 2714-2724.

9. Zeller, D., & Pauly, D. (2019). Viewpoint: back to the future for fisheries, where will we choose to go? Global Sustainability 2 (e11): 1–8.

Grading Rubric

Assignment and class presentation on an assigned course-related contemporary topic. 800-1000 words. 25% marks

Students need to write a take-home essay. They need to analyse the topic based on the course's insights, write an essay and make a short presentation of 10 minutes.

A take-home essay or a book review. 1000-1200 words. 25% marks

Students can choose a take-home essay on an assigned topic or a book review.

End-of-term in-class short essay writing on the reflections on key insights discussed in the course, 450-500 words, 25% marks

Students will be given a topic to write a short essay in the class.

Class participation and group discussions. Total 25% marks

Students need to actively participate in class discussions and provide insights on their understanding of the lecture (10 %)

Students need to form groups to discuss the readings assigned to their group and make class presentations. (15%)

Attendance Policy

None

Science, Society, and Environment [ES-2411] [ES-2411-1]

Faculty Name
Anita Pinheiro [anita.pinheiro@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Title: Science, Society, and Environment

Level: 2000 | Course Code: ES- 2411

Faculty: Professor Anita Pinheiro

Time Table : Mon- Wed, 10:10-11:40 am | Classroom: AC02 -006 (TR)

Overview

This is an interdisciplinary course aimed at helping the students to have a comprehensive understanding of the intricate connections between science, society, and environment. The course will examine a wide range of issues from a variety of perspectives, using examples from India and around the world. The course will help students to shape their perspectives on how environmental and societal well-being is interlinked with scientific knowledge development and its thoughtful application.

The course will also help students explore the following questions: How does society shape scientific decision-making on environmental matters? Whether and how socio-environmental concerns are incorporated in scientific endeavours? How can society be a part of scientific knowledge creation? How do people perceive science and engage in environmental decision-making? The controversies related to science and environment and the significance of science communication to inform better public decision-making.

Within the intersections of science, society, and environment, some of the focus areas include debates on pesticides, deforestation, biodiversity conservation, citizen science, global warming, glacier retreat, etc.The classes will include lectures, documentary/video presentations, and guided group discussions. Additional background material will be provided during the lectures to supplement the readings.

 

Learning Outcomes

The learning outcomes of this course are the following:

The students will be introduced to the interdisciplinary field of science and technology studies with a particular focus on environmental matters

Understand the intricate interplay between science and society in shaping environmental issues and policy-making.

With the example of case studies and relevant readings, explore the concepts of public understanding of science, public engagement in science, citizen science, science communication, people's science movements etc.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Indicative reading list

1. Carson, R. (2009). Silent spring. 1962

2. Inman, M. (2010). Settling the science on Himalayan glaciers. Nature Reports Climate Change, 28-30.

3. Madhusudan, M. D., Shanker, K., Kumar, A., Mishra, C., Sinha, A., Arthur, R., ... & Rajan, P. D. (2006). Science in the wilderness: the predicament of scientific research in India's wildlife reserves. Current Science, 1015-1019.

4. Maibach, E., Leiserowitz, A., Cobb, S., Shank, M., Cobb, K. M., & Gulledge, J. (2012). The legacy of climategate: undermining or revitalizing climate science and policy?. Wiley Interdisciplinary Reviews: Climate Change, 3(3), 289-295.

5. Mikami, N. (2015). Public participation in decision-making on energy policy: The case of the “national discussion” after the Fukushima accident. Lessons from Fukushima: Japanese case studies on science, technology and society, 87-122.

6. Rangarajan, M. (2007). Environmental Issues in India: A Reader. (select chapters)

7. Ranjit Daniels.R.J., Krishnaswami Jagdish,. 2014. Environmental Studies. Wiley. (Select sections)

8. Saberwal, V. K., & Rangarajan, M. (Eds.). (2009). Battles over nature: Science and the politics of conservation. Orient Blackswan. (select chapters)

9. Sekhsaria P, Thayyil N (2022) First steps: citizen science in ecology in India. New Delhi, DST Centre for Policy Research, IIT Delhi & Authors UPFRONT (select chapters)

GIS 1 [ES-2901/ CS-2383] [ES-2901/ CS-2383-1]

Faculty Name
Meghna Agarwala [meghna.agarwala@ashoka.edu.in] ,Anannya Sharma [anannya.sharma_asp24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

NOTE: I am going to try and get OAA to cap number of ASPs taking this class to 10. I would prefer students in first or second year. 

NOTE2: Syllabus attached. 

This course teaches you basic skills of GIS and remote sensing. It aims to teach through experience and expects that students will be able to conduct their own mini-projects by the end of the course. Students should be able to make beautiful maps on everything from resettlement following a dam construction to changing political choices in different parts of the world. Students should also be able to answer questions through their own analyses on: where to place windmills, whether deforestation has occurred in a given area and why, map flood risk and damages, glacial retreat and basically most topics in environmental studies. 

Grading Rubric

Students will be graded on 4 metrics:

Class attendance and participation: 15% of grade

Leading discussion (15% of grade): There are 10 readings in this class which will be uploaded on LMS as “Reading_Week2”, “Reading_Week3”, etc. Please sign up in the first class for the one you want to lead a discussion on. Everyone must read the paper prior to class on Thursday. Discussion will be for 35-40 minutes.

Assignments (35% of grade): We will learn a particular skill every Thursday which will be related to the lecture on Tuesday. This will be in the form of a class assignment, to be done in class as much as possible, and to be submitted as a pdf prior to subsequent class on Thursday. I expect you to be able to complete this in the Thursday class itself. If not, it should not take much extra time.

Final project (35% of grade): I want you to test your learning by doing an original analysis in this class. You can choose whatever topic you want—how does riverlinking impact flooding or river flow, why is deforestation happening in Tanzania, how much are the glaciers in Uttarakhand melting, where were people relocated due to floods, how much agricultural land has been lost to urban sprawl in Sonipat, how does change in concrete cover change groundwater recharge, are droughts related to voting out incumbents from political office, how much plastic is there in the ocean, how much area did an oil spill cover and how many sea birds were affected, ANYTHING YOU WANT. We will try to limit the scale of your project a bit so you can actually do it in the 3 weeks allotted just for the project.

The grading of the projected is distributed as:

Presentation of project/research question (5%) in the 10th week

Work on project (5%)

Final project presentation (5% + an additional 5% peer grading)

Final write-up (15%): The final write-up must include sections Introduction, Methods, Maps, Results, Discussion, References (at least 5 references)

Attendance Policy

Students can miss a maximum of 4 classes excluded excused absences, beyond which they will get a failing grade. All excused absences must be routed to me through the OAA.

GIS_Syllabus.docx

Faculty: sidharth.ravi_tf@ashoka.edu.in, mukul.sharma@ashoka.edu.in, shreya.uk_ug20@ashoka.edu.in, sidharth.ravi_tf@ashoka.edu.in, mukul.sharma@ashoka.edu.in, shreya.uk_ug20@ashoka.edu.in, shreya.uk_ug20@ashoka.edu.in
description:
Environmental Studies [FC-0102] [FC-0102-1]

Faculty Name
Shreya U K [shreya.uk_ug20@ashoka.edu.in] ,Mukul Sharma [mukul.sharma@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sidharth Ravi [sidharth.ravi_tf@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Environment has become an important area of interactions between society, politics, economy and culture. This foundation course will focus on diverse sets of social, economic and cultural values and political, ideological and religious views expressed through environment. The course will discuss how ecological issues are understood in different political and economic systems, ideologies and institutions. In turn, the political, ideological and social essence of ecological problems is manifested by deeply contrasting visions of what structuring society according to nature might mean. Taking a historical approach, the course will strengthen the interaction of natural and social sciences in understanding contemporary environmental politics. The course will give close attention to some prominent environmental and social movements in India, which will significantly enhance the knowledge about new developments in environment/politics/society interface.    

Learning Outcomes

The course is organized around weekly lectures and discussions based on the readings. Students will be asked to write an essay on one of the topics of the course, with footnotes and bibliography, and further readings will be given to them on their chosen topic, so that they can go in much more depth on a particular topic.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Unit 1: (Week 1 & 2): Environment, Politics, Society: The Dialectices of Civilisational, Historical, Natural, Material, Economic, Ideological and Political Aspects of the Ecological Issues and Changes

Unit 2: (Week 3): Environment, Green Village, Authority and Democracy: Ralegaon Sidhi and Anna Hazare

Unit 3: (Week 4 ): Nature and Nationalism: Anti-Tehri Dam Movement and Sunderlal Bahuguna

Unit 4: (Week 5): Environmentalism and Revivalism: The Vrindavan Forest Revival and Conservation Project

Unit 5: (Week 6): Environment and Ethnicity: The Politics of Sacred Groves in Jharkhand

Unit 6: (Week 7 & 8): Hindu Nationalism and the Environment: Elements and Theme

Unit 7: (Week 9): Environment, Labour and Labour Organisations

Unit 8: (Week 10-11): Environment, Social and Political Movement, Network & Alliance

Essential and Secondary Readings

Unit 1: (Week 1 & 2): Environment, Politics, Society  

Noel Castree and Bruce Braun (eds.) (2001), Social Nature: Theory, Practice, and Politics, Oxford: Blackwell Publishers

Environmental Studies [FC-0102] [FC-0102-4]

Faculty Name
Meghna Agarwala [meghna.agarwala@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Foundation course: Geo-spatial analysis for Environmental Studies

This course will consist of introduction to theory of environmental studies (political ecology, earth and climate systems, biological systems) and practice of using geo-spatial analysis for environmental questions (understanding, downloading and manipulating geo-spatial data in both qGIS and Google Earth Engine). We will then combine the two to answer important questions in biodiversity conservation, climate change and sustainable development. 

NOTE: This class will work better if students are committed to learning. So please do not sign up for this class if you are not interested in learning. 

NOTE2: This class can serve as a pre-requisite for my remote sensing class (cross listed with Physics and CS; and recommended for PhD students in Ecology). 

 

Learning Outcomes

At the end of the course, you should be able to understand, query and problematize environment related issue associated with biodiversity and climate change; a skill you will hopefully continue to use in your future careers. You will also have geo-spatial skills you can use to address several environmental and developmental questions.  

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

I usually share a google drive with all the readings and assignments. 

Grading Rubric

Weekly Assignments: 40% of grade

Projects: 20% of grade (5% peer-grading; 5% TF grading; 10% my grading)

Attendance and participation: 30% of grade (10 % attendance, 10% participation, 10% DS participation). This will include in-class writing assignments and in-class debates based on the readings. 

 

Attendance Policy

Students are allowed to miss 4 classes, no questions asked. There will be -2 for every class or DS missed thereafter. This will impact your total grades out of 100.

description:
Indian Civilisations [FC-0201] [FC-0201-2]

Faculty Name
Nayanjot Kaur Lahiri [nayanjot.lahiri@ashoka.edu.in] ,Rudrangshu Mukherjee [rudrangshu.mukherjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is a small course about a large and fascinating subject, that of Indian Civilizations. It has been structured in a way that it can be immersed in, we hope, with enjoyment.  The course will draw out civilizational elements from prehistory till the present – through travels and lives, through ideas and art forms – in which small phenomena will be linked to the larger world of the Indian subcontinent and beyond. In the process, the course will explore a varied and rich tapestry that includes rock art, the Harappan Civilization, the Mahabharata’s many stories, the iconic emperors Ashoka and Akbar,  and the words of the Buddha and the   Bhakti saints. Indian civilizations, as the course will emphasize, are not to be seen merely as part of the dead past but as elements that continued to be invoked in present times, by literary giants like Rabindranath Tagore and statesmen like Jawaharlal Nehru, and by more ordinary people in India’s villages and towns. Readings will be electronically shared with students.

description:
Indian Civilisations [FC-0201] [FC-0201-3]

Faculty Name
Raghu Malhotra [raghu.malhotra_asp19@ashoka.edu.in] ,Aparna Vaidik [aparna.vaidik@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Why should one learn the history of Indian Civilisation(s)? Young students are expected to study this history because the idea of Indian Civilization is fundamentally entwined with the Indians’ sense of nationhood. As if, to be a good citizen and a patriot one needs to be familiar with one’s civilizational history. But this  further raises the question: What meaning does it hold for a young citizen to belong to a country - a young republic - with claims to an ancient civilization? This course is an invitation for you to explore this question. It requires you to imagine yourself as a flaneur - a person who leisurely strolls, pauses and observes the world around them. Starting our journey at the Ganga ghats to observe the immersion of Gandhi’s ashes, we will enter the refugee colonies and detention camps to have conversations with women and children living there, make our way through the new borders with your passport and ration cards, encounter sex workers holding up the constitution asking for their rights, watch the farmers and village folks flicker on the TV screen as we purchase new luxuries in the multilingual city bazaar, and listen to the radio belting out Lata Mangeshkar songs as we make our way across India’s post-colonial history. Along the way we will see films, documentaries, posters, advertisements, theater, art, literature, cartoons and encounter peoples and voices that will introduce us to new ways of understanding what it means to be an Indian citizen or a young person living in India today.

Grading Rubric

Course Requirements

I.          Attendance for lectures: 15% - Attendance is mandatory. Each absence will lead to loss of the attendance grade and more than 5 absences will be an automatic fail. 

II.            Discussion Sections: 45% (25+10+10)

a.   Participation: This class is weighted heavily toward reading and discussion. Therefore, speaking and sharing ideas will contribute to your participation grade. Please also keep in mind that the assignments will not make up for absence in the classroom.

c.  Attendance: While attendance is implicit in your participation in the classes but your physical presence in the discussions also counts for your grade. Each absence will lead to loss of the attendance grade. More than 4 absences will result in loss of the entire attendance grade for the discussion sections. 

b.  Reflective essays (for any 10 topics): After the discussion section you are expected to write a paragraph journaling your thoughts, takeaways, critical reflections, or the points that remained unclear or unanswered for you. It is to be posted latest by 6pm next day for it to count towards the course grade.

III. Final Submission: 40% - This is a 1800-2000-word essay that you will work through the semester

Each absence will lead to loss of the attendance grade. More than 4 absences will result in loss of the entire attendance grade for the discussion sections.

description:
Indian Civilisations [FC-0201] [FC-0201-5]

Faculty Name
Projit Bihari Mukharji [projit.mukharji@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sai Mukhesh Chandra Jyothula [sai.jyothula_tf@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

There is one thing in which India today is unquestionably the world leader, viz. our population. There are more people in our country than in any other in the world. At a very basic level this demonstrates an ability to stay alive and multiply. In other words, to understand and care for human bodies. There are, therefore, few better vantage points than our understandings of human bodies and health through which to explore the contours, characteristics, and even the plausibility of an ‘Indian civilization’. Have there been particular civilizational ways to think about human bodily health? If so, what are these and how best to understand them? These are the main questions we will explore in this course.

To answer the questions, we will delve into over two millennia of medical ideas and practices in region. We will learn about the classical Sanskrit works of Caraka and Susruta, the Persianate canon of Ibn Sina, the birth of modern pandemics during the British Raj, heart transplants in postcolonial India and, finally, the profits and privations around the patenting of medicinal herbs like neem.

At the end of the course, students will acquire a broad sense of both Indian history in general and, more specifically, the history of medicine. They will further acquire critical tools for thinking about the role of specialized technical knowledge within society. Additionally, the course will also hone critical thinking and writing skills.

Quantitative Reasoning and Mathematical Thinking [FC-0306] [FC-0306-4]

Faculty Name
Conjeeveram Srirangachari Rajan [cs.rajan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Mathematics is central to modern day knowledge systems. It is one of the three R's (Reading, `Riting and `Rithmetic) 

and is considered as the Queen of the Sciences.  For those who use it, it is a science; for those who practise it, it is an art. 

Some are passionate about it, some despair at hearing about it. 

What is mathematics? What is it about that excites such contradictory responses? 

The course will try to give an introduction to some of the central themes, ideas and constructs in mathematics illustrated 

by some concrete examples.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Poincare: Science and Hypothesis

Beck and Geoghagen: The Art of Proof

Christopher Thomas: Math for Liberal Art Majors

Courant and Robbins: What is Mathematics?

and many others which will be referenced in due course of time.

Two mid terms and an end term with weightage 20 each. 

The grading will be relative. If I feel that the students are learning well, 

then there will be a larger number of higher grades;  on the other hand if I 

believe the performance is not satisfactory, then a larger number of lower grades.

Economy, Politics and Society [FC-0412] [FC-0412-1]

Faculty Name
Pulapre Balakrishnan [pulapre.balakrishnan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

                                                                                       ‘Economic ideas from Smith to Sen’

This course is intended as an introduction to the main currents of economic thought over the past two and a half centuries. It commences with the ideas of Adam Smith, moves on to those of the other members of the Classical School, namely Malthus and Ricardo, and ends the first section of the course with the writings of Marx. Significantly, their work continues to be extensively resorted to even today. Next, before journeying on to the ideas of the great economists of the twentieth century - notably, Marshall, Hayek, Keynes and Schumpeter – the course engages with the transition in the mode of inquiry to ‘neo-Classical’ economics, which has come to stay as the dominant pedagogical tool. The consequences of this transition will be highlighted. Neo-classical economics presents economic agents in isolation as opposed to viewing the economy as a whole, the defining feature of the Classical economists and Karl Marx. Now there is no longer a normative concern with the distribution of income or a recognition of its role in driving the economy. Finally, we study the rise after the Second World War of development economics, when the object of attention shifted to the economic problems of Africa, Asia and Latin America, requiring, it was argued, a different treatment than that found in mainstream economics. In this section, the course engages in particular with the ideas of Amartya Sen who opened up a new view of economic development, which can be creatively applied to an evaluation of India’s progress since 1947. The course concludes with an introduction to ecological economics, drawing out the implications of the economy being an entity embedded in nature.

The following two books form the main reading material for the lectures: ‘The Worldly Philosophers’ by Robert Heilbroner and 'Great Economic Thinkers' by Jonathan Conlin (ed.) Supplementary reading will be made available when necessary. In the Discussion Sessions students read original passages from the work of Smith, Marx, Keynes and Sen among other thinkers on economics. A contemporary account of the evolution of economics is found in 'The Poverty of Political Economy' by Meghnad Desai.

Opting for the course must go with a willingness to read both intensively and extensively. 

 

Learning Outcomes

The course reveals the various modes of reasoning that have been used in economics historically. It shows how economic ideas have been shaped by historical events and how they have in turn shaped ideas about the economy.

Discussion will be encouraged in the lectures, with time set aside for it at the end of each lecture session. However, timely reading is expected when taking advantage of the opportunity given. 

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The following two books form the reading material for the lectures: ‘The Worldly Philosophers’ by Robert Heilbroner and 'Great Economic Thinkers' by Jonathan Conlin (ed.).

Supplementary readings will be recommended as needed. All material will be made available via the library and postings on D-space.

In the Discussion Sessions students read original passages from the work of Smith, Marx, Keynes and Sen among other thinkers on economics.

A contemporary account of the evolution of economics ideas may be found in 'The Poverty of Political Economy' by Meghnad Desai.

Grading Rubric

I. Mid-term exam: 20 marks.

Participation in the Discussion Sessions: 10 marks.

Final exam: 70 marks. 

Questions in the exams shall be answered in the form of essays. 

II. The following interpretation of the grading scheme to be adopted may be noted:

· A, A–   Excellent quality and full mastery of the subject.  A grade of A means extraordinary distinction.

· B+, B, B– good comprehension of the course material, a good command of the skills needed to work with the course material, and the student’s full engagement with the course requirements and activities.

· C+, C, C– adequate comprehension of the course material and the skills needed to work with the course material. indicates the student has met the basic requirements for completing assigned work and participating in class activities.

· D+, D, D– barely satisfactory work indicating minimal command of the course materials and minimal participation in class activities.

· F -unsatisfactory and unworthy of course credit towards the degree.

Attendance Policy

Attendance is not compulsory at the lectures but is expected at the discussion sessions.

No food or drink other than water is to be consumed in class.

Faculty Name
Rahul Verma [rahul.verma@ashoka.edu.in] ,Neha Sheik [neha.sheik_asp24@ashoka.edu.in] ,Rishika Arora [rishika.arora_asp24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The primary objective of this course is to familiarise students with the world of social science to better understand that world we live in. Social realities are often complex due to continuous interactions of varied nodes of identities, socio-political institutions, and economic relations that shape individual lives and collectives. This course introduces students to the basic theories, methods, and particular contributions of economics, political science, and sociology . It would focus on - a) how social scientists study critical questions about economic development, political regimes, social systems, among others, and b) understanding the complexities and challenges of democracy and governance using India as a case study, in relation to other relevant examples depending on the theme. 

Learning Outcomes

Through the course, students will familiarise with various research designs to understand the social-political realities and  how to interpret basic quantitative data. The course intends to develop the thinking, writing, and communication abilities of students.  It will also provide important tools for analyzing the material covered in other courses, especially in social sciences. 

Grading Rubric

The final grades in the course will be based on a continuous assessment system, i.e., participation in the class (including attendance), two short short assignments, a mid-term and a final exam.

Attendance Policy

The course material requires students to attend lectures regularly. A percentage of the final grade is based on attendance/participation during the lecture and discussion section.

description:
Economy, Politics and Society [FC-0412] [FC-0412-3]

Faculty Name
Ravindran S [ravindran.sriramachandran@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

 

Course Description:

The course seeks to explore the emergence of modern Economy, Politics and Society in India by analyzing seminal writings related to the emergence of modernity on the Indian subcontinent. We will examine the evolution of modern South Asia from 1818 until 1947. The course surveys major figures who grappled with and helped shape social, economic and political struggles during the British colonial period.  We will consider the multiple debates that went into, nation formation, economic condition, caste stratification, the role of women, and religious reform, i.e.,the complexity of the social and political discourse of the period. We will analyse primary texts, including autobiographies, speeches, dialogues, treatises, ethnography, and where possible literary fiction. Please note that this is a tentative syllabus, and we will modify it suitably as the semester progresses.

Goals: 

Read, think, and evaluate critically modern South Asian society, economy and politics.

Acquire basic knowledge about major events in modern South Asian history.         

●         Understand the impact of important figures, and seminal debates in modern South      Asian culture and history

Gain comprehension about colonialism and its impact on modern South Asia

Understand the construction of communalism in modern South Asia

Learn to evaluate critically primary sources

          t.

 

Required Texts:

The following texts are available for purchase and on reserve at the library:

 

Modern South Asia, Sugata Bose and Ayesha Jalal (available free on LMS)

 

The bulk of the readings may be found on LMS, some will be given as handouts or sent via email as attachments.


 

 


 

Learning Outcomes

Outcomes:

         Upon completion the student will be able to 

Demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the dominant themes in modern South Asian society, history and culture

Demonstrate an analytical understanding of the impact of colonialism in South Asia and its lasting consequences in today’s modern states in the region.

Critically evaluate primary sources

Critically evaluate secondary sources 

Demonstrate an ability to synthesize information from non-traditional sources.

Demonstrate the ability to engage critically and analytically with the concept of modernity and its global impact.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Course Requirements:

Students are expected to attend each class meeting and to come to each class with at least one written question or comment from the reading. These comments/questions should be turned in by the end of each class, and they will be checked off (not graded). The grade break-down will be as follows: Class Attendance/Participation (10%); Discussion Section Attendance/ Participation (10%).  Response papers for the four modules (10%+10%+10%+10%) Mid-term (10%); Final Research Paper (30%).

All exams are cumulative. The grading criteria for the research paper and the exams will be discussed in class. I (or your TF) will give you feedback on your performance after each assignmentand after the mid-term exam. However please note that to make an appointment and meet your TF is your responsibility If you wish to discuss your performance at other times, you are welcome to see me during my office hours or schedule an appointment.

All essays should be written in 11 point Times New Roman (or Arial Narrow) and should be in double space. Citations should be clearly indicated in a standard format (which will be explained in class). 

A sample of the readings we will be discussing in class

In the first part of the course, we will analyze diverse strands of anti-colonial and nationalist discourse from the rise of Gandhi to Independence and the Partition of the Indian Subcontinent in August 1947.

What are the key differences between Gandhi’s and Nehru’s notions of progress and modernity?

What was the intellectual reasoning behind the call for Pakistan?

In what ways do the politics of Partition and identity-formation affect postcolonial societies and subjects?

Primary Texts

1. Mohandas K. Gandhi, Hind Swaraj

and Analysis

Bose and Jalal, Chapters 12-13, Modern South Asia

Partha Chatterjee, “Gandhi and the Critique of Civil Society,” in Subaltern Studies 3

Please note that this grading scale implies that, for example, 72.9% is a C- (NOT a C), 82.9% is a B- (NOT a B); 83.0 is a B and 87.0 is a B+, etc. Make sure you comply with the Ashoka Academic Integrity Code. Students must abide by the Student Academic Integrity Code as stated in the Ashoka Website.

Attendance Policy

Students have 5 free absences. In order to maintain a level of discussion
and participation, more than 5 absences from class will result in a

Economy, Politics and Society [FC-0412] [FC-0412-4]

Faculty Name
Mohammad Amir Ahmad [ali.khan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Mohammad Amir Ahmad Khan [mohammad.khan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Vineeth Srivatsava [vineeth.srivatsava_tf@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Objective and Description: 

This course will introduce students to non-European aspects of political thought with particular recourse to various parts of the colonised world. The course shall largely focus on the colonial and post-colonial periods in order to highlight to students, not only the reception of concepts like liberalism in the non-European world, but also explore how these concepts underwent changes and reinterpretations in new environments. An often-neglected aspect of the study of politics, is the study of the role of religion in the social and political formations of the non-European world and part of the aim of this course will be to highlight the continuing importance of religious thought to understanding wider political discourse. This course will equip students with a perspective that will enhance and broaden their understanding of notions like the state, liberalism and, democracy beyond their ‘Western’ interpretations in addition to providing the background for understanding the roots of these concepts in political theory. Most Importantly, the course will introduce students to major non-Western philosophers and thinkers. Apart from this the students will also understand how ideas travel and how these often disrupt the geographical imaginings that we often assume to be unassailable and fixed. 

The nature of academia has meant that subjects and disciplines have been divided and categorized in what are thought to be distinct conceptual frameworks. However, my own belief is that the most compelling work in the social sciences is predicated on approaches that interrogate and blur these boundaries. Therefore, although this FC is formally linked to the political science department, the material we cover, the debates we unpack and the ideas we explore will also take into account historical context, philosophical underpinnings and indeed aspects of sociological and anthropological work.

description:
Economy, Politics and Society [FC-0412] [FC-0412-5]

Faculty Name
Vinod Pavarala [vinod.pavarala@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In 2023, Reporters without Borders, a global media watchdog that measures press freedom worldwide, rated India at 161 among 180 countries, a slide from its 150th position in the previous year.  What does this negative assessment mean for a country that’s the largest democracy in the world and, as is being claimed recently, the ‘mother of democracy’? As the situation with media freedom is said to be going from ‘problematic’ to ‘very bad’ in several countries of the Global South, where deep inequalities still define their populations, what does it mean for substantive democracy, rather than merely electoral democracy?

In this course, we will examine these questions critically, using such indices as ownership of media entities, their proximity to political parties, the autonomy of other democratic institutions that are expected to ensure the independent and free functioning of the media. We will investigate the challenges posed by a severely constrained media space for sustaining a healthy civil society and fostering a deliberative democracy (one that is ‘talk-centric’ rather than ‘vote-centric’). Finally, the course will explore alternative, community-based, citizen-driven media initiatives in India that are seeking to transform our public sphere into a more vibrant, pluralistic, and diverse space.

Learning Outcomes
  1. Understand the theoretical foundations of media and democracy.
  2. Learn about the role of media in shaping public opinion and political discourse.
  3. Explore the challenges and opportunities of media technologies in democratic societies.
  4. Investigate the specific case of India to understand the nuances of media and democracy in a diverse and dynamic context.
  5. Develop critical thinking skills through analysis of media representations and their impact on democratic processes.
  6. Enhance research and communication skills through assignments and class discussions.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

READING LIST TO BE ADDED SOON

Grading Rubric

Grades for the course will be determined as follows:

1. A class test (date and format to be announced) -- 20 marks

2. Discussion Session assignments (3 reviews of about 600 words each of films/documentaries to be screened in class; 1 oral group presentation) -- 25 marks

3. A class blog on Media & Democracy -- groups to be created and subjects to be discussed in class -- 30 marks

4. Final essay on media and democracy (1500 words) -- topics to be suggested by Professor -- 25 marks

As per Ashoka norm, three absences are permissible without documentation. Students are expected to seek permission of the professor for all other absences and, where appropriate, with relevant documentation. If overall attendance falls below 80%, you should expect a grade reduction.

Economy, Polity, and Society: Through the Prism of COVID 19

description:
Mind and Behaviour [FC-0503] [FC-0503-3]

Faculty Name
Kranti Saran [saran@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What kind of creature are you? A human being, no doubt. But what kind of creature is that? How should such a creature live? We will critically explore influential models of human nature in the Indic and Western philosophical traditions and their profound implications both for how we ought to live and our place in the social world. Readings include selections from the Upanishads, Vasisṭḥa’s Yoga, Plato, Aristotle, Hume, Freud, Mill, Railton, Śāntideva, Korsgaard, Foot, O’Neill, Frye, Haidt, Milgram, Hobbes, Rawls, Bilgrami and others.

description:
Mind and Behaviour [FC-0503] [FC-0503-5]

Faculty Name
William David McDonald [william.mcdonald@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Who were we? Who are we? Who will we become? This course examines texts on human nature and human identity from the oldest extant written literature (The Epic of Gilgamesh), through texts on personal, collective and gender identities, to speculations on post-human being. We will also investigate the ethical question of how we should live, based on the sort of beings we are. This ethical question will require exploration of some theories of ethics with a special focus on virtue ethics. The texts are drawn from European, Indian, Near Eastern, Central Asian and Indigenous Australian cultures.

description:
Mind and Behaviour [FC-0503] [FC-0503-6]

Faculty Name
Mohammad Saeedimehr [mohammad.saeedimehr@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Faculty: Prof. Mohammad Saeedimehr

As human beings, we have the intrinsic desire to gain knowledge not only about the external world but also about the internal world i.e., our selves. On a par with the external world, the inner world of the self is so complicated and multidimensional that can, and indeed should, be studied by diverse branches of philosophy and science. Among other scholars, philosophers have always been tackling puzzlements about the nature of the human self. Some of the fundamental philosophical questions include: what is the nature of the mind and the mental states? What is the relation between mind and body? How can we best understand certain human phenomena like consciousness, intentionality, rationality and personhood? How can we understand and explain mental causation? Are we really free in at least some of our actions? How can we be justified in believing in other minds? … In this course, we shall explore such problems and examine the main philosophical theories offered as solutions. Though we will occasionally discuss ancient, medieval and modern views, our focus will be on the views of contemporary analytic philosophers. By the end of our intellectual journey, I expect you to get familiar with some of the mysteries of our “inner world” and become strongly encouraged to enhance your relevant knowledge in future.

description:
Great Books [FC-0601] [FC-0601-2]

Faculty Name
Madhavi Menon [menon@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Not all narratives become books and not all books are termed great. Many fabulous tales are transmitted orally and several terrific ideas are communicated through non-verbal means like art. Of the millions of stories and ideas and arguments that are written down in book form, only a fraction have significantly impacted the world as we know it today. In this course, we will read several books and fragments of books, all of which have shaped the ways in which we think about sexuality. The books we will read this semester come from different cultures, time periods, languages, and cover different subjects. Nonetheless, they all have something significant to offer us as we think about one of the most universal yet thorny issues in the world today.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Vatsyayana, Kama Sutra, Ovid, Metamorphoses, Plato, The Symposium, Darwin, Origin of Species, Descartes, Discourse on Method, Shelley, Frankenstein, Freud, The Interpretation of Dreams, Foucault, The History of Sexuality, Vol. I, Online material

Your formal requirements this semester will thus include a daily quiz, twice-weekly questions, attendance and writing in your weekly discussion sections, a midterm assignment, and a final essay of 5-7 pages in length.

Grading Rubric

Your grade for the semester will depend on your class participation (50% including quizzes, timely and thoughtful online posts, productive participation in the class and section discussions), and midterm and final assignments (20% and 30% each). However, I will weight your final grade towards your better rather than your worse performances.

description:
Great Books [FC-0601] [FC-0601-4]

Faculty Name
Devan Barker [devan.barker@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Know Thyself (Gnothi Seauton).  This was the injunction inscribed at the entrance to the ancient Greek temple of Apollo at Delphi.  Socrates claimed that understanding the self was the beginning of all wisdom, yet many of us walk through our lives gaining deep understanding of the world around us, but content to see our own inner life as something of a familiar mystery.
We will begin by surveying several “doctrines of soul” which emerged during the Axial Age, that great flowering of religious and philosophical thought. We will read excerpts from the Bible, from the Upanishads, the Pali Cannon, and from foundational texts of Confucianism and Daoism. We will then turn our attention to Plato and Aristotle, reading selections of the Republic and De Anima. Augustine’s Confessions will show us how the inner life of Platonism was reformed in the Christian west as a fallen spirit, a model that received its greatest treatment in Dante’s Divine Comedy, especially in Purgatory. This view of humanity was eventually challenged in the Renaissance by Pico Della Mirandola in his Oration on the Dignity of Man, and then powerfully by Shakespeare in his 1604 work Hamlet. Of the early modern philosophers, we will read excerpts from Descartes’ Discourse on Method, Hobbe’s description of human psychology in Leviathan, and we’ll compare and contrast the views expressed in Hume’s Treatise of Human Nature with those of Rousseau in Emile. Kant marks something of a split between the philosophers and the scientists on this question, so we’ll touch on his thought before turning to Darwin’s early description of human evolution in The Descent of Man, Sartre’s radical existentialism of human freedom in Being and Nothingness, and Freud’s reworking of Plato’s thought. Among the contemporary scientists, there aren’t necessarily classics or “Great Books”, so we’ll survey the territory using scholarly articles. The philosopher Chalmers will show us just how far we still have to go in discovering our inner essence in The Hard Problem of Consciousness. Both philosophers and neurologists are exploring the possibility that our inner life is nothing more than an epiphenomenon – foam tossed up by the waves of the neural structures in our brain, but of no essential or transcendent character. Other scientists are giving us insight into the differences between the inner lives of men and women (in general terms) in works like Why Gender Matters while authors Wilson and Holmstrom spar over whether gender differences are biological or social in nature. Other contemporary thinkers explore the role of culture and language in shaping our inner world and personal identity.
If this seems like a lot, it is, because it’s a question humans have been grappling with for a long time.  The good news it that we’ll be working with selections of these works rather than the entire books and all of it will be made available electronically in the course, so there won’t be books to buy. I hope you’ll join us for a fascinating intellectual journey into the essence of – US.
 

Learning Outcomes

Upon succesful completion of the course students will be able to 

  • Articulate the principle models and metaphores that have been used to define and explore the inner human life, whether articultate as a function of soul, spirit, mind, psyche, or brain
  • Use a general vocabulary drawn from the primary sources to compare and contrast the parts and the relationship between parts of the inner life
  • Associate general structure as well as details of each model with key thinkers and writers who have influences  the scholarly discussion of this topic
  • Articulate strengths and weaknesses of various models as well as methodological difficulties and limitations in our exploration of the question
  • Explore and narrate how these various traditions have influenced and continue to influence their own conception of self, identity, and consciousness
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

We will be reading selections of classic books as well as scholarly articles.  All the reading material will be provided in the course.

Week one: Course introduction and excerpts from the Jewish Old Testament (Genesis and Psalms)

Week two: Brihad Aranyaka Upanishad 1 sect 4, Katha Upanishad 1 sect. 3, Mencius: Human Nature is Good, HsunTsu: Man's Nature is Evil, Plato's Republic

Week three: Aristotle: De Anima, Paul's Letter to the Romans, Corrinthians (Bible,  New Testement), Augustine: Confessions

Week four: Murtadha Mutahhari: Fundamentals of Islamic Thought, Dante: Divine Comedy - Inferno

Week five: Dante: Divine Comedy - Purgatory, Pico della Mirandoa: Oration on the Dignity of Man

Week six: Shakespeare: Hamlet

Week seven: Descartes: Discorse on Method Parts 4 and 5, Hobbes: Leviathan 1, 5, 13

Week eight: Hume: Treatise on Human Nature, Kant: Anthropology from a Pragmatic Point of View, Religion within the Boundaries of  Bare Reason

Week nine: Rousseau: Emile 1 and 5, Durkheim:                 , Darwin: The Descent of Man, Wittgenstein:

Week ten: Sartre: Existentialism is a Humanism, Kierkegaard: Fear and Trembling, Nietsche: 

Week eleven: Bracken: Essence, Accident and Race, Rose et al: Not in our Genes -- Biology, Ideology and Human Nature

Week twelve: Sax: Why Gender Matters, Holstrom, Do Women Have a Distinct Nature?

Week thirteen: articles on brain neurology including, The Brain's Default Network

Grading Rubric

Preparation, attendance and class participation - 50%

Unit Assessments - 10% each                           - 40%

Capstone project                                                - 10%

 

Attendance Policy

This is not a course that will work without regular attendance and participation. Absensces will affect both the quality of learning and the grade.  Exceptions for extreme situations can be worked out individually with Prof. Barker.

description:
Literature and the World [FC-0701] [FC-0701-1]

Faculty Name
Abir Bashir Bazaz [abir.bazaz@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What is literature? And what does it teach us about who we are, the world we live in, and where we are going? Does literature help us make better sense of the lives of others or the necessary strife involved in the human condition? Does literature put us more genuinely in touch with ourselves and one another? What is the relation between literature and politics? Or literature and religion? In this course, we will search for answers to some of these questions by reading modern literature from all over the world. We will be studying literary texts by Fyodor Dostoyevsky, Franz Kafka, Ryunosuke Akutagawa, V.S. Naipaul, Tayeb Salih, Toni Morrison and Flannery O’Connor among others.

WeekDays: Monday, Wednesday, Wednesday, Wednesday, Friday, Friday
description:
Literature and the World [FC-0701] [FC-0701-2]

Faculty Name
Jonathan Gil Harris [jgharris@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This class begins with the premise that every story is a migrant.  A story migrates in a variety of ways – from the teller to the audience or reader; but also from reader to reader, place to place, and culture to culture, as the story gets told and retold (or written and rewritten) over space and time. 

We live in a capitalist age when ideas of private property have subtly colonized how we think about stories.  It is assumed that a story is always BY someone, and is therefore their possession.  But if stories migrate, can a single author really claim full ownership of the story she has written?  How is every story a re-imagining of another story, or many stories, that have become before?

The notion that a story is an author’s private intellectual property also inhibits how we read.  Readers become potential trespassers; they must pay the price of admission, and then act respectfully when they enter the property, making sure not to damage or alter it.  If you are a student of literature, it’s likely that the command to respect an author’s private property will be accompanied by the assumption that the objective of literary analysis is simply to understand what the author intended, and to submit to that deferentially.  But if stories migrate from teller to reader, and from reader to reader and culture to culture, maybe the act of reading should not be thought of just as a respectful encounter with an author’s private property.  Every act of reading instead becomes a creative re-imagining of the story, in conversation with new potential readers and audiences. 

If stories are migrants, then they are no longer individual property by authors who command their readers.  They are collective artefacts that invite us to respond creatively and re-imagine them anew.

If you doubt what I am saying, think this.  Do any two readers respond exactly the same way to a story?  Each reader, when asked about a story and what it meant, will retell it slightly differently.  Recognizing that reading is a form of creative re-imagining is one of this course’s most important themes.

As stories migrate across space, time, and languages, they are re-imagined by the world across many genres and media – poems, plays, novels, essays, films, graphic novels.  These re-imaginings might prove that, in literature, there is nothing original under the sun.  Yet how literature reimagines earlier stories also tells us a lot about the extraordinarily diverse ways in which different cultures have understood the world: relations between men and women, relations between diverse ethnicities and religions, the nature of political and social power, humans’ relations to the animal and plant world, the agonies and ecstasies of love, and the nature of imagination itself. 

How, for example, is a Roman re-imagining of an old Greek story about an Asian witch re-imagined by an English playwright in an “American” drama that has itself been re-imagined in very different ways by writers and artists from the Caribbean, Sierra Leone, Mauritius, and Samoa?  How is a Roman re-imagining of a Babylonian (ie Iraqi) love story reworked by the same English playwright in a Greek mythic tale with an Asian subtext that gets in turn re-imagined by a Bombay director in Hindi, Punjabi, Urdu and English as well as by an English graphic novelist in a reworking of an American comic-book hero’s saga based on a character from a German short story?  And how is an antique Persian story about an African migrant re-imagined in an Arab novel and then re-imagined by the same English playwright, whose play is then diversely re-imagined by a Sudanese novelist and a Hindi film-maker from Uttar Pradesh? 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

We will read, among others, Ovid’s Metamorphoses, Hanan Al-Shaykh’s The Thousand and One Nights, Shakespeare’s A Midsummer Night’s Dream, Othello, and The Tempest, Neil Gaiman’s Sandman: Dream Country, Tayeb Salih’s Season of Migration to the North, and Aimé Césaire’s A Tempest, as well as see films such as 10ml Love and Omkara.

Grading Rubric

A-F

Attendance Policy

No more than three absences.
