description:
Literature and the World [FC-0701] [FC-0701-3]

Faculty Name
Rita Kothari [rita.kothari@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Families shape us, form us, for better or worse. They are the sites of our secure selves and deepest fears. How does literature deal with the institution of the family? What are the filial universes in literature? Does the world of imagination tell us deeper truths about the family - its potential to define and destroy? We will read a range of texts from different cultures, in different genres and also in different languages (through English translations) and ask what might be universal, if any, truths about families. We will examine relationships between kinship, intimacies, sexualities and individual selves. We will dwell upon the community and the individual as a site of contestation, particularly in certain societies. In the process we also hope to gain an understanding of what is literature, what might be its functions and significance. Treat this course as a glimpse into the joy and difficulty of 'reading' literature. 

Learning Outcomes

We expect students to learn to engage deeply with a text, and also with their own selves as they do embodied readings, and reflect back upon their own lives. We expect this to be evident in the writing they do. Very importantly, we expect students to be active in class and allow the instructor to take them through questions that literature produces and real life hints at. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Here's a flavour of some texts we will do : 

Vivek Shanbag's Gacher Gocher, Alison Bechdel's Fun Home, Mahesh Dattani's Dance Like a Man, Manjula Padmanabhan's Lights Out, the Mahabharata (excerpts), Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice, Daya Pawar's Baluta, Attia Hossain's Sunlight on a Broken Column etc.

Principles of Science [FC-0801] [FC-0801-1]

Faculty Name
Alok Bhattacharya [alok.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in] ,Somak Raychaudhury [somak.raychaudhury@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sahithi Vedula [sahithi.vedula_tf@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Foundation Course: Principles and Practice of Science: From subatomic particles to complex biological organisms

Science entails the systematic pursuit of knowledge, which essentially involves unbiased observations and multiple methods of validation. Science gives us the ability to understand how our world works and how we interact with our physical surroundings. It not only incorporates basic ideas and theories about how our universe behaves but it also provides a framework for learning more and tackling new questions and concerns that come our way. Science also provides an unparalleled view of the order and symmetry of the universe and its workings—subatomic particles to the never-ending space. Science enables you to integrate with your surroundings, both living and non-living. It has also given us the tools to alter living and non-living things. It has the potential to have both positive impacts such as coping with natural disasters, curing diseases, and discovering new sources of energy, as well as negative impacts in the form of climate change and weapons of mass destruction.

The course narrates some of the key theoretical and technical developments in the evolution of the sciences and offers a synoptic view of the development of concepts that drive modern science.

Faculty: Alok Bhattacharya (AB), Department of Biology

alok.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in

Somak Raychaudhury

somak.raychaudhury@ashoka.edu.in

A basic understanding of the philosophy of science, methods of science, some of the fundamental discoveries and principles.

description:
Principles of Science [FC-0801] [FC-0801-4]

Faculty Name
Shraddha Karve [shraddha.karve@ashoka.edu.in] ,Somak Raychaudhury [somak.raychaudhury@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course discusses how we evolved the concept of age and time- age of the earth and of the solar system, time in relativity (and arrow of time, entropy), time in biological systems (biological clocks) etc. Through this course we would be like to bring to the students, our current understanding about the scale and age of the Universe, and how this knowledge has evolved; How biological systems including human body maintain temporal patterns; impact of climate change and ecological damage on biological time and the evolution of survival strategies that require understanding of past, present and future.

The course will start with a general introduction and historical perspective to the concept of time in our day-to-day life and in physics and in biology. We shall discuss the history of measurement of time and invention of clocks. Without involving much mathematics, the course will help students derive relationship between speed of light and time, space-time continuum, age of the universe, stars, earth etc. We would then follow concept of time in biology in the context of birth-growth-ageing-death. Seasonal variations in morphological and life-history traits as measurement of time, mechanism of timekeeping - biological clocks, circadian rhythms. We will also discuss the evolutionary time and the important concepts pertaining to our understanding of this such as generation time of different living beings. The course ends with discussions on human cognition and the concept of time: conceptual understanding of past, present and future.

The course is taught through lectures, discussions, flip-the-classroom mode (students making presentations on various related topics), reading books/watching movies and writing assignments.

Learning Outcomes

1.     Our current understanding about the scale and age of the Universe, and how this knowledge has evolved.

2.     Understanding how Astronomers and Geologists measure time and age, and how reliable these measurements are.

3.     How biological systems maintain temporal patterns; impact of climate change and ecological damage on biological time.

4.     Evolution of survival strategies that require understanding of past, present and future.

Overview

The course will be titled : Length Scales in Science"  will cover the science at different length scales, from atomistic to planetary scales. The approximations and theories change for different length scales.

Is there any unification ?

It will focus particularly on chemical and biological length scales. How from atoms/molecules to systems are formed? From quantum mechanucs to astomistic to coarse-graining encomapssing the the theme of multi-scale simulation.

About Foundation Course  and the title of Length scales in Science- An overview

Chemistry at small atomic and molecular length scales

Periodic table and its properties

Lewis theory of chemical bonding and octet rule

Bohr’s Atomic Theory- Hydrogen  and Hydrogen like atoms- Quantization

Bohr Orbits and energy levels

Chemical Reaction- Thermodynamics and Kinetics view

Science at higher length scales

Concept and units of Lengths

Change of paradigm and pedagogy as small becomes larger

Small molecules to large molecules, polymers, biomolecules

Quantum to Classical transitions

Engineering and Planetary length scales

CourseTitle: History of India II: From c. 200 BCE to 1000 CE
description:
History of India II: From c. 200 BCE to 1000 CE [HIS-2002] [HIS-2002-1]

Faculty Name
Upinder Singh [upinder.singh@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course offers an overview of the history of the subcontinent from c. 200 BCE to 1000 CE, divided this long, momentous period into three phases: c. 200 BCE-300 CE, 300-600 CE and 600-1000 CE. It highlights continuities and changes in politics, economy and society by focusing on political structures, class, caste, gender, agrarian relations, urban life and trade. Apart from Hinduism, Buddhism, Jainism and the advent of Islam, the themes in religious history will include the age-old popular worship of snakes and yakshas and the pervasive influence of bhakti and tantra across religious boundaries. The emergence of regional configurations in politics and the remarkable efflorescence in literary expression, and art and architecture in the early medieval period will be highlighted. The course will also look at the many different ways in which the Indian subcontinent was connected with the wider world across the centuries.

*** See attached course outline for further details

Learning Outcomes

Students will get an overview and grasp of the various aspects of the the history of the Indian subcontinent from c. 200 BCE to 1000 CE. They will also get an exposure to the primary sources used to reconstruct this history.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

General readings:

N. B. The list below contains some basic readings which students should read in order to understand the issues covered in this course. Further readings for class discussions will be circulated separately.

Bopearachchi, Osmund. 2015 From Bactria to Taprobane: Selected Works of Osmund Bopearachchi, 2 vols. New Delhi, Manohar.

Champakalakshmi, R. 1996. Trade, Ideology and Urbanization: South India 30 BC to AD 1300. New Delhi, Oxford University Press.

Chattopadhyaya, B. D. [1994] 1997. The Making of Early Medieval India. New Delhi, Oxford University Press.

Introduction to Mughal History [HIS-3204/ POL-3056] [HIS-3204/ POL-3056-1]

Faculty Name
Pratyay Nath [pratyay.nath@ashoka.edu.in] ,Chitra Shah [chitra.shah_ug24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Mughal emperors believed that they are the divinely-mandated rulers of the entire universe. This was reflected in their imperial titles like Jahangir (Conqueror of the World), Shah Jahan (King of the World), and Alamgir (Conqueror of the Universe). However, how much power did they actually wield? How did they use paintings and architecture to articulate their grand visions of power? What role did war, diplomacy, ideology, and religion play in the process of imperial expansion? These are some of the questions we will engage with. This course offers a comprehensive introduction to Mughal history and historiography. We will explore how the legacy of Chinghiz Khan and Amir Timur Gurgan shaped the empire in South Asia. We will look into the ideals of masculinity that animated Mughal courtly etiquette and study the role of Mughal women in court society. We will investigate how the empire legitimised its rule, disciplined its elite, and created its fabled riches. Finally, we will study why such a huge and prosperous empire fragmented away in the eighteenth century. By the end of the semester, students will have a firm understanding of various facets of the Mughal Empire as well as the myriad ways in which modern scholars have looked at this rich and complex history.

Learning Outcomes
  • Class Participation 25%
  • Mid-Term Presentation 35%
  • Term Paper 40%
Attendance Policy

Students can miss upto 5 of the 23 classes of this course without having to explain themselves; more unaccounted absences would attract grade cuts.

CourseTitle: Dharma, kingship and violence in ancient India
description:
Dharma, kingship and violence in ancient India [HIS-3217] [HIS-3217-1]

Faculty Name
Upinder Singh [upinder.singh@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Dharma is often considered a central moral and social concept in the classical Indian tradition. How did it acquire this status? Was it one or many? Was it universally accepted or contested? Was it visualized as a guiding principle for rulers, or was it expendable in the ruthless pursuit of power? This course answers such questions by examining the intersection between political ideas and practice in ancient and early medieval India through the prism of texts, inscriptions and visual sources. It explores how ideologies of kingship emerged and evolved over time with special reference to debates about the nature of political power, theories of the origins of the state, the duties of a ruler, the principle of renunciation, and the relationship between kings and the religious domain. It discusses the theory and practice of political violence, with special reference to punishment, war, and the state’s interactions with the forest. It also examines attitudes towards rebellion, resistance, and situations when the state became a target of the violence of others. Ancient Indian ideas and debates on the fine dividing line between legitimate force and illegitimate violence, between righteous rule and oppressive tyranny open a window into a comparative study of political ideas and events that is relevant even in our own time.

*** See attached course outline for further details

Learning Outcomes

Students will acquire an understanding of the interface between political ideas and practice in ancient India, with special reference to the relationship between kingship and violence. They will also get an exposure to the textual, inscriptional and visual sources through which these themes can be explored.

CourseTitle: The Jungle, the Spade and the Book
description:
The Jungle, the Spade and the Book [HIS-3218/ ES-3990] [HIS-3218/ ES-3990-1]

Faculty Name
Nayanjot Kaur Lahiri [nayanjot.lahiri@ashoka.edu.in] ,Avani Sudhir [avani.sudhir_ug24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

                                                                                  The Jungle, the Spade and the Book

This course looks at the jungle and the wilderness in the Indian subcontinent from antiquity onwards.  In what forms did the jungle enter into ancient Indian imagination? What are the literary images relating to the forests in writings of different genres? How do we ‘find’ forests through science and archaeology? Is the wilderness an unrecorded archaeological source and what are the various techniques that can be used in studying the forests ? These are some of the issues that the course hopes to explore. Simultaneously, the course will examine the interface between  humans and other species at different points in the past and thus, explore the associations and connections between history and natural history.

Weeks One and Two

Ways of looking  at the jungle and its inhabitants

Weeks Three and Four

Prehistoric peopling and depictions of  forests and animals

         Finding forests and grasslands through science

         Animals and humans in rock art

 Week Five and Six

The wild in the world of  cities  and city dwellers

      Harappan Civilization – from bones to seals

      Historic India’s travellers and their archaeological imprints in the jungle 

      Images of forests in ancient art

Week Six

Class Presentations

Weeks Seven and  Eight 

Forests in Ancient Indian texts and inscriptions

         Mahabharata, Jataka tales, Arthashastra, Ashokan edicts and Kalidasa

Weeks Nine and Ten 

Jungles and the State in early medieval India

         Religious complexes and political centres in central India

         The forest-dwellers and chiefs in Harshacharita

Week Eleven 

Mughals and  wild animals 

Week Twelve

Colonialism and forests 

Week Thirteen

Class presentations

Learning Outcomes

An appreciation of the diverse histories of forests and wilderness  in antiquity and beyond is one proposed outcome. The other is to explore the various kinds of sources through which the jungle can be recovered and studied.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Readings will be emailed to students

Grading Rubric

Class participation and performance - 30%

Two essays - 70%

History Sleuths [HIS-3527/ ENG-3910/ MS-3335] [HIS-3527/ ENG-3910/ MS-3335-1]

Faculty Name
Aparna Vaidik [aparna.vaidik@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Ever fancied yourself as Sherlock Holmes, Miss Marple, Mr. Thorndyke, Karamchand, Feluda or as a crime scene investigator – Gil Grissom or Fox Mulder or even James Bond? A reconstruction of the crime scene, a search for and evaluation of evidence, serializing events before and after the commission of crime, and coming up with a narrative of how and why a crime was committed are all part of a detective's workday. A historian’s practice of their craft is much the same. The whodunit in our case takes the form of collection and evaluation of several different kinds of evidence that are etched in time – archival, oral, material, experiential, digital, and psychic. The evidence may speak volumes or may be silent or scattered or fragmented; or it can be absent like Hansel’s breadcrumbs that were eaten by the birds; and on some days the Houdini historian even makes evidence appear where people believe there was none. After all, a historian, much like our literary detectives, combines the skills of a huntsman, a conjurer, a forensic scientist, and a ventriloquist. This course takes you on an adventurous journey into the world of history sleuthing where you will learn to hunt for clues, closely read them, and learn to narrativize them.

Special note for Media Studies students: Only 3rd and 4th years can opt of this course

Learning Outcomes

Learning historian’s craft: Historical thinking trains you to question what you know. You will learn to ask: how do I know what I know? How do I piece together the past from evidence that is fragmentary, silent, scattered, or absent? How does working with such evidence challenge the dominant narratives (as presented by the colonial documents)? 

Learning How to Narrativize: By learning to formulate a narrative, you will learn to look for sources, understand the relationship between evidence and narration, to establish the connection between evidence and conclusion; and to differentiate between an assertion and an argument. 

Learning history through literature: Appreciating that History and Literature are both narrative forms with common origins and that Literature also provides an important doorway for studying our past.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Still working on it. You may browse the draft here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1QiBlrtLdWtuDcwKs6DxE6v0c7S09ZjNv7q4F1nMV70w/edit

CourseTitle: Texts and Power in the Early Modern World
description:
Texts and Power in the Early Modern World [HIS-3534/ ENG-3220] [HIS-3534/ ENG-3220-1]

Faculty Name
Pratyay Nath [pratyay.nath@ashoka.edu.in] ,Akansha Singh [akansha.singh_phd20@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

How did Mongol and Mamluk sultans insult each other through letters? What did Ottoman maps say about the empire’s desire to conquer the world? What did the portraits of Queen Elizabeth Tudor say about the nature of her monarchy? How did nostalgia shape in Babur’s description of his homeland in his memoirs? These are some of the questions this course explores. It looks at various sorts of literary and visual texts - chronicles, biographies, letters, maps, and paintings. Focusing on the early modern period (1500-1800), the course is divided into two parts. The first part focuses on cases drawn from across the world. It unravels the world of Tudor portraits of monarchs, Ottoman maps of the world, letters exchanged between the Mongols and Mamluks, and writings of European explorers in the Americas. The second part zooms in on South Asia. It studies various texts including Mughal autobiographies, Muslim mahakavyas, Jain songs, Sikh chronicles, sufi poetry, Telugu narratives, Gond traditions, and warrior tales. Through this exploration, the course unravels how texts articulated particular notions of identity, how certain textual techniques legitimized authority, how texts expressed certain anxieties, struggles, and ambitions of their authors and patrons, and how textual traditions represented enemies and rivals. We will also understand how different kinds of textual politics resulted from different times and cultures within which they were produced. By the end of the course, students will have a sound idea about the relationship between the politics of textual representation and power in the world that produced our own.

NB: This course is cross-listed with the Department of English as ENG-3220.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, students will have a sound idea about the relationship between the politics of textual representation and power in the world that produced our own.

CourseTitle: Ethics and International Relations: Unpacking the Normative Dilemmas of our Times
description:
Ethics and International Relations: Unpacking the Normative Dilemmas of our Times [IR-2020/ POL-2042] [IR-2020/ POL-2042-1]

Faculty Name
Ananya Sharma [ananya.sharma@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

International Relations by its very nature is fraught with ethical issues. Actions in the global context (immigration, economic policy, human rights legislation, and (non)democratic institutions) have a pervasive impact on the lives of individuals and this impact often differs based on how one is situated in the world. This course is designed to explore, analyse and evaluate some of the central issues, values and debates in the contemporary world that have a bearing on normative political inquiry. What relevance do ethical considerations have in international conduct? Is ethical action possible, given the realities of national interests and power politics? Is it utopian to think about ethical factors playing a role in international affairs? And how, in ethical terms, can international acts be evaluated? Nowhere does the uneasy relationship between politics and morality become clearer than in International Relations. Drawing on interdisciplinary perspectives and thematic issues in the fields of international politics, the course will challenge students to reflect on major ethical theories and traditions as well as core problems in the current times. The goal is not to identify correct answers to these difficult questions, but rather to understand the debates involved. The course will engage with the dilemmas encountered in world affairs including: the moral economy of violence, the politics of exclusion, debates on human rights, global justice and cosmopolitanism, ecological responsibility and concerns regarding economic inequalities and unequal development.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

A 100 level course is a pre-requisite for taking this course.

International Relations of South Asia [IR-2036] [IR-2036-1]

Faculty Name
Amit Jai Pal Julka [amit.julka@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

South Asia, ‘Indian Subcontinent’, ‘The Subcontinent’, ‘SAARC’. There are many reasons to
study this part of the world – it comprises 5% of the world’s GDP, 25% of its people, and
100% of its dussehri mangoes. However, another great reason (especially for us) is that
what goes on in this part of the world directly shapes us (and we, in turn, shape it). This
course, in particular looks at one important aspect of this story – the international politics
of the region.
Most of us are familiar with the major plotlines – a former scheming landlord, two
perennially fighting neighbours, the smaller countries frustrated at this commotion, and
interfering outsiders. But, in this course, we not only study the story of South Asia’s
international relations, but also try and understand how things came to such a pass,
whether they were ‘always’ the same, and the possible future trajectories. Furthermore, the
course will try to contextualize these findings within a broader theoretical context in order
to understand how historical structures and relations have shaped the region.

 

Assessment Criteria:
Class Participation (Includes Memos (10%) + Thursday Seminars) – 20%
Two pop quizzes – 20%
Mid-Term Essay (2000 words excluding footnotes/references) – 20%
Final Essay (5000 words excluding footnotes/references) – 40%
Assignment Details:
Memos (after first week): To be submitted by every Tuesday 6pm (late submissions will be
penalized). Word limit: 500 words. Apart from the text, can include visual aids (diagrams,
pictures, memes etc.).
The point of the memos is to capture your (relatively) unfiltered thoughts on the week’s
readings and not constrain them. So, the language employed there need not be very
formal/straitjacketed academic prose. However, the memo should be well argued – it is not
an excuse for sloppiness.
The essays on the other hand are meant to train you to become producers of knowledge in
your own right. Thus, the expectation here in terms of hypothesis building, argument
construction, and use of evidence will be higher.
I shall upload both exemplary memos/essays from my previous courses for your reference.
In addition, I will also try to provide materials related to academic writing.

War and Strategy [IR-2048/ POL-2111] [IR-2048/ POL-2111-1]

Faculty Name
Ananya Sharma [ananya.sharma@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In this course, we seek to offer a global perspective on the evolution of modern warfare and strategy within a historical context. We will also follow its manifestations in international politics today. While delving into different case studies from Afghanistan, Vietnam and Ukraine, we will evaluate the potential and limitations of causal explanations of  warfare, and their embeddedness within different traditions of strategic thought, including from within Asia, as well as Western Europe. Through these discussions, we will explore the extent to which explanations about war have to be contextualized within global developments of the nineteenth and twentieth century, and how its present day conduct is also shaped by colonial and post-colonial influences. Finally, we will evaluate the role of access to technology, and how decision making structures on military affairs serve as the means to contain or to further proliferate war.

Foreign Policy Analysis [IR-2050] [IR-2050-1]

Faculty Name
Amit Jai Pal Julka [amit.julka@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Introduction

 

As a discipline, IR is initially taught in terms of grand theories – realism, liberalism, constructivism, Marxism – which try to explain in one fell swoop, the entirety of international politics. Foreign policy analysis is granular for it examines how policy-makers decide. As you will learn, actual decision-making is always messier than what grand theories imply. So, from the grand and the ‘macro’, we look on the domestic, state, organizational, and personal levels to understand the multitude of factors that affect a country’s foreign policy. In order to do this, we make use of various conceptual lenses: theories of rational choice, individual/group psychology, emotions, culture/identity, and political economy. In other words, this course will be an exercise in unlearning IR Theory 101.

So, what are the kind of questions that this class will help you think through? Perhaps questions such as ‘How did Nehru’s experience of colonial subjugation shape his ideas of non-alignment?’, Why did the US armed forces support the blockade option during the Cuban Missile Crisis?,  ‘How does the Pakistan Army’s organizational culture affect the country’s attitude towards India?’, ‘Does the shale-lobby affect Canada’s international commitments towards global warming?’, and ‘Does race impact EU’s refugee policy?’

Now the brass tacks – this is a core course and it will have an exam component (see below). In addition, you will also be required to submit one-page (500 words) weekly memos in which you are required to engage with the readings of that week. The tone of these may not be necessarily ‘academic’ – it can be conversational, reflective, or humorous. However, you will be expected to analyze, critique, and go beyond the text. What a memo WILL NOT BE is a summary of the readings.  

Also, an plagiarism (including ChatGPT) will result in an immediete FAIL. No exceptions.

Assessment Methods

The course includes both continuous and cumulative forms of assessment.

For continuous assessment, the students are required to submit six 500-word memos during the course of the entire semester (as per their choice of weeks). The aim of the memo is to make sure students both read and critically analyze the readings

Furthermore, there will be a mid-semester examination in which students will be tested on the fundamentals of foreign policy analysis 

At the end of the semester, students will have to write a 2500 word essay, the prompts for which will be provided beforehand. Students will have to choose one of the prompts for the end-semester essay

Regime type and War [IR-3011/ POL-3051] [IR-3011/ POL-3051-1]

Faculty Name
Bann Seng Tan [bannseng.tan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Why should you consider taking this course?  Given today's economy, some of you will go for further studies. Some will aim for schools in the United States. You want to signal that you are serious candidate who can handle academic rigor. Taking this course is a way to signal your competence to those who matter.

Put another way, the admission committee in prestigious universities know how to read between the lines. A strong GPA from a transcript full of fluff courses (lots of movies and fun) means less than you might think. A student who is willing to take more challenging courses even if it affects their GPA sends a different signal to the admissions committee.

With that in mind, What exactly does regime type (democracy/autocracy) has to do with interstate warfare? It turns out there is a body of literature, known as the Democratic Peace (hereafter DP), that focus on such issues. The DP or the absence of wars between democracies, is one of the more significant findings to have emerged within International Relations scholarship in recent decades. It has consequently attracted significant and critical attention of a large body of scholars and policy-makers alike. In this course we will examine the history of the idea, its main empirical claims, the explanations for it, the auxiliary claims and the criticisms of the research. While the methodological slant will be on quantitative research, we will also examine issues of research design as well as historical case studies as appropriate.

This course is level 3000, so a term essay is required. The IR course is cross listed with the PS department. A pre-requisite is a prior level 2000 course at either the PS or IR department.

Learning Outcomes

1) Since the course is focused on one topic, the DP, students will acquire substantive knowledge about the major issues in DP research. They should be able to highlight the major works and the arguments made therein. 2) Students should be able to provide a reasoned critique of the major works. This is part of the process of learning to reason in a social scientific manner. 3) Students should gain an exposure to some of the quantitative literature on international conflict. 4) Finally, students should be able to judge the validity of the democratic peace and crucially, justify their judgment. 5) When applying the logic of the democratic peace to actual cases, students learn to differentiate actual regime dynamics from superficial bullshit.   

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Most readings are published articles.  

There are three types of readings.

1. The majority of assigned readings are available in Google Classroom as weblinks. Please download the appropriate article for each lesson. These are denoted with a “C” and stands for ‘Compulsory’.

2. Some lessons have optional additional readings. These are meant for students who wish to pursue further studies on their own and are not mandatory. These are denoted with a “O” and stands for ‘Optional’. Since they are optional, most will not be uploaded.

We use Google Classroom, and the official AMS.

Calculus [MAT-1000] [MAT-1000-1]

Faculty Name
Gaurav Bhatnagar [gaurav.bhatnagar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The Calculus is a major achievement of humanity without which none of the developments in modern science or technology would have been possible. The course is a second look at the subject. I will say it a second time -- it is a second look! So it is expected that you have done Calculus in high school. 

It is an introduction to mathematics. The course is about building the intuition, knowledge and skills required for studying mathematics and other mathematical subjects. It is an `enabling' course -- a pre-requisite for every other mathematics course. It will probably help you develop the mindset for any other science too.

They say that Mathematics is learnt by doing mathematics. Be prepared for a lot of doing. In addition to lectures and discussion sessions, expect to spend 10-12 hours outside of class every week working on the material and working on problems; and more, if you have not done well in math in class 12. 

Please see: https://www.ashoka.edu.in/courses/mat-1000-calculus/

Learning Outcomes

The Syllabus is as follows: 

Number systems. Sequences and series. Functions of a real variable. Graphs of functions. Limits and continuity. Differentiation. Mean value theorem. L’Hospital rule. Maclaurin and Taylor series. Curve tracing. Riemann integral. Definite and indefinite integrals. Fundamental theorem of calculus. Applications of differential and integral calculus in areas such as optimisation and mechanics. Complex numbers.

It is expected that you will need to learn to use a symbolic algebra package to be able to do mathematical experimentation. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Textbooks and Readings:

My lectures will be sourced from the following books. They should be self-contained.  

1. Spivak, The hitchhiker's guide to the Calculus, Mathematical Association of America, 1995. A very pleasant introduction to the theory accompanying the problems. Read it to get the big picture.

2. Omar Hijab,  Introduction to Calculus and Classical Analysis, Springer Undergraduate Texts in Mathematics, 1997. UTMs are very easy to read. This one is closest to what we will do in class.

3. Peter Lax and Maria Shea Terell, Calculus with Applications, Springer UTM, 2014. This is one I followed earlier. We can do about half the book.

4. Spivak, Calculus (4th edition), Publish or Perish, 2008. This has been described as the best book on Calculus ever written. Explains things in great detail.  

5. I will provide a problem set every week. 

We require the use of commonly available free or online software, such as graphing calculators (desmos.com) and symbolic algebra packages (Sage). Download and install, or make an online account, before the first day of class. 

Prerequisites: High school mathematics (including trigonometry, analytical geometry and Calculus) or equivalent. You will not be able to keep up without this.  You need to be healthy and energetic all through the semester. 

If you have not done mathematics in high school (including Calculus), I suggest you sit in and try as many problems as possible this semester, and take calculus formally only in the next semester. 

Grading Rubric

The breakup of marks is as follows. 

1. Weekly quizzes 1-10 (in class): 200 

2. Midterms 1,  2 and 3 (all take-home): 300 

3. Final (in class): 100

Total: 600

Exact schedule will be given on or before the first day of class. 

Expect to solve a bunch of problems every week of the course. Problems are assigned from each week from material covered in class.  Midterms will be take home exams where you will get 3 or 4 days to finish. The dates of the final are decided later. 

More information, including a detailed daily schedule, will be available before the first day of class.

Attendance Policy

Plan to attend all the lectures and be there in time. Lectures will help you read the books and understand the material and solve the problems.  There will be a quiz evey week. Discussion sessions are focussed on solving the quizzes.  However, no makeup quizzes are given if you miss class for whatever reason.

Real Analysis [MAT-2003] [MAT-2003-1]

Faculty Name
Rajendra Bhatia [rajendra.bhatia@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The two fundamntal concepts of analysis are continuity and convergence. Some idea of these has been formed in earlier courses on Calculus. The aim of this course is to take that understanding further and to make it deeper.

We will study:

sequences and series of real numbers and their convergence

sequences and series of functions, their convergence and unifom convergence; power series

continuity, uniform continuity, differentiability, integration (all more rigorously than in the Calculus courses)

elementary functions like trigonometric, hyperbolic, exponential funcions

basic ideas of approximation

 

This course introduces rigorous arguments and is very important for further studies in mathematics. Many later courses, both in mathematics and applications, depend on the understanding gained in this course.

Learning Outcomes

A good understanding of rigorous concepts of elementary analysis. Development of skills to write rigorous proofs. Development of skills for solving problems.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Students must have taken the course Calculus befoe taking this course.

We will follow (closely but not exactly) the text

K. A. Ross, Elementary Analysis: the Theory of Calculus, Springer.

You may also see

W. Rudin, Principles of Mathematical Analysis

T. Tao, Analysis I

Complex Analysis [MAT-3018] [MAT-3018-1]

Faculty Name
Gaurav Bhatnagar [gaurav.bhatnagar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Complex analysis is one of the highlights of a mathematics education. They say that ``the shortest path between two truths in the real domain passes through the complex domain''. Theorems and proofs in complex analysis, when you first encounter them, appear to be indistinguishable from magic! 

However, all this only happens when one becomes adept at combining three different skills---analytical skills, algebraic manipulations (of series and products), and geometrical thinking. The goal of the course is to learn some of the basic moves so that you can begin to learn how to make magic yourself. 

This course is mandatory for Mathematics students. It may be useful for Physics students too as background material and for Computer Science students interested in the analysis of algorithms. That said, we may only be able to cover the theoretical background, and may only hint at some applications. 

Pre-requisites: MAT 1000: Calculus, MAT 1001: Linear Algebra, MAT 1004: Multivariate Calculus, MAT 2003: Real Analysis.

Learning Outcomes

Syllabus

The syllabus is as follows.
The algebra and geometry of complex numbers, representations of a complex number. Exponential and logarithmic functions. Differentiation, analytic functions, Cauchy-Riemann equations. Contour 
integrals, Independence of path. Cauchy’s Integral Theorem, Cauchy’s Integral Formula, Liouville’s Theorem and its applications. Complex power series, uniform convergence. Removable and isolated singularities, Taylor’s and Laurent’s Theorems. The residue theorem and applications.

In addition, we may cover some material involving infinite products, the Gamma function, and elliptic functions.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Texbook(s):
At present I am not sure of which book we will follow as a textbook. I like both of the following. Both are very clear. It is possible I will base my lectures from these as well as other sources.  
1. Ian Stewart and David Tall, Complex Analysis, Second ed.\ Cambridge, 2018 Friendly introduction, with great historical notes. The approach is by extending Real Analysis, so may be easier to learn from here.
2. Bak and Newman, Complex Analysis, UTM, Springer, 2010. Clearly written with complex analysis type arguments.

I will suggest problems to try from these, some of which will show up on the assignment. 

Grading Rubric

The breakup of marks is as follows.

1. Quizzes (10) -- 100
2. Assignments (5) -- 200
3. Midterm -- 100
4. Final -- 100
All assignments and exams are currently expected to be take-home.  There are no makeup quizzes. 

While we cannot promise this, roughly speaking 90s will get you A or A-, 80s will be B's, 70s, C, and 60s D. In general, A's are perceived by external agencies as excellent, B's good, C's average and D's barely acceptable. Plan to do as well as you can; don't play the percentage game. Chances of passing the course with less than 60\% marks are quite low. 
 

Attendance Policy

My expectations from you:
Lectures: It is a good idea to attend all the lectures. Review what was done in the previous lecture, and actively try to understand what is happening. And interrupt me. Bring your laptop to class. 
Work on the exercises/problems mentioned in the lectures. 
Quizzes Quizzes are given during the lectures. You may be asked to do something from the previous class, or even something done within the same lecture. So pay attention, keep up, and come on time. There will be very frequent quizzes with no advance notice.  They are an integral part of the teaching methodology. 
Assignments There will be 5 assignments. Plan to spend  8--10 hours  each week on the problems assigned in this course.  
Make sure you try every problem on your own for at-least an hour before giving up. If you give up, you should discuss with your peers, seniors and me, but I suggest you write the solutions on your own. I am happy if you work in a group too. 

It is expected that each one of you will do ALL the problems in the assignments and exams.

Algebraic Number theory [MAT-4012] [MAT-4012-1]

Faculty Name
Conjeeveram Srirangachari Rajan [cs.rajan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The course will be a classical introduction to number theor, beginning with the arithmetic of quadratic forms as 

developed by Fermat,  Euler, Legendre, Langrange, Gauss and others. This includes the theory of congruences, 

Legendre's local-global theorem and Gauss'  quadratic reciprocity. We will then move on to considering 

number fields and some of its basic aspects. If time permits, we hope to cover a theorem of Kummer relating 

special values of the Riemann zeta function to arithmetic of cyclotomic number fields.

Learning Outcomes

Already stated in the course catalogue.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

A first course in Algebra will be desirable (or at least has to be done simultaneously). Specifically, 

the student should be familiar with basic aspects of congruences, polynomials, unique factorization 

in integers, etc. 

There are many good books on number theory. Some of the authors that come readily to mind are: 

Niven-Zuckerman, Burton, Ireland-Rosen, Hardy-Wright, Silverman's A friendly introduction,

Daniel Flath (Introduction to number theory, AMS), Weil (Number theory for beginners), 

TIFR pamphlet on Algebraic Number Theory,  Serre's course in Arithmetic, Borevich-Shafarevich, etc.

Grading Rubric

Weekly quizzes will be there based on assignments/homework consisting 

of 5-10 problems. (25-30).

Two mid-semester exams (20 each)

A final end semester exam (30).

It is possible that there maybe class room presentations as part of the 

grading rubric, in which case the above percentages may change a bit. 

 

Attendance Policy

Explained above.

SpaceName: AC01-202 (TR), Media Lab 111, AC01-202 (TR), Media Lab 111
description:
Storytelling in the Digital Age [MS-3051/ CW-2051/ VA-2015] [MS-3051/ CW-2051/ VA-2015-1]

Faculty Name
Natasha Badhwar [natasha.badhwar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Storytelling in the Digital Age Natasha Badhwar (MEDIA PRODUCTION)

Course Cap - 20

Timetable - Monday and Wednesday 11:50 am- 1:20 pm

Prerequisite - None

 

This course will focus on the creative process of using digital technology as a medium and a tool of narrating stories, profiles and personal histories. Through workshops, hands-on projects and guided assignments, students will train in the practice of researching, planning, shooting and editing digital video documentaries.
In groups and as individual projects, students will create short films, reels, music videos and develop their own talent and skill with scripting, videography, interview, monologue, multimedia visualization, design and editing. They will be encouraged to craft narratives that interest them, reflecting on various aspects of contemporary lives.

Learning Outcomes: Through practical exercises, writing and collective brainstorming, students will learn to create digital stories that explain a concept, make an argument, reflect on a personal experience and retell a family or community history. They will acquire multimedia skills as well as engage in critical thinking and analysis as they complete their final projects for this course. 

Familiarity and experience with the basics of digital camera operation and video editing is preferred. 

Learning Outcomes

Through practical exercises, writing and collective brainstorming, students will learn to create digital stories that explain a concept, make an argument, reflect on a personal experience and retell a family or community history. They will acquire multimedia skills as well as engage in critical thinking and analysis as they complete their final projects for this course. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Familiarity and experience with the basics of digital camera operation and video editing is preferred. 
Workshops in filmimg with DSLR cameras and editing on non-linear software will be conducted in the first few weeks of the course. Attendance is mandatory for these workshops.

CourseTitle: Final Draft: The Editorial Craft of Investigative and Long-Form Stories
description:
Final Draft: The Editorial Craft of Investigative and Long-Form Stories [MS-3151] [MS-3151-1]

Faculty Name
Nikita Saxena [nikita.saxena@ashoka.edu.in] ,Devansh Mittal [devansh.mittal_ug24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

MS 3151 Final Draft: The Editorial Craft of Investigative and Long-Form Stories Nikita Saxena JOURNALISM

Course cap 20

Timetable: Monday & Wednesday, 4:30 - 6:00 pm

Overview: The health of a democracy can be measured by the ability of its independent press to hold powerful individuals and institutions to account. Such journalistic investigations are not a matter of chance. They are the fruits of rigorous editorial processes designed to support a reporter in the conception of ambitious ideas, nurture their ability to gather evidence through in-depth reportage, and interrogate gaps in the resulting material to produce a compelling narrative. As media organisations across the world navigate the challenges posed by the proliferation of fake news, reducing press freedoms, and the breakneck pace of the online ecosystem, the need to uphold robust editorial practices that strengthen credible stories has increased more than ever before. 

In this course, students will immerse themselves into diverse newsroom roles to understand how they influence the evolution of a story. The students will analyse investigations on the same subject by different publications to compare techniques, framing, and efficacy. Through readings, guest lectures (2), classroom discussions and assignments, we will study editorial roles such as that of a: supervising editor, publisher, reporter, fact-checker, copy editor, photo editor, designer, and multimedia producer. The first of the two weekly lectures will include readings and discussions on the specific role, and the second will focus on the break-down and short-term assessment of students’ understanding of these functions. The students will be asked to read one book (She Said: Breaking the Sexual Harassment Story that Helped Ignite a Movement) that will be referenced through the semester. They will also study national and international investigations across mediums, as well as book excerpts, essays, and interviews that illuminate the historical trajectory of different editorial functions.

Learning Outcomes

The course will aim to equip students with an understanding of ideas and practices that include:
 a) Story ideation and pitching
b) Editorial commissioning and management (including legal protections, physical safety, and mental-health concerns)
c) Building sources and deploying investigative techniques
d) Journalistic story structures (learning the way a report is constructed, examining its various sections, and building narrative chronology)
e) Visual editing
f) Different kinds of editorial interventions in journalistic stories
g) Fact-checking and proofing

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prerequisite terms & conditions:

This is an advanced Journalism course. You should be able to meet one of the following conditions:

a) If you are enrolling for MS 1101 Introduction to News Writing & Reporting course in the Monsoon Semester of AY 2023-2024, you are qualified to apply for this course. If you have not already done the MS 1101 course and enrol in the Monsoon semester, then, please know that if you drop the Prerequisite course, you will also be dropped from being eligible for this course.

b) Have already done the prerequisite course

c) For any exceptions, write to Tisha Srivastav, MS Student Rep team and course professor in a common email with evidence of experience in journalistic/news writing.Please note: All three should be marked on this mail.

The course professor is Nikita Saxena and she can be contacted at nikita.saxena@ashoka.edu.in

Grading Rubric

Grading Rubric
 - Attendance: 10% (This will be inclusive of attendance for guest lectures and the field visit)
 - Classroom Participation: 30 %
 - Assignment 1(a+b): 15 % [Student’s will be assessed for this assignment based on the instructor’s evaluation, as well as a peer review by their fellow students]
 - Assignment 1(c): 10 %
- Assignment 2: 15 %
-  Assignment 3: 20 %

There will be three major take-home assignments through the course of the semester:

1. Ideating and Pitching as Reporters [To be assigned on: 30 August || Due date: 25 September]:
 a) Students will be asked to develop and submit a pitch—500-800 words—for an investigative story idea. The assignment should broadly include, for each story:
- A brief overview of the story that is in the public domain so far
- The material they’re hoping to uncover and how
- The potential characters in their story
- An explanation for why the story is relevant
- An argument for why they are the best reporters to do it

b) Assessing Pitches as Editors [To be assigned on: 4 October || Due date: 21 October]: The submitted pitch documents will be anonymised and randomly allotted among students, who will be asked to submit a written assessment of the pitch (250-300 words), which would include thoughts on what worked, what didn’t, and the directions, if any, they would encourage the reporter to potentially expand the story.

c) Expanding the idea as Reporters [To be assigned on: 25 October || Due date: 30 October]:
Students will write a note [250-500 words] on possible ways of expanding their investigation based on information they have/can obtain through available records, filings and digital research.

2. Short Profiles [To be assigned on: 18 October || Due date: 15 November]:
Depending on the class size, students will be divided into four or five teams, and every team will identify one individual each whom they would like to interview. Each student from the team will then conduct an interview with the individual their team has selected—the student will have the freedom to decide how and where they want to conduct it, what the duration of the conversation would be, and what questions they would like to include. Based on the conversation, students will submit a 300-500-word profile of their interviewee.


3. Editorial Interventions on Reported Drafts [To be assigned on: 22 November || Due date: 9 December]:
Students will be given story drafts (1,000-1,500 words), which they will be expected to study for potential gaps in reporting, factual inaccuracies, and story structure. They will be asked to submit an edit memo (600-800 words) at the end of the exercise, along with in-line comments.  

Attachment
Lesson Plan - Final Draft- The Editorial Craft of Investigative and Long-form Stories .pdf

Light and Sound [PA-1012] [PA-1012-1]

Faculty Name
Abhinav Khetarpal [abhinav.khetarpal@ashoka.edu.in] ,Anirban Ghosh [anirban.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Abhinav Khetarpal, Anirban Ghosh

The course is an introduction to two crucial technical skills that are used in performance – stage lighting design and creative music production.

The Light component of the course is aimed at people looking to understand and explore the medium of lighting design and how it changes and adds to a performance. Students will be familiarized with the process of conceptualizing and executing an effective visual design for performance, through the various steps of drafting a design to physically setting up and running a cued show. We will also explore the basics of 3D visualization and show operation on the industry standard Grand MA2 ONPC software/console, as well as work with the inventory present at the Black Box Theatre.

In the Sound component of the course, students will learn how to produce soundscapes and sound design. Students will learn technical skills including sampling, looping, editing, MIDI, mixing, and sound and instrument design, along with musical skills - how to write beats, melodies and harmonies, arranging, pacing, development and form. The course will involve hands-on practice using all the tools available in the market (Ableton, Izotope, Reaper, Logic etc). Students will learn how to improvise, record, arrange and create soundscapes, and how to design their own sounds, instruments, and effects. While learning how to use the program, students will also learn how to generate and develop musical ideas, shape lines, harmonies and rhythms, and learn how to develop your own sound

This is an entry level course and no prior experience is required.

Grading Rubric

The criteria for grading are the following: attendance, participation in class, and a creative project/ assignment determined by the Professor. All three criteria are equal.

Attendance Policy

As the classes are highly participative in nature, more than 4 absences will affect your grade.

Poetics in Indian Dance [PA-2011/ ENG-2601/ PHI-2871] [PA-2011/ ENG-2601/ PHI-2871-1]

Faculty Name
Navtej Johar [navtej.johar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Navtej Singh Johar

This course will explore the abiding relationship between the suggestive-word and the responsive-body.  Considering that human experience can often exceed speech, we will see how the abstraction of poetry may be able to evoke, allow and also validate that “excess” in experience; and parallel to this, how the performative-body may be able to express layered meaning and experience through the nuanced use of the body, face and voice. 

The course will be structured around the bhava-rasa theory of the Natya Shastra and have a two-fold focus, it will explore a) the reciprocal possibilities of the poetic object or vibhava as an effective elicitor of expression (bhava) out of the poet-subject, and b) how for the reader or viewer, poetry may offer a re-cognition of their “excess” experience, drawing it out of obscuration into recognition and validation through poetic nuance and imagery. 

Equally dividing our time between theory and somatic practice, we will also sample different genres of amorous Indian poetry, i.e., the padam, thumri, javali, kafi and gazal. The aim of the course is to eventually orchestrate a free interplay between the three, facilitating a somatic engagement with the amorous song with sensorial nuance, ease and most importantly, autonomy obtained through theory. 

Grading Rubric

The criteria for grading are the following: attendance, participation in class, and a creative project/ assignment determined by the Professor. All three criteria are equal.

Attendance Policy

As the classes are highly participative in nature, more than 4 absences will affect your grade.

CourseTitle: Philosophy of Non-Violence: Jainism, Tolstoy, Gandhi
description:
Philosophy of Non-Violence: Jainism, Tolstoy, Gandhi [PHI-2091/ POL-2113] [PHI-2091/ POL-2113-1]

Faculty Name
Dimitry Shevchenko [dimitry.shevchenko@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Ordinarily, people set some ramifications to the permissiveness of violence in one’s personal life, as well as in the life of the society and in the relations between states, ethnical and religious groups, etc. However, there is much disagreement regarding the extent and the level of violence allowed. In this course, we will discuss the most radical philosophical theories of non-violence, aiming at eradicating violence from human society altogether.

The first part of the course will be dedicated to the most ancient systematic exploration of non-violence, which has been conducted by Jain philosophers in India. For these philosophers, the world is full of life, which we cannot avoid harming this way or another, but at the same time the practice of non-violence in its most extreme forms (e.g. making precautions not to step upon or breath in tiny insects) leads to one’s moral and spiritual perfection. During the second part, we will discuss the ethical, social, and religious aspects of non-violence in the works of a Russian anarchist thinker and a celebrated writer Leo Tolstoy. During the last part, we will turn to M.K. Gandhi’s philosophy of non-violence, which he tested both in his personal life and in the political struggle for India’s independence.

Sāṃkhya, Yoga, and Advaita Vedānta [PHI-2100] [PHI-2100-1]

Faculty Name
Dimitry Shevchenko [dimitry.shevchenko@ashoka.edu.in] ,Arindham Bhatia [arindham.bhatia_asp24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In this course, we will meet three of classical India's most influential philosophical traditions. Sāṃkhya, perhaps the most ancient philosophical system, formulated a radical metaphysical dualism between the objective and the subjective elements of reality, developed sophisticated epistemology and a unique theory of “natural” liberation from suffering and the cycle of rebirth. Yoga philosophers, such as Patañjali, Vedavyāsa, Vācaspati Miśra, and others, accepted the major aspects of Sāṃkhya ontology but also developed an elaborate philosophy of mind and theory of meditation. Advaita Vedānta, the most famous and popular philosophical tradition in India even today, rejected the metaphysical dualism of the other two schools in favour of metaphysical non-dualism, according to which only consciousness – undivided and eternal – is ultimately real, whereas the world as we know it is merely an illusion. During the course, the students will read the original texts of Sāṃkhya, Yoga, and Advaita in English translations, will engage with philosophical arguments, and assess the relevance and cogency of the ideas of classical Indian systems in the light of contemporary ways of being and thinking.

Classical Mechanics [PHY-2210] [PHY-2210-1]

Faculty Name
Amin Ahmad Nizami [amin.nizami@ashoka.edu.in] ,Garima Mishra [garima.mishra@ashoka.edu.in] ,Aditya Jain [aditya.jain_phd20@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Lectures: Mon - Wed  (15:00 - 16:30)

Part 1- Newtonian Mechanics (Amin A. Nizami):  We will begin by formulating the primary concepts: the laws of motion and the dynamical equations as differential equations which need to be integrated to find the solutions of mechanical problems. We will stress the importance of conservation laws (energy, momentum and angular momentum) not only in the solution of otherwise intractable dynamical problems but also their wider scope beyond Newtonian dynamics.  As applications we will deal with central force motion and the harmonic oscillator. Besides their historical importance, these are rich and instructive examples illustrating the basic concepts. The basics of rotational dynamics will also be considered.

Brief outline of topics: Space and Time, Force and Inertia, Inertial frames, Newton’s Laws, equations of motion, Galilean transformations as symmetries - principle of relativity. Work-Energy Theorem, Kinetic and Potential Energy. Rotational motion: Torque, angular momentum and moment of inertia.
Harmonic Oscillator: simple, damped and driven oscillators.
Many particle systems: Energy, Momentum and Angular Momentum - their conservation laws and use in solving dynamical problems.
Law of Gravitation, Kepler’s Laws and Planetary Orbits: motion in a Central force.

Part 2 - Analytical Mechanics (Garima Mishra)

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Recommended preparatory/supplementary reading: Feynman lectures on Physics Vol. 1, upto chapter 21

Marion and Thornton, Classical Dynamics of particles and systems [Cengage]
R. Douglas Gregory, Classical Mechanics [CUP] These two texts cover most of the lectured material at essentially the same level.

Grading Rubric

Assignments (30%), Mid-term and end-term exams (35+35%)

Attendance Policy

 

 

Students are expected to attend all classes

CourseTitle: Physics Lab 4 : Quantum Mechanics and Statistical Mechanics
description:
Physics Lab 4 : Quantum Mechanics and Statistical Mechanics [PHY-3010] [PHY-3010-1]

Faculty Name
Pramoda Kumar [pramoda.kumar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Please go through the PDF attached below

Attachment
Physics Lab 4_Course catalog.pdf

Quantum Mechanics [PHY-3510] [PHY-3510-1]

Faculty Name
Amin Ahmad Nizami [amin.nizami@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This third year undergraduate course aims to be an introduction to the fundamental concepts and methods of Quantum Mechanics.

Historical introduction and motivation: The need for quantum mechanics - structure and stability of atoms, atomic spectroscopy, blackbody radiation, properties of solids and gases. Wave-particle duality. The double slit and delayed choice experiments.

The fundamental basis of quantum physics: Amplitudes as pre-probabilities, their addition and multiplication for quantum processes - the principle of superposition.
Introducing the fundamental postulates of (the hamiltonian formulation of) quantum mechanics: Hilbert space of states, bra-ket notation, observables as linear operators, Schrodinger equation and unitary evolution, state vector collapse - Born rule. Stern-Gerlach experiment.

The energy, position and momentum basis - transforming between different bases.
Schrodinger and Heisenberg pictures. Heisenberg’s Uncertainty Principle, the Classical limit and Ehrenfest’s Theorem. Pauli matrices and two-level quantum systems.

Illustrating the basic concepts through simple examples: particle in a 1D potential (Dirac delta, infinite and finite square-well potentials) - bound states and scattering. Tunnelling and quantum mechanical explanation of radioactive decay.

The harmonic oscillator - the algebraic and analytical solution in QM.
Angular Momentum in Quantum Mechanics.
Spin in Quantum Mechanics.
The hydrogen atom - derivation of its energy levels.

Learning Outcomes

Learning Quantum Mechanics opens up a world of possibilities, given its range of applications throughout physics (and beyond). By the end of this course, it is expected that students will have a firm foundation in the fundamental concepts of QM,  will be familiar with both the state-vector and wave mechanics based approaches, and would have gained the relevant background to explore and understand the manifold applications of QM to explain diverse physical phenomena, be it in Atomic, Molecular, Nuclear, Particle Physics or Quantum Information  or Condensed Matter physics.  Some of these are covered in the QM2 and Physics of Matter courses in the subsequent semester.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Our approach (and level) will be closest to the following textbook:  Principles of Quantum Mechanics, by R. Shankar. It is recommended that students go through Chapter 1 of this book (on mathematical preliminaries) over the summer, before the course starts.

Also useful for this course would be part I of :
Introduction to Quantum Mechanics, by David J. Griffiths

Grading Rubric

The final assessment will be based on class quizzes (35%), assignments (25 %) and a final exam (40%). Audit requirements: An overall mark of over 65/100 in the class quizzes  (65% ) and assignments (35%).

Attendance Policy

Soft- Matter Physics [PHY-4720/ PHY-6720 ] [PHY-4720/ PHY-6720 -1]

Faculty Name
Garima Mishra [garima.mishra@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Matter exists in four phases-solid, liquid, gas and plasma. However, often the distinction is not so simple and wide ranges of systems seem to fall between the solid and liquid phase! For example, look at our skin; should we consider it as solid, or liquid? The screen of our smartphone and other similar display units; are they solid or liquid? They all fall under the domain of soft matter.

In this course of Soft Matter Physics, we will study some of the physical principles governing the characteristic behavior of different soft matter systems. This course will equip you with the fundamentals of soft matter, and also fulfil your immediate research needs in relevant fields

Contents:

Introduction to Soft Matter: Forces, energies and timescales in soft matter; Brownian motion and thermal fluctuations; Colloids: A single colloidal particle in a liquid, forces between colloidal particles, stability and phase behaviour of colloids; Polymers: various models for polymer, polymer solutions, scaling, biopolymers; Liquid crystals: liquid crystal phases and transition.

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

1. Soft Condensed Matter by R.A.L. Jones, Oxford University Press, (2002). 

2. Soft Matter Physics by M. Doi, Oxford University Press (2013). 

3. Intermolecular and Surface Forces by  J. N. Israelachvili (2011).

4. Polymer Physics by M. Rubinstein (2003).

5. Principles of Condensed Matter Physics by P. M. Chaikin and T. C. Lubensky, Cambridge University Press (2002). 

6. Scaling Concepts in Polymer Physics by PG de Gennes, Cornell University Press (1979).

Grading Rubric

25% (assignments/presentations), 5% quizzes, 35% mid-term exam, 35% end-term exam.

CourseTitle: Introduction to General Relativity with Application to Cosmology
description:

Overview

The main aim of this course to introduce the fundamental concepts of General Theory of Relativity and then extends its application to Modern Cosmology.

Brief review of Special Theory of Relativity

The Equivalence Principle and motivation to General Theory of Relativity

Hartlle. My line of reasoning of the subject of General Relativity will closely follow the arguments presented in A First Course in General Relativity by B. F. Schutz. Introduction to Comparative Politics [POL-1005] [POL-1005-1]

Faculty Name
Bann Seng Tan [bannseng.tan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Comparative Politics is the study of political phenomena occurring predominantly within countries. The comparative method is a way of examining such phenomena. The subfield itself is broad and encompasses a variety of pertinent questions. In this introduction, we will focus on the thematic question: How does regime type affect policy outcomes? As a first cut, we will explore the selectorate theory. We will use its logic to demonstrate how democracies can have policy outcomes that are systemically distinct from their autocratic counterparts. Next, we will explore the economic and cultural determinants of democracy and study how transitions to democracy can occur. In third part of the course, we will emphasize institutional variations within democracies and identify their consequences. For the last part the course, we will re-examine the policy consequences of regime type. Is it merely a dichotomy; namely that “democracy is good” and “autocracy is bad”?

Learning Outcomes

Through the substantive portion of this course, students will 1) identify the major issue-areas in comparative politics, 2) define and demarcate major concepts in comparative politics, and 3) explain the policy predilections of different regime types. Through an emphasis on social scientific methodology, students will 1) understand the importance of methods in political science, and 2) learn about the use of appropriate theories to explain political phenomena.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

W. R. Clark, M. Golder and S.N. Golder, Principles of Comparative Politics. 2nd edition, CQ Press 2012. ISBN 978-1-60871-679-1. Hereafter referred to as the “Textbook”.

B. Bueno de Mesquita, and A. Smith, The Dictator’s Handbook: Why bad behavior is almost always good politics. Public Affairs 2011. ISBN: 978-1-61039-184-9. Hereafter referred to as “Handbook”.

Western Political Thought I [POL-1008] [POL-1008-1]

Faculty Name
Vivek Yadav [vivek.yadav@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course offers an entry-level introduction to the Western tradition of political thought. In particular, we shall study four distinct strands within this internally differentiated tradition—Platonic, Aristotelian, Republican, and Liberal. We will read some of the classics of the Western canon and discuss themes and topics central to contemporary debates in political theory, such as justice, liberty, representation, equality. Students will learn not only how to read and engage with complex philosophical texts, but also how to apply the theoretical tools learnt over the course of the semester to make sense of contemporary problems and issues in Indian politics and society.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

We shall read selections from the following texts:

Plato, Republic

Aristotle, Nichomachean Ethics and Politics

Machiavelli, Prince and Discourses

Hobbes, Leviathan

Locke, Second Treatise of Government

Rousseau, Second Discourse and the Social Contract

Kant, Perpetual Peace
