CourseTitle: Political Thought in the Age of Nationalism
description:
Political Thought in the Age of Nationalism [POL-2046/ HIS-3809] [POL-2046/ HIS-3809-1]

Faculty Name
Mohammad Amir Ahmad Khan [mohammad.khan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will seek to explore notions of the state, nation, citizenship and other related concepts as they took root in 18th and 19th century Europe. It will then trace how these movements and ideas travelled to and took root in South Asia. This will allow students to not only understand the origins of today's 'dominant form of political representation'- the nation state-but will also give them an understanding of various nationalist and anti-colonial movements in the 19th century. Amongst others the works of Herder, Fichte, Mazzini, Mill, Jamaluddin Afghani, Savarkar, Golwalkar, Tagore, Iqbal and Gandhi will be engaged with.

CourseTitle: Indian State in a Comparative Perspective
description:
Indian State in a Comparative Perspective [POL-2086] [POL-2086-1]

Faculty Name
Anustubh Agnihotri [anustubh.agnihotri@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The Indian state has often been described as a paradox – a state that is both weak and strong due to its ability to effectively carry out some functions while failing to deliver on other crucial aspects. As India celebrates the 75th year of its independence, what are the successes and failures of the Indian state? Why do the successes and failures seem paradoxical when juxtaposed next to each other? Have rapid technological advancements fundamentally altered how the Indian state works? What are possible ways in which the state functioning can be strengthened? The course will rely on a comparative perspective to examine these questions. Throughout the semester, we will explore various dimensions of the Indian state while also comparing India’s performance with other countries such as USA, China, Brazil, and Nigeria. 

The course is broadly divided into two parts – the first part (first five weeks) will introduce students to the major theoretical frameworks used to understand the functioning of the state. We will begin by looking at a range of dominant theoretical paradigms like the principal-agent framework and the state-society framework to understand how politicians or social groups influence the functioning of the state apparatus. The second part will delve into empirical papers and exploration of quantitative metrics on state performance. The theoretical frameworks discussed in the first part will keep reappearing as the course shifts to specific case studies, empirical papers, and analysis of publicly available datasets.   

In the second part of the course, students will read more empirically oriented papers that explore different facets of the workings of the state. The students will also look at national, cross- national, and sub-national datasets 1  to test out the theories. Each week will touch upon a specific area of state functioning like regulating urbanization, providing basic education, delivery of welfare services, etc. The course will involve multiple group projects as well as an individually written final research paper.

Political Parties and Party Systems [POL-2089] [POL-2089-1]

Faculty Name
Rahul Verma [rahul.verma@ashoka.edu.in] ,Srishti Sikka [srishti.sikka_asp24@ashoka.edu.in] ,Vikramaditya Tapadia [vikramaditya.tapadia_ug24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Modern democracy is unthinkable save in terms of parties, yet our understanding about Indian political parties is rather poor. This course aims to broaden our understanding about the crucial role played by political parties in making Indian democracy work. In doing so, the course will introduce students to comparative literature on political parties and party systems. We will explore the main questions, puzzles and theories on how political parties originate, the conditions under which they thrive and decline in the electoral arena, and the various ways in which they aggregate societal preferences in the political realm. We’ll also focus on how institutions, societal cleavages and strategic action shape parties and party systems? Why do some countries have more parties than others? Finally, we will apply theoretical knowledge to learn about India’s political parties, its changing party system, and important debates linked to Indian politics and democracy.

Grading Rubric

The final grades in the course will be based on a continuous assessment system, i.e., participation in the class (including attendance), two short short assignments, a mid-term and a final exam. The final syllabus will have a more detailed grading rubric.

Attendance Policy

The course material requires students to attend lectures regularly. A percentage of the final grade is based on attendance/participation in the lecture.

CourseTitle: Social and Political Thought in Modern South Asia
description:
Social and Political Thought in Modern South Asia [POL-2105] [POL-2105-1]

Faculty Name
Sushmita Nath [sushmita.nath@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Description

In this introductory lecture course students will be acquainted with the history, culture, and the socio-political thought and experience in the Indian subcontinent in the nineteenth and the twentieth centuries. In order to understand the complexity of the socio-political discourse that was developing under conditions of colonial modernity during this time (roughly between 1857 – 1947), students will be introduced to seminal writings of major thinkers and leaders of South Asia who influenced the socio-political struggles in the subcontinent on issues such as nation formation, religious reform, the caste system, the role and place of ‘tradition’ and ‘modernity’ on questions such as women’s empowerment etc. We will focus on key primary texts, including autobiographies, speeches, dialogues, treatises, letters, ethnography, and literary fiction. We will also read relevant secondary texts to supplement the primary readings for a better understanding of the historical context as well as to gain an understanding of the discursive environment within which these debates are discussed in contemporary scholarly works. Based on complexity of ideas and arguments, students are expected to read approx. 100 pages per week for the lecture course.

Learning Outcomes

Course Objective and Learning Outcome

The aim of this lecture course is to introduce students to the historical experience and the socio-political discourses that were developing in the nineteenth and the twentieth centuries in the Indian subcontinent until the partition in 1947. The course will acquaint students with basic knowledge about major events in South Asia, as well as the impact of major figures and socio-political debates on the subcontinent’s history, culture, and politics. The lecture course will also equip students to critically evaluate primary sources. Upon completion of the lecture course, students will be able to demonstrate their knowledge and understanding of dominant themes, such as the impact of colonialism, nationalism, and modernity, that shaped South Asian history, culture, and politics. They will also be able to show their ability to analyse primary and secondary sources, as well as the ability to gain information and knowledge from non-traditional sources, such as letters and literary texts.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

TBA

Grading Rubric

Exam and Requirements

Class participation is going to count for 20% of your final grade. A class presentation, done jointly or in small teams, will count for 10% of your final grade. Apart from this, you will have a mid-term take home exam in the form of an essay that will count for 30% of your final grade and your final take home exam, also in the form of an essay, will count 40% of your grade. The mid-term essay should be 1800 words and the final essay should be 2800 words. Essays should be double-spaced using Times New Roman font with font size 12 for text. There will be a zero-tolerance policy for any form of cheating or plagiarism. In case you are not clear about what constitutes plagiarism, then please refer to Ashoka University’s Academic Integrity Policy.

CourseTitle: Interpretations of Democracy: Introduction to Contemporary Democratic Theory
description:
Interpretations of Democracy: Introduction to Contemporary Democratic Theory [POL-2110] [POL-2110-1]

Faculty Name
Vivek Yadav [vivek.yadav@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

How we understand democracy is a matter of first importance to democratic practice. This is because the practices enabled by the institutions of democracy are themselves premised upon an understanding of democracy—what it is, and what it ought to be. Over the course of its two hundred and fifty years long history, modern representative democracy has been understood in different ways by its admirers and critics. These different interpretations of democracy, which in many ways are at odds with each other, do not fit together into a unitary theory of democracy, but constitute a complex, internally differentiated, body of thought. This course offers an introduction to the various strands of this polyphonic tradition of modern democratic thought.

It is divided into three unequal parts. In the first part, we shall read some of the foundational texts of modern representative democracy from the 18th and 19th centuries. This is followed by a second part, in which we shall consider the debate between Carl Schmitt and his contemporary critics, a debate which constitutes the immediate intellectual context of democratic thought in the post WWII era. The latter is the focus of the third and final part of the course, which is devoted to a brief survey of present-day democratic theory. Here we shall begin with the standard procedural or minimalist theory of democracy, then study the deliberative interpretation and its epistemic version, and finally focus on the populist strand of democratic theory.

 

Learning Outcomes

The overall aim of this course is to furnish students of political theory and more generally political science some basic theoretical tools for analyzing and understanding the degradation of democratic practice currently underway in India and elsewhere.

Grading Rubric

(Tentative)

Class participation (40%)

Three short essays (20% each)

Attendance Policy

Students are expected to attend classes regularly. Absence shall be granted only in exceptional circumstances. All absences must be requested beforehand and supported with proper documentation. Every unexcused absence beyond three missed classes shall attract a deduction of half a grade point. More than five unexcused absences shall result in a failing grade.

Overview

Course Description: 

Welcome to PSY 101! This course will introduce you to the central principles of the field of psychology. You may be familiar with the definition of psychology as the scientific study of  thought and behaviour. What does this mean exactly? Understanding psychology as an empirical  science will be our starting point. Without rigorous standards for examining human behaviour,  psychology would be little more than intuition, opinion, whim or belief.

Statistics and Research Methods I [PSY-2001] [PSY-2001-1]

Faculty Name
Supriya Ray [supriya.ray@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Overview

“I couldn't claim that I was smarter than sixty-five other guys--but the average of sixty-five other guys, certainly!”― Richard P. Feynman [Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman: Adventures of a Curious Character]

In this course, you will learn how to use statistical tools (central tendency, variability, probability, hypothesis testing (e.g., t-tests, ANOVAs), regression, etc.) to answer questions of psychological interest. The emphasis will be given on understanding statistical concepts and performing basic statistical analyses, not on mathematical formulas and derivations. Many students, for whom the world of numerals and symbols has been a ‘no-go’ area, begin their statistics course with a fear of doing mathematics. However, statistics is not about (re-)learning summation; instead, statistics summarizes the data in a comprehensive manner.
 

COURSE STRUCTURE

Lecture Sessions are scheduled on _______ and __________,  in addition Dr. Ray will hold office on __________ every week. The aim will be to give a foundation on the topics listed below. Reading the corresponding topic before attending the lecture is expected, but not mandatory, for better understanding and interaction. Lectures are designed to supplement the assigned readings.

WEEK                                                                    TOPIC

1.                                 Scientific Approach to psychological research, Experiment design in psychology

2.                                 Introduction to frequentist statistics (conceptual primer)

3.                                Types of Data, Types of Statistical Analysis

4.                                Describing data using frequency distributions, graphs

5.                                Measures of Central Tendency, Measures of Spread, Skewness, Kurtosis

6.                                Introduction to Probability, Probability Distributions, z-statistics, Point estimation, Confidence interval

7.                                Introduction to Testing of Hypothesis, Finding outliers, Testing for difference between samples

8.                                Normality and significance testing

9.                                Analysis of variance (ANOVA), F-Ratio statistics, A priori and post-hoc comparison

10.                             Non-parametric tests of hypothesis

11.                              Correlation, Regression, Goodness of Fit

12.                              Effect size, Statistical Power, Sample size

Learning Outcomes

This course is primarily designed for undergraduate students. By the end of this course you
will be able to

  • Understand basic theoretical and applied principles of statistics.
  • Gain proficiency in using statistical software for data analysis.
  • Appreciate why data triumphs anecdotes.
  • Understand basic theoretical and applied principles of statistics.
  • Interpret complex statistical findings.
  • Communicate quantitative data in statistics, graphs, and tables

"Research Methods and Statistics in Psychology" by Hugh Coolican  (Hodder Education, Taylor & Francis)

Developmental Psychology [PSY-2031] [PSY-2031-1]

Faculty Name
Madhavi Latha Kari [madhavi.maganti@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The course examines changes across different time points in development by addressing four central questions of developmental science: continuity, plasticity, sources of development, and individual differences across lifespan. Empirical data from infants, children, and adults will be examined to explain the developmental processes and learn how the emergence of the human mind. The essence is to also to examine if the endpoints of human development are complex and unique.

 

Learning Outcomes

Specific Learning Outcomes (SLO)

 

SLO#1: Profound understanding of both ‘what’ develops and ‘how’ development occurs with a specific emphasis on recent developments and current issues in the studies of human development.

 

✔ Evaluate the relative contributions of nature and nurture to human development.

✔ Explain major issues and principles guiding the study of human development.

✔ Describe how developmental theories contribute to understanding the nature of developmental change.

 

SLO#2: Studying the influence of multiple domains (e.g., biological, perceptual, cognitive, affective/emotional, and contextual) on development.

 

✔ How behaviors develop and change throughout the life span.

✔ How internal, environmental, and social factors influence behavior.

✔ Individual differences in behavior, including those related to gender, ethnicity, and culture.

✔ Developmental changes and processes across multiple contexts to identify human universals as well as context-specific differences in human development.

 

SLO#3: Integrating research across multiple domains (e.g., biological, perceptual, cognitive, affective/emotional, and contextual) and examining the influence of their interactions across development.

 

✔ Use of experimentation and quasi-experimentation in studies of development.

✔ Developmental measurement issues.

✔ Conceptualizations of change and approaches to assess it.

 

SLO # 4: Application of developmental psychology principles to the real world.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Required text for the course:

 

Kail, R. V., & Cavanaugh, J. C. (2017). Human development: A life-span view. Cengage Learning (8th edition)

We will explore how the presence of others shapes and influences our motivations, cognition, attitudes, emotions and behavior, by looking at group processes involved in cooperation, conflict and competition.

Developmental Psychopathology [PSY-3031] [PSY-3031-1]

Faculty Name
Madhavi Latha Kari [madhavi.maganti@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The emphasis of the course is to examine the continuity of normal and abnormal behavior. Insights
from various theoretical frameworks will be examined to understand the etiology of
neurodevelopmental disorders. By using the principles of normative development, we will review
literature to study how vulnerability and environmental factors interact and determine the patterns of
adaptation and maladaptation. We will study selected childhood and adolescent disorders using case
studies from the perspective of diagnosis, etiology, and developmental trajectories. The clinical
contributions and potential research from case studies will provide additional insights into the course.

Learning Outcomes


1. Develop critical thinking and analytical skills pertaining to developmental psychopathology including etiology, treatment and prevention of neurodevelopmental disorders.
2. Develop skill at synthesizing and critically evaluating class readings in preparation for clinical case analyses.
3. Enhance critical and creative thinking regarding the integration of research and clinical approaches to understanding neurodevelopmental disorders.
4. Learn how to identify, critically evaluate and communicate about controversial issues in developmental psychopathology

CourseTitle: The Dance of Sound: An Introduction to Metre and Poetics in Sanskrit
description:
The Dance of Sound: An Introduction to Metre and Poetics in Sanskrit [SAN-2004] [SAN-2004-1]

Faculty Name
Naresh Keerthi [naresh.keerthi@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What sets apart song and poetry from prose? It is the rhythm that undergirds the verse or the lyric – subtle, yet strongly present. The South Asian languages have a rich repertoire of such metrical templates, and these are used with telling effect in poetry. There is even a highly sophisticated science dedicated to the study of metrics – Chandas-śāstra. In this course we will get an introduction to the major metres seen in Sanskrit and Prakrit literature - the syllabic (vṛtta) and the moraic (jāti) types. We will learn the 'science' of scanning a verse and identifying its type; we will also learn a bit about the history and development of metrical forms. More importantly though, we will listen to several samples of verses being recited and sung. Therefrom, we will cultivate an ear (and an eye-ear) for the major metres – and learn to identify them not only through scansion, but by hearing or seeing a couplet or even part of one. 

Curriculum –

Here is an indicative list of the topics we will study -

Week 1: The grammar and vocabulary of Sanskrit metrics

Week 2: The Śloka or Anuṣṭubh metre I

Week 3 -6: Some major syllabic metres (Vṛtta-s) 

Week 7-8: The moraic metres (Jāti-s)

Week 9: The Śloka or Anuṣṭubh metre II - Variants

Week 10-11: The hybrid metres (Vaitālīya, Aupacchandasika, Pajjhaṭikā)

Week 12-13: Beyond the paradigm – learning to hear rhythm

Learning Outcomes
  1. Students will learn the traditional techniques of scanning Sanskrit and Prakrit verses.
  2. You will learn the rhythm and cadence of individual metres, and learn to identify them both by reading and listening to them.
  3. You will learn about the history of the metrical systems of South Asia.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

We will not follow a single sourcebook for the course. Audio samples, Handouts and worksheets will be shared over the AMS. Here are some recommendations –

Andrew Ollett’s webpage on South Asian metrics

Sampadananda Mishra’s Chandovallari – a user-friendly primer of Sanskrit metrics.

The Appendix on metres in V.S.Apte’s Sanskrit-English Dictionary. (Available on the AMS).

Grading Rubric

Attendance and Class Quizzes 10%

CourseTitle: Sociology and the Making of Concepts
description:
Sociology and the Making of Concepts [SOA-1101] [SOA-1101-1]

Faculty Name
Swargajyoti Gohain [swargajyoti.gohain@ashoka.edu.in] ,Areeb Mansoor [areeb.mansoor_ug24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course explores important concepts and approaches in sociology and anthropology. The syllabus is designed to familiarize the students with select concepts and ethnographies of the discipline. We will discuss the sociology and anthropology of kinship, social stratification (caste, race, tribe), cities, migration, nationalism, and environment. Rather than treating these as independent concepts, we seek to show their inter-relation with other social phenomena. For example, how are notions of family and kinship intertwined with science and technology studies; what is the connection between migration and urban transformations, how does one critically study the relation between environment and tourism etc. By doing this, the course demonstrates how the sociological approach explores and finds relations and connections between people, places, and objects. The objective of this course is to develop students’ appreciation of concepts and categories and their evolution and innovation. This course will also demonstrate to students how theory, ethnography and critical thinking can be integrated. Course materials will include examples from India as well as other parts of the world, and will offer a representative overview and not exhaustive coverage of all topics and perspectives existing in the discipline. Evaluation will be on the basis of written assignments, discussion board responses and class participation.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

A.    Attendance and Class Participation: 10 points

B.    Discussion Board questions. Questions will be posted online for you to respond in 200 words on scheduled dates. See syllabus for dates (5x5) 25 points

C.    Mid-semester Exam. You will be given three questions that you will have to answer in 24 hours (10 AM – 10 AM, next day) 25 points. Questions will test your ability to apply concepts to real life situations

D.    End-semester Review Quiz. 15 Multiple Choice Questions on the last day of teaching. 15 points

E.    End-semester Assignment. Socio-autobiography/Auto-ethnography*

Word limit 3000/12 double spaced pages. 25 points

Magic, Science, Religion [SOA-2103] [SOA-2103-1]

Faculty Name
Ravindran S [ravindran.sriramachandran@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Description

What is magic? What is science? And what is religion? How are the three related? And in what ways are they different? In this course we will explore these questions through readings that include Sylvia Frederici’s Witches, Witch-Hunting and Women, Max Weber's The Protestent Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism, and Emily Martin's "The Egg and the Sperm." Along with reading ethnographies about magic, science, and religion that are drawn from from across the world, each week we will also think carefully about, and discuss, contemporary events and practices relevant to our context and interests.
You will read texts actively and closely, formulate your own interpretations of them, make persuasive arguments about them, and work with a community of writers and thinkers. Respect for diverse systems of belief is an essential part of the conversation in this class. This is true for most classes, but particularly true for a class that deals with religious belief. My hope is that we will leave this class
with further insights into how to think about, write about, and live with difference.

Learning Outcomes

You will read texts actively and closely, formulate your own interpretations of
them, make persuasive arguments about them, and work with a community of
writers and thinkers. Respect for diverse systems of belief is an essential part of
the conversation in this class. This is true for most classes, but particularly true
for a class that deals with religious belief. My hope is that we will leave this class
with further insights into how to think about, write about, and live with
difference.

Grading Rubric

Course Requirements and Grade Breakup
35% = Concept “bank” — we will begin class each week writing about important
concepts from readings and class discussions, attempting to both describe and
apply them. Each student is required to maintain a cumulative document of
concepts, that they will update and turn in. This is a turn-it-in grade, graded for
good-faith completion. If a completed document with all assigned concepts is
turned in, reasonably well-developed, the student will receive a full 20%
20% = Midterm assignment — To be developed
10% = Class participation — Participation Sincerity, class discipline, quality of
your contribution to class discussions, and to small-group assignments. If you
have questions about class participation please meet with the professor and TA to
discuss them early in the semester. Alternative assessments are being made for
students who cannot attend synchronous classes due to unavoidable
circumstances.
35% = Assignment 3 - Research Paper: You will conduct independent research on
a chosen topic and write a research paper. The requirements of this paper will be
described later in the semester, and will be developed in consultation with the
professor.
Note: I will make every effort to provide you with detailed feedback on your
writing for one assignment — either midterm or final.

Attendance Policy

Students have 5 free absences. In order to maintain a level of discussion
and participation, more than 5 absences from class will result in a
1-letter cut from the final grade, unless these absences are formally
excused by the instructor. In the event of an unforeseen circumstance or
emergency, please write to the instructor directly.

Home, belonging and identity [SOA-2236] [SOA-2236-1]

Overview

Faculty: Dr Radhika Mathrani Chakraborty

How do we make homes, and is home always a place? What role do non-humans (animals, objects, and beyond) play in homes? What do homes and ways of inhabiting them tell us about relations of power? What is the relationship between homes and nations; homes and identity? In this course, we will explore the relations, materials, objects, technologies, and practices that make homes - and how homes are lived, remembered, imagined and desired. Through varied experiences of home, we will address broader questions and theories of belonging and identity. This course will introduce students to sociological and anthropological perspectives on home and belonging. Drawing on a range of ethnographic texts, literary works, and personal accounts, we will undertake a critical reading of home, domestic space and the everyday, to draw out and interrogate concepts relating to belonging and identity.

CourseTitle: Movement and connection: Migration and diaspora
description:
Movement and connection: Migration and diaspora [SOA-3129] [SOA-3129-1]

Overview

Faculty : Dr Radhika Mathrani Chakraborty

Are we living in the ‘age of migration’? Why do people migrate? Who moves, and who stays put? What travels along with people on the move: objects, ideas, prejudices, desires? How is movement connected to power, and why are some forms of movement celebrated, and others deemed ‘illegal’? What kinds of connections and solidarities emerge through movement and migration? From images of the crowded trains of the 1947 Partition to boats filled with refugees – the stories of migration are most often told in the language of crisis, and on an international or national scale. This course explores migration as a multi-faceted and everyday social reality, across a variety of scales, and through a range of relationships. The texts and authors introduced in this course challenge us to imagine social life beyond binaries of fixity and motion, and highlight relational approaches to movement and connection. They introduce us to a variety of movements and connections, and the actors and institutions involved in them: migrants, refugees, workers, students, brokers, governments, and even animals, objects, and texts. This course helps make sense of what seems to be a world in motion, through an anthropological lens.

CourseTitle: Visual Culture of Indian Painting: Courtly Traditions
description:
Visual Culture of Indian Painting: Courtly Traditions [VA-2001/ HIS-3806] [VA-2001/ HIS-3806-1]

Faculty Name
Preeti Bahadur Ramaswami [preeti.ramaswami@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

As mobile and portable objects,  the visually saturated paintings  made for Mughal, Rajput and Decani courts in pre modern India had many lives. Accessible today though museum collections the world over, they were once collected  by  elite patrons to fashion courtly identities. This course will lead students to explore pictorial language used in these paintings and see the framing of subjectivities within them. Beyond this, the course will uncover the social lives of these works as material objects,  shaped by transregional networks that allowed cultural flows between people, places and artifacts. 

Students will be led to examine the place of these paintings within the arts of the book with transcultural connections, from Europe  to  China.  They will look at the histories of  artistic practices involved in the making of these highly crafted works of art. What did visual style mean to artists and patrons, and how is it seen today? How do contemporary artists from India and Pakistan view this legacy and interpret it?

The course is interdisciplinary in approach. It will bring literary, performative and sensory studies  to bear on understanding the visual using art historical frameworks.  This will explored through themes both as subject matter of the paintings, and as a lens for understanding the affective, cultural and political value of these works. The focus will be on  paintings made between the fifteenth  and the eighteenth centuries, and on contemporary reflections on this practice by artists from South Asia.  

Learning Outcomes

Upon completing this course students will be able to: 

  • Locate transcultural and cosmopolitan encounters in premodern India through the arts of the book.
  • Read the past in the present though contemporary art works that reference these traditions.
  • Trace the agency of individual artists in the creation of highly calibrated art works.
  • Engage with a contemporary artist re- working miniature painting formats, and/ or an exhibition featuring works by ‘contemporary miniaturists’ 
  • Curate a digital exhibition  as term end project

. 

                 . 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

General readings: 

Eaton, Richard M. India in the Persianate Age: 1000-1765. Penguin UK, 2019 , pp 430-553, 316-349

Asher, Catherine B., and Cynthia Talbot. India Before Europe. Cambridge University Press, 2006.pp 272-348

Between the scroll, the pothi and the codex.  

This module is an introduction to the arts of the book in India , before the advent of the Mughals.  It will look  at Indic and Islamicate approaches to book making in circulation in the fifteenth and sixteenth with regard to design, storytelling  and materiality.  Students will specifically look at colour and paper as  material agents of visuality. They will also examine hybridity as a cultural feature, while  exploring  the movement of artifacts and artists. 

J. P. Losty, The Arts of  the Book in India, (The British Library) 1982. 37-54

Kim, Jinah. Garland of Visions: Color, Tantra, and a Material History of Indian Painting. United States, University of California Press, 2021.

Bailkin, Jordanna. "Indian yellow: Making and breaking the imperial palette." Journal of material culture 10.2 (2005): 197-214.

Flood, Finbarr Barry. "Before the Mughals: Material Culture of sultanate North India." Muqarnas Online 36.1 (2019): 1-39.

 

Between Europe and Asia

Between the sixteenth and the eighteenth centuries the profuse output of paintings produced at the courts of the Mughals , the Deccani Sultanates and Rajput rulers was  in many ways the result of transregional and transcultural encounters.  The courts of the Deccani Sultanates and the Mughal court were actively connected with Persia and Europe through ties of trade, religion, politics, but also through networks linking  persons of talent including artists, poets and scholars. This module will look at paintings  on cloth, the  art of Ebru or marbelling on paper, a manuscript on esoteric practices  within the Deccan , and  Muraqqa or albums created at the Mughal courts, to explore cosmopolitanism  in pre modern India. 

Rice, Yael. "The Global Aspirations of the Mughal Album." Rembrandt and the Inspiration of India (2018): 61-77.

Khullar, Sonal, ed. Old Stacks, New Leaves: The Arts of the Book in South Asia. University of Washington Press, 2023.

Natif, Mika. Mughal occidentalism: artistic encounters between Europe and Asia at the courts of India, 1580-1630. Brill, 2018.

Flatt, Emma J. The courts of the Deccan sultanates: Living well in the Persian cosmopolis. Cambridge University Press, 2019.154.

Green, Nile. "Ostrich eggs and peacock feathers: Sacred objects as cultural exchange between Christianity and Islam." Al-Masaq 18.1 (2006): 27-78.

Haidar, Navina Najat, and Marika Sardar. Sultans of Deccan India, 1500–1700: Opulence and Fantasy. Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2015

 

On style and meaning

What can pictorial style harbour within its language? Can style be manipulated to convey political messages? Students will look at paintings that were produced at  Rajput courts to see how artists made paintings that recorded resistance or accommodation to the Mughals. 

Baxandall, Michael. Painting and experience in fifteenth century Italy: a primer in the social history of pictorial style. Oxford Paperbacks, 1988.

 Aitken, Molly Emma. The Intelligence of Tradition in Rajput Court Painting. Yale University Press, 2010

Singh, Kavita. "A Knowing Look: Appropriation and Subversion of the Mughal Idiom in Rajput Paintings of the Eighteenth Century." Synergies in Visual Culture/Bildkulturen im Dialog. Wilhelm Fink, 2013. 257-268.

 

On love and desire  

Students will explore the treatment of love as an emotion across literary and visual idioms in circulation.   How did poets and artists respond to differing notions of love drawn from rasa canonical literature and Persianate traditions?  Beyond literary tropes, students will look at representations of ideal women as objects of  desire, and examine the framing of the gaze within paintings from Pahari and Rajasthani courts.  

Readings 

Aditya Behl, Love’s  Subtle Magic: An Indian Islamic Literary Tradition 1379- 1545. OUP New York 2012.

Miśra, Bhānudatta. Bouquet of Rasa” & “River of Rasa. NYU Press, 2009.

Desai, Vishakha N. "Loves of Rādhā in the" Rasikapriyā" Verses and Paintings." Ars Orientalis (2000): 83-92.

Aitken, Molly Emma. "Spectatorship and femininity in Kangra style painting." Representing the body–gender issues in Indian art. Kali for women–in association with the Book Review Literary Trust, New Delhi (1998): 82-101

 

Artists: circulation and ateliers.

Painters and artists often led itinerant lives, moving between courts seeking patronage or being actively solicited. How did their mobility impact their art? Students will attempt to reimagine their lives and histories in the course of this module. This module will look also  at workshop and atelier practices to understand the production of these art works. 

Readings

 Pamuk, Orhan. My name is Red. Vol. 331. Everyman's Library, 2010.

Beach, Milo Cleveland, Eberhard Fischer, and B. N. Goswamy. "Masters of Indian Painting, I: 1100-1650." Zürich: Artibus Asiae (2011).

Seyller, John. "Farrukh Beg in the Deccan." Artibus Asiae55.3/4 (1995): 319-341.

Rice, Yael. "Workshop as Network: A Case Study from Mughal South Asia." Artl@ s Bulletin 6.3 (2017): 4.

 

Music, poetry and devotion

Paintings produced at courts and beyond created an aesthetic world that was multisensorial. The creation of this aesthetic was linked to ideas of pleasure and luxury but also to that of polity. Students will look at the cult of Nauras  at the court of Ibrahim Adil Shah, in the Deccan, at representations of musical soirees at Mewar and the Pahari hill courts, at paintings on cloth made for Vallabh Sampradaya at Nathdwara, and for the poet – ruler Savant Singh at Kishangarh.  

Pollock, Sheldon. A rasa reader: Classical Indian aesthetics. Columbia University Press, 2016.

Orsini, Francesca, and Katherine Butler Schofield. Tellings and Texts: Music, Literature and Performance in North India. Open Book Publishers, 2015.

Rajamani, Imke, Margrit Pernau, and Katherine Butler Schofield. Monsoon feelings: A history of emotions in the rain. Niyogi, 2018.

Pauwels, Heidi. Mobilizing Krishna’s World: The Writings of Prince Savant Singh of Kishangarh. University of Washington Press, 2017

 

Kingship, Connoisseurship, Portraiture 

The module looks at portraiture as a mode for expressing ideals of kingship, for political rhetoric or as notions of selfhood. Students will look at the differing representational approaches to portraiture practiced  at Mughal, Deccani and Rajput courts to examine the differing uses portraits were put to. 

Readings:  

John Seyller, 'A Mughal Code of Connoisseurship,' Muqarnas, 17, 2000: pp 177-202. 

Gulbransen, Krista Hall. "Jahāngīrī portrait shasts: Material-discursive practices and visuality at the Mughal court." postmedieval 11.1 (2020): 68-79.

Branfoot, Crispin. Portraiture in South Asia Since the Mughals: Art, Representation and History. Bloomsbury Publishing, 2018.

 

The Past in the Present : copying and citation 

Students will examine at ways in which works were copied as a mode of transmission, and at how this practice itself became a way of  commenting, wittily, and often subversively, on political contexts. They will be led to see this practice and its ‘re use’ in contemporary contexts, in the works of contemporary painters from Pakistan and India.

Readings: 

Desai, Vishakha N. "Reflections of the past in the present: Copying processes in Indian painting." Perceptions of South Asia’s Visual Past (1994): 135-148.

.Saraf, Varunika. "A Market for Fakes:" Miniature" Painting in Rajasthan, 1960-2000." MARG- 69.3 (2018): 54-63.

Whiles, Virginia. Art and Polemic in Pakistan: Cultural Politics and Tradition in Contemporary Miniature Painting. Tauris Academic Studies, 2010.

Grading Rubric

Students are assessed continually through the entire semester including active class and participation, class presentations, assignments and an end curatorial project. The assessment and grading pattern is as follows:

 Class participation and engagement : 10% of total grades. 

Class presentation and assignments : 60% of total grades

End semester curatorial project:  30% of total grades. 

 

Attendance Policy

90% attendance is mandatory

CourseTitle: Empire, Nation and Art: Histories from the Visual Image
description:
Empire, Nation and Art: Histories from the Visual Image [VA-3002/ HIS-3801] [VA-3002/ HIS-3801-1]

Faculty Name
Sraman Mukherjee [sraman.mukherjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course explores global social formations from the fifteenth century of Common Era to our present times through the prism of visual images. We specifically focus on the centrality of visual archives in mapping histories of European colonialism under Spanish, Portuguese, Dutch, French, and British empires. The course will address a range of colonial formations and diverse articulations of nationalist thought and consciousness in different parts of the world through different visual forms across a range of media, sites, and objects. Beginning from naturalist paintings and drawings of unknown landscapes and oceans, descriptions of plants and animals, of unknown humans and exotic objects, the course moves on to explore diverse media and technologies of visual (re)productions like water colour, oil painting, lithographs, oleographs, chromolithographs, aquatints, photographs and the moving image, and maps different sites of visual simulations like cabinet de curiosities, ‘freak shows’, world exhibitions, metropolitan, colonial, and postcolonial public museums, art galleries, institutes of fine arts, crafts and design pedagogy. The course argues that global histories of colonialism, nationalism, and decolonization can be partially explored as histories of encounters, violent conflicts, tortuous negotiations, and often uneasy accommodations played out at the register of the visual image. The course urges us to rethink that notions of metropolis and colony, empire and nation, colonizer and colonized, alien and indigenous, as they are configured and reconfigured in the archives of the visual image, are historically relative, often fluid categories, having only situational relevance. Moving away from a purely Euro-centric discussion of the beginnings of Art and Art History, this course seeks to move towards a global history of art.

Learning Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
On successful completion of the course, we will be able to:
a) Identify and analyze aspects of works of art and visual images in different material and medium using appropriate vocabulary.
b) Explore the main trends in the development of Art History and Visual Culture by accessing the critical essential skills.
c) Evaluate the approaches of artists, art historians, visual anthropologists and curators to the field of visual arts.
d) Develop the interests for a future training in critical art historical training and art curatorial programme.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Pre-requisites: None

Modules and Select Readings

1. Globes and the Maps

Readings

Sumathi Ramaswamy, Terrestrial Lessons: The Conquest of the World as Globe. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press, 2017 (Selections to be announced)

Nicholas Thomas, “Objects of Knowledge: Oceanic Artifacts in European Engravings” in Martin Jay and Sumathi Ramaswamy, ed. Empires of Vision: A Reader. Durham and London, Duke University Press, 2014.

Benjamin Schmidt, “Mapping an Exotic World: The Global Project of Dutch Cartography, circa 1700”, in Martin Jay and Sumathi Ramaswamy, ed. Empires of Vision: A Reader. Durham and London, Duke University Press, 2014.

Terry Smith, “Visual Regimes of Colonization: European and Aboriginal Seeing in Australia”, in Martin Jay and Sumathi Ramaswamy, ed. Empires of Vision: A Reader. Durham and London, Duke University Press, 2014.

2.Colonizing the Natural World

Readings

Daniela Bleichmar, “Painting as Exploration: Visualizing Nature in Eighteenth-Century Colonial Science”, in Martin Jay and Sumathi Ramaswamy, ed. Empires of Vision: A Reader. Durham and London, Duke University Press, 2014.

Serge Gruzinski, “The Walls of Images”, in Martin Jay and Sumathi Ramaswamy, ed. Empires of Vision: A Reader. Durham and London, Duke University Press, 2014.

 

3.Colour and Empires: Image productions, reproduction, circulation and consumption

Readings

Natasha Eaton, Colour, Art and Empire: Visual Culture and the Nomadism of Representation. London: I. B. Tauris, 2013 (selections to be announced)

Natasha Eaton, “Excess in the City? The Consumption of Imported Prints in Colonial Calcutta, c. 1780–c. 1795” in Martin Jay and Sumathi Ramaswamy, ed. Empires of Vision: A Reader. Durham and London, Duke University Press, 2014.

David Ciarlo,” Advertising and the Optics of Colonial Power at the Fin de Siecle” in Martin Jay and Sumathi Ramaswamy, ed. Empires of Vision: A Reader. Durham and London, Duke University Press, 2014.

4.The Photographic and Moving Images

Readings

Christopher Pinney and Nicholas Peterson, ed, Photography’s Other Histories. Duke University Press, 2003 (Selections to be announced)

James L. Hevia,” The Photography Complex: Exposing Boxer-EraChina (1900–1901), Making Civilization” in Martin Jay and Sumathi Ramaswamy, ed. Empires of Vision: A Reader. Durham and London, Duke University Press, 2014.

Brian Larkin, “Colonialism and the Built Space of Cinema”, in Martin Jay and Sumathi Ramaswamy, ed. Empires of Vision: A Reader. Durham and London, Duke University Press, 2014.

5.Viewing/ Thinking from the Postcolonial locations

Readings

Iftikhar Dadi, Modernism and the Art of Muslim South Asia. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press, 2010 (selections to be announced)

Zeynep Celik, “Speaking Back to Orientalist Discourse”, in Martin Jay and Sumathi Ramaswamy, ed. Empires of Vision: A Reader. Durham and London, Duke University Press, 2014.

Krista A. Thompson, “I Am Rendered Speechless by Your Ideaof Beauty”: The Picturesque in History and Art in the Postcolony, in Martin Jay and Sumathi Ramaswamy, ed. Empires of Vision: A Reader. Durham and London, Duke University Press, 2014.

Grading Rubric

Grading Rubric

This course follows a pattern of continuous assessment and grading through the entire semester including active class and site visit participation, and mid semester and end semester evaluations. The assessment and grading criterion are as follows:

1) Students will be assessed on basis on their active engagement with course contents which will carry ten percent (10%) of the total course grades.


2) The mid semester assessment will comprise of a class presentation and subsequent submission of an essay based on any one image chosen by the student in consultation with the instructor. The mid semester evaluation will carry 40% of the total course grades.

3) For the end semester evaluation candidates are required to write an essay between 2000 and 2500 words (including footnotes and bibliography). The topic of the end semester assessment has to be decided by the student in conjunction with the course instructor. The end semester assessments for this course will follow a feed forward method and students are actively encouraged to submit (within date and time specified) 2 working drafts/ drafts in progress to the course instructor for comments and feedback. The end semester assessment will carry 50% of the total course grades.


4) All submissions including mid semester and end semester papers have to be made electronically.

 

5) Plagiarism (intended or unintended) constitutes the most serious academic offence. Any act of plagiarism will be reported to the Academic Integrity Committee of the University and will attract punitive measures from grade cuts to failing the course. The first detection of plagiarism in any paper will result in grade cuts and reporting to the AIC. For repeat offense, students will be allotted a Fail grade for the entire course. Please go through the Academic Integrity document of Ashoka University to check what constitutes plagiarism and other forms of academic dishonesty. Specific citation styles for texts and images will be addressed by specific course instructors.
 

Attendance Policy

 

Three undocumented absences are permitted for the entire semester.

CourseTitle: Histories of South Asian Art: From the Earliest Times to the Present
description:
Histories of South Asian Art: From the Earliest Times to the Present [VA-3006] [VA-3006-1]

Faculty Name
Sraman Mukherjee [sraman.mukherjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What is Art and who is it meant for? What is specifically South Asian about South Asian Art? What does it mean to think of South Asia and Art as analytical categories? Did South Asian Art always exist? Or were historical processes involved in the making of the field? Where do we locate the “genesis” of art in South Asia? Did art forms in South Asia emerge in a zone of cultural and social isolation? Or can we trace trajectories of trans-regional contacts, encounters, and exchanges as central to the shaping of the field of South Asian Art? What is space of tradition and innovation in the visual arts of South Asia? Did arts of South Asia “influence” artistic practices in other regions? How did artists at different points in history think about the region we identify as South Asia? Seeking to address some of these questions, this course examines aspects of the visual arts of South Asia from its earliest traces in cave paintings and stone implements to sculpture, painting, illustrated manuscripts, calligraphy, and architecture. The course follows a chronological scale, from pre-history to c. 1980s. The vast geographical as well as the temporal span of the field will restrict the course from delivering an encyclopedic survey. Instead it will prioritize intensive analysis of selected themes. Rather than placing the teleology of South Asian “art” solely in the context of changing dynastic histories, the course takes up specific themes in art across a range of objects, artefacts, archaeological sites, built spaces, religious and political symbols, and institutions of art pedagogy and exhibitions. In the process we address the questions of image, icon, and representations of body, landscape, portraiture in the context of social and ideological changes, aesthetic turns, shifting patrons and markets, and introduction of new material media. The course will probe both ‘South Asia’ and ‘South Asian Art’ as stable (art) historical categories and map the new methodologies and vocabularies employed by art historians. Class discussions will form the basis for museum and gallery visits to the National Museum of India (New Delhi), NGMA (New Delhi), National Handloom and Handicrafts Museum (New Delhi), and KNMA (New Delhi) which will enable us to study the works of art in their institutional locations and explore the visual dynamics of organization of exhibition spaces.

 

Learning Outcomes

On successful completion of the course, we will be able to:
a) Identify and analyze aspects of works of art and visual images in different material and medium using appropriate vocabulary.
b) Explore the main trends in the development of Art History and Visual Culture by accessing the critical essential skills.
c) Evaluate the approaches of artists, art historians, visual anthropologists and curators to the field of visual arts.
d) Develop the interests for a future training in critical art historical training and art curatorial programme.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Pre-requisites: This course has no pre requisites

Course Modules and Readings

Introduction: Interrogating South Asia: Visualizing a “region”

Readings

Mohammad-Arif, Aminah. “Introduction. Imaginations and Constructions of South Asia: An Enchanting Abstraction?”, SAMAJ, 10, 2014, 1-27

Asher, Frederick M. “Historiography of South Asian Art”, Oxford Bibliographies (DOI: 10.1093/OBO/9780199920105-0010)

Module # 1 Art and the Ritual Lives of South Asian Images

Reading

Davis, Richard. "Loss and Recovery of Ritual Self among Hindu Images", Journal of Ritual Studies, Vol. 6, No. 1, 1992, 43-61.

Module # 2 Locating "Art"? Reading Material Traces of the Earliest Civilizations Compulsory

Reading

Neumayer, Erwin. “Bodies in Motion”, Archaeology, Vol. 50, No. 1, 1997, 56-59.

Lee, Sherman E. History of Far Eastern Art. New Jersey: Prentice Hall, 1994 (selections TBA)

Mitter, Partha. Indian Art. New Delhi: Oxford University Press, 2001 (selections TBA)

Further Reading

Chakrabarti, Dilip K. India, An Archaeological History: Palaeolithic Beginnings to Early Historic Foundations. New Delhi: Oxford University Press, 1999, 2010

Module # 3 Buddhism and Early Indian Narrative Relief Compulsory

Reading

Dahejia, Vidya. "On Modes of Visual Narration in Early Buddhist Art", The Art Bulletin, Vol. 72, No. 3 (Sep., 1990), pp. 374-392

Further Reading

Lee, Sherman E. History of Far Eastern Art. New Jersey: Prentice Hall, 1994 (selections TBA)

Module# 4 Stylistic Influences and Material Media of Sculptural Art: Art History and Historiography

Readings

Asher, Frederick and Walter Spink, “Mauryan Figural Sculpture Reconsidered.” Ars Orientalis, 19, 1989

Abe, Stanley K. “Inside the Wonder House: Buddhist Art and the West”, in Donald S. Lopez Jr., ed. Curators of the Buddha: The Study of Buddhism under Colonialism. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press, 1995

Module#5 Art as Cultural Index: The shifting landscape of Indic Art

Grading Rubric

This course follows a pattern of continuous assessment and grading through the entire semester including active class and gallery and museum visits and image analysis, and mid semester and end semester evaluations. The assessment and grading criterion are as follows: 1. Students will be assessed on basis on their active engagement with course contents during classes and after class office hours which will carry ten percent (10%) of the total course grades. 2. Museum and gallery visits and image analysis will carry thirty percent (30%) of the total course grades. The subsequent submission of a written report on an object/ image of your choice (within a word limit of 600 to 800 words) counts for 30% of the total course grades. 3. The mid semester assessment will comprise of a class presentation based on any one image chosen by the student in discussion with the instructor. The mid semester evaluation will carry twenty percent (20%) of the total course grades. 4. For the end semester evaluation we will write an essay between 2000 and 2500 words (including footnotes and bibliography). The topic of the end semester assessment has to be chosen by the student from a range of verbal text and visual image prompts provided by the course instructor. The end semester assessments for this course will follow a feed forward method and students are actively encouraged to submit (within date and time specified) one working draft/ draft in progress to the course instructor for comments and feedback. The end semester assessment will carry forty percent (40%) of the total course grades. 5. All submissions including field reports, mid semester and end semester papers have to be made electronically. 6. Plagiarism (intended or unintended) constitutes the most serious academic offence. Any act of plagiarism will be reported to the Academic Integrity Committee of the University and will attract punitive measures from grade cuts to failing the course. The first detection of plagiarism in any paper will result in grade cuts and reporting to the AIC. For repeat offense, students will be allotted a Fail grade for the entire course. Please go through the Academic Integrity document of Ashoka University to check what constitutes plagiarism and other forms of academic dishonesty. Specific citation styles for texts and images will be addressed by specific course instructors.

Attendance Policy

Three undocumented absences are permitted for the entire semester.

Western Art and Propaganda [VA-3016] [VA-3016-1]

Faculty Name
Devan Barker [devan.barker@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

 

OVERVIEW

This course will focus on the use of propaganda, art, and other forms of persuasion starting with the Modern Era (approximately post-1860) and continuing to the present. Students will experience this topic through various social issues and cultural influences from around the world, including the visual, performing, and literary arts. This course emphasizes the development of aesthetic judgment and critical thinking.

LEVEL: 

Undergrad, Masters’

year 1 - 1000, or year 2 -2000, Year 3, ASP, MLS

This course was designed as a general education elective and is conceived as an introduction to both the materials and the skills involved.

This course is being offered by our visiting faculty Prof. Devan Barker, a Fulbright fellow on a short term at Ashoka.

Questions may be addressed to devan.barker@ashoka.edu.in 

Learning Outcomes

You will recognize how knowledge of the humanities can enrich your life by promoting thinking, engagement, and empathy. 

You will interpret art and propaganda to understand what they reveal about history, culture, religion, and ideology.

You will apply the tools needed to discern the meanings, messages, quality, biases and agendas found in the arts and propaganda.

You will analyze the works of major composers, artists, writers, as well as cultures, movements, and themes of the modern era.

Cosmic Messengers -2 (Laboratory) [AST-3880/ AST-4880/ PHY-3880/ PHY-4880/ PHY-6880] [AST-3880/ AST-4880/ PHY-3880/ PHY-4880/ PHY-6880-1]

Faculty Name
Dipankar Bhattacharya [dipankar.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will introduce general techniques of data analysis and of drawing inference from multi-attribute, multi-mesenger data.  Specific exmples from Astronomy will be used, but the underlying methods will have applicability in a wide variety of domains.

Syllabus:

Brief overview of different electromagnetic bands and the instruments employed for astronomical data collection.  Ground vs Space based astronomy. Inference from data, role and techniqes of model fitting.  Temporal, spectral and direct/indirect imaging data will be treated in an unified framework.

Types of data - Image data, Spectral data, Temporal data, Interferometry data, Event data.
Principles of reduction of different data types. Calibration requirements.  Background estimation and removal. Error estimates.  Elements of Fourier analysis.

Astronomical data and metadata formats:  The FITS standard.  Viewing, writing and manipulating FITS files.  The AstroPy package.

Hands-on analysis of data including introduction to packages:

Optical: IRAF
Measuring the optical magnitude of a star. Estimating the surface brightness profile of a galaxy. Reduction of a one-dimensional spectrum - wavelength calibration, line identification, continuum subtraction, line profile fitting and radial velocity measurement.

X-ray/Gamma-ray: HEASOFT
Binning of event data to create image, spectrum and light curve.  Response Matrix and Auxiliary Response Files.  Orbital motion of a space-based observatory and charged particle background.
Temporal analysis of Crab pulsar data - barycentric correction, power spectral estimation, epoch folding, phase tracking.  Estimation of spin and spin-down rate.  Transient detection: GRB

Radio interferometry: friendlyVRI, CASA
Creation of an image from visibility data, snapshot vs earth rotation synthesis.  Spectral channels and data cubes.  Local Standard of Rest correction.

Gravitational Waves
Matched filtering through a burst segment

Learning Outcomes

1. Understanding general principles of data analysis and model fitting

2. Developing familiarity with common detection techniques of electromagnetic and gravitational wave radiation

4. Learning software tools for analysing astronomical data at different wavebands, including optical, X-ray, radio and gravitational waves. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Recommended Reading:

Observational Astronomy (2nd ed): D. Scott Bimey, Guillermo Gonzalez and David Oesper, Cambridge University Press
Essential Radio Astronomy: James A. Condon and Scott A. Ransom, Princeton University Press
Handbook of X-ray astronomy, ed. K. Arnaud, R. Smith and A. Siemiginowska, Cambridge University Press
General Relativity and Gravitational Waves: Essentials of Theory and Practice: Sanjeev Dhurandhar and Sanjit Mitra, Springer
Basics of Fourier Analysis for High Energy Astronomy: T. Belloni and D. Bhattacharya, Handbook of X-ray and Gamma-Ray Astronomy, Springer [arXiv: 2203.04106]

Pre-requisites:  Working knowledge of coding/scripting, preferably in python language; Familiarity with linux/unix.

Grading Rubric

Laboratory Reports (60%):  4 reports, each carrying 15% marks 

Final examinaion (40%):  Written paper: 15%,   Hands-on data analysis, report and viva-voce 25%

Attendance Policy

Attendance is compulsory

Chemical Basis of Life [BIO-2300/ BIO-6300] [BIO-2300/ BIO-6300-1]

Faculty Name
Kavita Agarwal [kavita.agarwal@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sandeep Ameta [sandeep.ameta@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The course aims at introducing basic concepts of chemistry in biology and provides a framework to understand basic biomolecular interactions and their mechanism. It will emphasise studying amino acids, proteins, and enzymes as biological catalysts and understanding the chemistry of enzymatic transformations. This course covers the basic building blocks of what constitutes life (nucleic acids, lipids, carbohydrates, sugar, protein, and molecular metabolism).

Course structure: 

  • Introduction to chemical concepts (Biomolecules and functionalities, basic chemical concepts: thermodynamics, reaction types, kinetics)
  • Molecules of life and function  (Carbohydrates, Lipids, Amino acids, Proteins, Nucleic acids, Vitamins, Small molecules)
  • Origins of Life: How chemistry transited to Biology?
  • Application of Chemistry in Health and Industry
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The course content will be prepared from multiple sources but will be sufficient to understand but the following books can be referred to for additional knowledge.

  • Lehninger Principles of Biochemistry David L. Nelson, Michael M. Cox. Publisher: W. H. Freeman

Faculty Name
Kritika Garg [kritika.garg@ashoka.edu.in] ,Rintu Kutum [rintu.kutum@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sanjeev Kumar [sanjeev.kumar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Understanding structure, expression and dynamics of a genome allows us to correlate structure with function and help to find molecular correlates of different phenotypic characteristics. Recent developments of high throughput technologies have opened unprecedented level of dissecting a genome that has opened up new ways of deciphering genotype-phenotype correlation. We will expose the students to these new ways of understanding genomes and show how the genomic data can be used to understand functional features.

Learning Outcomes

Students will learn about the genomes and history of genomic analysis including some of the technologies such as Sanger sequencing, next generation sequencing (NGS) technology along with the evolution of various NGS platforms. They will be exposed to the various “-omics” data and its applications. Hands on training will be provided to allow students to appreciate the various applications of NGS data.

Understanding Structure and Function [BIO-3006/ BIO-6006] [BIO-3006/ BIO-6006-1]

Faculty Name
Dilip Kumar [dilip.kumar@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sandeep Ameta [sandeep.ameta@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Have you ever visited a key maker? You must have seen lots of premade keys with unique shapes and sizes. However, only certain keys might work for a particular lock. But what makes a particular key functional, not the others? It entirely depends on the structural features of the key. Similarly, in Biology, thousands of such keys for specific locks mediate numerous biological functions. This course will discuss how these biological keys or biomolecules are structured for their specific functions. Through this journey, we will ask some of these questions:

How structure determines function L1-L2

The architecture of proteins L3-L4

Methods to determine macromolecular structures L5-L6

Carbohydrates and Lipids: Biomolecules and their functions L7-L8

Cell membranes L9

Viruses: symmetry and structure L10-L11

Structural biology of Immune system L12

Macromolecular interactions: making sense of molecular crosstalk L13

 

Nucleic Acids (Structure-function) (6 lectures)

DNA

  • Different structural forms of DNA, function, and biological importance
  • Catalytic DNA structure and function

RNA

  • Different types of RNAs and functional roles along with structures
  • tRNAs, Ribosomal RNAs, RNA-protein complexes
  • catalytic RNAs and riboswitches

How to evolve or select a structure/function? (6 lectures)

  • Directed evolution principles
  • Directed evolution of proteins (techniques, applications, achievements)
    • Antibodies, Enzymes, Binders
  • Directed evolution of nucleic acids (techniques, applications, achievements)
    • Aptamers, catalytic RNAs
  • Protein design (alpha fold and others)
Learning Outcomes

Students will acquire a fundamental understanding of the molecular basis and dependency of biomolecular structures and functions. We will walk you through a multidisciplinary approach to understanding the atomic and molecular level understanding of biomolecular architecture and its role in stability, diversity, and function. We will discuss how to utilize the molecular understanding of biologics in solving various genetic and epigenetic diseases. Students will also be introduced to the possibility of the structure-based functional aspect in synthetic biology and synthetic life.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Reading materials and books will be shared during the classes.

Books recommendations:

Lehninger Principles of Biochemistry- David L Nelson, Michael M Cox

Biochemistry - Donald Voet, Judith G. Voet

Molecular Biology of the cell; Bruce Alberts, Alexander Johnson, Julian Lewis, Martin Raff, Keith Roberts, Peter Walter

Assignments: 20 x 2 marks

Relative grading

Organismal and evolutionary biology [BIO-4412] [BIO-4412-1]

Faculty Name
Balaji Chattopadhyay [balaji.chattopadhyay@ashoka.edu.in] ,Imroze Khan [imroze.khan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will equip students with the basic concepts of evolutionary biology. Students will learn in detail about various evolutionary processes in natural populations, using the key concepts of population genetics, life-history evolution, sexual selection, phylogenetics, experimental evolution and molecular evolution.

Population genetics and Phylogenetics modules will introduce the students to the basics of evolution of natural population; elements of population subdivision (from segregation of social units to differentiation among geographically isolated populations), genetic connectivity, dispersal, and population divergence. The module on phylogenetics will introduce concepts and methods of reconstruction of population histories. Hands on exercises will help the student learn the application of these concepts on publicly available datasets and address pertinent questions. 

The module on molecular evolution will cover the molecular basis of variation, adaptation and selection. We will discuss how experimental evolution can be carried out in the laboratory, and how genetics, molecular biology and evolution blend in as we look at the evolution of genes and genomes. Real world examples of evolution in action will be discussed. We will also explore how the genetic code itself can evolve and its implications for living systems.

 

Learning Outcomes

Overall, this course will also strengthen the philosophy of studying Biology where understanding concepts and the ability to synthesize ideas are more important than mere acquisition of mundane information. At the end of the course, students will not only be familiar with the key concepts of evolutionary Processes, but also understand how they can collectively contribute to the development of almost all the other areas of modern biology, including our current research efforts on climate change, antibiotic-drug resistance, host-pathogen interactions and emerging infectious diseases.​​

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Suggested reading:

Principles of population genetics by Hartl and Clark; Tree Thinking

An Introduction to Phylogenetic Biology by David A. Baum and Stacey D. Smith.

Introduction to Molecular Evolution by Dan Grauer and Wen Hsiung-Li  (2nd edition), Strickberger’s Evolution (4th or 5th edition). 

Evolutionary Analysis by Scott Freeman

Specific book chapters from elsewhere, technical and popular science papers and links to podcasts will be handed out in class.

Grading Rubric

Grading scheme: 


 

60% (Written exam): There will be two written exams of 30 marks each.

30% (Assignment): There will be two writing assignments of 15 marks each.

10% (Class attendance and participation)

Most likely, we will use absolute numbers for grading (90 – 100 A; 85 – 89 A-; 80 – 84 B+; 75 – 79 B; 70 – 74 B-; 65 – 69 C+; 60 – 64 C; 55 – 59 C-; 50 – 54 D+; 45 – 49 D; 40 – 44 D-; < 40 F). In case this scheme changes, we will inform you in advance

Attendance Policy

Attendance is mandatory and it will count towards your class participation. You will be randomly asked to participate in discussions as and when needed. However, you can miss a maximum of 2 classes.

Seminar Series in Biological Sciences [BIO-6014] [BIO-6014-1]

Faculty Name
Anup Padmanabhan [anup.padmanabhan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Communication is key in science. The primary objective of this course is to help graduate students learn to review, critique and discuss scientific literature. This module is designed to help Ph.D students improve their presentation skills in their individual research topics as well as subjects beyond their primary expertise. In this era of multi-disciplinary research, this skill will be extremely valuable.

Learning Outcomes

This is a required module for all PhD/MSc students. The main purpose of this module is to help graduate students improve their presentation skills and participate in scientific seminars/exchanges in a professional manner.

The course is divided into 2 sections. In the first half, the instructor(s) engage with the class on various modes of scientific communication – reading, presentation, and writing.

In the second half, the students are allotted recent research papers (or manuscripts) in life sciences. The students then present a seminar on this paper including a suitable literature search and critical analysis. The research paper will be further discussed with their fellow graduate students and lecturers. This seminar style approach is very conducive to spreading new information and getting graduate students aware of and interested in other associated disciplines. The seminars given by students are open to UG students and other faculty members.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

CourseTitle: Introduction to the Study of China
description:
Introduction to the Study of China [CHI-2001/ HIS-2804/ IR-2038] [CHI-2001/ HIS-2804/ IR-2038-1]

Faculty Name
Sayantani Mukherjee [sayantani.mukherjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Tuesdays & Thursdays 10.10-11.40 am

AC04-006 TR

Course Description:

What is China? Who counts as Chinese? What is China’s place in the modern world? These questions have been continuously debated both inside and outside China, with more and more urgency. Using methodological approaches from history, anthropology, political science, sociology, international relations, cultural studies, economics, and other fields, we will explore how these questions have been answered, who has answered them, and who is allowed to ask them.

This course will introduce students to a variety of approaches to the interdisciplinary study of the lands, societies and peoples that have been called ‘Chinese,’ both past and present. As a deeply heterogenous cultural formation that has transformed and been transformed by other cultures and systems, we will consider what makes the study of “China” distinctive in our time and region.

Learning Outcomes

Learning Objectives:

Think critically about the concept of ‘China’ in long-term historical perspective.

Be able to identify multiple alternative sources through which to learn about China, and analyse their strengths and weaknesses.

Identify common tropes in written and visual primary source material related to China.

Analyse the arguments and sources used by scholars in different disciplines writing about China.

CourseTitle: Chinese Pasts: “Ancient China” Through Contemporary Eyes
description:
Chinese Pasts: “Ancient China” Through Contemporary Eyes [CHI-3004/ HIS-3514/ IR-3022] [CHI-3004/ HIS-3514/ IR-3022-1]

Faculty Name
Eloise Wright [eloise.wright@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In November 2021, the 6th plenum of the 19th Chinese Communist Party Congress adopted only the third ‘Historical Resolution’ since the CCP’s founding, and the first since 1981. While the focus of these resolutions was on defining the party’s role in Chinese history since 1921, they also located the CCP within a longue durée history of the Chinese state. These resolutions point to the significance of China’s pre-modern history as a source of ideas and narratives about China’s present and future.

Over the last four decades, Chinese journalists, academics, and other public intellectuals have energetically debated what direction China should take after the end of the Cultural Revolution. In this class, we will explore the contours of these debates through a focus on history. In addition to key concepts and figures in intellectual history, we will discuss the role of the state in shaping and restricting the scope of debate at particular times. Finally, we will extend our analysis into the ways that ideas about China’s history play out ‘in practice’ – practices of memorialisation and display, fictionalisation and entertainment.

Preparation for class and in-class participation: 30%

Writing portfolio (short pieces collected throughout the semester): 40%

Structure elucidation of organic molecules [CHM-4402] [CHM-4402-1]

Faculty Name
Vidya Dnyaneshwar Avasare [vidya.avasare@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The structure establishment is crucial for any synthesized/ naturally occurring chemical compounds The students working in any synthetic field should have the skills to analyze and interpret the spectral data and confirm the structural features of the synthesized or isolated natural products.There are various methods to establish the structure or composition of any chemical entity. However, NMR, IR, UV-visible spectroscopic methods, and mass spectrometry are commonly used in the interpretation of organic, inorganic, organometallic, and biomolecules.

In this course, the applications of NMR spectroscopy (basic and advanced) in the structure determination of the molecules consisting of primarily  C, H,  (N, F, and P  in a few cases) will be discussed along with basic mass spectrometry, IR, and UV-visible spectroscopy.

Who can attend?

This course will be useful for students who aspire to do research in

Synthetic chemistry

Material Chemistry

Chemical biology

Synthetic biology

Drug discovery

and also, from

Computational chemistry ( to predict NMR, IR of complex molecules)

Learning Outcomes

The students can analyse the spectra of complex organic molecules and can predict the approximate spectral patterns for synthesized products or biomolecules. They can easily monitor the progress or chnages in the reactions.   

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

 SPECTROMETRIC IDENTIFICATION OF ORGANIC COMPOUNDS (2nd  Edition) by Robert M. Silverstein  Francis X. Webster, David J. Kiemle and David L. Bryce Publisher: Wiley, Pages: 464, ISBN: 9780470616376

ORGANIC CHEMISTRY (2nd  Edition)by Jonathan Clayden, Nick Greeves, and Stuart Warren  Publisher: Oxford University Press, Pages: 1264, ISBN: 9780198728719

INTRODUCTION TO SPECTROSCOPY: A GUIDE FOR STUDENTS OF ORGANIC CHEMISTRY (2nd  Edition) by Donald L. Pavia, Gary M. Lampman,  and George S. Kriz Publisher: Harcourt College Pub, Pages: 416, ISBN: 9780030584275

INTRODUCTION TO SPECTROSCOPY (5th Edition) by Donald L. Pavia, Publisher: Cengage India Private Limited, Pages: 784, ISBN: 9789381466476

SOLVING PROBLEMS WITH NMR SPECTROSCOPY by Atta-ur-Rahman Publisher:  Academic Press, 1995

APPLICATIONS OF NMR SPECTROSCOPY: VOLUME 5 by Atta-ur-Rahman, and  M. Iqbal Chaudhary,  Publisher: Bentham Science Publishers, Pages: 275, ISBN: 9781681082875

APPLICATIONS OF MODERN MASS SPECTROSCOPY: VOLUME 1 by Atta-ur-Rahman, M. Iqbal Chaudhary  and Syed Ghulam Musharraf Publisher: Bentham Science Publishers, Pages: 226, ISBN: 9789811433801

Grading Rubric

Assignments (total six) = 30%

Mid term exam = 25 %

End term exam = 25 %

Review seminar = 20 %

 

Attendance Policy

Minimum 80% attendance is required.
