Data Structures [CS-1203] [CS-1203-1]

Faculty Name
Debayan Gupta [debayan.gupta@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will introduce students to a wide array of data structures, mechanisms of analysis, along with when and how to use them. This will involve some heavy implentation work. Students will:

  • Learn about the wide variety of data structures available and how they can completely change how we approach problems.
  • Design and analyze nontrivial algorithms using these structures.
  • Solve recurrences and learn standard graph and sequence algorithms; they will also apply their knowledge of how to write simple proofs of correctness from prior courses.
Learning Outcomes

Outline:

  1. Algorithmic Thinking, Peak Finding
  2. Asymptotics and a crash course in complexity, including competetive analysis
  3. Insertion Sort, Selection Sort, Merge Sort, Sorting Lower Bounds, Counting Sort, Radix Sort
  4. Arrays and Lists, Stacks and Queues
  5. Heaps, Heap Sort, Fibonacci heaps
  6. Binary Search Trees, BST Sort, dynamic optimality
  7. AVL Trees, AVL Sort
  8. (Optional) Red-Black trees, Zip-trees
  9. Direct access array, Hashing (including both SUHA and Universal hashing)
  10. Quadtrees
  11. Breadth-First Search (BFS), Depth-First Search (DFS), Topological Sort
  12. Single-Source Shortest Paths Problem, Relaxation Algorithms
  13. Bellman-Ford, Dijkstra, dynamic graphs
  14. Union Find, self-organizing lists
  15. Optimizing for the memory hierarchy
  16. Persistent structures
  17. Geometry (maps, database tables)
  18. Strings
  19. Integers
  20. Succinct and sublinear structures
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

I will provide links and other reading materials in class. Students do not need to buy any textbooks.

Grading Rubric

There will be 6 homework assignments (with the best 5 out of 6 being counted), along with 2 exams.

  • 40% homework
  • 30% first exam
  • 30% second exam

Homework assignments must be submitted on time. Late submissions will not be accepted.

Attendance Policy

I do not take attendance in class - you snooze, you lose! Missing an exam for any reason will result in a zero.

Introduction to Machine Learning [CS-1390] [CS-1390-1]

Faculty Name
Raghavendra Singh [raghavendra.singh@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Coverage:

Supervised Learning Algorithms:  Logistic Regression, Neural Networks, Decision Trees, Nearest Neighbour, Support Vector Machines, Naive Bayes. ML and MAP estimates. Bayes’ Optimal Classifier. PAC learnability and generalisation. Introduction to Graphical Models. Generative Vs. Discriminative Models. Unsupervised learning algorithms: K-Means clustering, Expectation Maximization, Gaussian Mixture Models, Graph-cuts and spectral methods. PCA and Feature Selection.  Reinforcement Learning. Deep Learning: CNNs and Trnasformers. Some application areas of machine learning.

Prerequisites:

Basic proficiency in programming and data structures, probability theory and linear algebra.

Reading:

Pattern Recognition and Machine Learning by Christopher M. Bishop. Springer.

Probabilistic Machine Learning: An Introduction by Kevin P. Murphy. The MIT Press. (https://probml.github.io/pml-book/)

Learning Outcomes

Basic familiarity with Machine Learning.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prerequisites:

Basic proficiency in programming and data structures, probability theory and linear algebra.

Reading:

  1. Pattern Recognition and Machine Learning by Christopher M. Bishop. Springer.
  2. Probabilistic Machine Learning: An Introduction by Kevin P. Murphy. The MIT Press. (https://probml.github.io/pml-book/)
Grading Rubric

Mid-term: 25%, Final: 25%, Assignments, quizzes and projects: 50%

Attendance Policy

No attendance will be recorded, but 100% attendance will be expected. It will be difficult to cope if classes are missed.

There will be no accommodation for missed in-class tests and quizzes.

Introduction to Critical Thinking [CT-0001] [CT-0001-1]

Faculty Name
Krittika Bhattacharjee [krittika.bhattacharjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The Introduction to Critical Thinking course is grounded in the building of proficiency through focussed attention on the basic tasks that develop a critical mind: reading, writing, speaking, listening. It considers these vital acts – of reading a text closely, of making connections between different subjects, of participating in an ongoing conversation, of being discerning about source material – as essential habits that can be strengthened through repetition. The course provides space in which you can engage with a variety of source materials and understand how to ask questions that extend and enrich your understanding -- of situations, texts, institutions and people. It is also intended to be an induction into the distinct practices of academic research and writing within a university. By the close of the course, you will have a keener sense of your own processes of learning, thinking and writing, and a more robust sense of what it means to be ‘scholar’ in an active knowledge community constituted by your peers.

Learning Outcomes

Reading:

1. Breaking down texts into identifiable parts.

2. Making patterns and connections across texts

3. Building reading stamina and the ability to select texts

4. Understanding textual context, genre and source material

Writing 

1. Developing the craft of outlining, revising, editing

2. Applying form, voice, style, tone to affect writing

3. Developing logical, coherent, structured writing

4. Using explanatory, narrative and justificatory writing

Thinking

1. Practising converting thoughts into words

2. Narrowing down a curiosity or thought into a question

3. Constructing and developing a reasoned argument

4. Engaging meaningfully with multiple perspectives

Speaking,Listening

1. Aiming for confidence, clarity, coherence 

2. Practising and harnessing audience engagement 

3. Developing active and respectful listening to others 

4. Engaging meaningfully with ongoing discussions

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

You do not need to have any specific kind of training in order to do an ICT course. Nor is any ICT course geared towards preparing you specifically for a career in a particular subject or field. Rather, you can expect it to guide you in transition out of how you approached academic work in school to how you might approach it in a university setting, and to sharpen your understanding of what it means to be critical, questioning and deliberate in your approach to the world. 

 

ICT is writing-intensive. You can expect to work on longer assignments (the Mid-Term and the End-Term essays) over multiple rounds of feedback, as well as shorter assignments through the semester. You will also need to rehearse regular habits of reading (of academic texts and wider materials) and responding (to prompts, or given materials).Finally, as the ICT is a small cohort-oriented course, you can expect it to have a strong participation and interaction component, and can expect to work on projects both individually and in collaboration with your coursemates. 

Grading Rubric

The ICT will be graded on a number of elements. Your final assessment will account for your participation and performance in writing and non-writing components, and in formative work (building towards a bigger piece, or continuing a specific ‘habit’) and summative work (producing a final output). 

 

The weightages for these components are below. 

 

1. Participation (in classes, meetings and peer work)

2. Regular Assignments 

3. Presentation 

4. A mid-term assignment of 700 words involving the synthesis of multiple sources

5. An end-term academic essay of 1500 words

6. Improvement over the course

A standard Ashoka rubric will be used in your eventual ICT grade, wherein the highest possible grade is ‘A’ and the lowest possible grade is ‘F’.In general, grades in the ‘A’ range demonstrate that you have consistently exceeded the expectations of the course; grades in the ‘B’ range indicate that you have met the expectations for the course; grades in the ‘C’ range and below, demonstrate that you have fallen short of the expectations for this course

Attendance Policy

For this course, you are allowed three unexcused absences (for which you do not need permission from the instructor) and two excused absences (for which you do need permission from the instructor). The penalty for any absence beyond these five will be decided by the ICT instructor on a case-by-case basis. Please note that a consistent pattern of non-attendance may include discretionary penalties such as grade cuts.

 

If you are absent, the responsibility for making up for what has been missed -- by looking at class notes and/or speaking to classmates -- is yours. The responsibility for finding out about any homework that has been set for future classes is yours too.

Introduction to Critical Thinking [CT-0001] [CT-0001-20]

Faculty Name
Varun Andhare [varun.andhare@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In this Introduction to Critical Thinking (ICT) course, we will examine a number of Hindi films from the years 2000 to 2010, drawing connections between the cinema and Indian society (inasmuch as Bollywood’s audiences can be constituted) to explore with a critical mind the habits of writing, reading and the practices and ethics of research for undergraduate students.

We will view Bollywood as an entry-point into the political economy and social milieu of Indian society at the turn of the millennium, employing a cultural studies-based framework to introduce students to practices of critical thinking. Simultaneously, the course will also foreground film-viewing as a social activity and incorporate the many delights of watching these films as a community into its pedagogy.

The attraction of the 2000s is twofold here: first, it plays on the nostalgic turn in contemporary culture, especially Hindi film and its discourses online, to re-examine some of the major films of the period as historical texts. Secondly, the various inflexion points the period experienced in the trajectories of both Hindi cinema, Indian politics, society and technology offer the opportunity to investigate each of these aspects anew within our current moment. The multi-modal nature of Indian film culture – its music, dance, and various contexts of consumption, for instance – offers a distinct opportunity to foster a multifaceted and interdisciplinary approach towards the curriculum, playing to the advantages of a mixed student cohort. By the close of the course, you will have a keener sense of your own processes of learning, thinking and writing, and a more robust sense of what it means to be ‘scholar’ in an active knowledge community constituted by your peers.

Learning Outcomes

Reading:

1. Breaking down texts into identifiable parts.

2. Making patterns and connections across texts

3. Building reading stamina and the ability to select texts

4. Understanding textual context, genre and source material

Writing 

1. Developing the craft of outlining, revising, editing

2. Applying form, voice, style, tone to affect writing

3. Developing logical, coherent, structured writing

4. Using explanatory, narrative and justificatory writing

1. Practising converting thoughts into words

3. Developing active and respectful listening to others 

4. Engaging meaningfully with ongoing discussions

The attraction of the 2000s is twofold here: first, it plays on the nostalgic turn in contemporary culture, especially Hindi film and its discourses online, to re-examine some of the major films of the period as historical texts. Secondly, the various inflexion points the period experienced in the trajectories of both Hindi cinema, Indian politics, society and technology offer the opportunity to investigate each of these aspects anew within our current moment. The multi-modal nature of Indian film culture – its music, dance, and various contexts of consumption, for instance – offers a distinct opportunity to foster a multifaceted and interdisciplinary approach towards the curriculum, playing to the advantages of a mixed student cohort. By the close of the course, you will have a keener sense of your own processes of learning, thinking and writing, and a more robust sense of what it means to be ‘scholar’ in an active knowledge community constituted by your peers.

Learning Outcomes

Reading:

1. Breaking down texts into identifiable parts.

2. Making patterns and connections across texts

3. Building reading stamina and the ability to select texts

4. Understanding textual context, genre and source material

Writing 

1. Developing the craft of outlining, revising, editing

2. Applying form, voice, style, tone to affect writing

3. Developing logical, coherent, structured writing

4. Using explanatory, narrative and justificatory writing

Thinking

1. Practising converting thoughts into words

2. Narrowing down a curiosity or thought into a question

3. Constructing and developing a reasoned argument

4. Engaging meaningfully with multiple perspectives

Speaking,Listening

1. Aiming for confidence, clarity, coherence 

2. Practising and harnessing audience engagement 

3. Developing active and respectful listening to others 

4. Engaging meaningfully with ongoing discussions

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

You do not need to have any specific kind of training in order to do an ICT course. Nor is any ICT course geared towards preparing you specifically for a career in a particular subject or field. Rather, you can expect it to guide you in transition out of how you approached academic work in school to how you might approach it in a university setting, and to sharpen your understanding of what it means to be critical, questioning and deliberate in your approach to the world. 

 

ICT is writing-intensive. You can expect to work on longer assignments (the Mid-Term and the End-Term essays) over multiple rounds of feedback, as well as shorter assignments through the semester. You will also need to rehearse regular habits of reading (of academic texts and wider materials) and responding (to prompts, or given materials).Finally, as the ICT is a small cohort-oriented course, you can expect it to have a strong participation and interaction component, and can expect to work on projects both individually and in collaboration with your coursemates. 

Grading Rubric

The ICT will be graded on a number of elements. Your final assessment will account for your participation and performance in writing and non-writing components, and in formative work (building towards a bigger piece, or continuing a specific ‘habit’) and summative work (producing a final output). 

 

The components are below. 

 

1. Participation (in classes, meetings and peer work)

2. Regular Assignments 

3. Presentation 

4. A mid-term assignment of 800-1500 words involving the synthesis of multiple sources

5. An end-term Academic essay of 1500 - 2500 words

6. Improvement over the course

A standard Ashoka rubric will be used in your eventual ICT grade, wherein the highest possible grade is ‘A’ and the lowest possible grade is ‘F’.In general, grades in the ‘A’ range demonstrate that you have consistently exceeded the expectations of the course; grades in the ‘B’ range indicate that you have met the expectations for the course; grades in the ‘C’ range and below, demonstrate that you have fallen short of the expectations for this course.

Attendance Policy

For this course, you are allowed three unexcused absences (for which you do not need permission from the instructor) and two excused absences (for which you do need permission from the instructor). The penalty for any absence beyond these five will be decided by the ICT instructor on a case-by-case basis. Please note that a consistent pattern of non-attendance may include discretionary penalties such as grade cuts.

 

If you are absent, the responsibility for making up for what has been missed -- by looking at class notes and/or speaking to classmates -- is yours. The responsibility for finding out about any homework that has been set for future classes is yours too.

Introduction to Critical Thinking [CT-0001] [CT-0001-22]

Faculty Name
Sidharth Singh [sidharth.singh@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In this course, you will develop, across the length of a semester, a discursive answer to a simple yet fundamental question: what is poetry? Our collective endeavour will not be limited to the interpretation of individual poems but will include determining the ways by which satisfactory answers to such a question can be figured out. In the process we will devise methods to reliably identify and study the fundamental constituents of any poem. Two such constituents, for example, are language and mind, and so we will explore ideas in the philosophy of these objects to develop an acceptable answer to our question.

As we progress, you will learn and practice via exercises some elementary techniques from logic, and bring them to bear on basic ideas about the nature and philosophy of art. This [logic, arts] framework will also necessitate a collective exploration of human nature (since explanatory thinking and artistic creation remain distinctly human properties, without discussing human nature questions such as ours remain a mystery). Other fixed aspects of the course include lectures on the philosophy of scientific methods and their convergence, distinction from—and use for—questions in the arts; group discussions on the interpretation of poems; discussing relevant scholarly essays from the syllabus; identifying, giving analysis and justifications for literary qualities in isolated sentences, among other activities.

You will find that typical academic activities will follow naturally for you to develop an answer. These activities include practicing relevant modes of thinking and analysis; navigating citations and bibliographies; organizing your thoughts by writing essays; and relying on peers for aid and discussion. In large part, however, the trajectory of the course will be decided by collective student effort and the progress made in developing an answer to the stated question. To this end, the syllabus remains flexible and secondary, and is only one means for our progress in discovery and learning.       

Learning Outcomes

Can be anticipated from the overview.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Syllabus

All texts will be provided to students either as print outs in class or as PDFs before class (uploaded to a shared drive). Modules on introductory logic will not be studied via texts. As mentioned above, this is a fairly flexible syllabus with guaranteed additions. But in one way or another, we will be touching on ideas from these following texts.

Essays and Book excerpts:

Immanuel Kant – ‘What is Enlightenment’

Wilhelm Von Humboldt—Limits of State Action

William Wordsworth- ‘Preface to the Lyrical Ballads’

Samuel Taylor Coleridge—Notes on Shakespeare

John Dewey—Art as Experience

Viktor Shklovsky—'Art as Device’

Noam Chomsky—What Kind of Creatures Are We?

It will be necessary for students to read some of this material before class. However, in some cases discussions in class should suffice if one cannot read the texts.

Poems:

Mostly selections from Lyrical Ballads. Since the endeavour of this class is a general explanation of poetry, students are free to suggest poems for everyone to read.

Novel:

Mary Shelley—Frankenstein. Students will have to review this novel for their mid term assignment.

Grading Rubric

The ICT will be graded on a number of elements. Your final assessment will account for your participation and performance in writing and non-writing components, and in formative work (building towards a bigger piece, or continuing a specific ‘habit’) and summative work (producing a final output).

The components are below. 

1. Participation (in classes, meetings and peer work) 

2. Presentation 

3. A mid-term assignment of 800-1500 words.

4. An end-term Academic essay of 1500 - 2500 words

5. Improvement over the course

A standard Ashoka rubric will be used in your eventual ICT grade, wherein the highest possible grade is ‘A’ and the lowest possible grade is ‘F’.In general, grades in the ‘A’ range demonstrate that you have consistently exceeded the expectations of the course; grades in the ‘B’ range indicate that you have met the expectations for the course; grades in the ‘C’ range and below, demonstrate that you have fallen short of the expectations for this course.

Attendance Policy

For this course, students are allowed three unexcused absences (for which you do not need permission from the instructor) and two excused absences (for which you do need permission from the instructor). Unexplained absences further than this will not result in a penalty but in a meeting to discuss any underlying reasons for lack of participation, after which a suitable action may be decided.

Prison Literature [CT-2332] [CT-2332-1]

Faculty Name
Nazish Ashraf Mir [nazish.mir_ga@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The intimate relationship between prison and literature is as old as the institution of confinement: writers are incarcerated, prisoners become readers and writers, and the supposedly free frequently  imagine incarceration. In this course we will explore the relationship between the literary and the carceral: Why do people write in prison?Why do people write about prison? Why should we read these narratives? These writings have often been valued as counter histories or for the political significance they hold. But what happens when we read these narratives as literature? What does a literary framework do that other disciplines of engagement cannot? How does the literary framework enhance the socio-political importance of these writings but also what are some of the ethical constraints that come with its association with the literary and how does it challenge the limitations of literature itself? We will read some of the prison writings of the twentieth century from across the globe and think through these questions. Some of the writings we will look at are Behrouz Boochani’s No Friend but the Mountains, Sinan Antoon’s Ijaam, Naguib Mahfouz’s Karnak Cafe, Mohamedou Ould Slahi’s Guantanamo Diary, Elias Khourey’s Yalo, Chester Himes’s Cast the First Stone and Varavara Rao’s Captive Imagination.

Narrativizing Death [CT-2415] [CT-2415-1]

Faculty Name
Pia Bakshi [pia.bakshi_ga@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The course asks the question: 
What about death makes it hard to see through one’s own biases, prejudices, contradictions, and ambivalences? This seminar will study how former colonial powers instrumentalize the affective absolutism of death to introduce ambivalence into the history of colonization even as, on the surface, they appear to gesture towards accountability and reparations. We will particularly be looking at how individual and collective deaths connected to India’s colonial experience are remembered in the present moment by the erstwhile coloniser. We will be close-reading life-writing by Indian sepoys who participated in the First and Second World Wars, Queen Elizabeth II's obituaries, and journals published by Raj-nostalgic British associations and visiting colonial cemeteries, museums, and memorials to see how narratives of mourning, martyrdom, and sacrifice support the circulation of ambivalence into colonial discourse. A considerable faction of the world still believes that colonialism was entirely beneficial for the erstwhile colonies even in the present moment of postmemory or countermemory, revisionist histories, oral histories, broadening of the archives, an intermingling of disciplines, and decolonisation of canon and knowledge. The seminar asks how that is possible. How is conscience managed? And how does mourning relate to it? Through the study of the specific context of India's colonial discourse, the seminar opens ways to think about how ambivalence of death feeds the present political discourse in the world with dangerously communal/racial undertones where wars, terror attacks, and martyrdom are all narrativized in fixed contexts to further specific ideologies.

Introduction to Creative Writing [CW-1001] [CW-1001-1]

Faculty Name
Sumana Roy Ghosh [sumana.roy@ashoka.edu.in] ,Pratiti Sarkar [pratiti.sarkar_ug24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In the introductory course, students will meet genres—the poem, the short story, the essay, the letter, the interview, graphic fiction, the memoir—and also try to overcome the limits of the genre. They are expected to write in at least three genres of their choice.

Reading for Writing [CW-1005] [CW-1005-1]

Faculty Name
Saikat Majumdar [saikat.majumdar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

How does one capture in English lives that are not lived in English? That is one of the defining challenges for the writer for whom English arrives as a literary language as a legacy of colonialism and globalization in contexts beyond the Anglosphere. In this course, we shall watch the paths taken by others who have grappled with this question, reading a selection of English fiction, poetry, and nonfiction by writers from sub-Saharan Africa, south Asia, the West Indies, and other possible locations on the globe where English co-exists with other indigenous and creolized languages. We will then turn to our own experience and discuss the possibilities before us as writers and translators who work with English as a medium of literature, with the chaos of many tongues around us.

The Craft of Writing: Fiction [CW-2014] [CW-2014-1]

Faculty Name
Amitabha Bagchi [amitabha.bagchi@ashoka.edu.in] ,Daya Atreya [daya.atreya_asp24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The purpose of this course is to facilitate the growth of the student as a creative writer with a focus on narrative fiction. The course will focus on the elements of the fiction writer’s craft. Grounded in the three basic elements—character, setting and narrative—the course will help students better understand the various aspects of language in the writing of prose fiction from a practitioner's point of view. The course will be writing intensive. Writing assignments will include, but not be limited to, short pieces of fiction, reports on close readings of assigned texts, and peer evaluations. Students will also be expected to engage in workshop-like discussions.

CourseTitle: Craft of Writing - Flock, Flight, Form: The Bird and the Essay
description:
Craft of Writing - Flock, Flight, Form: The Bird and the Essay [CW-2402] [CW-2402-1]

Faculty Name
Sumana Roy Ghosh [sumana.roy@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Is there any relation between the bird, its life and behaviour, and the form of the essay? In reading a selection of essays by writers – from across literary and linguistic cultures, and of various disciplines and persuasions – on the relationship between birds and race, cities, gender, art, history, the aesthetic, and, of course, the scientific, we will try to understand how the form of the essay might derive from the bird’s habit and habitat.

 

Students are expected to write two essays related to but not limited by the subject of the course.

English Communication [CWC-0002] [CWC-0002-1]

Faculty Name
Jyotirmoy Talukdar [jyotirmoy.talukdar@ashoka.edu.in] ;

Statistics for Economics [ECO-1400/ CS-1207] [ECO-1400/ CS-1207-3]

Faculty Name
Tanya Jain [tanya.jain@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is compulsory for all Economics Majors, PPE as well as Economics Minor. This course introduces students to the probability and statistical methods necessary for the study of economics at the undergraduate level. In particular, the course will cover random variables, probability distribution, joint probability distribution, interval estimation and hypothesis testing.

Learning Outcomes
  1. The course will introduce students to the statistical method, viz., deducing the characteristics of a population from observing characteristics of a sample. The main objective of the course is to convey to the students why we need to understand statistics for scientific inference.  
  2. This will introduce students to the concept of random samples, random variables, their distributions which will be needed to move from properties of a sample to that of an underlying population. This will be preceded by a quick recap of probability theory.
  3. The second half of the course will introduce students to methods of statistical inference, testing the significance of sample characteristics.

Students will be given problem sets regularly throughout the semester for practice.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

1.Ross, Sheldon M.2004.   "Introduction to Probability and Statistics for Engineers and Scientists", Third Edition, Elsevier Press. (Ross, henceforth)

2. Peck, Roxy, Olsen, Chris and Devore, Jay. 2012 "Introduction to Statistics and Data Analysis", Fourth Edition, Brooks/Cole Cengage Learning (POD, henceforth)

3. We will also refer to Ross, Sheldon. A First Course in Probability, 8th Edition. (Ross 2, henceforth)

Other material, including online resources, might be introduced during the class, but those would be optional.

Grading Rubric

Student grades have four components: final exam (50% weightage), first mid-term  (20% weightage),  second mid-term exam (20% weightage), and the total score in all problem sets combined (10% weightage).

The final exam would be a  2-hour assessment on the entire syllabus.

The syllabus for the first and second mid-term exams will be announced in class and on AMS. 

Attendance Policy

You can miss 8 classes over the semester with no penalty and no justification. If you miss 9 classes, you will be downgraded one grade (e.g. if your final grade was B, you would be given B-). If you miss 10 or more, you get an F.

Attendance during mid-term exams and final exams is compulsory, or else you'll be marked 0 in that exam, no exam will be re-taken.

The Ashoka grading scheme:
 A/A- letter grade = outstanding. Students know the mathematical techniques and have the ability to apply them in novel problems.
 B+/B/B- letter grade = good. Students have expertise in most of the mathematical techniques taught in the course. They may lack creativity in problem solving but are well trained to do well in any mathematical or applied course.
 C+/C/C- letter grade = adequate. Student knows enough. If s/he tries to revise the course content, s/he shall do well in any application of the course content.
 D+/D/D- letter grade = barely satisfactory. Student knows little. S/he requires guidance and then s/he would be able to apply the courses’ concepts.
 F letter grade = unsatisfactory. Student knows less than 40% of the course content. S/he has not achieved the minimum standards for this course.

Microeconomic Theory I [ECO-2101] [ECO-2101-5]

Faculty Name
Ratul Lahkar [ratul.lahkar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The course is designed to impart an understanding of the fundamental principles of microeconomic theory. Microeconomics studies the decision-making mechanism of individual participants in a market economy. The course will help the students understand the principles and rationale underlying the decision-making processes of consumers and producers in a market economy. 

Learning Outcomes

This course covers the fundamental principles of microeconomics, and illustrates how they apply to decision-making.  It has the following learning outcomes.

1. Understand decision making by consumers as they seek to maximize their utility given constraints imposed by prices and income.

2. Understand decision making by producers as they seek to minimize their cost of production.

3. Understand the interaction of consumers and producers in market environments like perfect competition and monopoly.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Primary Textbook: Intermediate Microeconomics by Hal Varian (8th edition).

Secondary Textbooks:

Microeconomics by Besanko and Braeutigam (B&B) (4th edition). 

Microeconomic Theory: Basic Principles and Extensions by Snyder and Nicholson (S&N) (11th edition). 

Grading Rubric

Grading will follow the rubric given in the academic handbook. The grading components are

Homework: 20%; Midterm exam: 40%; Final Exam: 40%. The final exam will not be cumulative although we will be using concepts learnt earlier in the course.

Attendance Policy

None

Macroeconomic Theory I [ECO-2201] [ECO-2201-1]

Faculty Name
Piyali Banerjee [piyali.banerjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is compulsory for all Economics, PPE, and Economics Minors.

This course takes the student to the next level of macroeconomics after the introduction s/he would have obtained in the Introductory course of the first year. The lecture notes will examine the determination of income, unemployment, price level, interest rates, and exchange rates in the economy. Piece-by-piece, we construct a 3- equation theoretical model (IS-MR-PC) that describes how each of these variables is determined in both the long-run, medium-run, and short-run through the aggregate demand and the aggregate supply. After the model is completed, we investigate business cycle theory, foreign trade, and macroeconomic policy issues. Special attention will be paid to current developments on these issues. We will also work on advanced macro models.

Learning Outcomes

Students will obtain a thorough and complete understanding of major macroeconomics and macroeconomic model issues at the intermediate level.

Overview

The course is dedicated to understanding causes and consequences of underdevelopment and how societies can move and have moved from being underdeveloped to being developed. Economic History of Modern India [ECO-3504] [ECO-3504-1]

Faculty Name
Pulapre Balakrishnan [pulapre.balakrishnan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is a course on the economic history of modern India, conventionally dated as the period 1757 to the present. It aims to introduce the student to economic change in the country. It locates the Indian economy within the world economy and dissects how that relationship has evolved over time. As contesting perspectives exist, students are exposed to them all. The course commences with a study of colonial economic policies and the impact they had on India's economy. In this section students read the work of major historians. The course then moves on to a study of the evolution of India's economy since 1947, taking the student through the Nehru era, the Indira Gandhi years, the reforms of 1991 and economic performance under the Modi government. In this section the students read the work of leading Indian economists. The topics covered will include the colonialisation of India's economy, the 'de-industrialization' debate, land tenure legislation and its enduring consequences, famines and the Raj, colonial institutions, the origins of modern industry, the Nehru era as a watershed, planning, the Green Revolution, early liberalisation moves, '1991', the high-growth phase 2003-08, the Modi years and the impact of COVID-19.

The course is structured as follows. It will start with lectures to be delivered by me. These will be followed by class presentations by the students arranged in groups, with the topics and groups to be formed by them. The major part of a presentation session will be the presentation itself. It will then be commented upon by another group during the session.

Students will receive guidance in the choice of topics for the presentation and the associated reading material.

The topics for the presentations shall be chosen by the end of the fourth week. There will be penalty for delay. Those presenting early on shall be given some bonus marks.  

Learning Outcomes

The objective of the course is to expose the student to the evolution of the economy over the last two and a half centuries, dissect the economic policies that have been implemented at various stages and sift the evidence so that he or she is able to form an understanding of the economic history of India on their own. With this, it is expected that by the end of the course, students will be equipped to form a critical judgment of much of the economic history of India.

Discussion will be encouraged in the lectures and is expected at the presentation. However, timely reading is expected when taking advantage of the opportunity given. 

  

 

 

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Essential reading

1. India under the East India Company

Irfan Habib (1977) “The Colonialisation of the Indian Economy”, ‘Social Scientist’, 3: 23-53.

2. The De-industrialisation Debate

Amiya Bagchi, A. (2010) 'Colonialism and the Indian Economy', Delhi: OUP.

Tirthankar Roy (2000) "De-Industrialisation: Alternative View", 'Economic and Political Weekly', 35: 1442-7.

3. Famines 

S. Ambirajan (1976) "Malthusian Population Theory and Indian Famine Policy in the Nineteenth Century", 'Population Studies', 30: 5-14.

T. Halder (2023) "Colonialism and the Indian Famines", https://developingeconomics.org/2023/02/20/colonialism-and-the-indian-famines-a-response-to-tirthankar-roy/.

T. Roy (2023) "Colonialksm did not cause the Indian famines", https://historyreclaimed.co.uk/colonialism-did-not-cause-the-indian-famines/#_edn5.

4. Institutions of the Raj

Lakshmi Iyer (2015) “The Long-Run Consequences of Colonial Institutions”, ín L.Chaudhary, B.Gupta, T. Roy and A. Swamy, ‘A New Economic History of Colonial India’, London: Routledge.

5. The British Economy and the Indian Empire

Aditya Mukherjee, A. (2010) "Empire: How Colonial India Made Modern Britain", 'Economic and Political Weekly', 45: 50: 73-82.

8. Early Independent India: 1950-65

Pulapre Balakrishnan (2010) ‘Economic Growth in India: History and Prospect’, Chapter 2.

9. The 'Leftward Lurch': 1967-1979

Pulapre Balakrishnan (2010) ‘Economic Growth in India: History and Prospect’, Chapter 3.

10. Gaining Momentum: The Eighties

Rodrik, D., and A. Subramanian, A. (2005) ‘‘From ‘‘Hindu Growth’’ to productivity surge: The mystery of the Indian growth transition", 'IMF Staff Papers", 52(2), 193–222.

11. The Reforms of 1991 and after

Pulapre Balakrishnan (2017) "Markets, growth and social opportunity: India since 1991”, 'Economic and Political Weekly', 52(2): 49-54.

Amartya Sen (1997) “Beyond Liberalisation: Social Opportunity and Human Capability”, Lakdawala Memorial Lecture.

Nagaraj, R. (2017) “Economic reforms and manufacturing sector growth: Need for reconfiguring the industrialisation model”, ‘Economic and Political Weekly’, 52(2): 61-68.

13. After 2014

Pulapre Balakrishnan (2019) "Unmoved by stability: Capital Formation in the Modi Economy", 'Economic and Political Weekly', 54(30): 33-6. 

Pulapre Balakrishnan (2022) 'India's Economy from Nehru to Modi: A brief history', Ranikhet: Permanent Black.

Panagariya, A. (2020) ‘India Unlimited: Reclaiming the Lost Glory’, HarperCollins Publishers, India.

Reference Books:

R.C. Dutt (1902, 1904) 'The Economic History of India', Volumes 1 and 2, London: Kegan Paul.

Dharma Kumar and M. Desai 'The Cambridge Economic History of India', Volume II, Cambridge University Press.

This is a reading list for the lectures. Readings for the class presentations will be announced when the topics themselves are chosen by the student groups. 

Two books on India's economy post-1947 published this year are 'Reform Nation' by Gautam Chikermane, HarperCollins (2023) and 'India is Broken: A people betrayed' by Ashoka Mody, Stanford University Press (2023). 

All material listed here will be available via the University.

Grading Rubric

 

I. Class presentation: 35 marks. This comprises 25 marks for presenting a chosen paper and 10 marks for commenting on a presentation made by another group. Final exam: 65 marks. 

II. The following interpretation of the grading scheme to be adopted may be noted:

· A, A–   Excellent quality and full mastery of the subject.  A grade of A means extraordinary distinction.

· B+, B, B– good comprehension of the course material, a good command of the skills needed to work with the course material, and the student’s full engagement with the course requirements and activities.

· C+, C, C– adequate comprehension of the course material and the skills needed to work with the course material. indicates the student has met the basic requirements for completing assigned work and participating in class activities.

· D+, D, D– barely satisfactory work indicating minimal command of the course materials and minimal participation in class activities.

· F -unsatisfactory and unworthy of course credit towards the degree.

 

Attendance Policy

Attendance is not compulsory at the lectures but is expected at the class presentations.

No food or drink other than water to be consumed in class.

Office Hours: Wednesdays 5-7, Room 805 AC4.

Urban Economics [ECO-3605] [ECO-3605-1]

Faculty Name
Lalit Hemant Contractor [lalit.contractor@ashoka.edu.in] ,Lakshmi Adithi Bumanapalli [lakshmi.bumanapalli_asp24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The decision of where to locate is essential for both business and individuals. It determines the profits of firms through the cost of inputs, market size, the level of competition, and the policy environment they face. It also determines the job opportunities, schooling, and other amenities accessible to individuals. In turn, firm and individual decisions aggregate to determine the performance of cities and regions.

This course studies business and individual location decisions and how they determine the main economic forces (agglomeration economies) that lead to the existence and performance of cities and
regional agglomerations. The course starts by developing a simple theory of cities (the monocentric city model) and its implications for density, city size and housing prices. We will study the internal structure of cities by introducing the key notion of spatial equilibrium, and then evaluate the effects of land use policies, different means of transportation and infrastructure and housing policies on land and housing values. We shall also consider spatial equilibrium across a region using the framework of Rosen and Roback.

We shall also briefly consider the empirical literature that seeks to test some of the theories developed. Other topics that will be covered, time permitting, include urban governance, urban growth and decline and more
local aspects such as neighbourhood choice and gentrification. Finally, the course will analyze cities in the developing world, and conclude with recent advances in the field.

Learning Outcomes

Students should gain an understanding of the forces that drive the formation of cities and the patterns of location and prices within cities. They should be familiar with the basic models and empirical approaches developed for these purposes, that should provide a conceptual framework for thinking about topics in the field.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Lecture slides and links to reading materials shall be provided on the course website.

I shall base the lecture materials on the text, 'Lectures on Urban Economics' by Jan Brueckner (MIT Press/Prentice Hall India). I shall also draw upon the text, 'Urban Economics and Fiscal Policy' by Holger Sieg (Princeton University Press).

Grading Rubric

Grades shall be based on the following components: problem sets, a midterm, a policy proposal on a relevant topic in urban economics, and class participation.

Attendance Policy

None

Health Economics [ECO-3650] [ECO-3650-1]

Faculty Name
Aparajita Dasgupta [aparajita.dasgupta@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is an introduction to the field of health economics. Health economics is an active field of microeconomics with a large and growing literature and is an important aspect of public policy. The purpose of the course is to understand the microeconomic foundations of health economics and to introduce students to some key research questions and methods in health economics. The course further aims to develop an understanding of a variety of econometric techniques and research designs used by applied microeconomists focusing on causal inference to critically evaluate key research papers in health economics.

 

The course will cover topics such as measurement and determinants of health, health disparities, relationship between health and economic development, the need for financial risk protection against health shocks, the determinants of fertility and demographic change, economics of nutrition and human capital formation, behavioural insights in health, health and gender, economic evaluation of health and health programs.

Economics of Gender [ECO-3660] [ECO-3660-1]

Faculty Name
Bipasha Maity [bipasha.maity@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course aims at undertaking an economic analysis of the issues affecting women in the economy. The discrimination faced by women in market scenarios, such as those of labour and credit as well as the impact of globalization on women will be studied. Further, the course will explore issues that women face in non-market situations such as bargaining within the household, marriage and fertility and how market and non-market scenarios interact to influence women's well-being. Lastly the roles of education, healthcare, property rights, birth control, political franchise and representation in mitigating gender-based inequalities will be studied. Students would be able to understand and appreciate both market and non-market factors that result in or promote gender based inequalities. They would also be able to critically understand why some policies succeed while others may fail to mitigate gender-based inequalities. Microeconomics I and Econometrics at the undergraduate level are pre-requisites for this
course.

Quantitative Techniques [ECO-5011] [ECO-5011-1]

Faculty Name
Mihir Bhattacharya [mihir.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is a compulsory course for MA Economics, which will provide the students the mathematical tools and techniques required for quantitative economic analysis in all sub-fields of economics. A basic knowledge of calculus, vector space and algebra will be required.

Learning Outcomes

Students are expected to have an in-depth knowledge of mathematical tools required for other fields within economics: Microeconomics, Macroeconomics and Econometrics. Some of the topics covered include existence of solutions to systems of linear equations using rank of a matrix, linear independence of vectors, basis of a set of vectors, span of a set of vectors, matrix algebra, determinants, Cramer’s rule, Inverse of a matrix, eigenvalues, properties of eigenvalues, etc. Differentiation and Optimization: derivatives, chain rule, directional derivatives, higher-order derivatives, implicit functions, system of implicit functions, quadratic forms, definiteness of quadratic forms, unconstrained optimization: FOC, SOC, local max/min, global max/min, constrained optimisation:equality constraints, inequality constraints, constraint qualification, homogeneous functions, concave/convex functions, quasi-concave/quasi-convex functions, concave programming, Weierstrass’ theorem, Lagrange's method, Kuhn-Tucker conditions, Slater's condition, etc.

Note that the list of topics is not exhaustive and the full course outline will be shared in class. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Main Textbooks:
1. Simon and Blume's “Mathematics for Economists” , Norton (1994)
2. Sundaram's "First course in Optimization Theory” (Cambridge University Press,
1996)

Other textbooks: 

Linear Algebra, G. Hadley, Addison-Wesley Publishing Co. (1977)
The Theory of Linear Economic Models, David Gale, University of Chicago Press (1960)
Introduction to Real Analysis, Robert G Bartle, and Donald R. Sherbert. New York: Wiley (2000).

Mathematical Methods and Models for Economists, Angel de la Fuente, Cambridge University Press (2000).

and below. These thresholds may be relaxed at the discretion of the faculty in a Pareto improving manner (for the students) based on difficulty levels of exams.

Advanced Macroeconomics [ECO-6201] [ECO-6201-1]

Faculty Name
Lalit Hemant Contractor [lalit.contractor@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course builds on the methods and concepts introduced in Macroeconomics I and II. The aim of this course is to learn: 1) recursive competitive equilibrium models that feature individual heterogeneity, with some coverage of firm level heterogeneity too ; and 2) how to solve numerically for the equilibrium of these economies. These models are helpful to analyze a wide range of questions pertaining to business cycles, income distribution, asset pricing etc. The course will start with a discussion of aggregation with heterogeneous agents. It will then consider the benchmark of complete markets and tests of the same, after which it will lay the foundations for models of incomplete markets, emphasizing the precautionary saving motive. These strands will coalesce in the canonical standard incomplete markets model of Bewley-Aiyagari-Huggett. The last set of lectures shall discuss extensions of the standard incomplete markets model, economies with heterogeneous firms, and conclude with a brief introduction to heterogeneous agent New Keynesian models.

Learning Outcomes

The main goals of this course are to expose students to questions and methods at
the research frontier, discuss a variety of open questions in this area that can lead
to research papers (or a dissertation), and equip students with the tools necessary to
tackle these questions.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Experimental Economics [ECO-6610] [ECO-6610-1]

Faculty Name
Swagata Bhattacharjee [swagata.bhattacharjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Experimental methods have been widely adopted by economists to develop new insights, it is the fastest-growing research methodology in economics. This course will be an introduction to experimental economics, its methods, and some of the major subject areas that have been addressed by laboratory experiments. Substantive areas of application in the course will include market equilibrium, individual decision-making, risk and uncertainty, strategic interactions, learning in games, public good provision, and labor market relationships. Additional topics will include field experiments in development economics.
 

Learning Outcomes

By the completion of the course the students should be able to do the following:
1. Understand and explain the principles behind experimental economics.
2. Recognize an original economic question and design a suitable experiment to address the question.
3. Conduct laboratory experiments using the software zTree.
4. Analyze experimental data to obtain results.
5. Evaluate the literature critically and determine what important elements may be missing that could lead to future research.
 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Textbook:
1. Handbook of Experimental Economics by Kagel and Roth (editors). Princeton University Press. ISBN
069104290-X.
2. Market, Games and Strategic Behavior by Charles Holt.
3. Experimental Methods by Friedman and Sunder.
4. Software to be used: zTree. Ref: Fischbacher U. (1999). Zurich toolbox for readymade economic
experiments, experimenter’s manual. Working Paper No. 21. Institute for Empirical Research in Economics, University of Zürich.
The textbooks are not required but highly recommended for providing background for several sections of the course. However, the course will mostly involve reading papers, to be uploaded on AMS/ moodle.

Introduction to Literary Theory [ENG-1002] [ENG-1002-1]

Faculty Name
Mandakini Dubey [mandakini.dubey@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The field of English is shaped by literary theory, through its profound engagements with big questions of reality, language, identity, power, desire, history – most broadly, the self and the world. When studying literature, we often seek out ways of uncovering the workings—and play—of these engagements in the texts we read. This course turns to the questions and answers posed by theory itself, rather than applications through the reading of literary texts.

Theory can seem complex and intimidating, but its questions are fundamental: how do we make meaning? How do we constitute texts, and how do texts constitute us? How are we to know those parts of ourselves that refuse knowledge? How do our bodies, our given identities and the material conditions of our lives shape who we are and how we feel, think, act, desire, and read? Keeping these and other basic questions in mind, this course will survey the key approaches and texts of contemporary literary theory.

Introduction to Literary Theory [ENG-1002] [ENG-1002-3]

Faculty Name
Alexander Robert Phillips [alexander.phillips@ashoka.edu.in] ,Ila Manish [ila.manish_asp24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

“Theory,” from the perspective of literary studies, designates an open-ended category of writings ranging from literary criticism to philosophy, sociology, and linguistics, to name a few. In this course we will have the opportunity to read a selection of texts that others in the community of literary scholars have found particularly helpful for thinking through some of the problems that crop up in our studies of literature and culture. We will become acquainted with the intellectual projects of authors whose names circulate frequently (Marx, Freud, Foucault, Butler, et. al.), but those people are by no means the be-all and end-all of theory. Rather, “theory” is simply a shorthand for a wide-open corpus of material: anything that helps us to speak, think, and write about literary texts and other cultural phenomena could be called theory. As such, what we call theory may go on and on, but the semester does not, so to lend sense and stucture to our investigations we will organize this class around a set of “big questions,” not the least of which is, “what is theory and what is it good for?” Instead of pursuing the impossible task of a comprehensive overview of theory, in this class we will work on the practices of reading theory, such as identifying arguments, key concepts, and getting comfortable with the idiomata of theory. Doing so will provide us a basis for further theoretical exploration and pointing us in new directions for our writing.

description:
Introduction to African-American Literature: A Literary Introduction to Antiracist Thought [ENG-2322] [ENG-2322-1]

Faculty Name
S Satish Kumar [s.kumar@ashoka.edu.in] ,Aayilah Ahmad [aayilah.ahmad_asp24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In keeping with the spirit of Toni Morrison’s famous collection of lectures from which this course derives its title, we will be mapping an evolution of Antiracist thought in the United States of America. Our exploration of this historical, ideational and experiential landscape will begin with the earliest literary and cultural expressions by Black American writers in the movements towards Abolition, through the Reconstruction and the ensuing battle for Civil Rights. Our journey will conclude in the present moment with readings that frame the Black Lives Matter movement in terms of an ongoing struggle for dignity, equity and justice faced by Black peoples in the United States—a nation that continues to be systemically hostile in radically racist ways.

CourseTitle: Introduction to Rhetoric: Rhetoric of Social Protest
description:
Introduction to Rhetoric: Rhetoric of Social Protest [ENG-2360] [ENG-2360-1]

Faculty Name
Subhasree Chakravarty [subhasree.chakravarty@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Have you ever wondered what Arab Spring, Occupy Wall Street, MeToo and the Tea Party have in common? Not much, you might think. On the contrary, quite a lot. Even when they are vastly different from each other in politics, whether left or right-wing, radical or conservative, highly organized or very diffused, they are all examples of social movements.

It is quite likely that you are often asked to tweet, friend, like or donate for some social cause. That is because social movements are propelled by the rhetoric and politics of emotions. It is true that intense emotions like those of anger, fear, disgust, love, empathy or grief are habitually invoked for social mobilizations and persuasion by most populist leaders. To study rhetoric and social movement therefore, is to study how dissent from poor and working-class people, women, people of color, LGBTQ activists, the disabled, immigrants, and other incompatible voices, come together in diverse ways to aid in building justice.

Postcolonial Literatures [ENG-3001/ ENG-5301] [ENG-3001/ ENG-5301-1]

Faculty Name
Subhasree Chakravarty [subhasree.chakravarty@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What is the relevance of reading postcolonial literature in contemporary classrooms? Do we still define ourselves through the category of the colonial subject and/or postcoloniality? Is it redundant to do so?  This course begins with such questions but moves beyond, to read certain postcolonial literary texts as not only physically rooted in material spaces – often poor, “backward,” and non-modern spaces – but also examine how they embody the spirit of such locations, often untranslatable and un-exportable.

CourseTitle: Studies in World Literature: Myth, Literature, and Africa in the World
description:
Studies in World Literature: Myth, Literature, and Africa in the World [ENG-3352] [ENG-3352-1]

Faculty Name
S Satish Kumar [s.kumar@ashoka.edu.in] ,Nupur Mahajan [nupur.mahajan_asp24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course seeks to explore the ostensible tensions that have historically existed and continue to do so, between what Chinua Achebe famously described as “An Image of Africa” and the plural experiential realities of the peoples and nationalities across Continental Africa. We will be working towards a sense of Afrocentric literary and cultural historiographies starting with perceptions of “Africa” and “Africans”. Beginning around “late antiquity”, through the Enlightenment and leading into the colonial enterprise, such “images” of “Africa” have not only dominated a Eurocentric imagination, but also formed the basis for the subjugation and despoliation of African peoples. Through readings of African mythologies, oratures and early colonial literatures, this course seeks to both problematize and deconstruct dominant Eurocentric discourses about “Africa” that continue to endure in our “global” imaginations.

CourseTitle: Studies in Film: Bollywood and Gender
description:
Studies in Film: Bollywood and Gender [ENG-3411] [ENG-3411-1]

Faculty Name
Geetanjali Chanda [geetanjali.chanda@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Bollywood and Gender aims to provide a brief and schematic history of Bombay cinema, focusing particularly on issues of gender and culture. The course aims to see how particular historical moments stimulate ­­specific ideologies especially of Indianness and awareness of gender identity. As we explore the hidden ideologies of gender, nationalism and sexuality that are embedded in apparently innocent entertainment we will also learn to read a text/film that will empower us to interpret, challenge and change mainstream norms. You will never watch a Bollywood film the same way again!

Learning Outcomes

To explore the main themes and ideologies in Bombay cinema

To be able to read a film closely

To examine gender in Bollywood cinema

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Attendance Policy

Attendance is mandatory and will impact your final grade. You may miss 3 classes during the semester without penalty.  After three absences, a letter from your final grade will be deducted for each missed class. If you have 3 unexcused absences, I will reserve the right to fail you for the course.  Coming more than 5 minutes late to class will count as an absence.

Reading Feeling [ENG-4314] [ENG-4314-1]

Faculty Name
Mandakini Dubey [mandakini.dubey@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What do we feel when we read, and how do we read feeling? This seminar thinks (and feels) about nineteenth-century novels through affect theory. Apart from considering emotions as interior and personal, we will think through the ways in which feelings are material, social, and political, and ask what feelings have to do with gender, class, and sexuality; places and times; bodies and minds. Many theorists of affect explore it as a way of thinking through interconnection and in-betweenness rather than essence; the keywords that emerge include force, intensity, flux, becoming. The Victorian novel, organised around intense sympathies, allows us to trace large forces that register as minute states of feeling, and to think about how genres of literature intersect with approaches to emotion. This is a reading-intensive seminar; we will spend time with theorists including Eve K. Sedgwick, Silvan Tomkins, Brian Massumi, Lauren Berlant, and Sara Ahmed; and literary works by Jane Austen, Walter Pater, Thomas Hardy, George Eliot, and Henry James, among others.

Children’s Literature [ENG-4330] [ENG-4330-1]

Faculty Name
Geetanjali Chanda [geetanjali.chanda@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What we read as children forms who we become and provides our first world view. This course provides an opportunity to critically assess the stories that shaped our understanding of morals, culture, and values, as well as those we will impart to future generations. In this discussion-oriented interactive course, we will read and review children’s books, examine the purposes of visual literacy, and write reviews on specific authors and illustrators. We will write our own children’s book to gauge all that we have learnt.

This course aims to examine how the books children read shape their outlook and emotional development. We will study the historical, creative, nurturing, emotional, and educational aspects of these forms of literature and their impact on us later in life. We will also consider why a study of children’s literature is important, and how it impacts pedagogies for children across borders.

            We will examine the views of multiple theoretical thinkers and texts in conjunction with actual children's literature. We will ask the important but often overlooked questions about this particular genre, mainly focusing on Indian and Western children’s literature. The purpose is not so much to compare these two cultural offerings, but to give us a taste of both. 

            We shall consider popular stories for children up to 12 years old, including Harry Potter & The Philosopher’s Stone, Amar Chitra Katha, Matilda, The Little Prince, Feluda and Mulan. At the same time, we will also study theoretical thinkers such as Jack Zipes, Seth Lerer, Paulo Freire, and Bruno Bettelheim to help us navigate the complex field of children’s literature in relation to issues of culture, religion, difference, gender, and sexuality.

We will unpack the didactic intent as well as the pleasure principle that might have prompted the writers. Authorial intent is, however, only one part of our study; the other part is to see how children and parents receive these stories. Children’s literature creates moral as well as national frameworks that help acculturate young people. In examining the genre of children’s literature, we will consider various sub-genres such as picture books, fairy tales, fables, and chapter books. 

Learning Outcomes

To understand the politics, purpose and utility of chlldren's Literatiure.

To familiarize ourselves with the theories  behind children's Literature.

To write our own children's book as a hands on experience.

To learn to critique various children's stories - including our own. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

For all readings that are written in the syllabus on a particular date: you should have completed your reading before that day’s class. 

Please note that supplementary readings may be assigned during the course of the semester. The syllabus and most readings are available electronically and can be viewed or downloaded on the Ashoka University server.

Below are the primary readings which you must have ordered before hand. Other readings, especially picture books, can be seen in the library or online. 

Rushdie, Salman. Haroun and the Sea of Stories. London: Penguin (1990). 

de Saint Exupery, Antoine. The Little Prince [Translated by Richard Howard] (2000).

  Dahl, Roald. Matilda (1988). 

Chandra, Nandini. The Classic Popular: Amar Chitra Katha (1967-2007), Yoda Press (2008).

Lal, Ranjit. The Battle for No.19, Penguin India (2007).

Ray, Satyajit. The Mystery of the Elephant God.

Ruskin Bond: The Room on the Roof (1987)

Attendance + Class Participation   : 5%

Oral Class Presentations (primary and theory): 10%

Visual Literacy project                      : 10%

Disney Blog (begin in-class)           : 15%

Mid-term paper                                   : 30%

Final paper                                            : 30%

Attendance Policy

Attendance + Class Participation (5%): Attendance is mandatory and will impact your final grade. You may miss 3 classes during the semester without penalty.  After three absences, a letter from your final grade will be deducted for each missed class. If you have 3 unexcused absences, I will reserve the right to fail you for the course.  Coming more than 5 minutes late to class will count as an absence. Participation in-class discussions are an essential requirement. This means listening as well as responding and reacting to the ongoing discussions about the readings. Your ability to raise issues and questions that occurred to you while you read the texts demonstrates your attention to the readings. You must complete the assigned readings by the day before so you come prepared to discuss in class. (E.g. – You must be prepared to discuss the readings listed for Tuesday, September 6 on that day. So you should have completed these readings by Monday, September 5 at the latest).
 

The Visual Literacy Project. (10%) Due on the 9th September by 11:45 PM.

(Note: The Visual Literacy Project and Disney-blog will be explained in class!)

Class Presentations (10%): Presentations can be done individually or in pairs. One or a pair of students will present in every class beginning September 15. Demonstrate how selected theoretical ideas apply to specific texts. Identify main points in the theoretical readings and show their practical application to a primary text. How does the theory help us read the primary text.

You can pick any of the texts chosen for the class or do your own research to bring in a text that is meaningful to you.

We are looking for your ability to understand the theoretical text and communicate the same effectively. 

Each student will have a time limit of 5 minutes. If you work in a pair though you will get 10 minutes.

Midterm Creative Assignment: The midterm assignment is due on the 16 October 2023. You are required to create your own children's book. This should include cover (with illustrations). Illustrations can be part of the whole book. (20%)

Please supplement this with a 1-2 pages critique that will comment on your authorial intention, the illustrations, plot, message, etc. (10%) Total= 30%

Film Blogs (begin in class) (15%) – Compare any 2 film styles – either 2 Disney films or 1 Disney and 1 Gibley studio. It would be good to focus on a general idea through specific examples of films.

Final Paper (30%): The final paper is due on the 4 December 2021 by 11.50 PM.  This should be a 3000-3500 words academic paper. You will be asked to formulate your own essay questions. We shall brainstorm the formulation of questions in class.

Please note – All written work should be submitted in ‘google docs’ format and submitted on Google Classroom. Please use only word format, 1.5 spacing.

General Classroom Policies

Please switch off your cell phone before coming to class. Please limit external distractions – especially for online classes.

Walking in and out of the session to get a drink of water, answer the phone or go to the restroom etc. are extremely disruptive and disrespectful to all. Please note that this is counted in your evaluation for class participation.

Late submissions will not be given credit, all submissions should be made on time. You already have the dates for submissions of papers.

Creativity and Design Thinking [ENT-1004] [ENT-1004-1]

Faculty Name
Ekanto Ghosh [ekanto.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Priyank Narayan [priyank.narayan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sagar Singhal [sagar.singhal@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

It is often said that “Today, thinking is more important than knowing”. Opportunities are what
we all look for and their counterparts—the problems—are what we should solve in daily
lives. Dynamic environment of twenty first century requires more creative skills from citizens
than just analytical skills to manage in the ever-changing work environment.

The course is designed to provide an understanding of problem solving with a touch of
creative focus in a systemic framework. The students will be introduced to concepts of
creative thinking like convergent and divergent thinking, lateral thinking and
brainstorming.

Structured techniques such as 6 thinking hats and mind maps will also be practiced.
Students will be expected to work on live projects to come up with creative Jugaad solutions
to problems that they see around them. Concepts around creativity such as the Medici Effect
will also be discussed in class through book readings.

Creativity _ Design Thinking - Priyank Narayan (2).pdf

Fundamentals of Marketing [ENT-1011] [ENT-1011-1]

Faculty Name
Ekanto Ghosh [ekanto.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Priyank Narayan [priyank.narayan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sagar Singhal [sagar.singhal@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sushil Jhangiani [sushil.jhangiani@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is designed to teach you the fundamentals of marketing keeping in mind an entrepreneurial context. The course assumes no knowledge of marketing, and moves from the basics of defining and capturing value and understanding consumers to key marketing concepts such as segmentation, targeting and positioning, and then culminates in the in-market execution of positioning using a synergistic mix of product development, pricing management, communication and in market execution. The course also looks at brands, brand strategy and brand equity and their impact on consumer value and brand strength. We will look at marketing theory, but with a strong application bias. As we seek to understand how to market products and services, we will reflect on and learn from our experiences as customers and how we are impacted by marketing. TO get the most out of this course, you will be well served by relying on your experiences as a consumer, and for keeping your eyes open and observing other customers as a marketer

description:
Business Analysis and Strategy [ENT-2011] [ENT-2011-1]

Faculty Name
Akhil Dhawan [akhil.dhawan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Ekanto Ghosh [ekanto.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Pavan Ahluwalia [pavan.ahluwalia@ashoka.edu.in] ,Priyank Narayan [priyank.narayan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sagar Singhal [sagar.singhal@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sanjay Kukreja [sanjay.kukreja@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What differentiates a good business from a mediocre one? How do you evaluate the quality of an industry and how can it change over time? Does a particular market entry plan, strategic plan or acquisition make sense? What tools do analysts, consultants, investors or industry professionals use to examine and gain insights into a business opportunity or problem? The goal of this course is to provide students with tools and concepts that have real-world applicability in understanding and addressing business situations. The content is designed to bring frameworks and methods used in today’s workplace into the classroom. Whether you choose to pursue a career in consulting, banking, investing, corporate strategy, or journalism, this course will provide you with a foundation that will allow you to analyze a business or an industry situation. By the third session of this course, students will be assigned to teams of 3 (or 4, depending on class size) to begin work on their projects for a Business Crackathon. The projects will address a specific business agenda from the real world, such as: (i) “After completing the Just Dial transaction, should Reliance consider acquiring Nykaa or another listed company?,” or (ii) “Shoppers Stop is evaluating a strategic reset and needs advice,” or (iii) “The Birla Group wants to restructure their portfolio for the next five years – what should stay and what should go?”

The Power Of Execution [ENT-2031] [ENT-2031-1]

Faculty Name
Ekanto Ghosh [ekanto.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Priyank Narayan [priyank.narayan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sagar Singhal [sagar.singhal@ashoka.edu.in] ,Vineet Gupta [vineet.gupta@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What is common among all the ventures that went big? What is common among all the entrepreneurs that became high profile? What is common among all the ideas that turned unicorn? One word - Execution. Designed exclusively for young and aspiring entrepreneurs, this transformative set of six sessions equips you with the essential frameworks and mindset to flawlessly execute your ideas. From strategic planning to effective decision-making, you'll dive into the art of turning dreams into reality. Learn from industry experts, and unlock the secrets to efficient implementation. This course is for you if you are looking to set yourself apart as a true game-changer in the business world.

Political Ecology of Food [ES-2442/ SOA-2505/ POL-2112] [ES-2442/ SOA-2505/ POL-2112-1]

Faculty Name
Amita Baviskar [amita.baviskar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Good to Eat, Good to Think: What does food tell us about ourselves, others, and the world? In essence, food is a way of fulfilling a biological need—nutrition—within an ecologically and culturally defined context.  At the same time, it is a medium for expressing one’s sense of self in relation to a changing world of ideas and institutions.  This course examines the cultural and political ecology of food from the farm to the plate, looking at the connections between the well-being of land-based resources and human and non-human living beings.  It provides an understanding of changing agrarian systems and how access to food intersects with existing structures of social inequality.  It explores how ethics and emotions, science and religion, nature and culture, shape contemporary food systems.

There are no prerequisites for this course.

Learning Outcomes

*  to appreciate the diversity and complexity of food ecologies and ideologies

*  to understand the long-term political-economic processes shaping food practices

*  to analyse contemporary food practices in terms of unequal social causes and impacts

*  to reflect on the connections between personal action and planetary welfare

*  to develop an interpretive frame that can be applied to understand and address issues around food justice and sustainability

*  to carefully read, critically appraise, and concisely write from a social science perspective

Grading Rubric

Attendance: 10%

Attendance in the lectures is compulsory.  To show that you have prepared for the lecture, you have to post one analytical comment or question (not more than 100 words) about the assigned reading or film. You must submit a minimum of 10 comments during the course.  They should be posted before 9 am on the day of the lecture and will be visible to the entire class after that. These will not be graded, but will count towards your marks for class attendance.

Short assignment: 15%

You will be asked to write two short notes (400 words each) on topics drawn from the readings. This assignment tests your grasp of the concepts and themes discussed in the course.

Mid-term exam: 25%

You will be asked to write a short (800 words) essay responding to a question handed out by the professor. The question will invite reflection on the readings of the previous weeks.

PPT presentations: 20%

You will form pairs and prepare a 10-minute presentation on an assigned topic.

Final Paper: 30%

You will be asked to write a final essay (1500 words) on some aspect of the political ecology of food that we have discussed in class. Students will be expected to relate two or more texts in the syllabus to their chosen topic.

description:
Environmental Studies [FC-0102] [FC-0102-2]

Faculty Name
Mitul Baruah [mitul.baruah@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is meant to introduce students to nature-society dialectics. We will examine the historical, social, and political processes that shape societal relations with the natural environment. The course has three overarching goals. First, it will help students gain an in-depth understanding of some of the pressing environmental issues of our times, such as the agrarian crisis, climate change, disaster and vulnerability, waste, the industrial food system, struggles over water, and neoliberalization of nature, among others. Second, drawing on a variety of theoretical frameworks, including Marxist, feminist, and post-structuralist perspectives, the course will expose students to a breadth of approaches to environmental questions. Finally, through this course, I hope to be able to cultivate a sense of environmental citizenship in students. The course will be taught using a combination of lectures, discussions, films, and group projects.  

 

Learning Outcomes

At the end of this course, you will think of "Nature" differently, and your relationships with and approaches to the environment, local and global, will change.     

Grading Rubric

Attendance and Participation: 20% (10% for lectures, 10% for DS)

Quizzes: 20%

Essays: 40%

Group Project: 20%
