description:
Quantitative Reasoning and Mathematical Thinking [FC-0306] [FC-0306-1]

Faculty Name
Mihir Bhattacharya [mihir.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The course will begin with pre-requisite tools of quantitative thinking vis-a-vis the number system, set theory, logic, probability and statistics. We will then learn how to use some of these tools to study (i) fairness in division of scarce resources, (ii) collective decisions in committees and democracies around the world (voting methods), and (iii) how to act optimally in competitive social interactions, i.e. game theory. By the end of the course, students would have a basic understanding of the most widely used mathematical tools in the liberal arts. They will learn how to approach different economic problems- by reducing them to their bare essentials (via modeling) and to mathematically analyse their underlying structural and logical patterns.

Learning Outcomes

Some topics include the following: Sets, Logic, Probability and Statistics, Functions, Fair division, Weighted voting, Voting methods, Economic reasoning, rationality, Game theory.

Students will be able to think quantitatively and mathematically across various disciplines and applications. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Mathematics for Liberal Arts Majors, Christopher Thomas, Schaum’s outline series, McGraw Hill, 2008

Games of Strategy, Avinash Dixit, David H. Reiley (Jr.) and Susan Skeath, W.W. Norton & Company (2009) (or Viva Books, 2017, Indian edition).

Other notes and papers will be shared in class.

Grading Rubric

There will not be any exams, but there will be continuous grading. Grading will be done on the basis of assignments and quizzes (60%), and presentations (30%). Active class participation is encouraged (including responses to other presentations) and will be accounted for in grading (10%). Relative grading with thresholds decided at the end of the semester based on how the groups are distributed. Those below 40% marks of the total score will receive F.

Attendance Policy

Attendance is compulsory. Students with more than 7 absences will be penalized, and more than 10 absences will be penalized with multiple grade cuts.

Overview

This is a foundation course in Quantitatve reasoning and Mathematical thinking. Mathematics is considered the queen of all Sciences and Number theory is the queen of all Mathematics. In this course, we shall explore the foundations of Number Theory and its applications to the areas of Cryptography and primality testing.

Learning Outcomes

Prime numbers, divisibility and primes, prime factor decomposition, Euclidean algorithm, Sieve of Eratosthenes, Infinitude of primes, Proof by induction/proof by contradiction, Modular arithmetic, Fermat's Little Theorem, Polynomials and modular arithmetic, Cryptography and RSA Algorithm are the some of the topics that will be covered in the course.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

We shall follow relevant sections of 'Primality testing for beginners' by Lasse Rempe-Gillen and Rebecca Waldecker, AMS Student Mathematical Library Vol. 70.

Students will be expected to solve problems in class (in groups of 2-3) almost every Thursday and each problem solving session will contribute towards the final grade. There will be a final project report as well. More details will be announced in the first lecture.

September 7,14,21,28; October 5,26; November 2,9,16,23

description:
Mind and Behaviour [FC-0503] [FC-0503-2]

Faculty Name
Bittu R [bittu@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will introduce you to questions of mind and behaviour and their relationship to the brain and body, and will encourage you to think critically and scientifically through your own ideas around these relationships. In this course we will try to understand ourselves, the people and animals around us, and all the ways in which our interactions produce learning. We will explore the specific question of how we learn, how we absorb and retain new material, the ways in which our brains tend to conflate correlation and causation, how we make decisions, and what critical thinking means. We will take a look at complex and interesting phenomena such as motivation, emotion, language, consciousness and attention. We will think through inter individual behavioural differences and what kinds of evidence we require to draw conclusions about group behaviour.

Learning Outcomes

Every conversation, every memory, even your reading of this course outline, structurally and functionally changes your brain, but not everything that the brain processes seems to make it to the realm of conscious perception. We will think about various seemingly intangible aspects of the mind and try to imagine how to make sense of them. We will focus on the limitations of what we collectively understand and the ways in which we might imagine advancing our collective knowledge about the mind and behaviour. The goal of the course is to provide you with the tools with which to ask these questions and begin answering them.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Every week of the course comes with specific readings. Soft copies of all readings are up on Canvas and will be made available students in the week that they are relevant.

Grading Rubric

30% Midterm Assignment

30% Final presentation

20% Quizzes: 4 quizzes: 5% each

20% Participation: 10% DS attendance, 5% DS participation, 2% class participation, 3% class attendance

 

This class will have at least four quizzes over the duration of the semester, all open book. The idea behind this is to keep providing conceptual testing to enable you to check the soundness with which you have understood the material. There will be no testing requiring rote learning or simply checking familiarity with information.

Your participation in class will count towards 20% of your grade: 10% is for attendance and 5% for participation in the discussion section; 2% is in terms of class participation (questions in class will be counted, as will engaging on Canvas, by email, if you have any anxieties around participating while class is ongoing) and 3% is your attendance counted as part of your participation grade.

Attendance Policy

Attendance: will be marked as a component of the participation grade, but not as a barrier to doing exams, etc. Three unexcused absences are permitted. Missing class is a student’s loss and will impact the class participation grades. For students who miss class for unavoidable reasons, they can visit the TF, during office hours for help. All those who are unable to attend classes due to medical reasons are requested to email the TAs  (and cc'd to the TFs, but please not to Bittu!), with a copy of their medical note or prescription (with the date clearly mentioned) along with their emails, for an excused absence.

WeekDays: Tuesday, Thursday, Thursday, Thursday, Friday, Friday
Faculty: kathleen.harbin@ashoka.edu.in, jasmine.kaur@ashoka.edu.in, jasmine.kaur@ashoka.edu.in, kathleen.harbin@ashoka.edu.in, jasmine.kaur@ashoka.edu.in, jasmine.kaur@ashoka.edu.in, jasmine.kaur@ashoka.edu.in, jasmine.kaur@ashoka.edu.in
description:
Mind and Behaviour [FC-0503] [FC-0503-4]

Faculty Name
Jasmine Kaur [jasmine.kaur@ashoka.edu.in] ,Rachel Kathleen Harbin [kathleen.harbin@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Is the essential nature of the mind its capacity to reason, to behave in certain ways, to feel, to grasp certain aspects of the world? This course explores the nature of the human mind and what it can tell us about ourselves and our place in the world. We will consider whether the operations of human minds are fundamentally different from those of animals and from various forms of artificial intelligence, whether the mind is identical with physical or brain processes or instead is something else over and above the material world, whether our minds enable us to make choices that are truly free or rather only to channel the influential forces in our environment, and what the nature of our minds implies about how we should live and treat each other.  

Grading Rubric

Weekly Quizzes (15%) 
Discussion Section Participation and Activities (10%)
Midterm Exam (20%)
750 Word Paper (15%)
1,000 Word Paper (20%)
Final Exam (20%) 
Optional Extra Credit Assignment: Peer Review of 1,000 Word Paper Draft (5%)

Attendance Policy

Attendance is required. Students are expected to complete course readings relevant to each class before it takes place and to participate in class discussions. Participation in discussion informed by course readings is crucial to achieving a thorough understanding of course material and to developing critical and analytical skills. Attending class involves being physically and mentally present for the entire class. Accordingly, any student who is more than 15 minutes late for class or who leaves class early will be counted absent, as will any student engaged in distracting activities during class (e.g. mobile phone use or carrying on private conversations). If there is an urgent reason why you need to arrive late or leave early on a given day, provide documentation of the same to the TF, and the teaching staff will consider whether the circumstances warrant an excused absence. If a class meeting is held in an online format, attending class involves being present for the entire online session with the computer camera on. Students who miss more than 5 meetings (2.5 weeks) due to unexcused absence are subject to automatic failure of the course.

WeekDays: Tuesday, Thursday, Thursday, Thursday, Friday, Friday

description:
Great Books [FC-0601] [FC-0601-3]

Faculty Name
Dilip Simeon [dilip.simeon@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sai Mukhesh Chandra Jyothula [sai.jyothula_tf@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

It is a truism that words mean something, and that they count for a great deal in life. However, the relation between thought, reality and time has always been a matter of debate. The Greek word theoria meant contemplation, the act of looking, which later acquired the sense of an intelligible explanation based on observation and reasoning. Historia meant inquiry, the search for knowledge; and it evolved over time to mean investigations and accounts of past events. Philosophia meant the love of wisdom. These words, which relate to human experience in its deepest sense, prompt my choice of great books. As to why this is so should become clear in due course.  The books are:

Simon Leys; The Hall of Uselessness: Collected Essays, (2011)

Tibor Szamuely; The Russian Tradition; (1974)

Margaret Chatterjee; Gandhi and the Challenge of Religious Diversity; (2005)

Albert Camus; The Rebel: An Essay on Man in Revolt; (1951)

Mark Lilla; The Reckless Mind: Intellectuals in Politics; (2001)

Stanley Rosen; Nihilism: A Philosophical Essay (1969)

The first three books deal (in part) with history; with what is called tradition; and the treatment of these themes in political writing and fiction. The latter three deal with philosophical issues directly. I will introduce students to these books and specify certain chapters for required reading. Their scholarship will educate us and prompt us toward further study. Some will illuminate important historical events; others will raise issues common to human experience regardless of time and place.

Dilip Simeon, PhD

Visting Professor, Ashoka University

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Aside from the specified books; an extended PDF archive of related books and articles (along with a summary of major events following the French Revolution of 1789) will be available to you for consultation; to which your professor and the teaching fellows might refer.

NB: This is a dense course of study and I advise you to opt for it if you are prepared to work hard. I will of course, be available for answering your questions, both in and after class. DS

Grading Rubric

Grading Policy: Attendance in the Discussion Sessions with your TFs is mandatory in nature and will count for 30% of your grade. This means only that your absences will count negatively. Unlike the main course, there are no permitted absences here other than for medical or other emergencies. 

The final essay will account for 70% of your final grade. 

NB: Grading policy is subject to alteration after the first class

Attendance Policy

Attendance in the main lectures is mandatory. You are permitted five absences in the semester. You do not have to inform us about your absence if the number of absences is five or less; but you must secure prior permission and provide documentation for excused absences, i.e., anything beyond five absences. If an emergency requires extended absence, you must notify the Teaching Fellows so that we can inform the Office of Academic Affairs and help you determine if you will be able to complete the course.

WeekDays: Tuesday, Thursday, Thursday, Thursday, Friday, Friday
description:
Great Books [FC-0601] [FC-0601-5]

Faculty Name
Ananya Vajpeyi [ananya.vajpeyi@ashoka.edu.in] ,Hari Haran [hari.haran_tf@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

GREAT BOOKS: LEARNING TO READ SOUTH ASIA

In this Foundation Course, students will read 8-10 books that are essential for an introduction to the humanities in India. These books give a sense of the long history, the many languages and cultures, the diverse religious and philosophical traditions, as well as the social and political complexity of South Asia.

The books assigned will be taken from a long-list of 14 (for 14 weeks of the semester). A list of assigned books, as well as supplementary and recommended readings will be provided closer to the start of the semester. The Argumentative Indian (2005) by Amartya Sen will serve as the backbone of the course. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The longlist of 14 is below: 

The Edicts of Ashoka / Romila Thapar 

Selections from Arthashastra / Kautilya 

Selections from Baburnama

Selections from Ardhakathanak / Banarasidas

Hind Swaraj or Indian Home-Rule / M.K. Gandhi

The Home and the World / Rabindranath Tagore

Short Stories / Saadat Hasan Manto 

Taking Issue and Allah's Answer / Mohammed Iqbal 

India: A Wounded Civilization / V.S. Naipaul

Walking with the Comrades / Arundhati Roy

One Part Woman / Perumal Murugan 

Baluta / Daya Pawar

The Intimate Enemy / Ashis Nandy

Tughlaq / Girish Karnad

Grading Rubric

Students will be marked for preparation (5%), class participation (10%), weekly quizzes (15%), tutorials with the TF (15%), half-term exams (20%) and final assignments (35%). 

Students needing a leave of absence must take prior permission and submit a medical certificate (if applicable). Anyone with less than 80% attendance will have to take an incomplete. 

Attendance Policy

Attendance is mandatory. Coming to class with the assigned portion read in advance is mandatory. 2 Teaching Fellows (TFs) will conduct weekly tutorials for smaller groups of students.

Students may meet the professor by appointment. Days and venue for office hours will be posted.

GREAT BOOKS 2023 SYLLABUS.docx

description:
Literature and the World [FC-0701] [FC-0701-5]

Faculty Name
Saikat Majumdar [saikat.majumdar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

FC/ LITERATURE AND THE WORLD

Is it possible to imagine a body of world literature in a single language? How did British colonialism shape a global terrain of colonial modernity? How did that modernity merge with Anglo-American globalization of the twentieth and twenty-first centuries? How did this create the reality of the Anglophone/Anglographic world, and how did it turn English into a language of world literature? This course seeks to examine the transnational trajectory of this diverse and diffuse body of writing, including work from spaces with vastly different histories – the colonies in sub-Saharan Africa, the Caribbean and South Asia, and the hard-to-classify context of South Africa.

WeekDays: Tuesday, Thursday, Thursday, Thursday, Friday, Friday
description:
Principles of Science [FC-0801] [FC-0801-3]

Faculty Name
Vidya Dnyaneshwar Avasare [vidya.avasare@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

A scientific viewpoint to understand the world started from Democritus (c. 460-c.370 BC), a Greek pre-Socratic philosopher who first coined the term atom and atomic theory Plato was an Athenian philosopher and founder of the academy, Platonist School of Thought, the first institution of higher learning in the western world. Platonism proclaims the existence of abstract objects associated with the physical world meaning, sets, numbers, etc. Aristotle a student of  Plato's Academy in Athens (c. 347 BC) contributed to science enormously. Philosophical issues related to scientific discovery are closely related to philosophical ideology and perception that arise through observation and curiosity.  During the modern era of scientific discoveries Antoine Lavoisier ( A father of Modern Chemistry), John Dalton, Michael Faraday, Dmitri Mendeleev, etc. developed scientific theories and based on those theories, today’s technological discoveries are happening at a great pace. The inspiring stories of seminal discoveries, understanding of scientific concepts are necessary to develop a  right scientific temperament and to change our problem-solving approach.

This course covers the following important topic which are necessary in developing a strong foundation to understand fundamental chemistry because chemistry is everywhere and in everything!

The course comprises the following topics

Background: Ancient chemistry and development of modern chemistry

Basic organic chemistry: chemical reactivity and understanding a logic of bond breaking and bond formation in organic reactions.

Chemistry in nature: Medicinally important small organic molecules

Periodic table: Discovery, development, and logic

Electrochemistry: Redox reactions and their applications

Chemistry for sustainability: Current global issues and possible approaches to address these issues

Learning Outcomes

Student will be able to explain

  • Basic concepts of organic chemistry
  • Logic and science behind the development of the periodic table
  • Basic concepts of oxidation and  reduction 

Student will be able to expand the fundmental knowledge of chemistry to address the queries not from other branches of the  natural sciences, humanities and social sciences.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The reading material will be shared after the commencement of  the classes.

Grading Rubric

Three Assignments: 30 %

Mid-term assessment: 25%

End-term assessment: 25%

Seminar presentation /review writing: 20%

Attendance Policy

Minimum 80%

Attachment
FC0801_POS-3_Chemistry.pdf

Financial Markets and Institutions [FIN-3002/ ECO-3207] [FIN-3002/ ECO-3207-1]

Faculty Name
S K Shanthi [sk.shanthi@ashoka.edu.in] ,Gaurav Agarwal [gaurav.agarwal_asp24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will enable students to understand the role of financial markets and institutions in shaping the economic and business environment of the nation. With the help of some simplifying frameworks and models, the students will be equipped to develop a series of applications of principles from finance and economics that explore the connection between financial markets, financial institutions and the broader economy. Students will learn how the term structure of interest rates, stock and derivative market developments and currency fluctuations drive the financial flows. Students will study the role of financial institutions such as central banks, commercial banks, investment banks, insurance companies and mutual funds in facilitating the flow of funds in the economy. Keynesian IS-LM theory and the loanable funds theory provide the theoretical background for the course and help students develop simple analytical frameworks to study the interaction of individuals, firms, governments, markets, financial institutions, and the aggregate economy. The students will get an introduction to the role of regulation in the overall functioning of financial markets and institutions in the economy.

Learning Outcomes

Upon finishing the course, students are expected to:

  • show the drivers the term structure of interest rates.
  • explain how investment banks and mutual funds operate.
  • discuss the stock valuation based on fundamental analysis.
  • read a bank’s balance sheet and discuss how risks are managed in banks.
  • grasp the basic features of options and futures and understand how they play out in the financial markets and by various institutions.
  • know the role and impact of the Central bank as the main regulator in the domestic and international currency markets.
  • grasp the fundamentals of regulatory practices in the stock markets and the insurance markets.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Main Text book:

Frederic S. Mishkin, Stanley G. Eakins, Tulsi Jayakumar and R. K. Pattnaik, Financial Markets and Institutions. Pearson India Education Services Pvt. Ltd. Eighth Edition 2017

Papers will be assigned during the course for classroom presentations

Grading Rubric

Mid-term exam 50%

End-term Paper 20%

Class presentations during the semester 20%

Attendance 10% - 80% mandatory attendance. Every 1% deficit in attendance will invite a 1% penalty in marks.

Letter grades to be based on the University’s guidelines

Obsession with grades is strongly discouraged

Attendance Policy

Attendance 10% - 80% mandatory attendance. Every 1% deficit in attendance will invite a 1% penalty in marks.

Advanced Persian 1 [HIS-1015] [HIS-1015-1]

Faculty Name
Nadeem Aktar [nadeem.akhtar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

 

Course Description
Advance Persian Courses are meant for Ashoka students who have successfully completed two years of Introductory Persian Courses at the University. The courses are designed particularly to equip PhD students in reading and interpreting historical texts for their research.


 Classical Persian Texts and Contexts
Persian literature written before the nineteenth century differs from modern literature both in form and content. The language of classical Persian literature is replete with Arabic words and literary phrases. They also have rich literary embellishments and artistic expressions. All this makes these texts very different from modern Persian texts. This course introduces these classical Persian texts to the students. It trains them to analyse these texts from a literary point of view and to enhance their skill of reading them in their historical contexts. This course will help the students negotiate the texts, documents, and archival materials of medieval and early modern periods in their PhD research.  


Codicology 
Museums, libraries, and archives are full of Persian manuscripts and documents which are treasure houses of information and knowledge about the past. These Persian texts were written in various scripts by scribes, artists, statemen, poets, and writers. Aside from texts, there are also additional documentary material – like flyleaf, colophon, endorsements, and seals – that are useful to understand the past. Many of these texts are not legible and can be read only by experienced readers. One of the challenges of modern times is to discern these writings and make the texts legible and translate them into English or vernacular languages. Many of the manuscripts lying in archival collection are still waiting for their readers, editors, and translators. As such, they are hidden from the public domain. This course on codicology will train research students in reading these manuscripts and using them for historical and literary research.

Inscriptions
In the medieval India, the usage of Persian language was not limited to the writings of administrative documents and literature; it was also used to write inscriptions on walls of forts, tablets of mosques, tombs, and gardens. Inscriptions in Persian language also adorned many swords, knives, armours, and cannons.  Coins minted by the rulers also bear inscriptions in Persian. Museums and archives have a vast collections of such coins and artifacts. All these inscriptions comprise extremely valuable sources for historical research and can be read only by trained scholars. This course equips research students to read and interpret inscriptional records to decode the past.

 

Learning Outcomes

The course enable PhD students of History to read and understand the Persian sources 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Relevant Persian Manuscripts and sources to be used by the PhD students in their researches shall be taught in the classes. 

Grading Rubric

End Sem Exam of 100 Marks

Attendance Policy

Not more than 2 Abscences allowed

Reading Archaeology [HIS-3002] [HIS-3002-1]

Faculty Name
Kalyan Sekhar Chakraborty [kalyan.chakraborty@ashoka.edu.in] ,Niharika Nimesh Shah [niharika.shah_ug24@ashoka.edu.in] ,Uma Tara Bakshi [uma.bakshi_ug24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Archaeology is a fascinating subject that studies the ancient and modern human past through material remains. As archaeologists, not only do we solve exciting puzzles about past human behaviour using state-of-the-art techniques, but we can also help solve crucial modern-day problems. In this introductory course, we will learn what archaeology is, important archaeological methods, techniques and theories, how archaeology is portrayed in popular culture, and some of the critical roles archaeology has played in solving current issues worldwide.

Modes of Evaluation:

Weekly quiz (10%): There will be assigned readings for most of the classes and the Teaching Assistant will coordinate a short MCQ based on the readings. You should complete the reading before coming to the class and actively participate in the discussions therein.

Exam 1 (30%): A written examination for the first part comprising MCQs, and short questions. All details will be provided by the third week of October.

Exam 2 (50%): The second exam for the second part of the course will be held during class hours. All details will be provided during the third week of November.

Movie Review (10%): Due in November. As a group or individually you will be watching any popular movies, shows or documentaries based on archaeology during your midterm break. Using your archaeological knowledge, you will review the movie and discuss the misrepresentation of archaeological facts, fantasizing about archaeological data, and stereotypes associated with archaeology and archaeologists. Finally, you will discuss the positive and negative impact this show might have on a layman, and you as an archaeologist will provide a review score to the show considering how archaeology has been portrayed.

CourseTitle: The Eighteenth Century in Indian History
description:
The Eighteenth Century in Indian History [HIS-3213] [HIS-3213-1]

Faculty Name
Seema Alavi [seema.alavi@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will span from the later half of Aurangzeb’s period (end of 17th century) to the age of reforms (1820-30s). It will look at changes in economy, society and culture that shaped regions, social groups and individual careers in the period of transition to English Company rule. An important part of this course will be to move the gaze away from the state and the meta-narrative of its oppression to in- house debates and discussions in the military, legal, medical and commercial cultures that determined the course of politics in the period of transition

Grading Rubric

1. Class discussion around readings every two weeks: 25%

2. Mid semester assignment: 25%

3. End semester exam: 50%

Attendance Policy

A maximum of 5 absences throughout the semester. Absences over and above 5 will lead to grade cuts.

Attachment
Monsoon2218thCenturyinIndianHistory.docx

CourseTitle: Traders, Merchants, and Capitalists: Business History of India 1600-Present
description:
Traders, Merchants, and Capitalists: Business History of India 1600-Present [HIS-3214/ ENT-3015] [HIS-3214/ ENT-3015-1]

Faculty Name
Gaurav Churiwala Garg [gaurav.garg@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Overview

When India became independent, it was one of the few countries of the global South with a robust business class and a sizeable private sector. Did this class emerge because of colonialism or despite it? What has been role of businesses in India’s capitalist development and politics? Why are Indian businesspeople from certain communities that hail from the arid parts of South Asia? And what has been the relationship between entrepreneurship, caste, class, community, and gender in India? With these questions in mind, this course will introduce students to the main themes and issues in Indian business history from 1600 to the present. This course will equip students with a firm understanding of the long- term patterns of changes and continuity in Indian business landscape; enable them to make better sense of what is new and what is not about Indian private sector today; and help them critically analyze the discourse on and by businesses in modern India.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Course Structure and Reading:

The course is organized chronologically into 4 modules— 1600-1800; 1800-1914; 1914-1947; 1947 to Present. Each session will incorporate seminar style discussion and lectures.

Basic Texts:

Dwijendra Tripathi and Jyoti Jumanji The Concise Oxford History of Indian Business (OUP 2006).

Medha Kudaisya (ed). The Oxford India Anthology of Business History (OUP 2011).

Tirthankar Roy A Business History of India: Enterprise and the Emergence of Capitalism from 1600 (CUP 2018).

Selected Topical Readings (excerpts will be specified).

1600-1800

Prasannan Parthasarthi Why Europe Grew Rich and India did not? (Cambridge 2011).

Sven Beckert Empires of Cotton (Alfred Knopf 2014).

Sanjay Subrahmayam and Christopher Bayly “Portfolio Capitalists and the Political Economy of Modern India” IESHR 25:4

Stephen Dale Indian Merchants and Eurasian Trade (Cambridge 2009).

Ashin Dasgupta Indian Merchants and the Decline of Surat (South Asia 1994).

Lakshmi Subramanian Indigenous Capital and Imperial Expansion (OUP 1996).

Cristopher Bayly Rulers, Townsmen and Bazaars (Cambridge 1982).

Tirthankar Roy The East India Company (Penguin 2016).

Chhaya Goswami Globalization Before its Time: The Gujrati merchants from Kachh (Penguin 2016).

1800-1914

David Rudner Caste and Capitalism in Colonial India: The Nattukottai Chettiars (Berkely 1994).

Blair B. Kling Partners in Empire: Dwarkanath Tagore and the Age of Enterprise in Eastern India (KLM 1981).

Clause Markovitz The Global World of Indian Merchants, 1750-1947: Traders of Sind from Bukhara to Panama (Cambridge 2000).

Thomas Timberg Marwaris: From Traders to Industrialists (Vikas 1979).

Maria Misra Business, Race and Politics in British India 1850- 1960 (Oxford 1999).

Douglas Haynes Rhetoric and Ritual (Oxford 1992).

Douglas Haynes Small Town Capitalism in Western India (Cambridge 2012).

Rajat Ray “Asian Capital in the Age of European Domination, 1800-1914,” MAS, 29:3 (1995).

Rajat Ray “The Bazaar: Changing Structural Characteristics of Indigenous Section of the Indian economy,” IESHR 25:3, 1988.

Anand Yang Bazaar India (Berkeley 1998).

Joseph Sassoon The Sassoons: The Great Global Merchants and the Making of an Empire (Pantheon 2022).

1914-1947

Amiya Bagchi Private Investment in India 1900-1939 (CUP 1972).

Mircea Rainau Tata: The Global Corporation that Built India (HUP 2021).

Medha Kudaisya The Life and Times of G.D. Birla (OUP 2002).

Rajat Ray Entrepreneurship and Industry in India 1800-1947 (OUP 1994).

Ritu Birla Stages of Capital: Law, Culture and Market Governance in Late Colonial India (Duke 2009).

Akshaya Mukul Gita Press and the Making of Hindu India (Harper Collins 2015)

1947-Present

Vivek Chibber Locked in Place (Princeton 2003).

Nasir Tyabji Forging Capitalism in Nehru’s India (OUP 2015).

Harish Damodaran India’s New Capitalists: Caste, Business and Industry (Palgrave 2008).

Sharad Chari Fraternal Capital (Stanford 2004).

CourseTitle: China&#039s First Historian: Sima Qian and the Shiji
description:
China's First Historian: Sima Qian and the Shiji [HIS-3521/ ENG-3061/ CHI-3201] [HIS-3521/ ENG-3061/ CHI-3201-1]

Faculty Name
Eloise Wright [eloise.wright@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Sometime around 100 BCE, Sima Qian 司馬遷 (c. 145-87 BCE), a former court official and political prisoner, completed a work of history begun by his father, Sima Tan 司馬談 (died c. 110 BCE), which he called “Records of the Grand Historian” (Shiji 史記). This work set the pattern for historiography – and fictional narratives – in the classical Chinese language, a narrative form which contrasts in many ways with the norms of modern history writing. At the same time, Sima Qian dealt with many of the same questions that perplex modern historians: how do we explain causation among seemingly unrelated events? How do the circumstances of the historian’s life shape their writing? How do we understand gaps in our sources? In this class, we will reflect both on traditional Chinese historical practice and on our own. In the first part of the class, we will discuss the world into which Sima Qian was born and the kinds of historical writing that were current before his transformative work. In the second part, we will read excerpts from the Records of the Grand Historian. In the third part, we will investigate his influence on Chinese historical writing in both its official and unofficial forms. Finally, we will experiment with writing in Sima Qian’s narrative style ourselves.

Grading Rubric

Preparation for class and in-class participation: 30%

Presentations and handouts (three counted out of possible five): 30%

Mid-term writing assignment (short zhuan-style piece plus explanation): 10%

Final project: an outline or draft of a (fictional or non-fictional) history you know well, plus an interpretive essay explaining your choices and how they relate to the themes of the class (2000-3000 words total): 30%

Monsoon 2023.pdf

The Indian Ocean World [HIS-3523] [HIS-3523-1]

Faculty Name
Seema Alavi [seema.alavi@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The Indian Ocean saw people from East Asia, the Middle East, South East Asia and Europe meet and mix over many centuries. This course will look at the histories of these interactions and what they meant to world history. The many intersecting histories that constitute the Indian Ocean are: maritime studies, weather patterns and the monsoon, religious networks (Buddhist, Christianity and Islam), diasporas, and the patterns of commerce. Through an exploration of these histories the course will offer insights on the making of the Indian Ocean as a textured canvas that sustained Asian and African Sultanates in the high period of imperialism (19thcentury) which is conventionally viewed as the Ocean’s European century.  

Grading Rubric

2. Mid semester assignment: 25%

3. End-semester examination : 50%

CourseTitle: Modern Megacities in History and Theory
description:
Modern Megacities in History and Theory [HIS-3525/ SOA-3091] [HIS-3525/ SOA-3091-1]

Faculty Name
Gaurav Churiwala Garg [gaurav.garg@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The world’s largest cities evoke extreme reactions. People either hate them or love them, but they cannot ignore them. Fascinating, bewildering, and thought-provoking, megacities can teach us a lot of about our past, present, and the future. According to the United Nations, there were 33 megacities in 2018— cities with populations exceeding 10 million. What global, regional, national and local forces have combined over time— through history—to produce modern megacities? What explains their resilience, growth, diversity, and dynamism? How have megacities and its people coped with this unprecedented concentration of people and capital? What does it mean to live in such cities? Through this course, students will gain a strong footing into the world of historical, social scientific and humanistic scholarship on modern cities and urbanization. Furthermore, students will learn about the complicated dynamics between capitalism, modernity and cities; and will be encouraged to think about the relationship between history, the social sciences and the humanities.

Learning Outcomes

This is an interdisciplinary course that will introduce students to some of the most important readings and themes in the field of global urban studies and urban history. Students will read and think about the relationship between history on one hand, and sociologically and anthropologically informed qualitative scholarship on urban studies on the other. Students will be motivated to challenge and go beyond the old-fashioned but common-sensical division between idiographic and nomothetic approaches to scholarship. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

  • Logan and Molotch Urban Fortunes 
  • Rahul Mehrotra et al The Kumbh Mela: Mapping the Ephemeral Megacities

  • Gyan Prakash Mumbai Fables 
  • Charles Tilly “What good is urban history?”

  •                           Spaces of Hope
  • Georg Simmel: “The Metropolis and the Mental Life”

  • Walter Benjamin Reflections

  • Ritojyoti Bandopadhyay “Politics of Archiving: Hawkers and Pavement Dwellers in Calcutta”

  • William Cronon Nature’s Metropolis

  • Carl H. Nightingale Segregation: A Global History of Divided Cities
  • Lewis Mumford: The City in History
  • Mike Davis Planet of the Slum
  • Edward Glaser Triumph of the City

CourseTitle: Eat Like a Human: A Glimpse into Ancient Foodways
description:
Eat Like a Human: A Glimpse into Ancient Foodways [HIS-3526/ ES-3223] [HIS-3526/ ES-3223-1]

Faculty Name
Kalyan Sekhar Chakraborty [kalyan.chakraborty@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

‘You are what you eat’ is a well-known truism, but what we are and what we ate both have undergone a major transformation during the course of human evolution and recent history. The study of ancient foodways is not merely an understanding of what people ate in the past rather it’s a process of understanding the interrelation between human diet and ecological, biological, social and ideological processes. Therefore, the study of foodways can potentially provide us with sufficient evidence to reconstruct the social, cultural, political, economic, technological, and ecological aspects of ancient societies. Once regarded as a rather unexciting field of studies associated with basic subsistence, paleodietary studies have been rejuvenated in recent years by both recent advances in scientific methods and new theoretical perspectives. In this course, we aim to first understand the major shifts in human food practices, and the major theoretical and methodological advancements to reconstruct ancient diets and then how the information gathered can potentially be used to reconstruct social, political, climatic, and economic aspects of past societies and the health and wellbeing of the indigenous population practicing traditional diet.  

COURSE EVALUATION

Reading reviews (20%): Before class begins, you will submit a short synthesis (approx. 1 page single-spaced) on that week’s readings.  (10x2) = 20%

Course Project (15%+25%=40%): Each student will do an individual project on examining any aspect of human diet from an anthropological and archaeological perspective. This project can take the form of an argument, critique or even a comparison of any aspect of foodways with human culture and ancient/ethnographic societies.

20 min class presentation                  in November                          15%

Written Paper                                    in December                          25%

Mid-term (20%): A mid-term MCQ/Short Answer quiz will be held in October during the class hour. Details of the quiz will be shared prior to the quiz.

Class Participation (20%): You will have to maintain a minimum of 70% attendance. You will be leading 1 weekly classroom discussion based on both primary and secondary readings. You will be submitting a set of questions/discussion points prior to the class that will be shared with the other students to help them participate in the debate/discussion. You participation in discussion for the entire course will also be counted. 

Audit only: Audit-only students will cover 50% of the class load. They will have to maintain attendance and participation 20%, submit 5 reading responses worth 10% and give an in-class presentation/lecture worth 20%. A case-by-case basis arrangement can be made if necessary.

TOPICS WE WILL COVER

What is like eat like a human: Food beyond calories?

The gatherer-hunter-forager diet.

Origin and spread of domestication.

Beginning of agriculture.

Animal domestication and secondary revolution.

Reconstruction of food ways from ancient stone tools.

Reconstruction of foodways from archaeological pottery.

Reconstruction of foodways from ancient human remains.

Foodways and environmental ecology.

Foodways and political ecology.

Food, transhumance, and population movement.

Food, religion, and rituals.

Foodways and food sovereignty.

CourseTitle: Foundations of Modern China: The Qing Dynasty in World History
description:
Foundations of Modern China: The Qing Dynasty in World History [HIS-3535/ CHI-3205] [HIS-3535/ CHI-3205-1]

Faculty Name
Sayantani Mukherjee [sayantani.mukherjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Tuesdays & Thursdays 11.50-1.20 pm

AC04-006 TR

Sayantani Mukherjee – sayantani.mukherjee@ashoka.edu.in – AC02-339

Modern China is among the world’s two largest countries by population, two largest by economy, and its fourth largest by geographical size. As a state, it follows centuries of imperial dynasties whose complex legacies it sometimes claims and sometimes rejects. In the last two hundred years, China has experienced some of the most dramatic social and cultural transformations and some of the most violent conflicts of any region of the world. As it was incorporated into an international system dominated by Europe and the United States, it became an integral part of global history in new ways and, increasingly, a shaper of that history. Often imagined as a monolith, it is in fact deeply heterogeneous, home to multiple languages and ethnicities, countless local traditions, millions of adherents of major world religions, and sizable foreign communities. Today, China is the site of crucial questions concerning geopolitics, the environment, global health, and human rights. At the same time, it has inherited and continues to produce immense bodies of art and literature, distinctive belief systems and intellectual movements, and delicious food. In these and other capacities, it also informs the identities of millions of people of Chinese ancestry living around the world.

            This course examines the Qing Dynasty (1644-1912) and the early days of the Republic of China. It makes reference to Tibetan, Taiwanese, diasporic Chinese, and global histories as well. It offers systematic coverage of Qing expansion and crisis, Qing culture, encounters with Asia and the West, the emergence of nationalism, and the transition out of the dynastic state. In the process, it gives special attention to questions of race and ethnicity, gender, frontiers, global connections, and nation-building. It emphasizes historical thinking skills (e.g. understanding causation, contingency, agency, anachronism, meaning, and so on) and highlights the voices of historical figures, both powerful and ordinary, through translated primary sources. No prior knowledge is required.

Decolonization: An International History [IR-1006/ HIS-1801] [IR-1006/ HIS-1801-1]

Faculty Name
Pallavi Raghavan [pallavi.raghavan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Description and Objectives

In this course, we consider the different motivations that accompany the internationalist behavior of decolonized states, and whether these should constitute a separate set of categories from the norms that otherwise govern the developed world.

To begin with, we examine how the term ‘Decolonization’ is defined, along its implications for how the internationalist behavior of states is to be judged. Subsequently, we will examine how this is connected to processes of state monopolization over violence, anxieties over territoriality, and the tensions involved in creating a unanimously agreed to ‘national’ identity in different parts of the Global South.

The concluding set of readings in this course will explore how the tensions of shaping the ‘national’ are also present in governing the ‘international’. We explore how the process of constructing an argument about “Decolonization” also entails a conversation between competing worldviews. We will explore how these tensions are present in the shaping of Foreign Policy as well as “Worldmaking” and develop a fuller analysis about how these also constitute a tussle over the definitions of international norms themselves.

CourseTitle: Rise of China and the Shifting Balance of Power in Southeast Asia
description:
Rise of China and the Shifting Balance of Power in Southeast Asia [IR-2035/ POL-2102] [IR-2035/ POL-2102-1]

Faculty Name
Nayan Ranjan Chanda [nayan.chanda@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The rise of China from one of Asia’s poorest countries to the world’s second-largest economy and challenger to the United States has been dramatic. Along with China’s growing power and influence, Asia’s political landscape has also gone through a stunning transformation. The course will offer a history of international relations in Asia woven around   China’s domestic transformation and its changing relationships with its Asian neighbors, the United States and the West. Nayan Chanda, who has personally witnessed the development in Asia for over four decades as a reporter and editor of the Far Eastern Economic Review, offers an analytical narrative of the important power shift in the region.

Learning Outcomes

Research Methodologies 1 [IR-2049] [IR-2049-1]

Faculty Name
Dipin Kaur [dipin.kaur@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The Research Methodologies course seeks to equip students interested in research (specifically, through the IR ASP Program) with the skills to conduct, write, read, and appropriately critique research.

Before the start of the course, students will have submitted a 1500-word piece of writing to their assigned ASP supervisors to get their input on required reading and research materials. The course begins once this first cycle ends — we will take these proposals as our starting point and from there, we will combine your research interests with elements of good research writing. Through the course, you will learn how to identify a research question, state your motivation for conducting this research (grounded in a well-surveyed literature review that identifies an apparent lacuna), develop testable hypotheses, and specify a methodological action plan for Spring 2024. As part of this plan, you will (a) briefly survey the various methods of data collection and analysis prevalent in IR research (historical and archival analysis, conducting interviews, discourse analysis, reading regression tables) and (b) interface with faculty experts on the subject/ and your supervisors on the dissertation.

The final output of the course is a Research Prospectus of about 5,000 words, which will ultimately constitute a chapter of your overall dissertation. This Prospectus will be graded for the course and will be presented by you to the Department as a whole at the end of the Monsoon Semester. The overall grade for the course will be based on a midterm assignment, periodical pop quizzes, final prospectus, and participation in in-class discussions.

Note: For Monsoon Semester 2023, this course is oriented towards ASP students in the department. However, enrolment into the course is NOT restricted only to students who wish to submit a dissertation in IR.

CourseTitle: Globalization Facing the Challenge of Populism and Pandemic
description:
Globalization Facing the Challenge of Populism and Pandemic [IR-2051] [IR-2051-1]

Faculty Name
Nayan Ranjan Chanda [nayan.chanda@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

As Covid-19 continues to ravage the world and life is disrupted by nationalist conflict there is a growing concern that this might mean the end of globalization. With all the restrictions on travel, and tariff wars breaking out, will the interconnected and interdependent world retreat into a collection of self-contained isolated communities?  The course. This course seeks to demystify globalization with a historical look at how the phenomenon -which is not new – has grown and what have been the drivers. The course then looks at the consequences of globalization on different societies and aspects of life to explore reasons for the rising opposition to globalization and most recently the challenges it is facing from pandemics. We will take a special look at the nationalist opposition that globalization has encountered, most recently from populist movements in Europe and the United States. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Towards Understanding Chinese Politics [IR-3009/ CHI-3001/ POL-3073] [IR-3009/ CHI-3001/ POL-3073-1]

Faculty Name
Shivshankar Menon [shivshankar.menon@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course of twenty-three lectures and a final project surveys China’s politics, worldview and strategic culture in history and its practice in today’s world. Beginning with an examination of what is China and of the Chinese polity, state and society through time, it considers the internal political dynamic in China that drives its engagement with the world in history and today. It also examines China’s responses to and uses of the changing international situation since the founding of the PRC. Thereafter it considers the effects on China, Asia and India of a risen and reformed China, and China’s possible trajectory in the future.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

India in Asian Geopolitics [IR-3014/ CHI-3302/ POL-3098] [IR-3014/ CHI-3302/ POL-3098-1]

Faculty Name
Shivshankar Menon [shivshankar.menon@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This twenty-three lecture course examines changes and constants in the geopolitics affecting India’s foreign and security policies since independence in 1947. It first considers chronologically the factors that affected Indian policy, its international context, and the role of personalities, structures and strategic culture in the making of that policy as it evolved over seven decades. It then focuses on the present, on the new geopolitics of Asia and India’s interests and policy choices today. The course concentrates on India in Asia, and considers the dynamic between India’s interests, the changing environment, and India’s growing capabilities as expressed in the practice of Indian policy.

Calculus [MAT-1000] [MAT-1000-2]

Faculty Name
Kumarjit Saha [kumarjit.saha@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Calculus is a foundational subject for all areas of mathematics, science and even modern social sciences. This course is a fast-paced but thorough coverage of the subject. We will see many elementary applications of the subject in Physics, Optimisation, Biology, Economics etc. so that students who have covered Calculus before will not feel the entire couse to be repetative. This course is not about applying formulas and solving problems. It goes to the real reasoning behind them .

 

It is expected that you will solve lot of problems in this course.  Expect to solve 10-12 problems every week for the entire semester. 

 

Learning Outcomes

This is a preparatory course which will prepare you for the next leg of college mathematics and other courses using calculus as a tool.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

We will follow the following texts (not exactly) in this course:

Textbooks: 

1) James Stuart, Calculus. (Cengage).

2) Apostol, Calculus, vol 1.

Reference books:

1) Oscar Fernandez, Calculus Simplified.  (Princeton).

2) Karl Menger, Calculus - A modern approach (Dover)

 

If you have done well in Calculus in classes 11-12 in school, that is excellent. However, the bare minimum prerequisite for this course is listed below for your guidance. At different points the course will draw on these topics and if you have never seen them, you will find it very difficult to proceed. We will recall some of the important topics that you have done in  Calculus at school level in 11-12,  but it will be at a faster pace and at a deeper level than what is taught in high school. You should treat this course as revisiting calculus from a more matured perspective. The course differs from your usual school level calculus course in the sense that we will not follow a "memorise a formula and learn hpw to apply it" type of approach. Deductive logic will our primary tool here and you will the "how and why" behind various ideas studied in Calculus. 

1) Algebra:  linear equations, quadratic equations, binomial theorem, sets and functions, graphs of functions, elementary functions like x^n, exponential and logarithmic functions, arithmetic and geometric progressions. Factorisation and roots of polynomials. 

2) Trigonometry: the sin, cos and tan functions, their basic properties, trigonometric identities, addition formulas

3) Coordinate Geometry: Equations of straight lines, circles, and other curves, slopes and tangents.

4) Graphs of functions.

To test yourself whether you are ready, take the diagnostics tests in James Stuart's Calculus book. If you find yourself struggling with those diagnostics tests, this will be a difficult course for you.

 

 

Grading Rubric

Grading will be done through combination of final term, mid term, class quizzes and assignments. Exact division will be shared later.

Attendance Policy

Attendance is not mandatory but strongly encouraged. For missed class quizzes no make-up option will be provided.

Algebra 1 [MAT-2001/ CS-2250] [MAT-2001/ CS-2250-1]

Faculty Name
Guhan Venkat [guhan.venkat@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is a 2000 level course in Abstract Algebra. It is a mandatory course for a major/minor/concentration in Mathematics as well as for a Interdisciplinary major in Mathematics and CS. This course is also a pre-requisite for Algebra II that will be offered in the Spring semesters. 

Learning Outcomes

Syllabus: Groups: Group structure and examples. Subgroups and cosets. Normal subgroups and Quotient groups. Lagrange, Euler and Fermat’s theorem. Homomorphism, Isomorphism, Automorphism. Group actions. Class equation, Cauchy’s theorem, Cayley’s theorem. Simplicity of alternating groups. Sylow theorems. Rings: Rings, Integral domains and fields. Isomorphism, homomorphism and quotient fields. Ideals - prime and maximal. Euclidean domain, division rule. Polynomials, irreducibility and Eisenstein’s criterion. Chinese remainder theorem. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Suggested Books:

1. M. Artin: Algebra, Second Edition, Pearson Prentice-Hall of India, 2011.

2. D. S. Dummit and Richard M. Foote: Abstract Algebra, Wiley, 2005.

3. R. Ash: Abstract Algebra : The Basic graduate year (Available at https://faculty.math.illinois.edu/~r-ash/Algebra.html).

Grading Rubric

We shall use the following grading rubric for the final letter grade :-

Mid-Term Exam : 30%

Final Exam : 30%

4 Assignments : 20%

2 take-home Quizzes : 20%

There will be no provision for make-up exams/quizzes.

Attendance Policy

No formal attendance policy. Students are highly encouraged to not miss any lectures.

Real Analysis [MAT-2003] [MAT-2003-2]

Faculty Name
Kumarjit Saha [kumarjit.saha@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The two fundamntal concepts of analysis are continuity and convergence. Some idea of these has been formed in earlier courses on Calculus. The aim of this course is to take that understanding further and to make it deeper.

We will study:

construction of real numbers

sequences and series of real numbers and their convergence

continuity, uniform continuity, differentiability, integration (all more rigorously than in the Calculus courses) 

sequences and series of functions, their convergence and unifom convergence; power seriese

elementary functions like trigonometric, hyperbolic, exponential funcions

basic ideas of approximation

 

This course introduces rigorous arguments and is very important for further studies in mathematics. Many later courses, both in mathematics and applications, depend on the understanding gained in this course.

Learning Outcomes

A good understanding of rigorous concepts of elementary analysis. Development of skills to write rigorous proofs. Development of skills for solving problems.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Students must have taken the course Calculus befoe taking this course.

We will follow (closely but not exactly) the text

S. K. Berberian, A first course in real analysis, Springer.

You may also see

Stephen Abbott, Understanding analysis, Springer 

T. Tao, Analysis I

W. Rudin, Principles of Mathematical Analysis

 

Grading Rubric

In addtion to the final examination there will be a mid-term test, assignents and quizzes. Exact weights for these will be discussed in class.

Attendance Policy

Regular attendance is necessary and is encouraged.

Coming late to class is not allowed.

Faculty Name
Krishna Maddaly [krishna.maddaly@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In this introductory course on Probability and Statistics deals with a  formal definition of Probability, Probability spaces, random variables, their distributions, their sums and realted concepts.  The Statistics part of the course deals with sample data, parameters, estimation, the notion of a statistic and  regressions. 

Learning Outcomes

Will obtain a good knowledge of formalising the notion of chance and will be able to apply some basic notions from statistics to analyse data.

Will be announced in the first class.

Linear Algebra and Matrix Analysis [MAT-3120] [MAT-3120-1]

Faculty Name
Rajendra Bhatia [rajendra.bhatia@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course goes beyond the first course in Linear Algebra usually taken by students in their second semester at Ashoka. Topics covered in this course are essential for several other areas of mathematics such as Functional Analysis, Calculus on Manifolds, Differentail Equations, Statistics, Numerical Analysis and Computation. They are also needed for applications of mathematics in areas like Data Sciences an Image Processing.

A side objective of the course is to advance the student's skills in abstract reasoning and problem solving.

Learning of advanced topics in Linear Algebra.

Connections between different topics in mathematics.

Solving problems and writing out clear proofs.

Learning economy of reasoning.

Before taking this course the student must have taken the courses titled Calculus, Linear Algebra and Real Analysis.

It is essential that students thoroughly brush up their knowledge of Linear Algebra before this course begins.

The following books are close to the contents of this course and have much more material:

S. Axler, Linear Algebra Done Right, Springer.

M. E. Taylor, Linear Algebra, American Math Society.

It is recommended that you look at the books, pick up one you like and use it to supplement the course material.

Introduction to Audio Visual Production [MS-1001/ VA-2014] [MS-1001/ VA-2014-1]

Faculty Name
A K Ranjit [ak.ranjit@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sanya Sharma [sanya.sharma_ug24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

MS 1001/ VA 2014 Introduction to Audio Visual Production, Mr. A K Ranjit, MEDIA PRODUCTION

Course cap: 50

Timetable: Two sections of 25 students each

Tuesday & Friday 10.10 am - 11.40 am

No prerequisites

Overview

This is an introductory technical course on audio-visual media; students will learn to listen, watch and create audio-visual stories of their own. This includes an introduction to handling audio and video recording systems. From microphones to cameras, basic audio and video editing. The course would begin with a brief introduction of the various roles required to be taken up for the smooth running of a studio. We will cover camera handling and basic techniques to take good-quality videos. We learn about the kinds of different microphones and where and when to use which one. While learning audio and video, we will simultaneously begin basic editing to stitch together the shots and audio samples we take. Gradually we get into more nuanced editing techniques followed by studio lighting.

Learning Outcomes

Media Literacy on how to hear & watch media in the audio-visual format, separately and together. - Comprehending basic camera operations. - Lighting Technique - Basic Audio-Video Editing tools like Adobe Premiere, Adobe Audition - Sound and Video recording - Constructing an audio and audio-visual narrative from end to end - Mastery of storytelling essentials, encompassing production, post-production, and preview stages.

Grading Rubric

This course will follow Ashoka’s grading rubric for the final grade. Three assignments through the semester will be an ascending base of developing skills in seeing, in making a media product and maintaining a proper record of the process. All classes will involve group work. The rubric is as follows:

1. Attendance 5%
2. Class Participation 5%
3. Team Work 5%
4. Assignment 1 20%
5. Assignment 2 25%
6. Viva 1 5%
7. Viva 2 5%
8. Final Assignment 30%

Attendance Policy

1. Attendance Policy- We have a total of 26 sessions. In accordance with Ashoka policy, students can miss up to 2 classes with no penalty, and 1% will be deducted from the attendance grade for every class missed beyond 2 classes. 

2. Class participation- This will include your participation in in-class assignments and interaction with other peers and professor.

3. Teamwork- This refers to your participation and contribution to group assignments.       

4. Viva- To ensure that everyone has understood the content and can contribute meaningfully to their assignments, a viva will be held at the end of the semester.                    

The students will have to submit three assignments throughout the semester. The First and Second assignments will be individual, and the Third (Final) assignment will be done with support. The exact details of the assignment will be shared during the class. 

* Late Submission will get a 10% grade cut on each assignment. In case of an emergency, the students must email Instructors and CC the TA 24 hours before the submission is due. The professor will grant an extension accordingly if the reason is valid and supported with evidence. No end-moment requests will be entertained.
