Introduction to Newswriting and Reporting [MS-1101] [MS-1101-1]

Faculty Name
Neha Dixit [neha.dixit@ashoka.edu.in] ,Isha [isha.thakur_ug24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

MS 1101 Intro to Newswriting & Reporting/NEHA DIXIT

Prerequisite: None

Course cap: 28

Time Table: Tuesday, 2:50 - 6:00 PM

Course Overview:

 

With so much white noise in the millennial digital space, opinion and content writing are often confused with journalism. This course is a primer on how to identify, report and write news pieces. It includes an introduction to journalism fundamentals and ethics, the concept of news- what is noteworthy and why, techniques to find news stories, building news sources and practising various news writing formats. 

The course will teach how to practice clear, accurate, informative, reporting and the art of listening, observing, interviewing and note-taking to dig out stories from strangers. The course will also focus on how to structure a news report and use research skills to find and evaluate sources, background the news, put stories in context, and check facts. 

Writing formats like a news report, features, profiles, analysis, investigative, narrative, and graphic non-fiction, will also be touched upon. Through editing workshops and a newsletter, the story will be given a final shape, like it is done in an actual newsroom. 
 
Reading lists and a collective weekly news bulletin will be used to identify news pegs and what fits into the current news cycle. Through practice in the field and the best examples of national and international reports, the student will know how to write a first-hand ground report in a concise, authentic and contextual manner.  

In this course you may encounter problems similar to those working journalists face: time and space limitations, missing facts, legal and ethical issues, meeting deadlines, and a sometimes-­‐grouchy editor. 

Learning Outcomes

Basic writing style, standards and techniques, including a variety of ways to lead and structure a story.
The importance of accuracy -­‐-­‐ accurate facts, but also accurate grammar and spelling.
The concept of news itself -­‐-­‐ what is newsworthy, and why.
Techniques to find and focus story ideas.
Reporting skills: listening, observing, interviewing and note-taking.
Research skills to find and evaluate sources, background the news, put stories in context, and check the facts.
Differences in story-­‐telling styles and techniques 
How to write a story pitch.
How to tell a story in a non-academic, simple, effective way

Media, Culture and Society [MS-1201] [MS-1201-1]

Faculty Name
Maya Mirchandani [maya.mirchandani@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

MS 1201 Media Culture Society Professor Maya Mirchandani

Course cap - 50

Timetable - Tuesday & Thursday,  8:30 -10 am

Overview: This gateway course has been created to recognize the utmost need for media literacy in contemporary times. It aims to give students a broad-based understanding of mass media form, be it the newspaper or social media or cinema.  It introduces key communication theorists who help reflect on the cultures, within which media emerge in particular ways. An understanding of media in terms of attitudes, consumption and engagement with communities and society, forms the final part of the course.

This is a mandatory gateway course for all forms of the Media Studies Program

Learning Outcomes

Students not only reflect on ways of seeing and listening, they get to explore how our everyday engagements with media are connected with broader economic, political, ideological, and social contexts. It also introduces students to all the four streams offered in media studies courses. There will be one field trip as part of the course.

CourseTitle: How to Read a Film: Introduction to Film Studies
description:
How to Read a Film: Introduction to Film Studies [MS-2410/ ENG-2803] [MS-2410/ ENG-2803-1]

Faculty Name
Aakshi Magazine [aakshi.magazine@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sehar Batra [sehar.batra_asp24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

MS 2410/ ENG 2803 How to read a film: Intro to Film Studies Aakshi Magazine    FILM

Course Cap - 30

Timetable- Tuesday and Thursday 15:00 - 16:30, AC01-104 (LR)

This film-analysis based course provides an introduction to the basic concepts of the interdisciplinary field of Film Studies. Using examples from across film industries, time periods and genres, it aims to equip students with a lens through which they can understand the language of film that will be helpful in film criticism. The course engages with film form, film analysis and film history.

Learning Outcomes

Introduction to film studies/ Overview of film history/ Develop key skills in film analysis/ Writing skills that will be helpful in film criticism

Cinemas of India [MS-3451/ VA-3019] [MS-3451/ VA-3019-1]

Faculty Name
Aakshi Magazine [aakshi.magazine@ashoka.edu.in] ,Kshitiz Pratap Shah [kshitiz.shah_ug24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

MS 3451/ VA3019 Cinemas of India Aakshi Magazine FILM

Course Cap - 20

Timetable - Tuesday & Thursday 10.10 - 11.40 am, AC04-404 (TR)

This course is interested in exploring the cinematic language of Indian cinema - its nuances, pleasures, possibilities, limitations. Through select films, we will be exploring Melodrama, Parallel cinema and Bollywood. Engaging with the narrative style, formal elements, industrial and social context of the chosen films, at the end of the course we will hope to have a nuanced understanding of the broad category of "Indian cinema".

Learning Outcomes

Overview of Indian film history/ Understand the nuances of Indian cinematic style and form/ Develop key skills in film analysis

Developing Performance Skills [PA-1003] [PA-1003-1]

Faculty Name
Abhinaya Penneswaran [abhinaya.penneswaran@ashoka.edu.in] ,Kriti Maria Pant [kriti.pant@ashoka.edu.in] ,Jaziya Saleem [jaziya.saleem_ug24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Kriti Pant, Abhinaya Penneswaran

Movement, text, sound, music- these are some of the areas touched upon while developing skills in performance.  The emphasis is on building a vocabulary of performance techniques. These techniques can include breathing, movement improvisation, and voice modulation, as well as exercises in awareness and musicality. These ‘tools of performance’ are often tempered by a plethora of contemporary performance outlooks. The emphasis in this most preliminary of Ashoka’s performing arts courses is on the individual as a performing entity. The consciousness of one’s own self vis-à-vis performative potentialities lays the foundations for the group work so essential to later performing arts courses.  The course work will proceed in a series of ‘etudes’ or studies which will result in small performance ‘moments’ or phrases. Some of the coursework will be based on texts and scripts to be chosen afresh each semester.  Other coursework can be based on non-textual concepts.

No previous experience is required. This course is a presumed prerequisite for higher-level performing arts courses.

This course is mandatory for all students wanting to pursue a minor in performing arts.

Grading Rubric

The criteria for grading are the following: attendance, participation in class, and a creative project/ assignment determined by the Professor. All three criteria are equal.

Attendance Policy

As the classes are highly participative in nature, more than 4 absences will affect your grade.

Embodying Stories Through Dance [PA-1013] [PA-1013-1]

Faculty Name
Abhinaya Penneswaran [abhinaya.penneswaran@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Abhinaya Penneswaran

Stories can be a collective medium of expressing and engaging with emotions. The embodiment of such stories using the body, movement, rhythm and sound creates a possibility to make dance a shared experience. The course aims to walk us through a reservoir of stories and to find tangible ways - preparing and conditioning the body, breathwork, task based improvisation, understanding rhythm, voice and sound explorations, emotive body work, etc - to present stories to an audience. 

The movement in the course is free of form. We will familiarize ourselves with basic techniques drawn from contemporary dance, bharathanatyam, yoga and somatic practice to create a common pool of movement vocabulary. This is an entry level course and no prior training in dance is required. 

Grading Rubric

The criteria for grading are the following: attendance, participation in class, and a creative project/ assignment determined by the Professor. All three criteria are equal.

Attendance Policy

As the classes are highly participative in nature, more than 4 absences will affect your grade.

CourseTitle: Action and Text: Writing for performance and performing writing
description:
Action and Text: Writing for performance and performing writing [PA-2018/ ENG-2260] [PA-2018/ ENG-2260-1]

Faculty Name
Neel Choudhary [neel.chaudhuri@ashoka.edu.in] ,Damini Jain [damini.jain_asp24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Neel Chaudhuri

This course explores the relationship between text and performance in contemporary theatre through a dynamic engagement with the most fundamental element of drama - action. What constitutes action in a dramatic work? How does it drive a narrative forward? How does action unfold in time and space? How can it be used to create rhythm and momentum in a play? Participants in the course will be challenged to consider these questions both as writers and as performers, working with text. As writers, we will investigate how to build and evolve elements such as space, time, character and dialogue that together create the dynamics of a scene. Each participant will work towards completing a short performance text/scene. As performers we will commit to the process of reading, analysing and staging pieces of dramatic text. We will explore specifically how the text provides the actors a map to explore on the floor. What drives a scene in performance? How do actors open up the action of a scene to reveal and play with a character's objectives and obstacles? 

Grading Rubric

The criteria for grading are the following: attendance, participation in class, and a creative project/ assignment determined by the Professor. All three criteria are equal.

Attendance Policy

As the classes are highly participative in nature, more than 4 absences will affect your grade.

The Making of Performance [PA-3012] [PA-3012-1]

Faculty Name
Thomas Michael Mccarthy [justin.mccarthy@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Justin McCarthy

Using diverse methodologies, students will participate in the creation of a performance based on a dramatic or poetic work. The focus will be on crafting a cohesive whole using the various facets of performance art. Practical texts on performance will also provide a grid for ongoing analyses of the performative process. The semester will be punctuated by semi-public and public delineations of the work in progress. Student participation will be both from the inside – moving, expressing, articulating- and from the outside- watching and critically engaging from the dispassionate place of the observer.

Grading Rubric

The criteria for grading are the following: attendance, participation in class, and a creative project/ assignment determined by the Professor. All three criteria are equal.

Attendance Policy

As the classes are highly participative in nature, more than 4 absences will affect your grade.

Introduction to Philosophy [PHI-1000] [PHI-1000-1]

Faculty Name
Dimitry Shevchenko [dimitry.shevchenko@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course aims at introducing the students to some of the major issues in the history of philosophy. Does God exist? What is the “self?” What makes some action right or wrong?  Which political and social order can be considered ideal? Do our senses provide reliable knowledge about the reality, and if not, how can the nature of the reality be known? What is the meaning of life?

Students will read the original texts of Plato, Aristotle, Descartes, Nietzsche, and other representatives of Western philosophical traditions, but will also become familiar with non-Western philosophers from Indian, Chinese, and other traditions such as Laozi, the Buddha, Al-Ghazali, etc. The students will also have an opportunity to critically assess and respond to these different philosophers - in class discussions and in writing assignments.

Symbolic Logic [PHI-1060/ CS-2160] [PHI-1060/ CS-2160-1]

Faculty Name
Alexander Iain Siantonas [alexander.siantonas@ashoka.edu.in] ,Vidur Kaushik [vidur.kaushik_ug24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is an introduction to logic as a resource for philosophy, though it should benet many who do not mean to make philosophy their primary subject of study. Logic is concerned with truth; in learning it, we learn to evaluate how well our thoughts and arguments are tied to truth. We will study several articial formal languages, especially rst-order propositional and predicate logic, as well as modal and higher-order logic. We will think about their relation to the natural language of English, and to the world, as it is independent of all our speech.

This is a demanding course, covering a good deal of challenging technical ground. It is still an introductory course, intended primarily to prepare philosophers for work across that subject. It is not an advanced course, exploring the field of logic for its own sake, in the manner of an advanced metaphysics course. But as an introductory logic course, it is more advanced than most (including, for instance, the logic course offered by the excellent department at Leeds, in Britain’s prestigious Russell Group). Some of the topics covered towards the end are at the edge of active research. You will have to work hard, and you may well feel yourself struggling at times. If you are prepared to put in the work, and square up to the struggle, you will learn a lot, and be equipped both to follow and create philosophical arguments at the highest level. 

Plan

Week 1: What is logic, and what do we want from it?

See Logic Manual 1

 

Week 2: Syntax and semantics of propositional  logic

See Logic Manuel 2

 

Week 3: Formalization in propositional logic

See Logic Manual 3

 

Week 4: Syntax of predicate logic

See Logic Manual 4

 

Week 5: Semantics of predicate logic

See Logic Manual 5

 

Week 6: Natural deduction

See Logic Manual 6

 

Week 7: Formalization in predicate logic

See Logic Manual 7

 

Week 8: Identity etc

See Logic Manuel 8

 

Week 9: Modal propositional logic

See Logic for Philosophers 6 

 

Week 10: Quantified modal logic

See Logic for Philosophers 10

 

Week 11: Second-order logic

See Crash Course 3

 

Week 12: Higher-order logic 

See Crash Course 5

 

Henceforward: Review/TBD

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this course, you will be able to:

Understand the fundamental ideas of logic.

Translate sentences of English into well-formed sentences of logical languages, and vice versa. 

Determine the formal properties of arguments, such as validity and soundness,  as they are used in philosophical writing and elsewhere. 

Construct formal proofs for sentences of our formal languages. 

Recognise some of the philosophical implications and applications of logic. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The three main texts for this course are Volker Halbach's The Logic Manual, which covers propositional and predicate logic; Ted Sider's Logic for Philosophy, from which we will study modal logic; and Sider's Crash Course on Higher-Order Logic, which will cover the last portion on higher order logic. 

Other recommended free online resources are Tim Button's Open Education Resources and Garson's Modal Logic for Philosophers 

Grading Rubric

Total grade: 30% homework, 30% midterm, 30% final, 10% participation. 

Expected grade boundaries: 90+ A, 80-90 B, 70-80 C, 60-70 D

Attendance Policy

Attendance is mandatory. After 5 absences, you can receive no more than 90% for your final grade. Your grades will decline thereafter until you reach 10 absences, at which point you will automatically fail.

Metaphysics [PHI-2000] [PHI-2000-1]

Faculty Name
Tatyana Aleksandrovna Kostochka [tatyana.kostochka@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This class will introduce students to some of the major general topics in the study of contemporary metaphysics: the nature of time and space, causation, composition, and personal identity. We will also examine a number of social phenomena by looking at the metaphysics of groups, disability, art, games, and even memes.

Together, we will explore questions like:

Does anything exist that is not in the present?

What does it mean to say that someone caused an accident?

Is there an object that has a dog and a tree as its parts?

Are you the same person as you were when you were a child?

What does it mean to be a member of a group?

What does it mean to have a disability?

What kind of objects are pieces of art?

What is a meme?

Can games change us?

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this course, you will be able to:

  Identify: (1) key metaphysical debates, (2) some of the possible views in those debates

  Clearly explain metaphysical arguments: (1) lay out the argument, (2) identify key premises, and (3) give reasons for/against those premises

  Apply various metaphysical positions to: (1) related debates (2) issues outside of the classroom

  Evaluate the relative merit of particular views or arguments

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

All readings will be provided

Grading Rubric

Initial/final reflection: 2.5% each (total: 5%)

Writing (Levels System): 60%

You will submit a series of assignments that progress in difficulty starting with an argument map (you will learn how to construct these in class) and ending with a short but clear essay (maximum 750 words).

Quizzes (regular in class quizzes): 25%

Short in-class presentation (5-10 minutes): 10%

Attendance Policy

No required attendance but regular in-class quizzes.

Ancient Greek Philosophy [PHI-2440] [PHI-2440-1]

Faculty Name
Rachel Kathleen Harbin [kathleen.harbin@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is an introduction to the central figures and problems of Ancient Greek Philosophy. We will engage with questions about the nature of ethics, knowledge, and the structure of reality, examining how various ancient views relate to one another and to present day philosophical concerns. We will briefly discuss some central pre-Socratic views before examining Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle in detail. These philosophers’ perspectives, from the alluring to the outrageous, can bring into focus both their distinctive, sometimes alien, worldview and their enduring philosophical legacy. 

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this course, students will be able to:

◊ Understand central philosophical positions of selected central figures in Ancient Greek philosophy

◊ Understand the ways in which philosophers of the period responded to the concerns and arguments of their predecessors and contemporaries

◊ Identify, analyze, and evaluate philosophical arguments in a range of forms and contexts, including poetry, dialogue, prose, and commentary

◊ Write well-reasoned philosophical essays that engage with primary historical texts and competing scholarly interpretations of such texts

Grading Rubric

Weekly Quizzes (15%)
Perusall engagement with readings (10%)
Midterm Exam (10%)
1,100-1,200 Word Paper (20%)
1,400-1,600 Word Paper (25%)
Comprehensive Final Exam (20%)

Introduction to Ethics [PHI-2730] [PHI-2730-1]

Faculty Name
Daniel Benjamin Weltman [danny.weltman@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Every day we face countless ethical choices. Is it okay to eat meat, or is this immoral? Should you cheat on your physics exam? Or should you burn down AC03 in the hopes of delaying the exam long enough to study? Which political parties should you support? Some of these questions are easier than others, but all of them require engaging in ethical analysis. This course is about that sort of thing. We will read 3 of the key works in the history of Western ethics because they are very insightful. The rest of the topics we study will be chosen by your votes.

Learning Outcomes
  • Learn about some of the key approaches to and topics in ethics
  • Get practice with reading, writing, talking about, and thinking about ethics in an academic setting
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

All readings will be available on the course Canvas website.

29 August: Anscombe, “Must One Obey One’s Conscience?”

31 August: Aristotle, Nicomachean Ethics Book 1

26 September: Kant, Groundwork for the Metaphysics of Morals Section 2 page 42/Ak 4:426 through the end of the section

28 September: Kant, Groundwork for the Metaphysics of Morals Section 3

3 October: Mill, Utilitarianism Chapters 1 and 2

5 October: Mill, Utilitarianism Chapters 3 and 4

17 October: Mill, Utilitarianism Chapter 5

The rest of the schedule depends on the topics we vote for. Below are the options. If you have suggestions for other topics, let me know.

Metaethics

  • African Ethics: Molefe, “African Ethics and Agent-Centred Duties”; Etieyibo, “On the One Concept and Many Accounts of African Ethics”
  • Evolutionary Debunking of Morality: Street, “Does Anything Matter or Did We Just Evolve to Think it Did?”; Isserow, “Evolutionary Hypotheses and Moral Skepticism”
  • Is Morality Objective: Enoch, “Why I am an Objectivist about Ethics (And Why You Are, Too)”; Williams, “The Truth in Relativism”
  • Moral Luck: Nagel, “Moral Luck”; Williams, “Moral Luck”
  • Moral Skepticism: Mackie, selections from Ethics: Inventing Right and Wrong; Brink, “Moral realism and the sceptical arguments from disagreement and queerness”
  • Moral Uncertainty: Harman, “The Irrelevance of Moral Uncertainty”
  • Morality as a System of Hypothetical Imperatives: Foot, “Morality as a System of Hypothetical Imperatives”
  • Morality without God: Plato, Euthyphro; Brink, “The Autonomy of Ethics”; Rogers, “God and Moral Realism”; Zagzebski, “Does Ethics Need God?”
  • Saints and the Difficulty of Being Moral: Wolf, “Moral Saints”; Adams, “Saints”

Normative Ethics

  • Care Ethics: Gilligan, “In a Different Voice”; Noddings, “An Ethic of Caring”
  • Communicative Ethics: Habermans, Selections from The Inclusion of the Other
  • Contractarianism: Scanlon, “Contractualism and Utilitarianism”
  • Buddhist Ethics: Siderits, “Buddhist Ethics”; Carpenter, “Kleśas and compassion”
  • Existentialist Ethics: Beauvoir, Selections from The Ethics of Ambiguity; Sartre, Selections from “Existentialism is a Humanism”
  • Feminist Ethics: Frye, “Sexism”; Baier, “The Need for More than Justice”; Walker, “Feminist Skepticism, Authority, and Transparency”
  • Jaina Ethics: Soni, “Jaina Virtue Ethics: Action and Nonaction”; Mitra, “Jainism and Environmental Ethics: An Exploration”
  • Moral Particularism: Dancy, “An Unprincipled Morality”; Little, “On Knowing the ‘Why’: Particularism and Moral Theory”; Dworkin, “Unprincipled Ethics”
  • Vedantic Ethics: Sreekumar, “An Analysis of Consequentialism and Deontology in the Normative Ethics of the Bhagavadgītā”; Ranganathan, “Three Vedāntas: Three Accounts of Character, Freedom, and Responsibility”

Applied Ethics

  • Abortion: Warren, “On the Moral and Legal Status of Abortion” and “The Moral Difference Between Infanticide and Abortion: A Response to Robert Card”; Card, “Infanticide and the Liberal View of Abortion”; Thomson, “A Defense of Abortion”
  • Drug Legalization: Husak, “Four Points about Drug Decriminalization”; Sher, “On the decriminalization of drugs”; de Marneffe, “Against the legalization of heroin”; Hunt, “Epilogue: What good are drugs anyway?”
  • Eating Animals: Diamond, “Eating Meat and Eating People”; Norcross, “Puppies, Pigs, and People”; Warren, “Eating Meat as a Morally Permissible Moral Mistake”
  • Karma: Potter, “How many karma theories are there?”; Matilal, “Karma and the moral order”; Mohapatra, “Karma as a Theory of Retributive Morality” and “Niskama Karma: A Critical Assessment”
  • Multiculturalism and Sexism: Okin, “Is Multiculturalism Bad for Women?”; Selected replies
  • Non-Human Animals: Singer, “All Animals are Equal”; Steinbock, “Speciesism and the Idea of Equality”
  • Patriotism and Nationalism: Nathanson, “In Defense of Moderate Patriotism”; Gomberg, “Patriotism is Like Racism”; Hurka, “The Justification of National Partiality”; Lichtenberg, “Nationalism, For and (Mainly) Against”
  • Same-Sex Marriage: Benn, “The Gay Marriage Debate – Afterthoughts”; Card, “Gay Divorce: Thoughts on the Legal Regulation of Marriage” and “Against Marriage and Motherhood”; Hartley and Watson, “Political Liberalism, Marriage and the Family”
  • Sex Selection: Sterri, “Sex selection in India: Why a ban is not justified”; Rogers, Ballantyne, and Draper, “Is Sex-Selective Abortion Morally Justified and Should it be Prohibited?”; Shahvisi, “Engendering Harm A Critique of Sex Selection for Family Balancing”; Zilberberg, “Sex Selection and Restricting Abortion and Sex Determination”
  • Terrorism: Wellman, “On Terrorism Itself”; Held, “Legitimate Authority in Non-state Groups Using Violence”; Jaggar, “What Is Terrorism, Why Is It Wrong, and Could It Ever Be Morally Permissible?”; Medina, “Unconditional vs. Conditional Critics of Terrorist Violence”; McPherson, “Is Terrorism Distinctively Wrong?”; Glasgow, “A Straightforward Analysis of Terrorism”
  • The Annihilation of Caste: Ambedkar, “The Annihilation of Caste”; Gandhi, “A Vindication of Caste”; Ambedkar, “A Reply to the Mahatma”
Grading Rubric

There are three kinds of assignments in this class: reading quizzes, Perusall annotations, and 500 word papers. There is also an attendance requirement which factors into your grade. Late quizzes will have a 10% lower score for every 24 hours they are late (calculated per hour), up to 50% for quizzes. Late Perusall annotations will not be accepted. 500 word papers are never late, but they have suggested due dates.

Reading Quizzes are to help you focus on the important parts of the reading and to get instant feedback on whether you have understood the reading. There is one quiz per reading. The quiz is due 8:00 AM the day we discuss the reading but you should complete it much earlier.

Perusall Annotation Assignments allow you to collaboratively read the readings by using the Perusall website. This allows you to share thoughts and questions with fellow students and to see their thoughts and questions. Canvas has a document detailing examples of annotations you can make on Perusall. Your Perusall annotations are due 8:00 AM the day we discuss the reading but you should write them far earlier.

500 Word Papers are to help you practice thinking about and writing about the complicated ideas that are present in the books we read. They also help you understand those ideas through the feedback you receive. A rubric for 500 wordpapers is available on Canvas.

Paper assignments will be given one of two grades: satisfactory or not yet satisfactory. You can resubmit any not yet satisfactory assignment for a regrade. You can only submit two papers per week. So, if you want to resubmit papers, do not leave all your resubmissions until the end of the semester.

Chinese Buddhist Philosophy [PHI-3095/ CHI-3402] [PHI-3095/ CHI-3402-1]

Faculty Name
Tatyana Aleksandrovna Kostochka [tatyana.kostochka@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The first Buddhist missionaries to China arrived around the 1st century CE but Buddhism did not become widespread in China until the 3rd or 4th century. The next several centuries were an incredibly fruitful time for Buddhism in China with Indian Buddhist works being translated into Chinese, new texts being written, and new schools sprouting up. In this course, we are going to start by setting the context for this period by learning the basics of some Indian Buddhist traditions as well as some of the non-Buddhist philosophical traditions that were already established in China at this time. We will then see how these traditions met in what became the Chinese Buddhist schools. We will specifically focus on the teachings of Huayan, Chan, T'ient'ai, and Pure Land Buddhisms.

Learning Outcomes

Define key ideas and compare/contrast philosophical views of major Buddhist Chinese philosophers

Identify and analyze arguments within complex texts

Articulate your opinion on difficult and nuanced philosophical topics in a precise and concise manner

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

All readings will be provided.

Annotations - 20%

Philosophy of Religion [PHI-3910] [PHI-3910-1]

Faculty Name
Mohammad Saeedimehr [mohammad.saeedimehr@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Faculty: Prof. Mohammad Saeedimehr

Throughout human history, religion (in its broad sense) has always played a pivotal role in the human individual and social life. Even those who personally do not follow any particular religion do not deny its overall importance. Nowadays, this inseparable aspect of the diverse human cultures is studied in different academic disciplines such as sociology of religion, psychology of religion, theology and the like. Philosophy of religion, however, scrutinises religious concepts, beliefs and doctrines employing a philosophical (rational) approach. There is a plenitude of deep and fundamental questions for which philosophy of religion tries to find rational answers. What is religion itself? How are we to explain the diversity of the existing religions? Are there any gods in the universe? One God (monotheism) or many gods (polytheism)? What are (if any) the evidences for or against the existence of God? Supposing that God exists, what are His attributes and how does He act in the universe? How can we think or talk about God? What is the relation between reason and faith and which one can support our religious beliefs? What is the relation between religion and science or religion and morality? How can we reasonably reconcile  God’s existence with the reality of evil? Does religion have any role in having a meaningful life? Will we continue to live after death (afterlife or resurrection)? 

In this course we will deal with some of the most significant philosophical answers to the above queries and try to finally form our own perspectives through critical thinking and mutual discussion.

There is also an attendance requirement which factors into your grade. Physics of the Universe [PHY-2850/ AST-2850] [PHY-2850/ AST-2850-1]

Faculty Name
Kandaswamy Subramanian [kandaswamy.subramanian@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Instructor:  Kandaswamy Subramanian

This course will introduce the students to the contents of the universe and the physical processes that occur in them.  It will describe how, starting from the big bang, the universe expanded to its present size, what forces it experienced, the nature of dark matter and dark energy, how galaxies, stars and planets formed, the origin and properties of compact objects such as neutron stars and black holes and the predicted future course of evolution of the universe.  The prime role of General Theory of Relativity in many of these processes will be highlighted.

Syllabus:

(1) Contents of the Universe from Stars/Galaxies to largest scales
(2) The smooth expanding Universe: Hubble law-redshift-Newtonian cosmology-Dark matter, Dark energy
(3) The Hot Universe: Big bang-Thermal history-Nucleosynthesis-Atom formation-Cosmic Microwave Background Radiation-Puzzles in cosmology-inflation-seed fluctuations-sound waves
(4) Structuring the universe: gravitational instability-spherical collapse-galaxy formation-dark ages-21 cm line-reionization-lyman alpha clouds-galaxies
(5) Gas in galaxies-atomic and molecular probes-formation of stars and planets-stellar structure and evolution-end state of stars.
 

Learning Outcomes

The student will develop appreciation of the many exciting phenomena that go on in the universe and learn how to understand them using only the basic laws of Physics.

Statistical Mechanics [PHY-3610] [PHY-3610-1]

Faculty Name
Bikram Phookun [bikram.phookun@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Both Statistical Mechanics and Thermodynamics are ways of studying systems with large numbers of particles — of the order of the Avogadro number. When the number of particle is so large it becomes possible to describe systems in equilibrium in terms not just of quantities inherited from mechanics — particle-number, volume, and energy, etc — but also ones that arise from statistical regularities and are purely thermodynamic — entropy, temperature, and chemical potential, etc. In statistical mechanics we begin with an explicit acknowledgment of the particle nature of many-body systems, whereas in thermodynamics we ignore the particle nature and begin with relationships between thermodynamic quantities. They are thus complementary, and each allows a deeper understanding of the other. 

In this course we will use statistical mechanics to study simple classical and quantum systems, with and without interactions. We will begin by understanding how the thermodynamic description of a simple system like an ideal gas in equilibrium can be found from statistical mechanics, and go on to more complex systems, both classical and quantum, that would be difficult to grasp using thermodynamics alone. We will learn to describe fluctuations about equilibrium, which tell us about the stability of equilibrium states and are also related to equilibrium properties like specific heat and compressibility. And we will try to understand the basic ideas of equilibrium between phases, and, through computational exercises, of transformation between them. 

The mathematical formalism of statistical mechanics draws both on the laws of mechanics — classical or quantum, as appropriate — and on probability theory and statistics. Bridging the gap between the mathematics and the physics can be difficult, but it is rewarding, for starting from little one can get a lot. 

The computer has become an indispensable complement to mathematics in the physical description of many-particle systems. Computational statistical mechanics will not be taught in class by the instructor, but the graduate assistant will help students to learn it. It will form an integral part of the course in that every homework assignment will contain a computational problem, and the term project will be computational. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Pre-requisites

Thermal Physics (PHY 2610). (Students are advised to revise this course thoroughly before the semester begins. It may be a good idea to watch and understand the first three lectures of Mehran Kardar’s MIT OCW course Statistical Mechanics, available on Youtube.) Mathematical knowledge at the level of MP 1 (PHY-1110) will be assumed. Some knowledge of programming will be needed. 

Books

Fundamentals of Statistical and Thermal Physics, F Reif. (This textbook is meant to specify the level of the course. I will use a large number of books and online resources, and encourage students to discover what suits them.)

An Introduction to Computer Simulation Methods: Applications to Physical Systems, 3rd ed, H Gould, J Tobochnik, and W Christian.

 

Grading Rubric

Attendance Policy

You may miss no more than 5 classes and 3 discussion sessions in the semester. Absence beyond that will require considerable justification.

Computational Astrophysics and Geophysics [PHY-4830/ PHY-6830/ AST-4830] [PHY-4830/ PHY-6830/ AST-4830-1]

Faculty Name
Dipankar Bhattacharya [dipankar.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Computational modelling is an essential tool in Astrophysics and Geophysics.  Comprehension of diverse physical effects including fluid and gas flow under gravity, heat and radiation transport, oscillations and seismology, formation of structures in the universe etc is being developed through computations.  This course will introduce the students to some of the basic techniques to perform such computational modelling.    At the heart of the mathematical description of these problems are partial differential equations (PDEs).  Several common methods used to solve PDEs will be discussed, with application examples drawn from Astrophysical and Geophysical settings.   Method of inference from observational data will also be discussed.

The following is an outline of the syllabus:

1. Ordinary and Partial differential equations; Different discretization schemes - Finite difference, Finite Volume and Finite element methods; Euler, Crank-Nicholson and Runge-Kutta integration schemes. Fourier Transforms and Spectral Methods.
2. Applications to the structure and oscillations of stellar and planetary bodies, N-body simulations and formation of structure in the universe, Geophysical heat and material transport.
3. Bayesian inference from observed data. Basic Monte Carlo and MCMC techniques.

Learning Outcomes

1. Learn to formulate physical problems in a computational setting
2. Learn various algorithms for solving problems described by differential equations, their pros and cons and domain of applicability.
3. Experience hands-on the application of numerical techniques to astrophysical and geophysical problems
4. Learn methods to draw statistical inference from data

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Recommended reading:

1. Numerical Recipes: The Art of Scientific Computing -  by W.H. Press, S.A. Teukolsky, W.T. Vetterling and B.P. Flannery, Cambridge University Press, http://numerical.recipes
2. Finite Volume Methods for Hyperbolic Problems - by Randall J. Leveque, Cambridge University Press
3. Numerical Solutions of Partial Differential Equations - by K.W. Morton and D.F. Mayers, Cambridge University Press
4. Partial Differential Equations for Scientists and Engineers - by Stanley F. Farlow, Dover Publications
5. Lecture Notes on Computational Geophysics by A.P. van den Berg: http:// www.geo.uu.nl/~berg/compgeoph/lecturenotes.pdf
6. Data Analysis: A Bayesian Tutorial by D.S. Sivia and J. Skilling, Oxford University Press

Prerequisites:

Coding ability in any one programming language such as Python, C, C++ or FORTRAN.   Familiarity with differential and integral calculus. Basic knowledge of classical mechanics and thermodynamics.  Basic plotting and visualisation techniques.

Grading Rubric

Quizzes:  15%

Assignments: 40%

Mid-term examination: 20%

Final examination: 25%

Attendance Policy

Minimum 80% classroom attendance required

Faculty Name
Bikram Phookun [bikram.phookun@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Objectives

To familiarise students with some of the philosophical, psychological, methodological, and ethical aspects of research, in particular research done for a PhD. 

To develop some of the skills required for it, e.g. reading and writing research papers and grant proposals, and listening to and delivering scientific talks. 

Contents

Philosophical, psychological, methodological, and ethical aspects

The nature of scientific research. Choosing an area of research. Choosing an adviser. Finding and formulating a research problem. The relationship between research scholar and adviser. The different stages of solving a research problem. The creative process. Publishing: authorship, citation, acknowledgement, plagiarism. The research scholar as member of a community of scientists. Collaboration with other senior scientists, with peers, and with undergraduates. Independent work unconnected with main thesis problem. Evolution from dependence to independence.  The spectrum of ethical problems — recognising them and dealing with them. Sexism and other prejudices in the world of science. The importance and dangers of networking. The bureaucratic aspects of a PhD. Time-management. 

Skills

Making a CV. Maintaining a log-book. Reading papers. Writing papers. Writing a thesis. Writing a grant proposal. Using reference and citation repositories. Writing a letter of recommendation. Listening to scientific talks. Scientific interactions. Giving scientific talks. Writing for and speaking to the public. Teaching: conducting discussion sessions and labs. Interviewing and being interviewed. Interacting in person and online with senior scientists, peers, and undergraduates. Attending conferences. Reviewing papers. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

This course is open only to students enrolled for a PhD.

References

Advise to a Young Scientist, by P B Medawar

The Scientist’s Guide to Writing: How to Write more Easily and Effectively Throughout your Scientific Career, by S B Heard 

The Great Betrayal: Fraud in Science, by H F Judson

The Ethics of Science: an Introduction, by D B Resnik

Grading Rubric

Weekly writing exercises: 40%; talks: 10%; mock interview: 10%; interview of practising scientist: 10%; mid-term paper: 10%; final paper: 20%.

Attendance Policy

Regular attendance is expected.

CourseTitle: Qualitative Research Methods in Political Science
description:
Qualitative Research Methods in Political Science [POL-1030] [POL-1030-1]

Faculty Name
Dipin Kaur [dipin.kaur@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The course will introduce students to qualitative research design, data collection, and analysis. It will focus on a variety of political questions to cover the basic techniques for collecting and interpreting qualitative data. The first part of the course is organized around the sequence scholars conventionally follow to conduct qualitative research: find a research question, engage with existing literature, formulate hypotheses, collect material, analyze it and effectively communicate findings. The second part of the course will familiarize students with various qualitative research methods and tools, including interviews, participant observation, case studies, and archival research using primary sources. In the process, students will reflect on (a) the ethics of conducting qualitative research and (b) the types of research questions to which such techniques are best suited. In the final part of the course, students will develop (and present) a research plan to collect data on their chosen topic using any one combination of methodologies from the following options:

1. Participant Observation and Interviewing OR (developing interview questions, identifying a diverse portfolio of interviewees, identifying the biases/ positionally of people you are interviewing) 2. Thick description/ case study and archival research (what you find, what is missing, the positionally of the people who wrote the material)
Based on this data collection, students will write a final paper that formulates a research question, relevant hypotheses, and initial findings.

Introduction to Chinese Politics [POL-1031/ CHI-1301] [POL-1031/ CHI-1301-1]

Faculty Name
Saul Kriger Wilson [saul.wilson@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

China’s rapidly emergence as an economic and geopolitical heavyweight has been deeply political.  In the past century, Chinese politics have been transformed first by a Communist revolution and then by Reform and Opening.  This course asks why China experienced a Communist revolution and why it opened its doors to the outside world.  The course focuses on the political structures that facilitated these transformations and the political changes they have, in turn, wrought on China.

CourseTitle: Religion, Modernity, and Secularity in Contemporary Political Theory
description:
Religion, Modernity, and Secularity in Contemporary Political Theory [POL-2106] [POL-2106-1]

Faculty Name
Sushmita Nath [sushmita.nath@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Description

This lecture course explores contemporary epistemic interventions related to the concepts of religion, modernity, and secularity as they have come to be scrutinized, contested and reformulated in  light of the socio-political experiences of non-Western and post-colonial societies of South Asia and Africa. We will engage with contemporary theories and responses to the global condition of the rise of religion under conditions of colonialism and modernity. This course has two main sections: (a) a conceptual and theoretical survey of religion, modernity and secularity in contemporary political thought where the Euro-centrism of canonical sociological theories of religion, modernity, and secularity are questioned and challenged; (b) various responses to the global condition of the rise and relevance of religion in South Asia and Africa, and its engagement with modernity and secularity.

A core objective of this lecture course is to bring together meta-theorization and area studies to highlight how current debates emerging from the experiences of the non-Western world challenge the Eurocentrism of concepts and theories of religion, modernity and secularity. We will not only study the reception of ostensibly ‘Western’ concepts like modernity and secularity in South Asia and Africa but also understand how they underwent change as they were re-interpreted or rejected in new environments. Thus, we will put canonical theories under critical scrutiny to demonstrate the plurality and contested nature of what is considered to be “religion” or “secular” or “modern”. The course has a rigorous theoretical basis, and students will be familiarized with the current state-of-the-art debates on religion in the public-political sphere, secularism, secularization, and modernity. The course has a regional focus – South Asia (Undivided British India, and post-colonial nation-states of India and Pakistan) and Africa (Egypt and South Africa), and a disciplinary breadth that draws on a wealth of interdisciplinary perspectives (Political Science, Sociology, History, Philosophy, and Anthropology, amongst others).

Learning Outcomes

Course Objective and Learning Outcomes

The aim of this course is to: a) critically examine canonical theories of religion, modernity and secularity; and b) engage in comparative social and political theorization by getting acquainted with non-western (South Asia and Africa) thought and societies which have challenged and reformulated canonical studies in religion, modernity and secularity in light of their particular socio-historical experiences. This course will equip students with perspectives that will enhance and broaden their understanding of the state, society, religion, secularism, and modernity beyond their ‘Western’ interpretations in social and political theory. Apart from this, students will also learn how ideas travel and are transformed in that process. Thus, the entire course is designed to develop the student’s knowledge of contemporary theoretical discourses on religion, modernity and secularity beyond the Western world, the capacity to critically and respectfully engage with diverse approaches and multiple perspectives emerging from non-Western thought and experience.

Goals

The course’s inter-disciplinary focus and comparative framework aims to train students in comparative theorization by exploring a wide range of theoretical and regional perspectives. The course offers students:

In-depth knowledge and understanding of major theories, methods, and debates in the field of religion, modernity and secularity, with a particular focus on South Asia and Africa;

Develop skills in researching and writing about topics in and theorizations of religion, modernity and secularity;

Develop skills in the presentation or communication of knowledge and understanding of debates related to religion, modernity and secularity, and as they pertain to regional, international, and transnational contexts.  

Outcomes

Upon completion of the course students will be able to:

Demonstrate their ability to engage analytically and critically with theories and conceptions of religion, modernity and secularity and their global impact.

Demonstrate an analytical understanding of the varied impact of modernity, colonialism, and capitalism in South Asia and Africa and their lasting consequences in today’s modern states in the region.

Demonstrate knowledge and understanding of contemporary society and politics in South Asia and Africa.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

TBA

Grading Rubric

Exam and Requirements

Class participation is going to count for 20% of your final grade. A class presentation, done jointly or in small teams, will count for 10% of your final grade. Students will grade their peers for the presentation. The details of evaluation by peers will be explained in class. Apart from this, you will have a mid-term take home exam in the form of an essay that will count for 30% of your final grade and your final take home exam, also in the form of an essay, will count 40% of your grade. The mid-term essay should be 1800 words and the final should be 2800 words. Essays should be double-spaced using Times New Roman font with font size 12 for text. There will be a zero-tolerance policy for any form of cheating or plagiarism. In case you are not clear about what constitutes plagiarism, then please refer to Ashoka University’s Academic Integrity Policy.

The Idea of Equality [POL-2108/ PHI-2771] [POL-2108/ PHI-2771-1]

Faculty Name
Bastian Steuwer [bastian.steuwer@ashoka.edu.in] ,Ruhaan Shah [ruhaan.shah_asp24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Equality is a key value in politics. Many political movements appeal to some idea of equality. Critics of equality point out that humans are diverse and different. They allege that making everyone equal or the same does not reflect this diversity. On closer reflection, it turns out that equality is a complex value. There is equality of opportunity, equality of outcome, equality of status, equality of resources, equality of welfare, economic equality, gender equality, and so on. In this course, we will investigate the idea of equality and some of its complexity. We will start, in the first half, by discussing ideas of equality as distributive ideal. This includes looking at equality of opportunity, equality and bad luck, equality in the distribution of chances, and the different between equality and priority. In the second half of the course, we discuss ideas of equality as a relational ideal. What makes humans fundamentally equal? Why and when is discrimination wrong? How should we tackle caste?

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The course requires a basic knowledge of political theory, political or moral philosophy. Students are expected to have completed Introduction to Political Theory, Western Political Thought I, or an equivalent course in political theory and/or philosophy.

Political Philosophy and Public Policy [POL-3084/ PHI-3810] [POL-3084/ PHI-3810-1]

Faculty Name
Bastian Steuwer [bastian.steuwer@ashoka.edu.in] ,Pratham Arora [pratham.arora_asp24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Public policy requires value judgments. Cases in which we only need to know “what works” are rare. The choice between different policies requires us to trade off different values or trade off benefits to some against burdens to others. Some social scientists therefore seek to describe their task more modestly. The task of social policy as a discipline is to measure, at least estimate, the outcomes or effectiveness of a policy proposal. But even this modest task involves value judgments. How should we measure welfare? Or health? Or poverty? Or inequality? In this course we will connect political philosophy with public policy. Political philosophy is concerned with reasoning about value judgments.

Each week we will connect one debate in political philosophy with a debate in public policy. The public policy debates are often examples. Philosophical debates on inequality, for instance, bear on many policy questions. However, for this course it helps to focus our discussion by looking at one policy case in particular. There will be student presentations on the policy cases and we will work together to draw the connections between the political philosophy material and the social policy debate in India.

The course is intended for two groups of students. First, it is intended for students interested in entering public policy. This means students interested in working for policy-oriented NGOs, think tanks, IAS, public interested spirited litigation, political parties, and so on. The course shall help students sensitize about value questions as they arise in public policy. At the end of the course, students shall be able to identify implicit value questions and reason about them critically. The second group of students are students interested in political philosophy and political theory. Many courses in political theory are, well, theoretical. This course seeks to apply and make relevant debates in political philosophy for real-world concerns. Students interested in political theory can benefit from this applied focus.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

In the course well will draw on political philosophy/theory as well as economics and law. Basic knowledge of political theory, political or moral philosophy is highly recommended as evidenced by completion of Introduction to Political Theory, Western Political Thought I, or an equivalent course in political theory and/or philosophy. Students without such prior courses should approach me with a short description of their background before registration. Prior knowledge of economics and/or law is helpful but not required.

Comparative Politics of Urban Development [POL-3096] [POL-3096-1]

Faculty Name
Saul Kriger Wilson [saul.wilson@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Urbanization has been a driving force behind social change and economic growth.  It has also been a deeply political process, in which urban space is distributed and its development subject to state regulation.  This course examines the politics of urban development through international comparisons, primarily between the United States and China, but with reference to India, Europe, and Brazil as well.  Addressing in turn land takings, the governance of urban development, and informality in urban development, this course is an opportunity to identify commonalities and differences in urbanization processes across the world.

Thinking like a Psychologist [PSY-1003] [PSY-1003-1]

Faculty Name
Manon Grube [manon.grube@ashoka.edu.in] ,Navya Mendiratta [navya.mendiratta_tf@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Welcome to PSY-1003!        
This course builds on and strengthens the central principles of the field of scientific psychology. You should be familiar with the definition of psychology as the scientific study of thought and behaviour. What does this mean exactly? Understanding psychology as an empirical science will be our starting point. Without rigorous standards for examining human behaviour, psychology would be little more than intuition, opinion, whim or belief. A large part of this course will be devoted to a critical analysis of things you might have already learned in psychology – some of which might, in fact, be classic misconceptions, in other words “myths”… Waiting for us to be explored and find out! 
We will parallel some of what students are learning in Psychology-1001 but will focus on exploring psychology as a science, including aspects of how to study questions of interest, critical thinking, and analysis of general findings.

Structure of the Course
This course introduces the scientific discipline of psychology and familiarises the student with basic concepts within it. We look at how researchers and practitioners conduct their work and the various challenges, myths, misunderstandings and misconceptions that the discipline often has to grapple with. First and foremost, this is not a class composed only of lectures. We will devote class time to discussions, demonstrations and in-class presentations, which will add to your appreciation of the application of scientific psychological knowledge in our lives (: Psychology is fun :) However fun it can be, you will need to put in a considerable amount of work. Please come to class with a mindful, interested, curious & courageous mindset, prepared to ask your questions and ready to respond to mine and discuss: I very much look forward to healthy lively discussions in class, as a whole but also in small groups.           
Please note, that this is only the second time I am taking this course, therefore and as in all my courses, there will be a fair amount of flexibility in the course timing as well as in the shaping “the course” of the course according to your interests, especially in the small group presentations part during the second half of the course!


Discussion Sections
We will be holding discussion sections during the course of the semester to help you review course material and gain further understanding about the application of the concepts covered in class. To further your understanding and assist with clearing queries, discussion sections in smaller groups will be held once a week with the TF(s). Please register for a DS via LMS.

Learning Outcomes

Knowledge:
State the goals and methods of science as they allow for evaluation of the quality of the evidence, distinguishing between evidence and pseudoscience.
Articulate the rationale and the need for considreing psychology among the sciences. 

Meta-Skills:
Read, summarise, paraphrase, critique primary reserach in psychology.

Personal:
Apply theoretical principles from psychology to enhance you everday life - especially student life.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Reading Material
E-copies of the main textbooks will be shared with you via Google Classroom.
These are the two main textbooks:
. Stanovich, K. E. (1992). How to think straight about psychology. Harper Collins  Publishers.
. Lilienfeld, S. O., Lynn, S. J., Ruscio, J., & Beyerstein, B. L. (2011). 50 great myths  of popular psychology: Shattering widespread misconceptions about human  behavior. John Wiley & Sons.
An excellent additional introductory textbook, for this course in particular with reference to some specific chapters:
. Bhatia, A. (2018). Introduction to Psychology. DEF Publishers

Any further additional articles / chapters to read up on more specific topics will also be shared via Google Classroom over the course of the semester. 

Grading Rubric

Following are the mandatory, graded course requirements along with a breakdown of how they contribute to the final grade:

1. Attendance and Participation (20%)(10% each)
The elements that contribute to this grade include: being in good standing of the attendance requirements as mentioned in this document, being on time for the classes and discussion sessions, participation in the class and discussions sessions, in the form of asking and responding to questions, making comments and points about the content being taught, and actively engaging with the course.

2. Three Quizzes (30%)
Three quizzes will be conducted, each worth 10% of the overall grade. 

3. One Written Assignment (25%)
A review paper, written in groups of two, will be assigned as the midterm/final assignment. 

4. One “Final”  Presentation Assignment (25%)
A presentation, in groups of two, on one of the 50 myths in the textbook will be the midterm/final assignment. 

 

Additional & Bonus Assigments: 
 

5. Make-up quiz:
Make up quiz that can substitute the lowest score in the 3 quizzes. 
 

6. Bonus assignment
Bonus presentation assignment for a maximum of up 5% of overall grade.

Attendance Policy

Attendance and presence in the physical classroom is mandatory, unless announced differently. Attendance will be recorded by the TAs during the first 10 min of the class. You are allowed three unexcused absences for the course. Taking more than five absences will result in a grade cut. Please note that you must not miss more than 7 classes in order to pass the course.

For the Discussion Session, you are allowed two absences.

Statistics and Research Methods II [PSY-2002] [PSY-2002-1]

Faculty Name
Krishna Venkata Melnattur [krishna.melnattur@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Quantitative psychological data is frequently a bunch of structured numbers. These cannot be interpreted meaningfully until one understands and appreciates how the data came about and what can be properly inferred from the data. In this course, we will focus on quantitative methodology. This course is for students who know the basics of statistical analyses. The aim is to develop a trained eye for sound methodology to better evaluate other scientists’ research, as well as their own. Students will also learn about planning, ethical conduct, and reporting of findings from a survey and experimental study. Along with some of the most widely-used quantitative methods in psychology (e.g., surveys and experiments), students will also understand how these methods are different from alternative methodologies (i.e., qualitative methods, mixed methods).

 

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this course, you will be able to:

  • Understand various quantitative methods that psychologists use to investigate research questions.
  • Plan, design, and conduct a psychometrically-sound survey; formulate hypotheses, test them, analyze the results, interpret them
  • Write report of a survey study to effectively communicate your results
  • Plan, design, and conduct an experimental study; formulate hypotheses, design and conduct an experiment to test the hypotheses, analyze the results, interpret them
  • Write report of an experimental study to effectively communicate your results
  • Understand alternative methodologies available for researchers (qualitative and mixed-method) and when to use them
  • Grasp, analyze, and critique academics research papers in psychology
  • Become literate consumers of scientific information.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prerequisites: Pass in Statistics and Research Methodology I, or equivalent modules in math, economics, or political science.

Required materials:

Shaughnessy J. J., Zechmeister, E. B., Zechmeister, J. S., & (2012). Essentials of research methods in psychology. (9th ed.) Tata McGraw-Hill.

 

Grading Rubric
  1. Quizzes (including syllabus quiz): 20%
  2. Survey Research Report [Group]: 30%
  3. Experimental Research Report [Group]: 35%
  4. Participation: 10%
  5. Attendance: 5%
Attendance Policy

Attendance will be taken within the first five minutes of every class. I expect students to attend all lecture and discussion sessions. The following rules will apply for absences:

  • Missing 5 classes: Excused (no grade cut)
  • Missing 6 classes: One grade cut on the final grade for the course
  • Missing 8 classes: Two grade cuts on the final grade for the course
  • Missing 10 or more classes: A ‘Fail’ grade for the course

Introduction to Neuroscience/ Biological Psychology [PSY-2011/ BIO-2103/ BIO-6103] [PSY-2011/ BIO-2103/ BIO-6103-1]

Faculty Name
Bittu R [bittu@ashoka.edu.in] ,Vikrant [vikrant_tf@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The goal of this class is to enable students to understand how a biological system mostly composed of salty proteinaceous water bounded by fat is able to signal information, perform complex computations and produce behaviour. We will start by understanding how single neurons can perform computations and can be understand in the same framework as electronic circuitry. We will understand then how complex information processing and calculation can happen as a result of the ways in which multiple neurons signal to and connect to one another. We will then look at how the brain is organized, and study the nervous systems of humans and other animals, approaching this through the lens of the various tools that neuroscientists have historically used to study neuronal connectivity and the brain. We will cover the electrical properties of nerve cells and voltage dependent membrane permeability; channels, transporters, neurotransmitters and their receptors; synaptic transmission; the brain and its development and plasticity. We will also study complex brain functions and the neural basis of complex cognition, learning and information processing. We explore the ways in which the neuronal processes underlying behaviour have been deduced from various animal models of behaviour, and ways in which genetics and the environment shape the systems that produce behaviour during development. We will explore sensory perception and motor movement in depth.

Learning Outcomes

This course is offered to both biology and psychology students and covers the same ground as a standard course on Biological Psychology. It aims to introduce neuroscience as a specialized discipline, and to enable students to understand how a biological system is able to signal information, perform computations and produce behaviour. This course will also use teaching tools in the discussion section that enable an intuitive grasp of neural processes, such as simulations to understand how various factors affect neuronal functioning, and experiments to demonstrate neurons in action and how various interventions affect neuronal functioning.

In order to equip students to become familiar with the level of rigour needed to think through some of these questions, we will also look at how to survey and evaluate literature in the field of biological psychology, how to quickly but accurately read graphs and how to cite literature.

We then turn to the question of how we learn, how we absorb new material, the ways in which our neural systems tend to conflate correlation and causation, and how critical thinking and environmental training can change learning patterns and feedback to change the structure of the brain. We will take a quick look at the neural basis of complex and interesting phenomena such as motivation, emotion, cognition, consciousness, attention. We will end with an exploration of how neural systems can exhibit pathology, how neurodegeneration and trauma can impact the system, and how medication and drugs work, with a focus on the limitations of what we collectively understand and the pressing need for further research to take forward the field. This course eventually hopes to make clear the relationship between brain and behaviour.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The recommended textbook for this course is Biological Psychology by James W. Kalat (Kalat, J. W. (2008). Biological Psychology. Calif: Wadsworth, Cengage Learning). I have a physical copy of the 11th edition. A soft copy of the 10th edition is also available on Canvas - the 10th and 11th editions do not differ hugely and I’d recommend this for anyone who is comfortable with reading on their computers.

 

For additional reading students can refer to:

Kandel, E. R., Schwartz, J. H., & Jessell, T. M. (2000). Principles of neural science. New York: McGraw-Hill, Health Professions Division.

Purves, D., Augustine, G., Fitzpatrick, D., Hall, W., Lamantia, A.-S., & White, L. (2012) Neuroscience. Sinauer Associates, Inc.: Sunderland, MA.

Grading Rubric

This class will have fourteen weekly quizzes, all open book. The idea behind this is to keep providing conceptual testing to enable you to check the soundness with which you have understood the material. There will be no testing requiring rote learning or simply checking familiarity with information. The best 9 out of 14 will count towards 90% of your final grade.

 

Your participation in class or even by email or Canvas will count towards the remaining 10%. In terms of class participation, questions in class will be counted, as will engaging on Canvas, by email, etc. Your attendance counts as part of your participation grade: 5% of your total grade is class attendance and 2% is DS attendance.

 

The quizzes will be administered by Canvas. This requires a laptop or phone in class. The quizzes will be administered at the beginning of the Thursday class, and should take 25 minutes. The quizzes will be autograded and returned with the answer scheme by the following Tuesday at the latest, for immediate feedback.

 

For Graduate students (MA/PhD), the only difference between this course as offered for undergraduate and graduate students is that the assignment is mandatory for graduate students, and it counts for 30% of the final grade (and accordingly, only the best 6 quizzes count towards the final grade).

Attendance Policy

Your attendance counts as part of your participation grade: 5% of your total grade is class attendance and 2% is DS attendance. Attendance: will be marked as a component of the participation grade, but not as a barrier to doing exams, etc. Missing class is a student’s loss and will impact the class participation grades. For students who miss class for unavoidable reasons, they can visit the TA, during office hours for help. All those who are unable to attend classes due to medical reasons are requested to email the TAs  (and cc'd to the TFs, but please not to Bittu!), with a copy of their medical note or prescription (with the date clearly mentioned) along with their emails.

Cognitive Psychology [PSY-2021] [PSY-2021-1]

Faculty Name
Dipanjan Ray Ray [dipanjan.ray@ashoka.edu.in] ,Navya Mendiratta [navya.mendiratta_tf@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Cognitive psychology is the study of how we think, and how we make sense of the external (and internal) environment using our prior experiences, and determine how to respond to an ever changing environment. While the main purpose of this course is to introduce you to the scientific study of the mind, you will also begin to understand the central role cognition plays in our everyday lives. 

Learning Outcomes

Upon completing this course, students should be able to:
• Trace the history of cognitive psychology and its influence on other fields of psychology.
• Critically compare and contrast different theories of cognitive function.
• Demonstrate knowledge of the basic methods of cognitive research, plus their strengths and weaknesses.
• Apply communication skills using oral and written materials to discuss topics related to human cognition or to critically review a paper.
• Explain how theories and research findings from cognitive psychology can inform everyday problems

Grading Rubric

Grading rubric: A= 90-100; A- = 85-89; B+= 80-84; B = 75-79.4; B-= 70-
74; C+= 65-69; C= 60-64 ;C-= 55-59; D+= 50-54; D= 45-49; D-= 40-44;
F= Below 40. Curving is at the discretion of the professor.

Clinical Psychology [PSY-2041] [PSY-2041-1]

Faculty Name
Simi Ghosh [simi@ashoka.edu.in] ,Anandita Liddhoo [anandita.lidhoo_tf@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course focuses on understanding the phenomenology (description), etiology (causes), and treatment of abnormal behavior. Major psychological syndromes will be discussed along with the current APA classification system (DSM-5) and other classification systems. Genetic, biological, social, and psychological parameters implicated in the etiology of these syndromes will be introduced

Learning Outcomes
  • Understand the merits and limitations of research methods and assessment techniques for clinical psychology
  • Learn basics of critical and analytical skills required to read a journal article on clinical psychology
  • Understand and be able to describe the current APA classification system (DSM-5) and show appreciation for other classification systems internationally
  • Understand and be able to describe the major psychological disorders
  • Describe the genetic, biological, social, and psychological influences on these disorders
  • Understand the influence of societal, cultural, historical, and environmental influences on these disorders
  • Appreciate the concept of comorbidity
  • Discuss mental health services historically and contextually
  • Understand ethical issues involved with mental health services
  • Learn the importance of vocabulary, empathy and nuances in abnormal behavior
  • Be able to navigate and think through elementary clinical problems in practice
  • Learn to write an interview questionnaire based on a clinical case study
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Text : Butcher J.N, Mineka S, Hooley J.M, Kapoor P (2019) Abnormal Psychology (18th ed) Pearson India
https://www.amazon.in/dp/9353065593?tag=pearindieduc-21 ( Rs.781 from amazon India for paperback, Rs. 389 for Kindle edition) Students are highly encouraged to get their own copy of the south asian edition)

In Addition to text chapters, occasionally, there will be sections from the reference, other book chapters, or articles. All chapters, articles, readings, lectures, will be uploaded on Google Classroom

Auditory and Temporal Cognition [PSY-3022] [PSY-3022-1]

Faculty Name
Manon Grube [manon.grube@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Welcome to “Auditory & Temporal Cognition”!

This course will: take you on a journey deep into the human central auditory system, its structure and functions, ranging from simple pitch discrimination to rhythm perception, and all the way up to language and music processing, the two most sophisticated “end uses” of auditory cognition. We will also cover the related dysfunctions, including developmental and neurological ones, with one specific focus on rhythm and timing in the human brain as the basis for music, language - and even movement. 
We will start with the inner ear and move on into the brain, along the ascending auditory pathway, discover specialisation of the relevant brain structures, learn about the role of expertise (e.g. musicianship) and go full circle by touching on predictions and top-down projections.
Each of the lectures will in the following session be complemented by presentations and critical discussion of related articles of your choice, which will range from relevant classical studies to hot-of-the-press ones.

Learning Outcomes

Knowledge:  An in-depth understanding of the human auditory system, backed up by animal models, and its “high-end functions” of rhythm, speech, music and more in the human brain; getting to know state-of-the-art research, ranging from the past decades to hot-off-the-press.

Meta-Skills: Understanding, explaining and discussing research articles, including aspects of critical thinking, as well as the development of new research ideas from there.

Personal development: Discovering or shaping your personal research interests, with the possibility to partake in cutting edge science on rhythm and time perception in the human brain, and gaining insights into the world of research and publishing.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Recommended Textbooks (not mandatory but to choose from to back up or deepen your understanding of the respective topics)
E-copies of the textbooks will be shared with you via the AMS/Google Classroom.
All relevant reserach articles/chapters to be read or used for the presentations will also be shared. 

1. Moore, B. C. J. (2013). Introduction to the Psychology of Hearing. MIT Press.

2. Patel, A. (2007). Music, Language, and the Brain. Oxford University Press. 

3. London, J. (2004). Hearing in Time: Psychological Aspects of Musical Meter. Oxford Univ. Press.

4. Schnupp, J. (2012). Auditory Neuroscience: Making Sense of Sound. MIT Press

Grading Rubric

Course Requirements & Grading

Exams (20% each of final grade):
There will be two exams: one after the first part (around midterm break) and one after the second part (toward the end of the semester). They are designed to assess your learning of the relevant knowledge and understanding of the auditory system and the higher cognitive skills including rhythm, language and music as covered in the course. The first one will be an in-class one consisting of questions requiring circumscribed concrete answers about the lecture material; the second one will be a 48h essay-type take-home exam, based on a choice of research topic questions for you to select from, which are open to more elaborate or even “blue skies'' answers.

Research Article Presentation (20% each of final grade):
Over the course of the semester you will partake in two rounds of scientific papers. These papers will typically be peer-reviewed research articles, published in more or less “prestigious” journals. In each round, you will study, present, discuss and critique with the group in class one peer-reviewed journal research article that will be related to the topics of the lecture. The presentation will be held in groups of 3 (or 2 - depending on the class size). Each presentation will be 20 min long, plus up to 10 min for discussion of the research and the paper (methods, results, conclusions, possible future directions to go into), during which the instructor can also give some additional background -or even anecdotal- knowledge on the topic, followed by up to 10 min of feedback from the group and instructors. Precise guidelines for this assignment will be discussed in class and shared with you. Also the list of the research papers and the PDFs of the papers will be shared with you on AMS/google classroom, where you can have a look at them and then choose your three favourites, so we can create the list of presentations for the first, and later on the second round. In case anything remains unclear or you would like some help with choosing your paper to present, do not hesitate to contact myself or the team. In case you have a research paper that you are interested in and wish to present that fits the topic of the course but is not on the course list, please feel free to reach out to me or the team (:

Participation (20% of final grade):
Participation will be a composite score from attendance, participation in class by asking questions and engaging in discussions during lectures and research article presentations details, as well as the possible participation in research requirements which will be communicated separately.
