Cognition in Action [PSY-3024] [PSY-3024-1]

Faculty Name
Supriya Ray [supriya.ray@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

“We have a brain for one reason and one reason only -- that’s to produce adaptable and complex movements. Movement is the only way we have been affecting the world around us…. And therefore it’s important to remember when you are studying memory, cognition, sensory processing, they’re there for a reason, and that reason is ACTION.”― [Daniel Wolpert in Fred Kavli Distinguished International Scientist Lecture at the Society for Neuroscience meeting, 2009]

In this course, you will learn how we plan, control and execute an action. Different kinds of action will be categorized to reflexive, patterned, voluntary and autonomic. You will learn neuroscience and cognitive processes underlying a large repertoire of actions we perform on day-to-day basis, from elementary activity like walking to complicated and time-critical action like key-boarding or catching ball in cricket game. We will also discuss the physiology of human motor system, and atypical movement behaviours in pathological conditions. 

Learning Outcomes

This course is primarily designed for undergraduate students. By the end of this course students will be able to
•    Understand basic principles of the motor actions.
•    Describe organisation of human motor system in the brain.
•    Explain the psychology of action.
•    Characterize different types of activity systems like spatial navigation, eye-hand coordination etc.
•    Distinguish different brain mechanisms of motor control.
•    Understand fundamental reasons behind movement disorders.
 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Lecture Sessions are scheduled on _______ and __________,  in addition Dr. Ray will hold office on __________ every week. The aim will be to give a foundation on the topics listed below. Reading the corresponding topic before attending the lecture is expected, but not mandatory, for better understanding and interaction. Lectures are designed to supplement the assigned readings.

WEEK                                                                    TOPIC
1 – 3.                        Module I (Overview of the motor system)

                        Types of action:
                        a)    Reflex action
                        b)    Instinctive action
                        c)    Voluntary action
                        d)    Central pattern generation
                        Issues of motor control
                        a)    Degrees of freedom problem
                        b)    Sequencing and timing problem
                        c)    Perceptual-motor integration problem
                        d)    Learning problem
                        Psychology of action
                        a)    States of mind (Attention, Intention, Emotion, Ideo-Motor theory)
                        b)    Motor memory (Implicit and explicit memories, Acquisition, Consolidation)
                        c)    Skill acquisition (Closed loop theory and Stage theory, Hierarchical learning, Imagery)
4 – 6.                        Module II (The neuroscience of action)
                        Motor command generation system
                        a)    Motor, Premotor, Supplementary motor cortices; Frontal and Parietal lobes.
                        b)    Basal ganglia, Cerebellum
                        c)    Spinal cord
                        Motor command execution system
                        a)    Motor neurons and motor units
                        b)    Muscle spindles
                        c) Proprioception
7 – 9.                        Module III (The activity systems)
                        a)    Navigation
                        b)    Reaching and Grasping
                        c)    Eye movement and Eye-hand coordination
                        d)    Drawing and Writing
                        e)    Keyboarding
                        f)    Vocalization
                        g)    Action integration (e.g., Social interaction) 
                        h)    Action in ball sports (e.g., Hitting/ Catching an oncoming ball)
10 – 12.                    Module IV (Disorders in motor control)
                        1. Mechanisms of motor control
                        a) Representation b) Dynamics c) Kinematics d) Flexibility
                        2. Movement disorders
                        a) Ataxia, apraxia, dyskinesia, hyperkinesias
                        b) Parkinson’s, Huntington’s, Lou Gehrig’s (ALS) disease
 

Prerequisites: Elementary knowledge in cognition and neuroscience may help

Course Reading

Introductory Python for Experimental Psychologists [PSY-3025] [PSY-3025-1]

Faculty Name
Dipanjan Ray Ray [dipanjan.ray@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Introductory Python for Experimental Psychologists is designed as an undergraduate course for students who are seeking to build their expertise in experimental psychology with an emphasis on using Python. This course will provide an introduction to the Python programming language, focusing on how it can be utilized for the design and analysis of psychology experiments. Students will learn how to use the PsychoPy package for creating experiments and the matplotlib library for data visualization, along with other relevant Python libraries. The current course aims to introduce the fundamentals of Python programming while also helping students gain confidence when designing experiments. The course was designed keeping in mind the students who have minimal or no coding experience but who are interested to learn to program.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this course, students will be able to:

  • Understand the fundamentals of Python programming.
  • Create simple scripts and functions in Python.
  • Use Python libraries such as PsychoPy to design psychology experiments.
  • Process and analyze experimental data using Python.
  • Use Python libraries such as matplotlib for visualizing experimental data.
  • Understand the importance of reproducibility in psychological research and how to achieve it through coding best practices.

CourseTitle: State, Stateless Societies and Problems of Power
description:
State, Stateless Societies and Problems of Power [SOA-2101] [SOA-2101-1]

Faculty Name
Mekhala Krishnamurthy [mekhala.krishnamurthy@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is a course about social order and as its title indicates it explores the subject by working through the relationships between the idea and existence of state/s, stateless societies, and power in human societies. How is social order made and maintained in stateless societies? What is the difference between stateless societies and stateless persons? How are states formed and what forms do they take, when and where?  For instance, how does colonialism rationalise the use of power? What is the relationship of legitimacy to power in the making of the modern state? And what are the forms of belonging and resistance to the authority of the state? What is the meaning of sovereignty? How does bureaucracy work? Who is a citizen? What are the processes through which membership to the nation-state is achieved? Like all sociology and anthropology cores, the course must contend with the complex and oftentimes confusing relationship between chronological and conceptual evolution across different scales and diverse contexts, working through history, social theory, and ethnographies of the state. In the process, we will also reflect on the role of the State in shaping the state of our discipline and others. Inevitably, the problem of capitalisation (State/state) is one among many problems of power we will have to deal with and try to evade. 

Grading Rubric

1. Preparation and class participation
This is a core course for Sociology and Anthropology Majors. Regular attendance, preparation, and critical engagement are required of each and every participant. This will account for 10 percent of your grade.


2. Mid-term Examination
There will be a take-home examination around mid-term. This will account for 45 percent of your grade

3. Final Examination/Paper
There will be a take-home examination at the end of the course. This will account for 45 percent of your grade. The end-of-term assignment may be converted into a research paper, which will need to be discussed and agreed upon well in advance and by 31 October at the latest to provide adequate time for research. The final exam itself will be structured to give you enough choice to explore themes and regions of specific interest.  

Attendance Policy

From Week 2 onwards, you have 4 unexcused absences. If you have a valid excuse, e-mail me and the TF with the reason as soon as the reason allows. You are expected to attend and participate in the Discussion Sessions and I look forward to also meeting during office hours.

CourseTitle: ??Boom and Bust: The Politics of Economic Crisis
description:
​​Boom and Bust: The Politics of Economic Crisis [SOA-2235] [SOA-2235-1]

Faculty Name
Nishita Trisal [nishita.trisal@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course examines the lived experience of economic crises—at the level of individuals and households, institutions and nations. We will begin with interrogating the idea of crisis itself, asking about what the term enables us to understand and what it obscures. We will then move into tracking different forms of economic transformations and crises across time and space, from early financial “bubbles” to market liberalization and structural adjustment to more recent experiences of financialization and austerity. The course’s broader aim is to demystify and dissect economic arrangements that we have come to see as given and natural. Assignments will include weekly responses, short essays, and a final project.

Nature, Culture, Power [SOA-3125/ ES-3343/ SOA-6115] [SOA-3125/ ES-3343/ SOA-6115-1]

Faculty Name
Mitul Baruah [mitul.baruah@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course examines the political economic contexts of environmental transformations and the ways in which our understandings of and relations with nature are materially and discursively bound up with notions of culture, identity, and power. In the Anthropocene, it has become particularly important to re-examine the meaning(s) of nature, and the relations that humans have with the non-humans, including material artefacts, across different scales. Equally relevant is to question what constitutes anthropological knowledge and how it is produced. This course engages with these issues by drawing on scholarship in political ecology, agrarian studies, and the Anthropocene.

The course is designed as a graduate seminar, which means it is reading- and writing-intensive. It has a component of student-led discussions for which you will need to form small groups and I will work closely with each group to help you select topics and readings. You will also need to write a final research paper on a topic of your choice that is relevant to the course. Advanced undergraduate students are also welcome to take this course.    

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

This course is designed as a graduate seminar. Advanced undergraduate students are welcome as well provided they are committed to the course and are willing to keep up with the course requirements.

Strike! [SOA-3126] [SOA-3126-1]

Faculty Name
Nishita Trisal [nishita.trisal@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course explores the strike in its many forms—anti-colonial, general, labor—to consider questions of value, work, sacrifice, temporality, and collective action. What is a strike and what are its effects? How is the success or failure of a strike measured? What do strikes reveal about the ways that groups manage the needs of individuals and of the collective? The course will delve into classical works on the strike as well as ethnographies, literary, and cinematic depictions. We will examine the strike in a number of contexts, from colonial Jamaican plantations to the mills of Bombay to the Palestinian Intifada. Readings will draw from Rosa Luxemburg, W. E. B. Du Bois, M.K. Gandhi, Verónica Gago, Banu Bargu, Eli Thorkelsen, Yarimar Bonilla, among others. Potential films will include Albert Pinto Ko Gussa Kyun Aata Hai? (1980), The Battle of Algiers (1966), and Hunger (2008). In addition to class presentations and weekly Canvas posts, for the final project students will critically examine a historical or contemporary strike action.

CourseTitle: The Overstory and Understory of Laws for Nature: State, Society, Environment
description:
The Overstory and Understory of Laws for Nature: State, Society, Environment [SOA-3128/ SOA-6117/ ES-3422] [SOA-3128/ SOA-6117/ ES-3422-1]

Faculty Name
Rita Brara Mukhopadhyay [rita.mukhopadhyay@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Justice for nature calls for critical understanding of laws that have been designed for its protection. This course will look into the ‘overstory’ of environmental laws - the stated intent  - along with the sub-plots and conflicts that comprise the ‘understory’ as we tease out the layers of entangled meanings on the ground. We will analyse why environmental laws are not delivering and delve into how we might straighten the crooked timber and remodel what could form a protective canopy for the planet.

Case studies from India will add  life and depth to the course. We hope to enliven legal content with an assignment that has a field-research component.

Anthropology of Mental Health [SOA-3213/ PSY-3151/ SOA-6116] [SOA-3213/ PSY-3151/ SOA-6116-1]

Faculty Name
Bhrigupati Singh [bhrigupati.singh@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Mental illness and wellbeing have been defined and treated in dramatically different ways across cultures and historical epochs. In this course we engage with religious and secular diagnostic traditions, and the ways in which these forms of knowledge shape the experience and understanding of “unreason”. We examine the emergence of modern diagnostic categories such as depression, anxiety, addiction, and schizophrenia, and debates on changing perceptions of the normal and the pathological. Drawing on anthropology, psychiatry, philosophy, literature and cinema, we follow the emergence, translation and critique of diagnostic categories across different parts of the contemporary world. We begin with a canonical “history of madness” by Michel Foucault, which sets out key discursive shifts that led to contemporary formations of medical knowledge and power.

We take up longstanding debates on whether or not psychiatric categories are inherently western, as well as anthropological attempts to understand the ways in which such categories are translated and deployed in new cultural contexts. We engage with traditions of spiritual healing and the ways in which such traditions remain alive in the contemporary world. We read classic ethnographies of mental illness and closely examine three conditions of local and global significance – addiction, depression, and schizophrenia, placed within the wider contention that mental health/illness may be one of the most urgent albeit elusive and shape-shifting crises in the contemporary world. This course aims to introduce students to anthropological approaches to mental health, to engage with varied concepts of psychic distress, the experiences of patients and caregivers, and the instability of the idea of the normal.

This course seeks to familiarize students with current debates and older and newer literatures in the anthropology of mental health, through which we learn ways of thinking about subjectivity, selfhood, the history and emergence of particular diagnostic categories, the cultural valences of scientific categories and their modes of translation into new contexts. We also engage other ways of understanding such experiences for instance through forms of religion, from the vantage point of families and institutions, and the varied ways in which suffering and healing are experienced in the contemporary world. Welcome to what we hope will be an adventure of thought and learning!

Thesis Workshop I [SOA-4101] [SOA-4101-1]

Faculty Name
Kathryn Collins Hardy [kathryn.hardy@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This workshop aims at helping ASP and MLS students in Sociology-Anthropology and related fields design and execute their research projects.  It will be run as an intensive seminar where students actively collaborate with each other to refine their research proposals and provide support during data collection and interpretation.  By the end of the course, students should have finalised their project design and started collecting data.

Since this is a student-driven workshop, its structure will evolve according to participants’ needs.  Nevertheless, here is a provisional list of topics that we expect to address:

*  The well-designed proposal: asking a good question, converting it into a do-able project

*  What counts as evidence?

*  Mapping the field: using preliminary surveys, genealogies and other relationship charts

*  Using secondary sources

*  Interviewing and observing

*  Making notes, record-keeping and revising

*  Ethical concerns

Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, each student shall have finalised their research proposal and made some progress towards collecting and interpreting data.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Draft proposal for an ASP or MLS thesis in Sociology-Athropology or allied discipines.

Grading Rubric

Students will be graded on the basis of (1) the quality of their participation in the course, and on (2) timely submission of assignments. 

The grade break-up is as follows:

Proposal presentation (another student’s): 10%

Comments on other proposals: 20%

Revised proposal: 30%

Written assignment: 30%

Overall participation: 10%

Attendance Policy

Each student is allowed up to 3 absences during the semester, as long as they inform the professor and TA in advance.

Those students who are absent from a class must send written comments on the proposals that they missed discussing, by the end of the week. The comments should be added to the Classroom Stream.

Critical Writing Workshop [SOA-6102] [SOA-6102-1]

Faculty Name
Mekhala Krishnamurthy [mekhala.krishnamurthy@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The Critical Writing Workshop is one of the three core courses in the PhD programme in Sociology & Anthropology and is generally taken in the first semester of coursework, alongside Concepts, Contemporaneity and the Social. Like all critical writing courses, it is also, inextricably, a course about critical thinking and critical reading and about the craft, disciplinary practices, politics, responsibility of academic writing, and all the many ways that sociologists and anthropologists have engaged with what it means to write critically. So, there will be room to read, talk and think about writing as scholars in university. But most of all it is structured around the understanding that it is critical that we write, not only eventually in a vocational sense, but quite simply that we write in this semester-long workshop. So we will write. 

Grading Rubric

TBC, but it's all about written assignments

CourseTitle: Visual and Material Cultures of the Himalayas
description:
Visual and Material Cultures of the Himalayas [VA-2006/ SOA-2215/ MS-3098] [VA-2006/ SOA-2215/ MS-3098-1]

Faculty Name
Latika Gupta [latika.gupta@ashoka.edu.in] ,Praise Yohannes Kassa [praiseyohannes.kassa_asp24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course focuses on the Western Himalayan regions of Ladakh, Himachal Pradesh and Tibet to understand how visual and material cultures are intrinsically connected with the idea of ‘place’. It examines how places, cultures and people are constructed through representations — visual and written — both by outsiders as well as local communities. Students will engage with critical questions about the ethics of representation in imaging ‘other’ places and people through photography and writing, the political and social processes that inform the making of tradition, and the entanglements of politics and culture in the formation of regional and national identities.

We will study colonial and contemporary photography, travel accounts, art historical writing, contemporary fiction, material culture at temples and monasteries, performative rituals, museum displays, films and representations in popular culture. We will visit Buddhist monasteries at Majnu-ka-Tilla in Delhi to study material culture through its use, and look at the role that cultural markers such as architecture, clothing and food play in marking places of specific communities and cultures.

A key area of study will be major museum collections of Himalayan art in India, Europe and North America. Some of the questions we will be exploring include: How are cultures constructed through acts of museumisation? How did the field of Himalayan Art emerge? Where do we locate this field; which geographical areas and religions are made emblematic of this discipline; which cultures are excluded and why? How were museum collections built and in what historical circumstances? What curatorial strategies are used to reconstruct the auras of objects? How are sacred objects of use segregated into categories of art and ethnography?

The course will examine the recent museum-making impulse in the Himalayas through case studies of a range of museums situated in these borderlands — war memorial museums, community museums of conflict and trade route artifacts in the Kargil district of Ladakh, and museums in Buddhist monasteries to understand the relationship between heritage and religion, the impact of the movement of things from sacred sites to ‘secular’ museums, and to ask how a politics of remembrance may manifest in cultural production.

The course will conclude with an introduction to contemporary Tibetan art and Tibetan/ Buddhist culture-in-exile where we will explore modern and contemporary art, poetry and literature, films and pop culture.

 

Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, students:
• will be familiar with the broad field of the visual and material cultures in the Western Himalayas in Tibet, Ladakh and Himachal Pradesh.
• will learn about major museums and collections of Himalayan Art and be able to critically analyze the framing of objects as art/ ethnography, and questions of provenance research and label writing in object displays.
• will be conversant with critical questions around heritage, the politics of museums and the role of tradition in the construction of contemporary cultural identities.
• will acquire the critical tools interrogate the nature and impact of representation of regions, cultures and communities through images and written texts.
• will be able to critically read images and texts, with a focus on meaning making through vocabularies and and terminologies, and apply this critical thinking through a
practical curatorial project with each student curating an independent exhibition.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Preliminary/ Select Bibliography:
• Anand, Dibyesh. “Western Colonial Representations of the Other- The Case of Exotica Tibet”, New Political Science 29 (1) March 2007, 23-42.

• Bishop, Peter (2000) The Sacred Myth of Shangri-La: Tibet, Travel Writing and the Western Creation of Sacred Landscape. New Delhi: Adarsh Enterprises, 2000.

• Harrison, Victoria S. 2021. Introduction to the Special Issue “Religion in Museums”. Religions 12: 139. https://doi.org/10.3390/rel12020139

• Heimsath, Kabir M. “Lhasa Nights”, https://www.asianart.com/exhibitions/lhasanights/index.html
• Hopkirk, Peter. Trespassers on the Roof of the World- The Race for Lhasa. Oxford University Press, 1983.

• Linrothe, Rob. “Photography, painting, and prints in Ladakh andZangskar. Intermediality and transmediality” Études mongoles et sibériennes, centrasiatiques et tibétaines, 51, 2020.

• Wingfield, Christopher (2010) ‘Touching the Buddha: encounters with a charismatic object’ in Sandra Dudley (ed.) Museum materialities: objects, engagements, interpretations. London and New York: Routledge, pp 53-70.

 

Grading Rubric

Students will be graded on the basis of active participation in class seminars, on written assignments (essay, critical report), a curated exhibition for the larger community at Ashoka, and a presentation about it in class. All assignments will be evaluated for originality of thinking, critical analysis and clearly expressed arguments. Plagiarism will not be tolerated.

  • Seminar Participation: 20%
  • Critical Report (1000 words): 25%
  • Exhibition and Presentation: 25%
  • End Semester essay (2000-2500 words including footnotes, bibliography): 30%
Attendance Policy

Three absences without notice are permitted. However, since grading will be based on continuous assessment through the semester, absences during participative seminars will result in a reduction in the overall grade.

CourseTitle: Figure Drawing as Remembering and Reimagining
description:
Figure Drawing as Remembering and Reimagining [VA-2016] [VA-2016-1]

Faculty Name
Rakhi Peswani [rakhi.peswani@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Title of the Course: Figurative Drawing

Level of the Course: 2000, 3000,

Prerequisites: None

Course Description: In Western academic art education, figurative drawing was until recently considered the foundation, the essential prerequisite for mastering disciplines of painting, sculpture, frescos and murals. Although it is no longer a requisite skill for contemporary artists, a high proportion would still agree that irrespective of whatever material they might chose to work in, they ‘think’ in terms of drawings. Drawing is more than simply a skill in the sense that it offers a path to self-discovery, revealing a cast of mind, an imaginative capacity and a mode of perception.

This course encourages students to re-think and re-imagine the human body beyond a representational image, as an entity with constant trans-mutative possibilities in terms of form, functionality and aesthetics. Through a combination of practice and discourse, the course encourages explorations beyond human anatomy by focusing on the varied manifestations and meanings ascribed to the human figure, vis-à-vis the body, in the context of visual art and beyond.

Students will be introduced to contemporary artistic practices and deliberations on artistic visions, experiences and wisdoms that push the boundaries of excepted notions of ‘high’ art and critique hierarchies of attitude. Tracing the history of figure drawing as a genre that goes back to Classical antiquity to Italian Renaissance, extending into the 18th century French academia and the 19th century Victorian Era, students will get a broad overview of how the established notion of accuracy and idealized beauty continues to be challenged and reinvented as artists take on a variety of approaches to drawing the human figure. 

The course looks at how the idealized notion of body is challenged and replaced with bodies that are bruised, grotesque and out of proportions with visible stretch marks, skin hair, wrinkles and pigmentation. How has the conscious shift towards drawing from memory and imagination as opposed to drawing from a live model or from photographic references allowed artists to create works that are often loaded with political commentary and emotive power?

In this course, students have the flexibility to work with both analog and digital mediums and materials in enabling them to connect to their own context, concerns and interests with a sense of immediacy by using the human figure as a trigger.

The frameworks we will be working through the course include:

Understanding the various kinds of representations of human figure - from different social and cultural contexts. Locating discursive modes of representation.

Probing ideas of beauty, identity, sexuality and gender, through human form.

Understanding space-time and memory in the context of human body and its representation.

Exploring the human figure in contemporary drawings under the broad categorizations of the body, self, personal lives, social realty and fictions.

Reflecting on processes of overlapping, erasures and incision as acts layered with emotive and intuitive sensibilities.

Developing an individual methodology /strategy to figurative drawing.

The course will unfold over three modules; each spread over four weeks respectively, and will include both theoretical readings and practical assignments.  

Module 1

The human figure in visual arts:

A historical perspective, a cultural and social perspective.

Representing human body- a repository of concepts.

Overview- Western naturalism through Renaissance, Human form in Egyptian Drawing, Indian painting and Human form.

Basic observational drawings.

Portraiture and history painting.

The renaissance body- Leonardo, Michelangelo and Raphael, Durer

Representing flesh and desire- Boucher, Ingre, Rubens,

Modernity and Body - Humor, satire and politics of  expressing the Body in painting, sculpture. (Manet, van Gogh, Rodin, Daumier,  

Drawing from archival works,

Conceptualising a space for body – Giorgio de Chirico, Piranesi, Escher,  

Module 2:

Body as a biological entity

Anatomy studies, life drawing, studies in biology and medical discourse.

Triumph of realism in representations of body,

Drawing the body- precision in Biology

Structures of form- synthesizing biological and organic material.

Module 3:

The human figure in Contemporary Art

Body as a Phenomenological tool-

Expressionism, Surrealism, Body and Conceptual Art, Feminism, Neo- expressionism, the Popular

Depictions through drawing and photography, - Ana Mandietta, Janine Antoni,

Body as performative tool. - Marina Abramovic, Yoko Ono, Rumana Hussain

Depictions through journaling, everyday bodies – Louise Bourgeoise, Chittoprasad, Arpita Singh,

Body as wear and tear, absences, fragmented, diseased – Kiki Smith, Eva Hesse, Anthony Gormley

Body as text and body as material- Jenny Holzer, Nalini Malani, Mithu Sen, Juul Krajer

Body as Monuments of  social expressions. – Doh Ho Suh, Kara Walker, William Kentridge

Learning Outcomes

Learning Objectives: 

The course is expected to make students aware of the significant position of the human figure in art, especially in the context of drawing and conceptualization.

Some of the key concepts on culture and representation will be explored-  realism, mimesis, illustration, and the role of fantasy and memory in the process of artistic production.

Students will learn about fundamental techniques of representation through observation, imaging.

Students will learn processes, mediums and materials employed by artists, both historically and in contemporary times.   

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Readings

Gombrich, E. H. The Story of Art. Phaidon, 1995.

Seligman, Isabel, et al. Lines of THOUGHT: Drawing from Michelangelo to Now. Thames & Hudson, 2016.

 

Laurenza, Domenico. Art and Anatomy in Renaissance Italy: Images from a Scientific Revolution. Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2012.

McLean, Cheryl, and Brown, Clint. Drawing from Life. United Kingdom, Wadsworth/Thomson, 2004.

Keele, Kenneth D., and Jane Roberts. Leonardo Da Vinci: Anatomical Drawings from the Royal Collection, Windsor Castle. Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1983.

Hale, Robert Beverly. Drawing Lessons from the Great Masters. Watson-Guptill Publications, 1964.

Benjamin A. Rifkin, Michael J. Ackerman. (2006) Human Anatomy (From the Renaissance to the Digital Age)

Richard Barnett(2014).  The Sick Rose: Disease and the Art of Medical Illustration

Malbert, Roger, and Sarah Praill. Drawing People: The Human Figure in Contemporary Art. Thames and Hudson, 2016.

Bell, Julian, et al. Ways of Drawing: Artists' Perspectives and Practices. Thames and Hudson, 2019.

Additional readings: 

Gardner, Helen, and Fred S. Kleiner. Gardner's Art through the Ages: The Western Perspective. Cengage Learning, 2021.

Man as Hero: The Human Figure in Western Art. W.W. Norton, 2005.

Thomson, Arthur. The Handbook of Anatomy for Art Students. Clarendon Pr., 1896.

Farnell, B. M. (2011). Theorizing “the Body” in Visual Culture. In M. Banks, & J. Ruby (Eds.), Made to Be Seen: Perspectives on the History of Visual Anthropology (pp. 136-158). University of Chicago Press

Rice, Pierce.

Grading Rubric

Continuous assessment throughout the semester on the basis of class assignments, readings and contribution to class discussions.

Grading Rubrics for assignments:

Dedicated work in images. (stipulated number of drawings will not be enough to produce quality in work. Quality of drawing will be dependent on learning skills. Each assignment will have grading based on your skills of boldness, willingness to experiment, dedication at work and bringing minute observations onto your media form. The essay will look at your understanding of concepts and relation with the world of visuals. )

Mid-Term assessment:

Assignment 1 (20%),

Attendance (20%),

End semester assessment:

Assignment 2 (25%),

Assignment 3 (25 %),

Display (10 %) 

Attendance Policy

2 absences need no prior approval or medical documentation.

(Each class is for 3 hours, taking two weekly sessions together. )

The Earth and Other Planets [AST-2840/ AST-3840/ PHY-3840] [AST-2840/ AST-3840/ PHY-3840-1]

Faculty Name
Sujan Kumar Sengupta [sujan.sengupta@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course wll be taught by Guest Faculty Prof. Sujan Sengupta (sujan@iiap.res.in)

Syllabus:

Introduction- Why study planetary science: Towards a possible answer to the eternal question of mankind “Are we alone”.   

Solar Planets- A brief history of the number of solar planets and their discovery. The Sun: properties and position in our Galaxy. Formation of the Sun and the Solar system.

The Earth- the only known habitable planet. Structure and composition of the Earth’s interior; Atmosphere, Ocean and their interaction; source of water on Earth; past and future course of evolution of the earth; origin of the Moon

The other rocky Solar planets – Mercury, Venus, Mars. The asteroid belt.
The gas giant planets- Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune.  Why Pluto is not a planet, the IAU definition of Solar planets and the dwarf planets.
Kuiper belt and Oort Cloud- the boundary of the Solar system. Comets and the moons of the solar family.
Can there be life anywhere in the solar system?
The search for the ninth planet – last station of the solar system.
The ultimate fate of the Sun and its planets.

Extrasolar Planets- Introduction: A brief history of the search and discovery of exoplanets. Detection methods of exoplanets – Radial velocity, Transit, Gravitational microlensing, Timing, Astrometry, Polarimetry. The wonderful worlds beyond our own- Hot Jupiters, Mini Neptunes, Super-Earths, Planets orbiting multiple stars, Free-floating planets, Self-luminous exoplanets, Exomoons.

Astrobiology- Galactic Habitable Zone and Circumstellar Habitable Zone. Equilibrium temperature, Albedo and Greenhouse effect. Definition and Origin of Terrestrial life. Various astrophysical and geological life-supporting conditions on Earth. Intelligent life and Drake equation. Kardashev scale of civilizations. Transmission spectra of planets and search for bio-signature. Search for techno-signature of intelligent life. Threats to terrestrial life and its future.

Learning Outcomes

Knowledge about planets in the solar system and around other stars.  Learning the methods of detecting extra-solar planets.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Recommended reading:

(1) Worlds Beyond Our Own- The Search for Habitable Planets by Sujan Sengupta (Springer,  
      2015).
(2) ExtraSolar planets and Astrobiology by Celeb A Scharf (University Science Books, 2008).
(3) The Exoplanet Handbook by Michael Perryman (Cambridge University Press, 2018).
(4) Fundamental Planetary Science: Physics, Chemistry and Habitability by Jack J. Lissauer  
     (Cambridge University Press, 2019).
(5) Handbook of Astrobiology by Vera M. Kolb, (CRC Press, 2021).

Grading Rubric

Quizzes and Assignments: 50%

Mid-term Examination: 20%

Final examination: 30%

Attendance Policy

Miimum 80% attendnce required

Ecology and Evolution (Lab) [BIO-3012/ ES-3301] [BIO-3012/ ES-3301-1]

Faculty Name
Balaji Chattopadhyay [balaji.chattopadhyay@ashoka.edu.in] ,Imroze Khan [imroze.khan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Shivani [shivani.krishna@ashoka.edu.in ] ;
Overview

Students will be introduced to quantitative methods of research in ecology and evolution including experimental design, data collection, analysis, interpretation and scientific writing using field, laboratory and bioinformatic studies. They will work with plant and animal models from local ecosystems to empirically test concepts in population growth, competition, resource utilization, foraging behavior, communication, ecological parameters on bacterial growth (e.g. pH & temperature), data mining, sequence analyses and phylogenetic reconstruction. The course aims at giving an experience of concepts and methods discussed in theory courses of ecology, evolutionary biology, bioinformatics, and biostatistics. Towards the end of this course, students will be able to design and implement appropriate methods for sampling individuals, populations and communities and ask questions on their diversity, stability, productivity, and evolutionary history. Modules dealing with behavioral experiments will also demonstrate potential errors that arise due to observer bias, the significance of blinded methods, and other potential ways to improve the reliability of the data collected.

Below is the tentative schedule for the course

1. Models of spatial distribution: a test using dispersion of leaf galls

2. Patterns of morphological variation: geometric morphometric analysis

3. Influence of floral rewards on foraging behavior of bees (optimal foraging)

4. Prey capture dynamics and personalities in social spiders- I

5. Prey capture dynamics and personalities in social spiders-II

6. Quantitative morphology of divergent traits in insects

7. Interspecific competition

8. Public database and mining of sequence data

9. Sequence data analyses

10. Phylogenetic reconstruction

11. Sexual selection and mate harm (Antagonistic coevolution)

12. Evolution of antibiotic resistance-I (Tracking evolution as it happens)

13. Evolution of antibiotic resistance-II (Tracking genetic basis of adaptation)

Note that this is a tentative course structure and hence, is subject to further change, if necessary

Learning Outcomes

This course comprises 12 stand-alone laboratory modules. Each module aims at revisiting some of the concepts introduced in the lectures and will provide a hands-on
experience of general methods used in ecological and evolutionary biology studies. Thinking analytically and scientific writing are best developed through practice.
Thus, actively engaging in writing laboratory reports will serve as a useful tool to improve students’ writing skills.

Grading Rubric

1) Weekly reports (90%): Each lab report is worth 10 marks. Final grading will consider
the best nine reports. Reports need to be submitted before the following week’s practical.
Delayed submission of weekly reports will result in a deduction of 2 marks. The weekly lab report written based on the experiment conducted should comprise a brief
introduction, aims/objectives, methods used, analyses and results, discussion and conclusion.
2) Lab etiquettes and class participation (10%)

Experiments will be carried out in pairs unless instructed otherwise during the class. Since the lab reports will be based on ones’ own results, attendance to the labs and active
participation is strongly encouraged. Please communicate in advance to the instructors if there is any unavoidable reason for missing the lab. Each student has to write his or her
own report. Any sort of plagiarism or copying will not be tolerated. Late submissions will be accepted only under exceptional circumstances of emergencies or medical conditions.

Attendance Policy

1. Attendance is mandatory. No more than two unexcused absences will be allowed.
2. It is not possible to repeat experiments that have been missed.

Overview

Please contact OLS and / or email Rama before the start of the course if you have any specific learning or access needs.

Who should take this course? Immunology is the study of the immune system - a complex network of organs, cells and proteins that protect the body from disease (except when it doesn’t!). It is an evolving field that is difficult to understand and memorize, making it a challenging subject to learn. This course focuses on introducing fundamental concepts rather than a comprehensive coverage of the subject. UG, ASP and PhD students who want to grasp key concepts of how the immune system works should consider this course. This immunology course can complement student interest / knowledge of cancer therapy, vaccine biology and infectious diseases.

What are the pre-requisites for this course? It is mandatory that students have a background in basic biology. The immune system uses molecular mechanisms that are a part of cell and molecular biology courses (Introduction to biology II and III), so these are a prerequisite for BIO-3443/6443.

What are the expectations from students? The topics being covered are interconnected so it is important that students clarify doubts as we progress through the course. Students are expected to take active part in their learning experience and contribute to an environment conducive to learning in the following ways: Staying current with any mandatory reading / videos / knowledge checks / quizzes / assignments etc; meeting deadlines; sharing thoughts, questions or doubts in class; actively participating in discussions; being enthusiastic about learning the subject, being mentally and physically present in class.

One 15-minute session of office hours per student is mandatory in the first month of the course.

Academic integrity is a must. Any plagiarism or cheating will be dealt with according to the university policy.

Learning Outcomes

After completing this course students will be able to:

  1. Identify components of the immune system. (Unit 1)
  2. Describe how diseased / infected cells are identified (Unit 1)
  3. Describe the key processes in initiation of an immune response. (Unit 1)
  4. Explain how the immune system is able to respond to so many different pathogens, even those that have not been encountered previously. (Unit 2)
  5. Describe some general and specialized immune mechanisms used to control pathogens. (Unit 2)
  6. Explain how immune cells move through the body. (Unit 2)
  7. Describe the fundamental principle behind some common techniques used in immunology research. (Unit 3)
  8. Describe how the immune system is able to discriminate non-self from self or harmful from harmless. (Unit3)
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

We will be loosely following the general structure of the textbook How the immune system works by Lauren Sompayrac. The instructor may also direct students to specific videos / articles or sections from immunology textbooks (Janeway's Immunobiology or Kuby's Immunology). Copies of all are available in the library.

Grading Rubric

Course assessment will be done using absolute grading based on the assignments listed below. This can deviate a little from the plan below based on the instructor’s discretion.

Attendance (10 marks). Learning through interacting with your peers is an important part of this course. You can miss up to 4 unexcused classes. Sick leave beyond that will need a doctor’s note and unexcused absences will  result in loss of 2 marks per class. Absence from 7 or more classes will result in loss of a grade. 

Class participation (10 marks). This can be earned by giving a 10-minute recap of a topic covered in the previous classes (students can do this with or without slides), making a knowledge check quiz for the class, flash cards or by participating in class discussion (in class  or by text in google classrooms).

Written exams (80 marks). There will be 4 written assessments (1 hour, 20 marks each). These will be quiz or short answer type tests conducted in class. The best three (a total of 60 marks, which will count for 80% of the grade) will be counted towards the final grade. It is mandatory for students take at least 3 of the exams. Please talk to the instructor about how to make up in case you are unable to take three exams.

Attendance Policy

The instructor will be following guidelines in the OAA document titled Ashoka Guidelines on Class Attendance and Accommodations OAA (version 2022-01-31).

Learning through interacting with your peers is an important part of this course. As a minimum general attendance policy, students may miss three sessions of 90 minutes each without penalty. For such absences, students do not need to submit any supporting evidence such as doctor’s notes. Note that this does not apply to sessions during which exams or other assignments are scheduled. For any absences the instructor would appreciate an email before class where possible as some class exercises are tailored for a group or need a full class. Sick leave beyond the three unexcused absences will need a doctor’s note and unexcused absences will  result in loss of 2 marks per class. Absence from 7 or more classes will result in loss of a grade. Please see sections 7 and 8 in the Ashoka guidelines for absences in the other situations (representing the university as an athlete or artist, absences related to documented disability or mental health issues).

Archaeology and Science [BIO-3505/ HIS-3993] [BIO-3505/ HIS-3993-1]

Faculty Name
Kalyan Sekhar Chakraborty [kalyan.chakraborty@ashoka.edu.in] ,Nidhi Rudraswamy [nidhi.rudraswamy_ug24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1A1LIWhdPbuI8TKZtmFaGrBex9VM25J3y/view?usp=sharing

Course outlook:

This is a course where archaeology and science meet in order to reconstruct the human past from the relics of past activities using cool scientific techniques. These relics range from the garbage that people have generated as they have lived their daily lives to deliberate constructions like temples and fortifications. Extraction of information from fragmentary material remains and sites require the ingenuity of modern science ranging from dating techniques and experimental methods that is capable of analyzing tiny amounts of archaeological materials to reveal the nuances of the human past. In this course, we will learn how archaeologist piece together the human past using sophisticated scientific techniques. We will learn the history of archaeological science. And how it has helped rediscover past human actions and how these advanced techniques can solve future puzzles about our own history and existence. 

Evaluation system: 

Final exam:                     30%

*Hands-on exercises:        20% (2 x 10%)

Research Presentation:     20%

Research Paper:               30%

*Students will prepare reports of any two exercises. 

Attendance Policy: 70%

Assessment rubric for audit students: Research Paper

CourseTitle: Specificity in gene expression & Cell Signalling
description:
Specificity in gene expression & Cell Signalling [BIO-4226/ BIO-6230] [BIO-4226/ BIO-6230-1]

Faculty Name
Alok Bhattacharya [alok.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in] ,Kasturi Pal [kasturi.pal@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Cell signaling or signal transduction pathways are fundamental mechanisms used across biological systems to effectively relay information within extracellular and intracellular milieu. Understanding such cellular information processing strategies have led to the discovery of numerous drugs which are used for pharmacological perturbation of deleterious pathways in multiple diseases. This course will provide students a broad perspective on how cell signaling mechanisms significantly affect physiology and pathophysiology.  

Learning Outcomes

In this course the students will learn how components of signaling pathways (receptors, ligands, channel proteins and second messengers) regulate physiological functions and phenomenon like host-pathogen interaction, innate and adaptive immunity and embryonic development. The overall goal will be to appreciate the vast diversity in signaling mechanisms and crosstalk between different pathways.

The following topics will be covered during the lectures:

Introduction to Biological signaling

Signaling tool box and methods for deciphering signaling pathways

Second messengers, calcium, cAMP and lipids

Ca2+ and its involvement in cytoskeletal dynamics and exocytosis

Signaling in neurons and cardiovascular system

Signaling in embryonic development

Cell signaling in innate and adaptive immune systems

Cancer signaling

Host-pathogen interaction

Quorum sensing, two component system and communication in bacteria

Endoplasmic stress response and unfolded protein response

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

1. Molecular biology of the Cell

2. Molecular cell biology

3. Other reading materials will be provided during the lectures

Grading Rubric

There will be one mid-term and one final exam. Points will also be awarded to students for class participation.

The final letter grade will be based on a curve

Attendance Policy

70% attendance is mandatory for appearing for the final exam.

CourseTitle: A Cultural Reading of India and China: Connections and Networks
description:
A Cultural Reading of India and China: Connections and Networks [CHI-3005/ HIS-3517/ ENG-3060] [CHI-3005/ HIS-3517/ ENG-3060-1]

Faculty Name
Barnali Chanda [barnali.chanda@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

COURSE DESCRIPTION

In this course we will conduct a comparative cultural and literary study by focusing on the resemblances and contactual relationships and typological affinities within two ancient civilizations, India and China. The complex method of cultural confluence between India and China was initially a spontaneous contact that happened primarily as a result of an intellectual quest by the Buddhist monks. This literary-historical comparative study reveals the spontaneous interliterary contacts between these two civilizations. The Indian literary and philosophical values contributed to the formation and the development of the new trends of the strange tales in the recipient literature. This exchange between India and China is important because Chinese literature is enriched by Indian literature not only as a consequence of direct contacts but also because of the inner potentialities of the emitting Indian phenomenon and this happened in spite of the existence of China’s own strong and powerful cultural heritage. The interliterary reciprocity of these two countries formed a concrete literary and cultural relation and the impact of the source culture was almost undistinguishable and had a creative manifestation in the recipient narrative tradition. The creative manifestation of the narrative tradition due to this direct impact from the source culture was only possible for the recipient culture of China because it already had its own strong and written literary tradition. This course will conduct the thematic comparative study of the strange tales of China and India and its migration to Afroeurasian region. This study will execute a systematic analysis with reference to the cultural, aesthetic and intellectual situation while looking into the lapses and the surviving and the residual elements.

The Unit –I touches upon the advent of Buddhism and the transmission of the Buddhist elements via the translation of the miraculous indigenous strange tale tradition to which Buddhism contributed immensely. A short introduction to the bianwen genre which is considered to be a direct descendent of the Indian gatha tradition will be introduced. Following the Confucian ideology which emphasise greatly on the documentation of history, the narratives that included supernatural elements were documented as a history of the other world. Buddhism, Confucianism and Daoism together had contributed to the growth of the strange tale tradition in China.

Unit 2 will examine the emergence of China as a Buddhist realm and the phase of termination and also discuss the Tang-India diplomatic relations during premodern time. With this advent of Buddhism the translation of Buddhist literatures escalated. The course will discuss the problems and prospects of the early Chinese translations which helped in the linguistic development and evolution.

Unit 3 will discuss the spread of Buddhism across and beyond Asia. Buddhism in China has immensely contributed to the evolution of narrative traditions in China. This unit will illustrate the Indic philosophical concepts and estimate its influence on different narrative genres through the readings of folktales and strange stories. The connection between the historicity and fictionality of the narratives can be understood through the readings of different genres of literatures.

Unit 4 will examine four motifs/themes that are essentially Buddhist and the course can study their reception and acclimatization within the Chinese strange tale tradition. Parallely the course will examine the evolution of similar motifs in the Indian Sanskrit tradition. The purpose of the course also is to draw a pattern expressed through thematic resemblances of the strange and the fantastic stories of the medieval Indian and Chinese literary traditions. With this parallel study it can also be established that after traveling to China, Buddhist philosophy influenced indigenous Chinese folk and popular story tradition and the idea of Buddhism eventually got merged with Daoism and indigenous story tradition.

Learning Outcomes

1. Students are expected to understand what it means when we say comparative and cross-cultural

2. Are expected to understand the multifarious literary connections between China, India and the world

3. will be able to understand and explore the interliterary and cultural connections through Buddhist networks.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

COURSE REQUIREMENTS

READING LIST :

Sen, Tansen. Buddhism, Diplomacy, and Trade: The Realignment of India-China Relations, 600-1400. , 2016. Print.

Sen, Tansen. India, China, and the World. a Connected History. Blue Ridge Summit: Rowman & Littlefield Publ, 2017. Print.

Wang, Bangwei, and Tansen Sen. India and China: A Collection of Essays by Professor Prabodh Chandra Bagchi. London: Anthem Press India, 2011. Internet resource.

Mair, Victor H. Tʼang Transformation Texts: A Study of the Buddhist Contribution to the Rise of Vernacular Fiction and Drama in China. Cambridge, Mass: Council on East Asian Studies, Harvard University, 1989. Print.

Mair, Victor H, and Mark Bender. The Columbia Anthology of Chinese Folk and Popular Literature. New York: Columbia University Press, 2011. Print.

Mair, Victor H. Tun-huang Popular Narratives. Cambridge, UK: Cambridge University Press, 2007. Print.

Mair, Victor H. Experimental Essays on Zhuangzi. Dunedin, Fla: Three Pines Press, 2010. Print.

Kao, Karl S. Classical Chinese Tales of the Supernatural and the Fantastic: Selections from the 3. to the 10. Century. Bloomington: Indiana Univ. Pr, 1985. Print.

Zeitlin, Judith T. Historian of the Strange: Pu Songling and the Chinese Classical Tale. Stanford, Cal: Stanford University Press, 1997. Print.

Owen, Stephen. Remembrances: The Experience of the Past in Classical Chinese Literature. , 2014. Internet resource.

Dudbridge, Glen. Books, Tales and Vernacular Culture: Selected Papers on China. Leiden: Brill, 2005. Print.

Zürcher, Erik, and Jonathan A. Silk. Buddhism in China: Collected Papers of Erik Zürcher. Leiden: Brill, 2014. Print.

Zürcher, Erik, and Stephen F. Teiser. Buddhist Conquest of China: The Spread and Adaptation of Buddhism in Early Medieval China. , 2014. Print.

Lu, Hsiao-peng. From Historicity to Fictionality: The Chinese Poetics of Narrative. Stanford, Calif: Stanford University Press, 1994. Print.

Burton, Richard F, René Bull, and Alfred W. Cooper. The Arabian Nights. , 2016. Print.

Somadeva, , Charles H. Tawney, Norman M. Penzer, and Richard C. Temple. The Ocean of Story Being C.h. Tawney's Translation of Somadeva's Kathā Sarit Sāgara: Or Ocean of Streams of Story. Delhi, Patna, Varanasi: Motilal Banarsidass, 1923. Print.

Grading Rubric

Modes of assessment

Class discussions (30%): There will be an assigned reading for most of the classes, which will either be e-mailed to you a few days in advance or if you need to track it down yourself, you will be informed well in time.You should complete the reading before coming to class and actively participate in the discussions therein. The final class participation grade will be awarded on the basis of your sustained performance throughout the course. Therefore, it is in your best interest to be regular with your readings.

Class presentations (35%): You will be expected to make class presentations before the Mid-Sem in early October. Details will be discussed around the end of September.

Home Assignment (35%): To be submitted at the end of the semester, around the first week of December. Details of the assignment will be discussed in November.

 

 

All assessments will be made by the following grading standards:

A only, A minus: outstanding, very good | B plus, B only, B minus: good | C plus, C only, C minus: adequate | D plus, D only, D minus: barely satisfactory | F only: unsatisfactory

Attendance Policy

Attendance policy and class etiquette

You are expected to attend all the classes and sit through the entire class duration. Please come to the class on time and stay away from your mobile phones. You will be allowed a total of five absences in the course of the semester, which includes medical leave. If you plan not to come to the class, you should inform the teacher (in-person or through electronic message). For every additional absence over and above the permissible limit, there will be a grade cut, one for each additional absence.

Attachment
A Cultural Reading of China and India Connections and Networks.docx

CourseTitle: The Urdu Alphabet and the Poetics of Ghazal
description:
The Urdu Alphabet and the Poetics of Ghazal [CLA-0042] [CLA-0042-1]

Faculty Name
Shah Faisal Mushtaq [shah.mushtaq@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Shah Faisal Mushtaq


نہ تھا کچھ تو خدا تھا کچھ نہ ہوتا تو خدا ہوتا
ڈبویا مجھ کو ہونے نے نہ ہوتا میں تو کیا ہوتا
غالب~

Over the centuries, Ghazal has been one of the most loved genres of poetry. But what exactly is a Ghazal? Where did it originate? What makes the Urdu Ghazal different from other poetic genres? In this course, we will delineate the fundamental structure of Urdu Ghazal, learn the basics of the Urdu poetic metre and trace the poetics of Urdu Ghazal by studying the canonical poets of Urdu. From Amir Khusrau to classical poets like Meer and Ghalib to contemporary poets like Farhat Ehsas, we will try to decipher the philosophies embedded within their Ghazals.

Also, you might be wondering about the Urdu text above. Don't worry! You will be able to read it by the end of the course.

Grading Rubric

The criteria for grading are the following: attendance, participation in class, and a creative project/ assignment determined by the Professor. All three criteria are equal.

Attendance Policy

As the classes are highly participative in nature, more than 2 absences will affect your grade.

CourseTitle: Desan mein Des Haryana: Haryanvi from the Folk to the Popular
description:
Desan mein Des Haryana: Haryanvi from the Folk to the Popular [CLA-0043] [CLA-0043-1]

Faculty Name
Sanchit Toor [sanchit.toor@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Sanchit Toor

The course begins with attempting to locate ourselves in Haryana, understanding our immediate experiences at the University in Haryana's cultural terms. We will consider linguistic diversity in Haryana, wherein features Haryanvi bhasha in the oral domain. The course will progress from looking at the basic structure of the language to mapping the language's expanse from the folk to the popular, including the associated stereotypes. In doing so, we will explore a variety of literary, ethnographic, performative, and cinematic material, particularly through the recent resurgence of transmission channels via social media. Beyond occupying ourselves with the regional firsts—the first Haryanvi poet, the first Haryanvi film, etc.—we will also situate Haryanvi in the national sphere of politics, linguistic or otherwise. As we learn basic communication skills through in-class activities and exchanges, we will also inquire into acts of naming and translating.  
(Basic knowledge of Hindi-Urdu-Punjabi is appreciated but not mandatory.)

CourseTitle: Aspects of Bengali: Sound, Image and Script
description:
Aspects of Bengali: Sound, Image and Script [CLA-0045] [CLA-0045-1]

Faculty Name
Senjuti Chakraborti [senjuti.chakraborti@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Senjuti Chakraborti

The course will attempt to teach listening, reading, speaking, and writing skills in the Bengali language through sound, image, and text encountered in historical, cultural, and everyday contexts. From early in the course, students will be introduced to the Bengali script found on cultural artifacts like Bengali food menus, film, and music subtitles. A key component will be the use of visual materials chronicling the Bengali Language Movement and the birth of Bangladesh. Learning the Bengali alphabet through these sounds and images, students will then be taught how to combine these alphabets to compose Bengali words. The course will finally aim for a short exhibition in which students can label their family/college photographs in Bengali to create an album, and/or label food items to create a short menu.

Indian Dance: Kathak ki Pehchaan [CPA-0019] [CPA-0019-1]

Faculty Name
Daniel Freddy [daniel.freddy@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Daniel Freddy

An introduction to Kathak, a classical dance form. The course would include both practical and theoretical training. The Practical part of the course would mainly focus on the basic techniques of Kathak, namely footwork (tatkaar, tihais, and ladi), hand movements, wrist movements, chakkars, and tukdas. Apart from technique, the course would give the students an insight into ‘abhinaya’ (expressions). The students would be taught either of the following: thumri, vandana, bhajan, based on their understanding and interest.

The theory would include a basic introduction of Kathak, its history, and about some of the eminent dancers belonging to a specific gharana. Apart from this, the students would be given detailed explanation of the entire practical knowledge, and an in-depth knowledge about the piece of abhinaya that they would be learning.

CourseTitle: Pulse and Impulse: Rhythm and Time in Music
description:
Pulse and Impulse: Rhythm and Time in Music [CPA-0058] [CPA-0058-1]

Faculty Name
Punita Gurpreet Singh [punita.singh@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Punita Singh

Intuitive human tendencies like beat induction and entrainment have led to most music adhering to a cyclical metrical structure with a regular pulse, but creativity and cultural propensities produce artistic variants that enrich the musical universe. Some genres of music displace or layer sound sequences to generate syncopation and polyrhythms, or dispense with a temporal scaffold altogether, to produce acyclical music. The use of instruments and the body to create rhythm patterns or mark time also varies across cultures. Drawing on concepts in music and dance, as well as neuropsychology, literature and physics, the impulse to produce and perceive rhythm is explored and experienced in this course through attentive listening and performance activities.

Grading Rubric

Faculty Name
Purvadhanashree [purvadhanashree@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Purvadhanashree

Vilasini Natyam is the dance tradition of Telugu temple dancers. It was performed as a dance ritual, in royal courts, in chamber concerts and as dance theatre. 

The course will take students through an interesting journey of exploration, understanding, experiencing, re-discovering and sharing of Vilasini Natyam. Students will engage with the unique vocabulary of Vilasini Natyam movements, text deconstruction and analysis, rasa theory, the interconnectivity of different arts and self exploration. The course will enable students to engage with this dance form through different artistic, aesthetic, gender and spiritual perspectives.

Acting Beyond the Stage [CPA-0082] [CPA-0082-1]

Faculty Name
Sanyukta Saha [sanyukta.saha@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Sanyukta Saha

Performance is an interplay of bodies, space, and time. This course will explore the relationship between the three by understanding the process of meaning making in theatre. The bodies in space are not just those of the actors, but also of those witnessing them. The space and time are not just that of the show, but of the context we live in. What happens when we begin to explore the processes of meaning making with this deeper understanding? What happens when we take our personal narratives and make it collective? What happens when we pick up scripts written in a different time and place and make it our own? What happens when we just switch the body of the actors the written text may have assumed? We will begin our course with these curiosities, and let the processes lead the exploration.

Peter’ Brook says - “acting begins with a tiny inner movement so slight that it is almost completely invisible”. What happens when our explorations in the rehearsal room find a life beyond this room - in our everyday lived experiences?

Grading Rubric

Tango is a social art of creative expression which fuels interpersonal and intrapersonal connection. The course will have the following components:

CourseTitle: Street Theatre: Calling Out the Elephant In the Room
description:
Street Theatre: Calling Out the Elephant In the Room [CPA-0084] [CPA-0084-1]

Faculty Name
Navtej Johar [navtej.johar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Navtej Singh Johar

The street is a space to voice, respond, react, celebrate and protest. A collective space, it warrants proximity, energy, enthusiasm and a viscerality of a kind that makes it a very infectious space. Street-theatre is both a form and a place, it lends itself to the relatively “loud” variety of expression that cannot be free from the compunctions of a public space where opinions are made and unmade. In this course we will examine some popular opinions that are opaquely present in our midst today.  We will work in teams to research facts about these opinions, examine the medium of here-say upon which they popularly ride, and enact scenarios that such opinions can cause and control in order to offer the public a larger, more realistic perspective from a human angle.    

Grading Rubric

The criteria for grading are the following: attendance, participation in class, and a creative project/ assignment determined by the Professor. All three criteria are equal.

Faculty Name
Madhavan Somanathan [madhavan.somanathan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Madhavan Somanathan

Singing music for SATB (soprano, alto, tenor, bass) choir, clapping music by Steve Reich, learning how to sight-sing, how to breathe while singing, ear-training for the purposes of hearing others and singing at the same time, etc. Class participation is mandatory, prior singing experience is not required but a good attitude towards learning new things and an appetite for criticism may help.

Introduction to Critical Thinking [CT-0001] [CT-0001-18]

Faculty Name
Chinmoy Saikia [chinmoy.saikia@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course, Introduction to Critical Thinking, (ICT) will be an exercise at reading through the cracks, ruptures, bandages, and facades that constitute our social, economic, and emotional realities. While primary materials may range from peer reviewed articles to court verdicts to short films to memes, the focus will remain squarely on enabling and urging the student to read the text closely and to help them inculcate a range of scholarly habits. A major component of the course is to instill among the students an appreciation for structure and precision both in thought and writing, a dichotomy which the course will also attempt to bridge by engaging the student in discussions and debates. At the end of the semester, the students will not only be able to write a well researched essay but will also begin to interrogate the mechanisms through which knowledge is produced and reproduced.

 

Learning Outcomes

Reading:

1. Breaking down texts into identifiable parts.

2. Making patterns and connections across texts

3. Building reading stamina and the ability to select texts

4. Understanding textual context, genre and source material

Writing 

1. Developing the craft of outlining, revising, editing

2. Applying form, voice, style, tone to affect writing

3. Developing logical, coherent, structured writing

4. Using explanatory, narrative and justificatory writing

Thinking

1. Practising converting thoughts into words

2. Narrowing down a curiosity or thought into a question

3. Constructing and developing a reasoned argument

4. Engaging meaningfully with multiple perspectives

Speaking,Listening

1. Aiming for confidence, clarity, coherence 

2. Practising and harnessing audience engagement 

3. Developing active and respectful listening to others 

4. Engaging meaningfully with ongoing discussions

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

You do not need to have any specific kind of training in order to do an ICT course. Nor is any ICT course geared towards preparing you specifically for a career in a particular subject or field. Rather, you can expect it to guide you in transition out of how you approached academic work in school to how you might approach it in a university setting, and to sharpen your understanding of what it means to be critical, questioning and deliberate in your approach to the world. 

 

This is a writing intensive course. You will be required to turn in short written assignments every week. For longer assignments, (the Mid-Term and the End-Term essays) you will be offered multiple rounds of feedback. You will also need to rehearse regular habits of reading (of academic texts and wider materials) and responding (to prompts, or given materials). You can expect it to have a strong participation and interaction component, and can expect to work on projects both individually and in collaboration with your coursemates. 

 

An exhaustive list of reading materials will be uploaded soon but you can expect it to be diverse in form and content. All reading will be done in class barring the odd unavoidable take home reading assignment. 

Grading Rubric

The ICT will be graded on a number of elements. Your final assessment will account for your participation and performance in writing and non-writing components, and in formative work (building towards a bigger piece, or continuing a specific ‘habit’) and summative work (producing a final output). 

 

These components are below. 

1. Participation (in class as well as in meetings with the instructor and the peer tutor): 15% of the final grade.

2. Regular Assignments. 15% of the final grade. 

3. Presentations: 15% of the final grade. 

4. A mid-term assignment of 800-1500 words involving the synthesis of multiple sources: 20% of the final grade. 

5. An end-term Academic essay of 1500 - 2500 words : 25% of the final grade. 

6. Improvement over the course : 10% of the final grade.

Attendance Policy

For this course, you are allowed three unexcused absences (for which you do not need permission from the instructor) and two excused absences (for which you do need permission from the instructor). The penalty for any absence beyond these five will be decided by the ICT instructor on a case-by-case basis. Please note that a consistent pattern of non-attendance may include discretionary penalties such as grade cuts.

 

If you are absent, the responsibility for making up for what has been missed -- by looking at class notes and/or speaking to classmates -- is yours. The responsibility for finding out about any homework that has been set for future classes is yours too.

Introduction to Critical Thinking [CT-0001] [CT-0001-2]

Faculty Name
Arpita Das [arpita.das@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In this course, you will develop and rehearse the habits that are essential to the development of a critical mind: reading, writing, speaking, listening and, of course, thinking. In effect, you will learn to ask the ‘why’ and ‘how’ questions alongside the ‘who’ and ‘what’ queries you have been posing through your school education. You will engage with a variety of source materials and understand how to ask questions that extend and enrich your understanding—of situations, texts, institutions and people. You will explore the distinctness of academic research and writing, and participate in an active knowledge community constituted by your peers. By the close of the course, you will have a clearer understanding of what it means to be a scholar in an academic setting, and a keener sense of your own processes of learning, thinking and writing. 

The theme of the course this particular semester for my students will be The Flaneuse in the City. We will be reading articles and extracts by a wide range of authors beginning with Edgar Allen Poe, Walter Benjamin and Virginia Woolf and ending up with Rebecca Solnit, Olivia Laing, Lauren Elkin, Nanjala Nyabola and Shilpa Phadke.

Most important for me, is that we generate a safe space in the classroom together where we learn to think and write as a community and as critically thinking individuals. 

Learning Outcomes

Reading:

1. Breaking down texts into identifiable parts.

2. Making patterns and connections across texts

3. Building reading stamina and the ability to select texts

4. Understanding textual context, genre and source material and documenting these via strategic note-making.

Writing 

1. Developing the craft of outlining, revising, editing

2. Applying form, voice, style, tone to affect writing

3. Developing logical, coherent, structured writing

4. Using explanatory, narrative and justificatory writing

Thinking

1. Practising converting thoughts into words

2. Narrowing down a curiosity or thought into a question

3. Constructing and developing a reasoned argument

4. Engaging meaningfully with multiple perspectives

Speaking-Listening

1. Aiming for confidence, clarity, coherence 

2. Practising and harnessing audience engagement 

3. Developing active and respectful listening to others 

4. Engaging meaningfully with ongoing discussions

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

You can expect to do regular reading (of academic texts and wider materials) in this course. These are specified on the schedule which will be shared and updated continuously through the semester. In addition, you can expect to write consistently, participate in giving and taking feedback, and work on medium-term projects both individually and in collaboration with your course mates.

 

Grading Rubric

The ICT course will be graded on a rubric containing the following elements:

1. Participation (in classes (attendance, participation in the reading aloud sessions and the discussions that will follow), meetings and consistency of contribution to the class blog.) 

2. Research paper (a longform (1500-2000 word) argumentative paper with citations, written in an academic style. Broad topic to be decided by each student by Week 4; research question to be framed by Week 5; outline to be submitted to me after the mid-term break; penultimate draft to be submitted to me by Week 10; final assignment to be submitted by Week 12. )

3. Shorter writing assignments: One will be your mid-term assignment and is usually a literature review; the second will be a response to a short film we will watch in class; the third will be a review of an event in the campus.

4. Presentations: There will be one individual presentation in Week 8-9 where students will present the evidence for their semester-end research paper and their argument using these.

Participation - 30%

Presentations - 20%

Short Writing Assignments -20%

Research Paper -30%

Attendance Policy

For this course, you are allowed three unexcused absences (for which you do not need permission from me) and two excused absences (for which you do need permission from me). The penalty for any absence beyond these five will be decided by me on a case-by-case basis. Please note that a consistent pattern of non-attendance may include discretionary penalties such as grade cuts.

Framing Adaptation [CT-2602] [CT-2602-1]

Faculty Name
Ved Dutt Arya [ved.arya_ga@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Adaptation in theatre, film, and literature is a recurrent practice. The task of explaining it in theoretical terms, however, is fraught with many problems. On the one hand, it has been likened to concepts and practices like translation, transposition, interpretation, rewriting, palimpsest, a dialogic process, and performance. On the other hand, its intertextual quality, which marks every text, makes it difficult to answer what is not an adaptation. In this course, we will engage with this ubiquitous phenomenon by thinking critically about questions like: What is adaptation? Why adapt? What does adaptation do? How is it different from other forms of cultural production? In pursuing these and other related questions, the course seeks to open a dialogue between theory and praxis of adaptation. While we will read and discuss theoretical texts by Plato, Aristotle, Bharata, Anandavardhana, Sigmund Freud, Mikhail Bakhtin, Walter Benjamin, Roland Barthes, Erving Goffman, Diana Taylor, Linda Hutcheon, and Jonathan Gil Harris, our thinking and conversations on adaptation will also be guided by an engagement with the practitioner’s craft, especially from the theatre. We will look at how adapters like Shakespeare theorize adaptation in their practice, and go on to frame/create our own adaptations—for the page and stage—to arrive at a practice-based understanding of the nature and social, cultural, aesthetic, and political implications of adaptation.

Pictorial Calligraphy (Urdu-Hindi) [CVA-0035] [CVA-0035-1]

Faculty Name
Qamar Dagar [qamar.dagar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Qamar Dagar

This course is about brief learning of how to use Hindi and Urdu scripts as art material to be integrated in an artwork. It is for a personal experience of seeing beyond the apparent and creating original works based on one's own ability to understand the meaning of a word or theme. This is an art of refinement both internally and on paper. Expect a different approach to calligraphy.

Grading Rubric

The criteria for grading are the following: attendance, participation in class, and a creative project/ assignment determined by the Professor. All three criteria are equal.

Attendance Policy
