Tapestry Art [CVA-0050] [CVA-0050-1]

Faculty Name
Anshu Singh [anshu.singh@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Anshu Singh

Tapestry is one of the oldest forms of woven textile. As a technique, tapestry has been used to create everything from tunics and purses to table covers and chair backs as well as some of the world’s largest and most beautiful pieces of textile art. Tapestry is traditionally woven by hand on a loom or a wooden frame. This project aims at introducing some basic key elements of Tapestry for the students as an alternative form of imagination. In a period where digital images have become the primary source of visual information, in this course students will manipulate the materials by using their own hands. Since the process of weaving is time-consuming and demands extraordinary patience and concentration, it will help students to get back to their basic hand-and-brain skills.

Grading Rubric

The criteria for grading are the following: attendance, participation in class, and a creative project/ assignment determined by the Professor. All three criteria are equal.

Faculty Name
Birender Yadav [birender.yadav@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Birender Yadav

This course is aimed at imparting basic skills in the technique of Papier Mache. The course is structured to cover historical and contemporary knowledge of papier mache as well as its concrete uses, particularly in fine art. It will impart an understanding of papier mache, its making, moulding and modelling, and eventually how to prepare and cast a final sculptural work. The student will also be given examples of how different artists use papier mache in their own works.

CourseTitle: Introduction to Indian Documentary Films: Theory and Practice
description:
Introduction to Indian Documentary Films: Theory and Practice [CVA-0076] [CVA-0076-1]

Faculty Name
Nakul Singh Sawhney [nakul.sawhney@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Nakul Sawhney

While Indian mainstream cinema has made rapid strides over the last two decades, another genre has grown quietly, away from the glare of the commercial glamour that surrounds the Mumbai film industry. It has not only blossomed but also made interventions through unconventional channels of dissemination. Not only has an alternate film movement emerged but has also offered an alternate narrative to various socio-political and economic issues that are reported or ignored by the mainstream electronic media. 

The course will try and expose the students to visual aesthetics employed in these films, the multiple forms in which these films have been approached, as also the counter-narratives that the polemics of these films raise. Students will also introduced to basic elements of making non-fiction or documentary films. Elements will include how to visualise a film, taking interviews etc.

As a culmination of the course, students will be required to create small videos themselves. These videos will be in the form of non-fiction documentary films.  

Grading Rubric

The criteria for grading are the following: attendance, participation in class, and a creative project/ assignment determined by the Professor. All three criteria are equal.

Attendance Policy

As the classes are highly participative in nature, more than 2 absences will affect your grade.

Seeing, Drawing and Meaning Making [CVA-0077] [CVA-0077-1]

Faculty Name
Argha Kamal Ganguly [argha.ganguly@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Argha Kamal Ganguly

This course will primarily engage students to see, experience, exercise and reflect upon with individual understanding. Mediums to be explored will be - Sketching, Drawing, Colouring , Painting, Paper-Collage , Mobile Photography, Pop-Up Card , Accordion  Book making etc.

Emphasis will be on both, the process as well as the outcome. There will be studio based learning, and the sharing ambience will be informal, interactive with needed demonstration and hands on practical experience. 

Learning , unlearning and relearning will be the three key words  to open up minds to be aware while observing, critically thinking, planning & creatively communicating. 

Grading Rubric

The criteria for grading are the following: attendance, participation in class, and a creative project/ assignment determined by the Professor. All three criteria are equal.

Attendance Policy

CourseTitle: Filming Reality: The Personal and Political in Documentary Cinema
description:
Filming Reality: The Personal and Political in Documentary Cinema [CVA-0078] [CVA-0078-1]

Faculty Name
Amit Mahanti [amit.mahanti@ashoka.edu.in] ,Ruchika Negi [ruchika.negi@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Amit Mahanti, Ruchika Negi

The invention of the moving image in late 19th century changed the way we look at the world, and us, within it. What does it mean to frame the Real? Whose Real is one attempting to represent, and what are the histories and ways of seeing that influence this construction? What is the position and role of the Self within this Reality? What are the freedoms that newer technologies of image making allow us today? What are the constraints of these narratives? Through a mix of illustrated lectures, film screenings and practical exercises, the course will decode the politics and methods of image making and representation, as experienced in non-fiction practice.

Some of the course components include:

- A glimpse into documentary film history

- Introduction to different forms of storytelling in non-fiction cinema

- Translating reality into image and the politics of representation

- Exploring the documentary subject

- Interrogating the documentary ‘Character’

- The Political and the Personal in narrative-making

- The students will make at least one image narrative work during the semester

Grading Rubric

The criteria for grading are the following: attendance, participation in class, and a creative project/ assignment determined by the Professor. All three criteria are equal.

Attendance Policy

As the classes are highly participative in nature, more than 2 absences will affect your grade.

Self-Portraiture and Travelling with the "I" [CVA-0079] [CVA-0079-1]

Faculty Name
Divya Sihag [divya.sihag@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Divya Sihag (Neer)

In this course, we will explore three artistic mediums and techniques to create our Self Portraits. They include

- the classic artist whose bust foregrounds the canvas, peering into the eyes of the viewer.

- the surrealist collage which confounds the senses and lures the witness into its world.

- the performative mask, which reshapes the face and introduces play as a means of exploring the seemingly rigid definitions of being.

The course is structured for participants to devise their own ways of interacting with the abovementioned techniques. They shall be offering witness to each other’s process so as to learn the interconnectedness between these methods. This is the work of a collective that is invested in highlighting the differences which mark the beauty of self-portraiture alongside initiating an inquiry into its efficacy as a medium for exploring the questions of self and identity. We will talk about the stories behind some famous artists and their self-portraits while reflecting upon our own practice.

The participants will be encouraged to maintain a process journal which will document their journey from ideating to drafting and the final piece that they work on as part of the submission for the course. This journal is as much a part of the final work of art that we will be working towards.

Grading Rubric

The criteria for grading are the following: attendance, participation in class, and a creative project/ assignment determined by the Professor. All three criteria are equal.

Attendance Policy

As the classes are highly participative in nature, more than 2 absences will affect your grade.

Drawing Non-Fiction Graphic Narratives [CVA-0080] [CVA-0080-1]

Faculty Name
Sunandita Mehrotra [sunandita.mehrotra@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Sunandita Mehrotra

This course introduces the basics of drawing comics and longer graphic narratives, with a focus on lived experiences, reportage formats and graphic journalism. 

With a hands-on practice based approach, it explores multiple formats of bringing together image, text, cut outs, collective story building and book making, while also raising questions about who and how narrative cultures are shaped, their hierarchies in production and circulation, and how the subversive medium of comics can possibly undo those. 

This engagement with comics making and collective creative processes in the classroom, is consistently encased in the broader understanding of how countercultures are shaped, and the attempt to tell stories that are people first, and might also find circulation in multiple formats other than the mainstream media economy. 

The course moves from drawing, collage making, basic comics, to more playful and complex formats of visual storytelling, encouraging immense creative production and also bringing in key works by comics makers from around the world, to examine together. 

It will offer students the opportunity to critically examine (from a maker’s perspective) – narrative structures, the power of visual cultures that surround us, the intersections between art and socio-political concerns, the boundaries between fiction and non-fiction, art and literature – and methods to push at these. It aims to enable students with basic skills in life drawing, comics making, visual journaling and producing books in different playful formats.

Grading Rubric

The criteria for grading are the following: attendance, participation in class, and a creative project/ assignment determined by the Professor. All three criteria are equal.

Attendance Policy

As the classes are highly participative in nature, more than 2 absences will affect your grade.

Microeconomic Theory I [ECO-2101] [ECO-2101-1]

Faculty Name
Bhanu Gupta [bhanu.gupta@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is designed to introduce you to fundamental ideas regarding decision-making and the implications of those decisions. We will consider how choices are made by economic agents who may be consumers, households or firms. We will also study tools that can help in evaluating performance of various types of markets such as competitive markets and monopolies. As the title suggests, this course emphasizes theory over empirical techniques which are taught in other courses. 

Learning Outcomes

At the end of this course, the aim is to make you comfortable with the fundamentals of micro theory and develop problem-solving skills that will be beneficial in other economic courses.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The primary textbook for this course is Intermediate Microeconomics: A Modern Approach (Ninth Edition) by Hal R. Varian. You may get an older edition, but there might some errors in the previous versions. Additional references include Microeconomics by Besanko and Braeutigam (4th edition). This is freely available online.

Grading Rubric

There will be 5 homeworks during the semester. Together, they will constitute 20% of the grade. To calculate the final grade, we will drop the HW with the lowest score. There will be two exams: midterm and finals. The final exam will not be cumulative, although the concepts learned during the course of the semester will be utilized. Both midterm and final exams will each count for 40% of the total grade.

Attendance Policy

There are no requirements of attendance. Having said that, attending and participating in the classes and discussions will most certainly help in improving your grade.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

You may get an older edition, but there might some errors in the previous versions. Additional references include Microeconomics by Besanko and Braeutigam (4th edition). This is freely available online.

Grading Rubric

There will be 5 homeworks during the semester. Together, they will constitute 20% of the grade. To calculate the final grade, we will drop the HW with the lowest score. There will be two exams: midterm and finals. The final exam will not be cumulative, although the concepts learned during the course of the semester will be utilized. Both midterm and final exams will each count for 40% of the total grade.

Attendance Policy

There are no requirements of attendance. Having said that, attending and participating in the classes and discussions will most certainly help in improving your grade.

Microeconomic Theory I [ECO-2101] [ECO-2101-3]

Faculty Name
Srijita Ghosh [srijita.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is the first course in the two-semester Microeconomics sequence. The objective of the course is to provide and use analytical tools to solve optimization and equilibrium problems and
apply them in the context of individual economic decision-making. In the second half of the course, we will apply these ideas to explore choice under risk, choice over time, and (time permitting) choice in the labor market.

Grading Rubric

  • Midterm (30%)
  • Final (30%)
  • Class Participation (10%)
Attendance Policy

Attendance is not mandatory but strongly recommended.

Macroeconomic Theory I [ECO-2201] [ECO-2201-3]

Faculty Name
Abhishek Rai [abhishek.rai@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course takes students to the next level of macroeconomics after the introduction they would have obtained in the Principles course of the first year. In this course, we will focus on the determinantes of three aggregate variables: output, unemployment rate and prices. In particular, we will:

a)  use the AS-AD and IS-LM framework to study determinants of output and prices,

b) analyze how three variables move through the business cycle (recurring expansion and contraction of economic activity) and how they relate to each other with a particular focus on the unemployment rate-inflation trade-off (or lack of it),

c) study the effect of monetary and fiscal policy on output and prices,

d) learn the role international linkages (trade in goods and capital mobility) play in determining domestic ouput and prices,

e) cover brief case-study of four economic "crisis": the great depression, the great recession, the Asian Financial crisis and the Japanese stagnation.

While this courses uses theoretical models to focus our attention on few key variables and mechanisms at a time, we will always endeavor to place the models in historical perspective and keep them empirically informed. Further, we will also explore if the macro behaviour postulated in each model can be micro-founded or not.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Macroeconomics by Olivier Blanchard
Macroeconomics by Andrew B. Abel, Ben S. Bernanke and Dean Croushore (Required)

Macroeconomics: Institutions, Instability, and the Financial System by Wendy Carlin & David Soskice 

 

Grading Rubric

The grading components are:

Mid-Term : 40 percent

Final Exam : 40 percent

Homeworks : 20 percent

Attendance Policy

There is no attendance requirement.

Monetary Theory [ECO-3200] [ECO-3200-1]

Faculty Name
Arghya Bhattacharya [arghya.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What exactly is "money"? Is it simply something that we needed for trading? If so, then money would be a constraint - a thing without which trades can't happen. What about alternative trading arrangements like barter or credit? Why is barter, credit, or a system that keeps track of transfers, inferior to money? Why is fiat money Pareto superior to commodity money (gold, silver, etc.)? What causes inflation? What about banking - why do we need it? Are banks always welfare-improving? Why do banks fail? This course starts with a micro-founded approach to money using an overlapping generations model and discusses why money is not a constraint but an instrument that arises endogenously leading to welfare gains for the economy. Then we build on this model and go on to study the relationship between money and other institutions that issue/ use money - financial intermediation & banks, a model of bank risk and bank panic (Diamond-Dybvig model).

Time permitting and based on your collective interest & my expertise, we might cover other interesting topics in monetary economics such as national debt, fiscal theories of price level & inflation, pension systems, and/ or one or two MA/ Ph.D. level papers on money-related topics.

Grading Rubric

Components

Midterm 1: 20% weightage


Midterm 2: 20% weightage


Homework: 8% weightage


Pop Quizzes: 7% weightage


Final Exam: 35% weightage


Participation (including attendance): 10% weightage

 

Points to note

  • Pop quizzes are random quizzes (i.e. not pre-announced) that could be given on any lecture day. If you miss a pop quiz, you earn zero on that particular quiz. I will, however, drop 1/4th (rounded up to the nearest integer) of your lowest pop quiz scores. For example, if there are a total of 6 pop quizzes, I will drop the lowest 2 scores. If there are 5 pop quizzes, I will drop the lowest 2 scores. If there are 4 pop quizzes, I will drop the lowest score. 
     
  • If your score on the Final Exam is better than your lowest midterm, I am willing to drop your lowest midterm and scale up the score on the final exam by a factor of (35+20)/35 = 1.571 (approx)
     
  • Your Total Score will be calculated according to:
    Total Score = maximum of Method 1 Score and Method 2 Score rounded up to zero decimal places, where
    Method 1 Score = Midterm 1 + Midterm 2 + HW + Pop Quiz + Participation + Final
    Method 2 Score = max(Midterm 1, Midterm 2) + HW + Pop Quiz + Participation + (55/35)*Final

 

How difficult is this course?

In the last academic year median grade in this course was between B and B+. Median grade usually hovers in this zone; some cohorts are better than others and their median grade has been between B+ and A-. With regular and consistent efforts it is not difficult to get an A. Past data shows that a typical student's class participation and performance in the course are positively correlated.

 

Total Score to letter grade conversion

90 to 100 is A
85 to 89 is A-
80 to 84 is B+
75 to 79 is B
70 to 74 is B-
65 to 69 is C+
60 to 64 is C
55 to 59 is C-
50 to 54 is D+
45 to 49 is D
40 to 44 is D-
Below 40 is F

Attendance Policy

If you are not in the habit of attending lectures regularly do not sign up for this course.

 

10% of the course grade is allotted to Participation an important part of which is regular and timely attendance. There are 26 scheduled lectures, of which 2 will be reserved for the two midterms. The class will effectively meet 24 times during the semester. If a student’s lecture attendance falls below 17 lectures (~ 71% of 24), then the student will earn nothing on the Participation Grade (0 on 10% of the total course score). This almost certainly amounts to the difference between two consecutive letter grades, and in some cases between three consecutive letter grades.

 

I will be taking a roll call at the beginning of every class. If a student shows up after the roll call, they will be marked as "absent" for that particular lecture. This is what I mean by timely attendance.

 

Due to seminars, conferences, or other such scholarly engagements, I might be traveling for some days of the semester. If I am out of the station on a lecture day and unable to teach in person, I will make up for it either through an in-person lecture or an online lecture on a pre-agreed date or time. If I teach an online lecture, I will take note of the Zoom attendance log to determine your participation points.

 

Finally, it is called Participation Grade so a student must not engage in anything that qualifies as non-participatory or disruptive behavior including (but not limited to) using laptops/ tablets/ cellphones for purposes not related to the course, sleeping in class, studying for another course in class, chit-chatting, leaving the lecture early without permission, etc. Non-participatory or disruptive behavior will lead to the cancellation of attendance points for that particular lecture.

During the first couple of weeks (shopping weeks)

  1. If you are attending my lectures without being enrolled in the course, make your presence known so that I can mark you as attended (even when your name isn't on the roster)
  2. If you miss the first couple of lectures and enroll in the course late, how will I calculate your attendance points? Ans: Just like anybody else's. The total number of lectures attended out of 24. If less than 17, zero on participation.
  3. During the shopping weeks, if you are contemplating whether or not to enroll in my course, given point 2 it would be best (for your sake) to attend the lectures and do as instructed in point 1.

Development Economics [ECO-3500] [ECO-3500-3]

Faculty Name
Anisha Sharma [anisha.sharma@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Why are some countries so poor and others so rich? Can governments act to eliminate poverty or must the poor remain poor? What sorts of interventions work and how do we evaluate them? Through this course, you will question the meaning of economic development and identify the factors that a ect growth, poverty and inequality. You will engage with contemporary research on markets, institutions, education and health. You will analyse these questions by using both theoretical frameworks as well as empirical evidence based on survey data. In doing so, you will gain an insight into the challenges and constraints faced by developing countries in their quest to improve the quality of human life.

The course is designed for undergraduates pursuing a major concentration in economics. Students should have completed Microeconomics and Econometrics.

Learning Outcomes

Gain an overview of critical questions in development economics and learn to read papers at the cutting edge of economic research, which empirically evaluate these questions. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

There is no single textbook for this course. I will expect you to read original research papers for this course as well as some review articles. I list recommended readings by topic and I will provide soft copies of most texts via a shared google drive. 

Grading Rubric

1) Class participation: 5%

2) Two quizzes (2): 20%

There will be two short quizzes (around 30 minutes each) on causal inference. 

3) Policy workshop (group work): 35% 

A policy workshop will take place in the middle of the semester. You will make a presentation on an academic paper that evaluates a government or non-governmental intervention selected by you that addresses either education or health in a developing country. You will also submit a written critique of the paper of no more than 1200 words. This assignment will take place in groups.

4) Midterm and Final tests: 40% in total and 20% each

There will be two tests: one around the mid-term mark and one in the final week of the course. These will cover conceptual theories as well as empirical applications that we have covered in class.

Attendance Policy

There is no attendance policy. However, 5% of the grade is for class participation.

Development Economics [ECO-3500] [ECO-3500-4]

Faculty Name
Hemanshu Kumar [hemanshu.kumar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Why are some countries so poor and others so rich? Can governments act to eliminate poverty? What sorts of interventions work? How do we evaluate them?

Through this course, you will question the meaning of economic development and identify the factors that affect growth, poverty and inequality. You will engage with contemporary research on markets, institutions, education, agriculture, and caste. You will analyse these questions by using both theoretical frameworks as well as empirical evidence.

In doing so, you will gain an insight into the challenges and constraints faced by developing countries in their quest to improve the quality of human life.

Learning Outcomes

On successful completion of this course, you would have learnt

  • some of the ways economists have tried to model economic growth, and how one can relate the model to the data
  • the factors that shape long run differences in growth across countries
  • how the developing country context affects markets for land, credit, and insurance
  • how economists have tried to evaluate interventions in a key area of market failure -- education
  • how economists have begin to study questions of group identity -- particularly caste, discrimination and affirmative action
  • some methods in the toolkit of causal inference, notably randomized controlled experiments, natural experiments, as well as quasi-experimental setups such as instrumental variables, difference-in-differences, and regression discontinuity designs
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The readings for this course consist of a few chapters from a couple textbooks, and a fair number of journal articles. The two textbooks are

[RAY] Debraj Ray (1998). Development Economics. New Delhi: Oxford University Press 

[BBM] Abhijit Vinayak Banerjee, Roland Bénabou, and Dilip Mookherjee, eds. (2006). Understanding poverty. New York: Oxford University Press

Physical copies of both these texts are available in the university library, and individual chapters can be downloaded via the university’s digital library. We will rely on [RAY] for the formal models we discuss in this course, while [BBM] provides excellent summaries of a number of topics, written by economists for the interested lay reader. Both books deserve a place in your library, especially if you think your intellectual engagement with economic development will outlast this course.

Additionally, we will frequently refer to articles and other references. These will be posted on Moodle for you to download.

Grading Rubric

 

Assessment Components
Component Weight
Reading summaries 3%
Class participation 12%
Class tests (3) 60%
Group project 25%

Note that the assessment weightage are subject to change based on class enrolment. The final weightage will be communicated after the first four weeks of the semester.

Notwithstanding this calculation, absence from more than eight class meetings at which class participation is assessed, will result in automatic failure (grade F) in the course.

Reading summaries

The primary method of learning in this course will be class discussions based on the readings. The starting point of these discussions will be a summary prepared by a group of students, and posted on Moodle.

The summary should also include a list of questions or points to ponder, to engender discussion. As a rough guide, I expect a summary of about 150-200 words (excluding discussion points), and about 4-5 discussion points.

The instructor will split students into groups of 2-3 members each, and assign them one or more readings to summarise. The summary is due at noon, two days in advance of the class in which it is to be discussed. Thus, the summary of the reading(s) to be discussed on Wednesdays are always due on Monday 12:00pm sharp, and for Fridays, are due on Thursday, 12:00pm sharp.

Late submissions are costly for the entire class and will be heavily penalised.

Class Tests

Three class tests will be conducted during the semester. The tests will be held in discussion sections at various points of the semester. Each test will be closed-book and closed-notes, and will typically expect short answers on 4-5 questions. No make-up will be offered for a missed test.

Group Project

Each student must complete a research project over the semester, as part of a group with one other student. Project groups will be created by the instructor. The project must involve empirical analysis using existing data from published sources.

Attendance Policy

Class discussions are central to the way we will all learn in this course. These discussions will occur in two ways:

  • after the summary of a reading is posted on Moodle, students may post responses, or additional questions and/or discussion points on that reading. Only comments posted until 11:55pm on the night prior to the class will count towards the participation grade.
  • during class meetings, we will have discussions on the readings, based on the summary, discussion points etc posted on Moodle. Students should expect to be cold-called by the instructor during class.

Class participation will be graded on a simple scale: 0 if you are absent, 1 if you are present, and 2 if you are present and actively participating. For the purposes of receiving a score of 2, active participation in the online discussion and active participation in the discussion in class will be treated as substitutes. However, absence from class will result in a score of 0 irrespective of your participation online.

Grading is the sole prerogative of the Teaching Fellow and the instructor.

Attendance will be taken in the first 5 minutes of a class meeting. If you are not present during that time, you will be marked absent for the day. Please make it a point to be punctual. The instructor reserves the right to mark you absent if you leave for a substantial part of the class after attendance is taken.

Class participation will also be assessed in Discussion Section meetings.

The number of assessment points for class participation are not pre-determined. The lowest 15% of such assessments (including absences) will be dropped in the computation of your final class participation grade.

There is no concept of "excused absences" in this course, other than in exceptional cases of protracted illness, etc.

Absence from more than eight class meetings at which class participation is assessed, will result in automatic failure in the course.

Monetary Theory [ECO-6200] [ECO-6200-1]

Faculty Name
Arghya Bhattacharya [arghya.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

We start the course by asking a fundamental question: what is money and why is it essential? We will start with a simple overlapping generations (OLG) model where intrinsically worthless objects are valued at equilibrium. This is fiat money. We will study the role played by different frictions in monetary economies, why a monetary economy is welfare improving than a barter/ credit economies, the necessity of banks and financial intermediation, etc.

After this we will graduate to third generation New Monetarist a.k.a. Lagos-Rocheteau-Wright (LRW) class of models and use them to understand different aspects of monetary economies and how a monetary economy interacts with other markets – labor markets, asset markets, and over-the-counter (OTC) markets. I might teach some non-monetary macroeconomic models – if they haven’t been covered in other courses and provided such models are relevant to our course.

In the third phase of the course we will discuss selected papers on important as well as interesting issues in monetary economics. Some of these might be “current issues”, while the rest are perennial questions. Students taking the course will be required to select a paper from a predefined list and present it in class. The presentation will be followed by Q&A.

I will teach selected chapters from the book Modeling Monetary Economies (Cambridge University Press) by Champ, Freeman and Haslag. This is an undergraduate book that teaches monetary economics through OLG models. In the second phase of the course, I will teach selected chapters from the book Money, Payments, and Liquidity (MIT Press) by Rocheteau and Nosal. This is a graduate textbook on LRW models.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Books:

  1. Modeling Monetary Economies (4th ed. CUP) by Bruce Champ, Scott Freeman and Joseph Haslag: this is an undergraduate textbook we will use it only for introductory purposes.
  2. Money, Payments, and Liquidity by Ed Nosal and Guillaume Rocheteau. MIT Press (2017): this is a graduate textbook and the main reference for this course.

Suggested Papers (each of you will read one paper and present it to the class):

  1. Monetary Equilibrium and the Cost of Banking Activity, by Paola Boel and Gabriele Camera, Journal of Money, Credit and Banking, 52(4) (2020), 653-683
  2. Money Mining and Price Dynamics 2021, American Economic Journal: Macroeconomics. By Michael Choi and Guillaume Rocheteau
  3. More on Money Mining and Price Dynamics: Competing and Divisible Currencies 2022, Journal of Economic Dynamics and Control 142. By Michael Choi and Guillaume Rocheteau
  4. Entrepreneurial Finance and Monetary Policy, by Paul Jackson and Florian Madison, European Economic Review (2022)
  5. The Shadow Economy as an Equilibrium Outcome, by Pere Gomis-Porqueras, Adrian Peralta-Alva and Chris Waller. Journal of Economic Dynamics and Control (2014)
  6. A New Monetarist Model of Fiat and E-Money, by Sebastien Lotz and Francoise Vasselin. Economic Inquiry (2019)
  7. Payments on Digital Platforms: Resilience, Interoperability and Welfare by Jonathan Chiu and Russell Wong. Journal of Economic Dynamics and Control (Forthcoming)
  8. Search and the market for ideas, by Rafael Silveira and Randy Wright. Journal of Economic Theory (2010)
  9. Venture capital: A model of search and bargaining, by Rafael Silveira and Randy Wright. Review of Economic Dynamics (2016)
  10. Innovation and growth with financial, and other frictions, by Randy Wright, Jonathan Chiu and Cesaire Meh. International Economic Review (2017)
  11. An Information-based theory of international currency, by Cathy Zhang. Journal of International Economics (2014)
  12. Asset Liquidity and International Portfolio Choice by Athanasios Geromichalos & Ina Simonovska. Journal of Economic Theory (2014)
  13. An Over-the-Counter Approach to the FOREX Market by Athanasios Geromichalos and Kuk Mo Jung. International Economic Review (2018)
  14. Marriage, markets, and money: A Coasian theory of household formation by K. Burdett, M. Dong, L. Sung and R. Wright. International Economic Review (2016)

 

Grading Rubric

This course is an MA Elective. It is also open to interested PhD students. At this stage of education, participation in class and engagement with the course is both expected and desired of you. You are all grown-ups, ready to face the world - I shouldn't have to coax and cajole you to come to class or encourage you to study. In this course, I will be more of a guide by the side than a sage on the stage. I will teach you some seminal models and how certain aspects of monetary economies can be analyzed through the lens of these models, but the rest is up to you to discover. I will give you a map and you need to explore yourself. You will be evaluated under the following heads:

  • Participation (20%): The expectation is that you will attend lectures regularly (and on time), pay attention to what is being taught, and ask pertinent questions. Before coming to class you should study the things covered in the last few lectures. Paper presentations – everyone should read the papers and not just the presenters. During paper presentations, you should ask reasonable questions based on the paper.
  • Homeworks and Class Tests (35%): While teaching, I will at times skip some of the mathy details and simply present the results. It is your job to do all the math/ derivations/ diagrams and convince yourself of the results. Sometimes I will assign these “filler” derivations/ math/ diagrams as your homework. Sometimes I will assign end-of-chapter questions as homework. Sometimes I will give you short, straightforward class tests based on the material taught the week before.
  • Paper presentation (35%): You will select a paper from a list and present it in front of the class.
  • Research Proposal (10%): 10% might not look much, but I will thoroughly and critically evaluate your proposal. A poorly done, last-minute proposal will earn a really inopportune score. Also, a good research proposal distinguishes you from others.

There are no midterms or final exams. However, if I do not see adequate participation and engagement from your side, I will change the evaluation criterion and you will be evaluated under the following heads: HW & Class Tests (10%), Midterm (30%), Final (30%), Paper Presentation (20%), Research Proposal (10%).

Attendance Policy

Read the other sections. Do I really need to say more?

Labour Economics [ECO-6640] [ECO-6640-1]

Faculty Name
Anisha Sharma [anisha.sharma@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Labour economics, broadly defined, is the study of the interaction of individuals, firms, institutions and the public sector in determining employment and wages. This course will cover the theoretical and empirical issues relating to labour economics, with a strong applied focus where we will discuss research designs to empirically measure theoretical predictions as well as evaluate policy interventions.

The course is designed for students pursuing a Masters degree in Economics and it is designed to cover empirical methods. You should be familiar with either Stata or R.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

I will supply most articles via a shared google drive. If you would like to consult a textbook for theoretical topics, Cahuc, Carcillo and Zylberberg's `Labor Economics' is a good option.

Grading Rubric

Class participation: 10%

In-class stata exercises: 30%

Presentation + paper critique: 20%

Final paper: 40%

Attendance Policy

There is no attendance policy.

Introduction to Literary Theory [ENG-1002] [ENG-1002-4]

Faculty Name
Huzaifa Omair Siddiqi [huzaifa.siddiqi@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Literary theory encompasses texts by phenomenologists, existentialists, linguists, psychoanalysts, Marxists, structuralists, deconstructionists, feminists, queer theorists, Critical Race and anti-caste theorists. What this course seeks to explore is why the study of literature needs ‘theory’ in all its various guises. What kind of relation does literature have with theory that is manifestly different, and indeed incompatible with, the traditional understanding of object and knowledge in philosophy and the sciences? The advent of ‘theory’ (as contrasted with ‘philosophy’ and ‘science’) has to be seen, not just as the beginning of a radical critique of the purportedly self-evident notions of subject, class, caste, race, gender and identity but also as a revolution in the very concepts of knowledge, truth and reality themselves. What happens to these concepts when literature (which has for so long been the catch-all term for illusion, falsity, imitation and error) becomes the site of truth; when theory replaces philosophy?

This course seeks to enter into these questions raised by literary theory. We will read texts by major theorists to see how theory displaces traditional philosophy and necessitates a practice that may be artistic, political, ethical or a combination of all three.

 

Learning Outcomes

Course Objectives:

To understand the importance of literary theory for literary studies.

To be able to write and think about theoretical texts.

To introduce students to the basics and make them understand the strengths and weaknesses of various theoretical approaches.

Grading Rubric

Presentations: 2 oral presentations in groups of 2 during the semester, one before the midterm break and one after. (30% of the final grade)

In-class participation: 10% of the final grade

Summaries: Post summaries of each day’s reading of around 400-500 words. If there is more than one reading allotted for the day, post the summary of any one. (10% of the final grade)

End term paper: 10 to 12 page essay (maximum 4000 words) on a topic of your choice. Topic to be decided after consultation with me. (50% of the final grade)

CourseTitle: Studies in Urdu Literature: The Urdu Short Story
description:
Studies in Urdu Literature: The Urdu Short Story [ENG-3402] [ENG-3402-1]

Faculty Name
Huzaifa Omair Siddiqi [huzaifa.siddiqi@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The short story as a genre in Urdu is not merely imported and imitated from European models but continues an already extant fictional tradition of Perso-Arabic storytelling and the Panchatantra and Jataka tales of the Indic tradition. In this course we will study the birth, growth and development of the short story in Urdu, from its origins with Premchand, its use by the Progressive Writer’s Association in their proscribed work Angaaray, the birth of the naya afsana with Saadat Hasan Manto and Ismat Chughtai, and the advent of modernism in Urdu post Independence with Surender Prakash, Ahmed Hamesh, Enver Sajjad, Balraj Manra and Khalida Asghar, moving on to more contemporary authors like Naiyer Masud and Siddiq Alam.

The Problem of Reality [ENG-3875] [ENG-3875-1]

Faculty Name
Amrita Narayanan [amrita.narayanan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Across time and culture, human beings’ interest in pleasure and fulfillment has been far beyond what is possible in reality. In this class we shall examine literary and real examples of how the human imagination steps in to promise (and sometimes deliver) moments of heightened intensity that address reality’s limitations. This class provides an introduction to the devices of the imagination--dreams, pictures, and fantasy laden objects--that allow human beings to adapt to reality. Drawing from the theories of psychoanalysis, and the experiences of literary characters, we will attempt to understand how humans invest imagined meanings and denied aspects of the self into other people and into objects. As we travel through the terrains of the real and the imagined, we will address important questions about how these two realms relate to each other. Why do the real and the imaginary sometimes live in an antagonistic relationship within the psyche? What happens when the imagination appropriates the psyche to exclude the real? How do literary characters invest people and objects with imagined meanings and denied aspects of the self? How has humans' investment in physical reality changed with the birth of virtual reality? Theory texts include Lionel Trilling, Sigmund Freud, Masud Khan, D.W. Winnicott and Adam Phillips. Literary texts include Oscar Wilde’s The Picture of Dorian Gray, T.C. Boyle’s The Relive Box, C.S. Lakshmi (Ambai)'s Journey 14, Scott Fitzgerald’s The Great Gatsby, Charlotte Perkins Gilman's The Yellow Wallpaper, Margery Williams' The Velveteen Rabbit and Ottessa Moshfegh's My Year of Rest and Relaxation.

Graduate Seminar in Literary Theory [ENG-5001] [ENG-5001-1]

Faculty Name
Abir Bashir Bazaz [abir.bazaz@ashoka.edu.in] ,Neel Vaidya [neel.vaidya_asp24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is required of all first-year MA and PhD students (with the exception of ASP graduates in English).  It provides an introduction, led by a different faculty member each week, to the most formative methods of critical theory at the interfaces of literary, linguistic, political, economic, sociological, anthropological, and psychoanalytic theory.

Artificial Intelligence and Data Analytics [ENT-2017] [ENT-2017-1]

Faculty Name
Ekanto Ghosh [ekanto.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Priyank Narayan [priyank.narayan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sagar Singhal [sagar.singhal@ashoka.edu.in] ,Tushar Ramesh Jaruhar [tushar.jaruhar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The future of work is expected to evolve rapidly. Artificial intelligence is going to drive this change. We are already feeling the impact of AI in several products and services that we use almost daily. For example, Google uses an AI tool to selectively show us advertisements. The income tax department is using A.I. with business intelligence to identify people who have not been paying taxes. The world of medicine is undergoing changes with A.I. being used to identify cancerous cells. Companies are looking to hire data analysts and scientist who can create novel products and solve complex problems. The acute shortage of skilled manpower is being felt globally. Therefore, providing undergraduate students with skills in artificial intelligence and business insights is the need of the hour. This course is designed to teach students the core concepts of data analytics. It is oriented towards undergraduates who may not necessarily have coding skills. The audience is expected to have the willingness to learn and explore. The focus will be to help students create a portfolio of projects where they can demonstrate the application of data analytics

Attachment
Artificial Intelligence and Data Analytics - Tushar Jaruhar.pdf

Financial Analytics and Artificial Intelligence [ENT-3012/ FIN-3014] [ENT-3012/ FIN-3014-1]

Faculty Name
Ekanto Ghosh [ekanto.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Priyank Narayan [priyank.narayan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sagar Singhal [sagar.singhal@ashoka.edu.in] ,Tushar Ramesh Jaruhar [tushar.jaruhar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The evolution of computing power along with large amounts of data that is being collected has transformed the world of finance. An example of this is algorithmic trading where an algorithm uses trading data to determine when you should buy or sell a stock in the market. It becomes more interesting when the income tax department assess a lot of data about individual taxpayers and determines that some of the citizens are not paying enough in taxes. The third example is based on the idea of who should be given a credit card. Most people who have high savings qualify for a credit card but what about those people who have low to medium savings. What about students at Ashoka? Many of these decisions in finance, such as selling a stock, obtaining a credit card, and identifying defaulters, are based on technology, mathematical algorithms, and knowledge of finance. A person who masters these 3 fields can work for large companies, set-up their own start-up, trade in the markets, pursue a career in research, become a financial consultant and pursue many more opportunities than what is mentioned here. The course starts with a brief understanding of markets and data that we can obtain for these markets. Then we look at how to use this data to decide if we should buy or sell a stock or bond. After having evaluated it heuristically we try to explore algorithms that can fit the behaviour of the data and perhaps indicate the buy and sell decision. Similarly, we apply this broad principle of identifying the data, examining it and then determining which model should be fitted to different problems in finance including predicting stock price, detecting fraud, providing credit, pricing options, sizing of companies based on financial attributes. Companies worldwide are looking for talented people who can understand different parts of finance and apply the right tools and techniques to analyze the products, customers and services. Our goal is to provide students an opportunity to learn these skills and see challenging careers in finance globally. It is oriented towards undergraduates who may not necessarily have coding skills. The audience is expected to have the willingness to learn and explore. The focus will be to help students create a portfolio of projects where they can demonstrate the application of data analytics

Attachment
Financial Analytics and Artificial Intelligance - Tushar Jaruhar (3).pdf

Animal Behaviour [ES-1191/ BIO-1191] [ES-1191/ BIO-1191-1]

Faculty Name
Manvi Sharma [manvi.sharma@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

If you have ever seen the baya weaver bird emerge from its pendulous nest after weaving it, you might wonder how and why this bird builds such a complex home. Why do birds sing complex melodies and rock agamas do push-ups? Do animals have personalities? Through this course, we will peek into the secret lives of animals in the natural world and will provide answers to these fascinating questions about puzzling behaviours around us. This course will build the understanding that natural selection can shape the evolution of animal behaviours. We will examine the cost-benefit approach to explain the function of behaviour. The students will gain a big-picture understanding of the form and function of animal behaviour in the natural world. The students will develop how studies of animal behaviour can help towards wildlife conservation.

Learning Outcomes

Course objectives:

Examining different levels (ultimate and proximate) of studying animal behaviour

Understanding the genetic basis of behavioural traits

Examining the context that shapes behaviour, such as predation and communication

Understanding reproductive behaviour, mating systems, and sperm competition

Understanding the tools and approaches to study animal behaviour for wildlife conservation

This course will help students to appreciate the fascinating diversity in the animal world and learn the quantitative tools to study animal behaviour in the wild. Students will learn the research tools to study animals of conservation importance and appreciate the process of how behavioural research can inform conservation action and policy making.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

An Introduction to Behavioural Ecology. (4th Edition). John Krebs, Nicholas Davies, and Stuart West.

Animal Behaviour. (11th Edition). Dustin R. Rubenstein and John Alcock.

Principles of Animal Behaviour. (4th Edition). Lee Alan Dugatkin.

The Beak of the Finch: A Story of Evolution in Our Time. Jonathan Weiner.

In the Shadow of Man. Jane Goodall.

The Selfish Gene. Richard Dawkins.

Niko’s Nature. Hans Kruuk.

The Panda’s thumb. Stephen Jay Gould

The Marvellous World of Outsourcing Parenting Duties. Raghavendra Gadagkar

Not a Human, but a Dancer. Ed Yong

Tribute to Tinbergen: Putting Niko Tinbergen's ‘Four Questions’ in Historical Context. Richard W. Burkhardt

One good turn. Exploring honeyguide-human mutualism. Claire Spottiswoode.

The Animal Behaviour Podcast

Grading Rubric

Participation (25%)

Students will be asked to fill out learning cards after class. These learning cards are intended for students to share what they take home from the class in the form of a short essay (500 words). The students will be asked to fill out 5 learning cards during the course.

Assignments (20%)

Two assignments based on the readings in the course. Students will be given reading material and will be asked to write an essay (1000 words).

Exam (15%)

Students will be asked to write an exam based on the readings in the class.

Documentary making (15%)

Students will be asked to make a short (5-minute) documentary on any group of animals or any behaviour as a theme.

Field project (25%)

Students will conduct a behavioual observation project and submit a report (1200 words)

Attendance Policy

Students can miss upto five classes.

Environment Justice [ES-3443] [ES-3443-1]

Faculty Name
Mukul Sharma [mukul.sharma@ashoka.edu.in] ,Tishya Doraiswamy [tishya.doraiswamy_asp24@ashoka.edu.in] ,Vedaansh Uberoi [vedaansh.uberoi_asp24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

ENVIRONMENT JUSTICE: HISTORICAL, GLOBAL, INDIAN

This elective course specifically centers around the evolution of environmental justice, examining it through historical, global, and Indian perspectives. Its origins can be traced back to the 1980s, primarily among Black communities in the United States. It also encompasses a pivotal reshaping of the American landscape after World War II, which involved state-endorsed racial discrimination and segregation against people of color. This discrimination manifested in various aspects, such as housing, workplaces, the placement of hazardous and polluting factories, as well as the disposal of toxic wastes. Environmental historians have pointed out that the first national People of Color Environmental Leadership Summit, held in Washington DC in October 1991, represented a historic moment in the environmental justice movement. Social justice has found frequent mention in the vocabulary of environmental justice.

Environmental justice concept and activism have been grounded locally; at the same time, it has continued to evolve globally. Not only has its initial perspective been anchored in bourgeoning thinking about the interconnectedness of environmental justice with “different cultural and political histories” and “the rejection of any form of racism, discrimination and oppression,” it also has had good traction in different continents around broader concepts of justice. Horizontal and vertical globalizing of environmental justice has found echoes in different countries and continents, including India. Going beyond national borders, its concerns have encompassed trade agreements, transfer of wastes, climate change, and the Rights of Nature. The “new pluralism” of environmental justice, which offers ways to include diversity, difference, recognition, and participation, for unpacking histories and geographies of exclusion, refers to development-induced displacement, gender and caste-based discrimination in accessing natural resources.

Through historical and comparative perspectives, which encompass gender and class, environmental authors in India have argued that varieties of environmentalism in South Asia originate in social conflicts and justice issues over access to and control over natural resources—for example, conflicts between peasants and industry over forest produce; rural and urban populations over water and energy; or struggles of the poor against corporates, markets, and state to retain their control over natural resources.

Learning Outcomes

The course is organized around weekly lectures and discussions based on the readings. Students will be asked to write an essay on one of the topics of the course, with footnotes and bibliography, and further readings will be given to them on their chosen topic, so that they can go in much more depth on a particular topic.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

NO REQUIREMENT

Unit 1: An Introduction to History

Unit 2: Theories and Perspectives

Unit 3: Global Trajectories: Africa, South America and Asia

Unit 4: Indian Perspectives and Case studies

Unit 5: Climate and Energy Justice

Unit 6: Caste, Dalits and Environment Justice

Essential and Secondary Readings:

Bryant, Bunyan, ed. 1995. Environmental Justice: Issues, Policies, and Solutions. Washington, DC: Island Press.

Bullard, Robert D. 2000. Dumping in Dixie: Race, Class, and Environmental Quality. Boulder, CO: Westview Press.

Byrne, John, Leigh Glover, and Cecilia Martinez. 2002. Environmental Justice: Discourses in International Political Economy. New Brunswick, NJ: Transaction.

Cole, Luke W., and Sheila R. Foster. 2001. From the Ground Up: Environmental Racism and the Rise of the Environmental Justice Movement. New York: New York University Press.

Dobson, Andrew. 1998. Justice and the Environment: Conceptions of Environmental Sustainability and Theories of Distributive Justice. Oxford: Oxford University Press.

Guha, Ramachandra, and Juan Martinez-Alier. 1998. Varieties of Environmentalism: Essays North and South. Delhi: Oxford University Press.

Guru, Gopal. 2012. “Experience, Space, and Justice.” In The Cracked Mirror: An Indian Debate on Experience and Theory, ed. Gopal Guru and Sundar Sarukkai, 71–106. New Delhi: Oxford University Press.

Harvey, David. 1996. Justice, Nature and the Geography of Difference. Cambridge: Blackwell.

Martinez-Alier Joan, Leah Temper, Daniela Del Bene, and Arnim Scheidel. 2016. “Is There a Global Environmental Justice Movement?” Journal of Peasant Studies 43: 731–755.

Rajan, S. Ravi. 2014. “Environmental Justice in India.” Environmental Justice 7 (5): 117–121.

Sandler, Ronald, and Phaedra C. Pezzullo, eds. 2007. Environmental Justice and Environmentalism: The Social Justice Challenge to the Environmental Movement. Cambridge, MA: MIT Press.

Sharma, Mukul. 2017. Caste & Nature: Dalits and Indian Environmental Politics. New Delhi: Oxford University Press.

Steady, Filomina Chioma, ed. 2009. Environmental Justice in the New Millennium. New York: Palgrave Macmillan.

Taylor, Dorceta E. 2014. Toxic Communities: Environmental Racism, Industrial Pollution, and Residential Mobility. New York: New York University Press.

Wells, Christopher W., ed. 2018. Environmental Justice in Postwar America: A Documentary Reader. Seattle, WA: University of Washington Press.

Grading Rubric

There will be one internal assessment exam held after four weeks. This will be out of 20 marks. 2) There will be one class presentation. This will be 25 marks. 3) Students will also be asked to submit a written essay of 2500-3000 words with footnotes and bibliography, which will be out of 30 marks. 4) 25 marks will be attendance, participation and discussion.

Attendance Policy

As per university policy

Persian - I [HIS-1011] [HIS-1011-1]

Faculty Name
Nadeem Aktar [nadeem.akhtar@ashoka.edu.in] ,Najam U Sakib [najam.sakib_asp24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The course will be covered in two lectures of 90 minutes each, per week in the monsoon semester 2020. Students will be initiated into learning Persian language and literature from learning alphabet to formation of words and sentences in Persian. Learning materials will be provided by the course instructor. Weekly class room activities are given below:

 Persian Alphabet and Script

Persian alphabet consists of 32 letters which are written from right to left. It is a Perso-Arabic script. Students will be taught to write the alphabet. The letters are to be written separately and jointly in which they will change forms.

 Formation of Words

Once the students learn alphabet and script, they will easily use them to form words which is the first step towards learning a language. Besides, they will be introduced to short and long Persian vowels. Separate letters will be given to the students to join them and form words. They must make 100 Persian words from the given letters. Pronunciation and meaning of every word will be explained to them.

Numbers, Names of Days of the week, Months and Seasons

Persian numbers are written from left to right in similar way as in English. In this class students will learn to write Persian cardinals and ordinals with proper pronunciation. Further, it will help them to learn the names of days of the week in Persian easily. Students will also learn the names of months and seasons. They will learn to use the numerical also to denote singular and plural noun.

 

Possessive Case and Usage of Noun with Adjectives

In Persian language personal pronoun plays an important role. It has both long and short form which help learner to identify the subject/object in a sentence. In this class students will be taught to form or connect noun with adjective and noun with noun. Usage of link (Ezafe) will be taught to the learners to form possessive case or to connect noun with noun and adjective with noun to describe the noun. Students will also learn to use positive comparative and superlative degrees of adjective. List of adjectives will be provided to them in order to build their vocabulary, clauses and expressions.

 Infinitives and Conjugation of Tenses

Grammar or the science of language is essential to learn a language in an easy and systematic way. Persian grammar is limited and easy to learn. It has etymology (sarf) and syntax (nahv) which help the learners to identify words and write sentences grammatically correct. Persian grammar begins with infinitive (masdar) which is considered as “mother of words”. Infinitive begets different forms of a word. They also enable to form tenses- Present, Past and Future. The verbs also correspond with subject. Therefore, verbs and nouns will be taught together and in this way etymology and syntax will go hand in hand.

In this class students will learn to form past tense in Persian. All the types of past tense are formed by a simple manner and easy to learn method. Persian infinitives (masadir) provide forms of past tenses. Students will be provided with a list of infinitives (masadir) in the class and their meaning will be explained to them. They will have to memorize the infinitives (masadir) which will help them to form sentences in various past tenses.

 Conjugating Present Tense

Present tense in Persian is formed by using the present stem of verb deduced from   an infinitive. In this class students will learn to form the present stem from Persian infinitives which help them to form sentences in present tense.

They will be provided with a list of present stems from Persian infinitives. They will memorize them to develop their skill to form sentences in present tense in Persian. The present tenses are simple present and present continuous tense only which are used to convey proverbial, universal and general matters of fact.

Conjugating Future Tense

In this class students will learn to form sentences in future tense. In Persian language there are two types of future tense. Present continuous tense is also used to express future act. However, there is a particular method or usage of word to denote future tense. Students will be taught to use both the forms of future tense in the class and their appropriate usages.

Interrogative, Affirmative, Negative, Interjection and Conjunction

After learning the three forms of tenses of Persian language students will be able to form sentences in various tenses. In this class they will learn to make interrogative sentences in Persian. Students will learn to make the sentences by using different interrogative words. They will also learn to change affirmative sentences into negative. Interjection and conjunction make a sentence expressive and cohesive. A list of words (interjection and conjunction) will be given to the students to use them in their sentences.

Persian Adverbs

In this class students will become familiar with the different types of adverb used in Persian language. Adverb of time, place and manner will be used by the students to form sentences.

 Persian Prepositions

The link (ezafe) that has been taught in previous class joins two words together. However, there is a list of prepositions in Persian language. Prepositions are necessary to learn in order to make their appropriate usage in sentences. Their usages will make expressions meaningful.

Auxiliary Verbs

Besides learning the main verbs, it is expedient for the learners to know and use auxiliary verbs in Persian. They are an added advantage to a sentence to express ideas in a whole some manner. They are used along with the main verb in a grammatical template. The template will be explained to the students to use auxiliary verbs in a sentence in past, present and future tenses.

 Persian Proverbs and Idioms

Proverbs are the condensed form of human wisdom expressed in crisp and clear words in society. Idioms are the way of expression in a language. Proverbs and idioms make a language beautiful, graceful and meaningful. Students will learn

at least 10 to 15 Persian proverbs and 20-25 idioms that will help to develop their linguistic skill.

Composition

Composition, précis writing and essay help a language learner to express himself in his language. Texts will be provided to the students to comprehend and respond to them and make a precis of them. They will be asked write essays on topic of their choice.

Reading and Translating Persian Text

After learning the basic grammar, students will start reading the Persian texts both poetry and prose. They will be able to translate them into English. Students will be provided easy and simple Persian texts to read and translate them into English. They will improve their reading and comprehension abilities. They will also be encouraged to use Persian dictionary to translate the given texts. In order to develop proficiency in language reading Persian texts and translating them into English on daily basis are recommended. This exercise of reading and translating Persian texts will continue for next five weeks. Different texts will be provided to the students every week to read, comprehend and translate them. To begin with, a poetic text of Nizami Ganjavi will be studied in the class which is simple and easy to understand. It is a hymn written in beautiful and elegant Persian. Text of Nizami’s hymn is titled: Be Naam-i-Izad Bakshayendeh (In the Name of God the Merciful) compiled in Farsi wa Dastur by Zahra Khanleri will be provided to the students.

Learning Outcomes

At the end of the course students will have a basic understanding of the Persian language and they will be able to read, write and understand basic Persian texts

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Materilas will be provided in the class

Grading Rubric

Three Monthly Tests of 25 Marks each (Marks of the best two shall be considered for the final grading)

Final End Semester Exam of 50 Marks

Attendance Policy

Not more than 2 Abscences allowed

Querying the Early Medieval [HIS-3203] [HIS-3203-1]

Faculty Name
Sanjukta Datta [sanjukta.datta@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The period between c. 600-1300 CE is considered to be a distinct stage in Indian history, connecting the ancient to the medieval, and is labelled as the early medieval. So what are the distinguishing historical markers of the early medieval? How have historians contextualized the early medieval vis-à-vis the conventional categorization of Indian history into ancient, medieval and modern? Beginning with the question of periodization in Indian history, the course moves on to an exploration of diverse themes such as the unfolding of particular political processes and articulations of kingship; flowering of regional identities through language, literature, art and architecture; emergence of religious movements and encounters between distinct religious traditions; and expanding networks between the subcontinent and the rest of Asia through military campaigns, trade and pilgrimage. 

Learning Outcomes

1. This  course will enable students to delve deeper into a period which is not adequately covered in two of the mandatory courses on Indian history, History of India II and III. 

2. It will familiarize students with the astonishingly rich historiography on the early medieval in India, encompassing theoretical models as well as empirical case-studies. 

 

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The syllabus along with a reading list will be emailed to the enrolled students the day before the first class on Wednesday, 30 August.  

There is a strong possibility that some of the regular classes in October will be rescheduled on Saturdays in November and during the reading week in early December. 

Grading Rubric

The different modes of assessment (class participation/ class presentations/ written assignments) and the grading rubrics will be clearly outlined in the syllabus. 

Attendance Policy

The course will follow a strict attendance policy, allowing for a total of five (5) absences throughout the semester, which includes medical leave. Absences over and above the five will incur grade cuts, one for each additional absence.

CourseTitle: Journeying with the Jinas: A Brief History of Jainism
description:
Journeying with the Jinas: A Brief History of Jainism [HIS-3220] [HIS-3220-1]

Faculty Name
Sanjukta Datta [sanjukta.datta@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Practitioners of the Jaina religion constitute the smallest amongst India's six major religious groups today (Hindus, Muslims, Christians, Sikhs and Buddhists). But Jainism (along with Buddhism) began as one of the most successful heterodox movements that challenged Vedic orthodoxy and initiated the oldest renunciatory traditions in India in 6th century BCE. This course undertakes a broad survey of the roughly 2,5000 year-old history of Jainism, highlighting its key precepts and practices. Some of the exciting questions that will be investigated are as follows: How are Buddhist and Jaina philosophies similar to yet different from each other? What is the philosophical underpinning of the defining Jaina principle of non-violence (ahimsa)? What explains the sustained worship of Jaina scriptures and the maintenance of Jaina libraries (bhandaras)? What is the history of Jaina interface with other religious traditions such as Śaivism and Islam? What are the legal implications of competing claims over Jaina sacred sites and the Jaina practice of fasting unto death in contemporary India? For students of history, reading the 17th century autobiography of a Jaina merchant, which is the first autobiography in an Indian language, is likely to be a memorable experience. 

Learning Outcomes

1. The course will familiarize students with the building blocks of Jainism, a religious tradition which is frequently clubbed with Buddhism. 

2. It will equip students to evaluate some of the prevailing stereotypes about Jaina thought and practice. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The sylllabus along with a reading list will be shared with the enrolled students the day before the first class on Wednesday, 30 August.

International Relations Theory [IR-1009] [IR-1009-1]

Faculty Name
Quintijn Benjamin Kat [quintijn.kat@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is aimed at students who are new to the discipline of International Relations (IR) and have no prior knowledge of or experience with the subject. It introduces them to several key theoretical perspectives and concepts of IR and encourages them to apply these to contemporary issues of international politics. The course begins by studying mainstream theoretical approaches (realism, liberalism, and constructivism), touching on their political- philosophical foundations and how these evolved into becoming a distinct branch of political science in the twentieth century. It then covers the subdiscipline of International Political Economy (IPE) and thinking about ethics in IR that the dominant theories have produced. Turning to more reflective approaches, the course discusses the need to ‘globalize’ or ‘decolonialize’ IR, as well as feminist contributions to the study of international relations. Students will learn how each of the theoretical perspectives and approaches provides for a distinctive way of understanding the relations between states and other international actors. In terms of application of the theories, the course encourages students to apply their obtained theoretical knowledge to the pertinent issues of war, the environment, humanitarian intervention, and nuclear proliferation, weighing and evaluating the contributions that the different perspectives make to our understanding of each of these topics.

Students who have already completed IR-1008 ‘Theories and Issues of International Relations’ should not enroll in this course. IR-1009 is a revised version of IR-1008 aimed at students who are entirely new to the discipline of International Relations. It consists of much the same content and largely covers the same topics as IR-1008.

Learning outcomes:

Familiarity with IR’s foundations in political philosophy and with the main thinkers that inspired contemporary IR theories.

Understanding of what the three (or four) ‘major debates’ of IR are about.

Understanding of the main concepts and key arguments of dominant IR theories.

Understanding of and ability to explain and apply main theories of IR to current-day issues.

Ability to formulate an opinionated answer that is grounded in theory to essay questions that cover basic debates of IR.

Linear Algebra [MAT-1001/ CS-2210/ PHY-1001] [MAT-1001/ CS-2210/ PHY-1001-1]

Faculty Name
Sourav Ghosh [sourav.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Real and complex vector spaces, subspaces, spanning sets, basis sets, dimension of a vector space.  Solution of a system of linear equations. Row space and column space of a matrix, rank of a matrix, elementary row and column operations of a matrix. Inversion of square matrices, rank factorization of a matrix. Properties of determinant. Linear transformations, range and null space of a linear transformation, rank-nullity theorem. Matrix representation of a linear transformation. Inner product spaces, normed linear spaces, examples of different normed linear spaces, orthonormal basis sets. Eigenvalues, eigenvectors, characteristic polynomials. Spectral theorem for real symmetric matrices. Singular value decompositions.

Learning Outcomes

Analyze and picturize multivariate data.

  • A. R. Rao and P. Bhimsankaram: Linear algebra, Hindusthan book agency, 2000.

Symbolic Logic [PHI-1060/ CS-2160] [PHI-1060/ CS-2160-2]

Faculty Name
Alexander Iain Siantonas [alexander.siantonas@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is an introduction to logic as a resource for philosophy, though it should benet many who do not mean to make philosophy their primary subject of study. Logic is concerned with truth; in learning it, we learn to evaluate how well our thoughts and arguments are tied to truth. We will study several articial formal languages, especially rst-order propositional and predicate logic, as well as modal and higher-order logic. We will think about their relation to the natural language of English, and to the world, as it is independent of all our speech.

This is a demanding course, covering a good deal of challenging technical ground. It is still an introductory course, intended primarily to prepare philosophers for work across that subject. It is not an advanced course, exploring the field of logic for its own sake, in the manner of an advanced metaphysics course. But as an introductory logic course, it is more advanced than most (including, for instance, the logic course offered by the excellent department at Leeds, in Britain’s prestigious Russell Group). Some of the topics covered towards the end are at the edge of active research. You will have to work hard, and you may well feel yourself struggling at times. If you are prepared to put in the work, and square up to the struggle, you will learn a lot, and be equipped both to follow and create philosophical arguments at the highest level. 

Plan

Week 1: What is logic, and what do we want from it?

See Logic Manual 1

 

Week 2: Syntax and semantics of propositional  logic

See Logic Manuel 2

 

Week 3: Formalization in propositional logic

See Logic Manual 3

 

Week 4: Syntax of predicate logic

See Logic Manual 4

 

Week 5: Semantics of predicate logic

See Logic Manual 5

 

Week 6: Natural deduction

See Logic Manual 6

 

Week 7: Formalization in predicate logic

See Logic Manual 7

 

Week 8: Identity etc

See Logic Manuel 8

 

Week 9: Modal propositional logic

See Logic for Philosophers 6 

 

Week 10: Quantified modal logic

See Logic for Philosophers 10

 

Week 11: Second-order logic

See Crash Course 3

 

Week 12: Higher-order logic 

See Crash Course 5

 

Henceforward: Review/TBD

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this course, you will be able to:

Understand the fundamental ideas of logic.

Translate sentences of English into well-formed sentences of logical languages, and vice versa. 

Determine the formal properties of arguments, such as validity and soundness,  as they are used in philosophical writing and elsewhere. 

Construct formal proofs for sentences of our formal languages. 

Recognise some of the philosophical implications and applications of logic. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The three main texts for this course are Volker Halbach's The Logic Manual, which covers propositional and predicate logic; Ted Sider's Logic for Philosophy, from which we will study modal logic; and Sider's Crash Course on Higher-Order Logic, which will cover the last portion on higher order logic. 

Other recommended free online resources are Tim Button's Open Education Resources and Garson's Modal Logic for Philosophers 

Grading Rubric

Total grade: 30% homework, 30% midterm, 30% final, 10% participation. 

Expected grade boundaries: 90+ A, 80-90 B, 70-80 C, 60-70 D

Attendance Policy

Total grade: 30% homework, 30% midterm, 30% final, 10% participation.
