CourseTitle: Michel Foucault: History of Systems of Thought
description:
Michel Foucault: History of Systems of Thought [PHI-4430/ POL-3101] [PHI-4430/ POL-3101-1]

Faculty Name
William David McDonald [william.mcdonald@ashoka.edu.in] ,Akshali Archana Gugle [akshali.gugle_asp24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Michel Foucault (1926-1984) developed sophisticated methodologies for investigating dynamic, complex systems of thought. Using these methodologies, which he dubbed ‘archaeology’ and ‘genealogy’, he examined histories of madness, medicine, criminality, sexuality, and governmentality. He also examined the epistemological relations among sets of social sciences (economics, biology, linguistics and philosophy) across a major epistemological break (from the ‘classical age’ to ‘modernity’). In doing so he identified ongoing antinomies in modern social sciences, which threaten their coherence. At the heart of his investigations of systems of thought lie questions regarding the production of knowledge, structures of power, the meaning of ethics and the possibility of freedom. He builds on the work of Kant, Hegel, Marx, Nietzsche and Heidegger to create an astonishing set of tools for analysing knowledge, power, and the subject (of power, ethics and freedom). This course will give an overview of Foucault’s work, with a focus on the concepts of knowledge, power and the subject.

CourseTitle: Militants or Freedom Fighters? Armed Conflicts in India
description:
Militants or Freedom Fighters? Armed Conflicts in India [POL-2091] [POL-2091-1]

Faculty Name
Kaustav Dhar Chakrabarti [kaustav.chakrabarti@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

“One person’s freedom fighter is another person’s terrorist” is a common expression that sums up the complexity of armed conflicts around the world. How should we understand the state’s claims to legitimacy versus some of our most cherished beliefs in civil rights and the right to self-determination? This course will approach the question through the lens of theories in political science while being grounded in the empirical realities of armed conflicts across India. The course does not take a normative position on these conflicts – we will not assume that armed groups are ‘unlawful’, neither will we valorise them. We will treat armed conflicts as a political phenomenon of interest, and I invite you to use the course to sharpen and test your prior views.

The course will cover five major themes on armed conflicts. We will begin with establishing a solid conceptual foundation – What are armed conflicts? How are they different from other forms of organized violence? What are armed groups? Next, we will examine the causes of armed conflicts. Are conflicts rooted in political and economic grievances? Or should we blame self-interested leaders?

In the second module, we will study how combat, or war-fighting differs between civil wars and conventional interstate war. We will explore how armed groups organize for war (the lessons of Mao, Irish Republican Army) and how India responds and read counterinsurgency doctrine and examine the effect of ‘hearts and minds’ development programs. The third module covers arguably the core of guerrilla warfare – armed groups’ relations with the community. We will examine how armed groups mobilize support, the depth of their connections with the community and their treatment of civilians, and the methods that they adopt to solicit the community’s support. We will also cover the terrain of pre-existing social institutions and the community’s experience with the incumbent state and examine how it affects its decision to support (or withhold support) to armed groups. 

The fourth modules returns to aspects of armed groups where we will study how commitment to ideology, and robust centralized organization to ensure discipline among cadre, and splintering into factions,  affects the behaviour of armed groups.

The final module covers the role of external factors – foreign bases in inaccessible forests of Myanmar, support from China and Pakistan, the role of diaspora, and ask if the presence of ‘foreign fighters’ should change our understanding. The course culminates with the important theme of conflict resolution; why did military methods succeed in Punjab but not in Kashmir? Why did negotiations succeed in Mizoram but have failed to resolve the dispute in Nagaland? 

Learning Outcomes

The goals of the course are three-fold. By the end of the course, students should have an overview of some of the major debates in the political science of civil war, especially those that are pertinent to India. In addition, the course will familiarise students with major civil wars (or ‘insurgencies’) in India through detailed case studies. Finally, the course will reinforce the department’s continuous training in analytical thinking. It will bolster students’ ability to distinguish between different theoretical explanations, evaluate the merit of competing arguments made in the literature, and communicate their arguments clearly in written form.  

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

To be shared soon. 

Grading Rubric

Course will not grade on a scale. 

Attendance Policy

Your participation is essential for the course’s success and you are expected to attend all lectures. As a form of professional courtesy, I expect that you will inform me about medical contingencies and scheduling conflicts (related to sports, debate events etc) ahead of time, with a written note from your coach or concerned authority. As long as you inform me with a valid reason, you can miss classes. You are allowed three unexcused absences. Beyond three unexcused absences, I’m afraid that we will dock points.

Gender Politics 101 [POL-2109] [POL-2109-1]

Faculty Name
Malvika Maheshwari [malvika.maheshwari@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What is the value of being a feminist? What does it mean? What are the implications of not being a feminist? What more there is to say? Do feminists talk about men and women differently? Why bother? What is the relevance of feminist theory to policy issues? What have been some of the most noteworthy interventions in the subject? We’ve all heard of the feminist glossary and terms like performativity, patriarchy, gender fluidity among others, but surely their history matters. Through thematic sessions on the interrelations of caste, sexuality, class, and specific questions pertaining to power like pornography, masculinity, family among others, the course will explore analytical ideas and examine political issues - including important and urgent issues we face in Indian politics and everyday life. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The classes for this course will begin on 1st September.

Lectures: Students are expected to attend all lectures and to have completed the reading assigned for that day before class. Students are expected to be able to participate in colloquies conducted by the professor.

I am also willing to meet with groups of students during office hours for tutorial seminars, and to make appointments to meet with students who cannot make it to my posted office hours (within reason).

Cheating: Cheating includes any form of plagiarism, including the use of AI and any web resources, or collaborating with and/or copying from other students in your graded work. Copying a fellow student’s lecture notes if you miss a class is accepted. The grade for plagiarism is a straight F for that particular work. 

Grading Rubric

Grading: Final grade consists of three components: class participation + a short mid-term essay plan + a final, longer take-home essay. The details of each are as follows:

Midterm essay: This short essay-plan will be written as a road map for a question framed by students themselves, drawn from the assigned themes and texts. This should include: what the research question is, how you plan to answer it and what is the value of asking this question. The plan should include a hypothesis, a short literature review and a working bibliography. The length of this assignment is 1500 words. Please avoid late submissions, and extensions will be granted only in documented cases of illness or family emergency. The essay is worth 20% of the final grade.

Final examination:  The final examination will be a take home essay, on questions framed by students. The length of the essay is 3000 words. This is an exercise in writing and research, and it helps to spend an entire semester working on this one paper. Given that the deadline of the submission for the two essays in mentioned in the syllabus already, which is shared with you in the first week of classes itself, please avoid asking for extensions on the deadline. There will be penalties for late submission and extensions will be granted only in verified and documented cases of illness or family emergency. The essay is worth 30% of final grade.

Class participation: Apart from the two essays, students will be graded on their class participation, which includes their attendance (20%) and participation through the semester during lectures (30%). The grade on class participation is thus worth 50% of final grade.

Students are not allowed more than 5 absences through the term (which includes absences due to participation in university events, and common illnesses. More than 5 absences will lead to a straight F for the course. For any long-term medical assistance and absence (more than three absences in a row), please submit a medical certificate to the OAA.

Politics and Psychoanalysis [POL-3044] [POL-3044-1]

Faculty Name
Malvika Maheshwari [malvika.maheshwari@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In what ways might we understand politics and various aspects of the political system by studying psychoanalytic theory? In its inverse sense, how might political theory or activity contribute to psychoanalytic reasoning? This course aims to explore intellectual ideas and conversations between primarily these two perspectives, including the disciplinary anxieties and methodologies through which these perspectives are shielded and made relevant. In this course – of thirteen weeks, and twenty sessions – we shall aim to study in depth six broad but critical political phenomenon that have not just shaped contemporary psycho-social dynamics, but have also remained central to the sense of the political at the level of the personal and the public. These themes are: (i) colonialism and racism, (ii) narcissism and political leadership, (iii) sexuality and psychopathology, (iv) violence: individual and communal, (v) hysteria, trauma and guilt, (vi) visuality and psychoanalysis.

CourseTitle: Ties that Bind: Communities and Collective Action
description:
Ties that Bind: Communities and Collective Action [POL-3097] [POL-3097-1]

Faculty Name
Kaustav Dhar Chakrabarti [kaustav.chakrabarti@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

How do communities organise collective action to advance their demands and grievances? The course will offer a sweeping review of collective action by communities – villages caught between rebels and military as they collectively deliberate over whom to support, economic migrants in foreign soil who use informal networks to send money ‘back home’, neighbourhood groups who organise collective petitions to force the government to hear their demands, ethnic groups in conflict who mobilise for peace and reconciliation. 

Consider the following examples. In rural China, Lilly Tsai tells us, state officials embedded into temple networks of their home villages refrain from demanding bribes. In the absence of democratic institutions of accountability, temple leaders, on behalf of the community, reward upright officials with higher social standing. In Afghanistan, villages with strong councils (jirga) organise more successfully to ward off predatory behaviour from distant state officials. Similarly, communities organise for, but also against, rebel groups. In Mizoram, regions where villages were strongly interconnected through rotating church pastors witnessed greater rebel recruitment; the frequent exchange of information between well-connected villages reassured rebels that their secrets will not be leaked to security forces. In Colombia, in contrast, indigenous communities mobilised against FARC rebels. The ability of a community to organise collectively affects outcomes as varied as riots, prison violence, and the inner workings of the Sicilian Mafia. At the broadest scale, to echo Robert Putnam’s celebrated work on Italy, robust connections across otherwise disparate communities enhances social capital, which in turn, ‘makes democracy work’.

These anecdotes barely touch the surface of the critical role of community ties and networks in a diverse range of political phenomena – accountability, economic exchange (we will study how Hawala transactions work), civil war resistance, democracy, riots, and organised crime.      

In order to understand communities and collective action, the course will survey both classical and contemporary exemplars from across the social science (admittedly with a strong focus on political science). We will begin with a thorough baseline understanding of the concept of collective action – why do groups struggle to organise toward a goal that each member desires and will benefit from? What are some of the well-known solutions to collective action problem? 

Building upon this foundation, we will delve deeper into specific instances of collective action. To cite a few, we will study how closely-knit social networks (imagine a village where ‘everyone knows everyone’) can monitor their members (peer monitoring, in-group policing). We will uncover the nebulous concept of ‘trust’, that allows individuals to anticipate that their peers will honour their word when rational calculations should suggest otherwise. Of course, a course like this will remain incomplete without engaging with norms of reciprocity, solidarity and altruism.        

Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, students should have a sound overview of some of the major debates surrounding collective action by communities. It will also reinforce the department’s continuous training in analytical thinking. It will bolster students’ ability to distinguish between different theoretical explanations, evaluate the merit of competing arguments made in the literature, and communicate their arguments clearly in written form. 

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

This is a senior-level course and will follow the seminar format. In each meeting, I will frame the discussion and raise a few questions. I expect you to come prepared with summaries, thought-provoking questions and comments. Of course, I will contribute and moderate the discussion. That said, for a senior-level seminar to work, it is critical that you come prepared for a robust discussion.

Familiarity with civil war/conflict literature is necessary as the course structure simply does not afford time to get everyone up to speed.  Accordingly, I invite students who have previously taken at least one conflict-related course, either with me (POL 2091: Militants or Freedom Fighters, POL 2067: Nation and State-Making in India’s Borders) or Prof Dipin Kaur (IR-2041/ POL-2096 : The Politics of Peace: Reconstruction and Justice in Post-Conflict Societies, IR-3025: Security, Conflict, and Political Violence in the Contemporary World)

Readings

I defer other details to the syllabus. To preview the flavour of readings, here are some of the texts that you can expect to read:

Sample Suggested Readings:

Olson, Mancur. The Logic of Collection Action. Harvard University Press, 2009.

Gould, Roger V. “Collective Action and Network Structure.” American Sociological Review 58, no. 2 (1993): 182–96.

Ostrom, Elinor. Governing the Commons: The Evolution of Institutions for Collective Action. Cambridge [England]; New York: Cambridge University Press, 1990.

Tsai, Lily L. Accountability without Democracy: Solidary Groups and Public Goods Provision in Rural China. Cambridge Studies in Comparative Politics. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2007.

Murtazashvili, Jennifer Brick. Informal Order and the State in Afghanistan. New York, NY: Cambridge University Press, 2016.

Putnam, Robert D., Robert Leonardi, and Raffaella Nanetti. Making Democracy Work: Civic Traditions in Modern Italy. Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press, 1993.

Sarbahi, Anoop. “The Structure of Religion, Ethnicity, and Insurgent Mobilization: Evidence from India.” World Politics 73, no. 1 (January 2021): 82–127.

Rubin, Michael A. “Rebel Territorial Control and Civilian Collective Action in Civil War: Evidence from the Communist Insurgency in the Philippines.” Journal of Conflict Resolution 64, no. 2–3 (February 1, 2020): 459–89.

Skarbek, David. The Puzzle of Prison Order: Why Life Behind Bars Varies Around the World: Why Life Behind Bars Varies Around the World. New York, NY: Oxford University Press, 2020.

Skarbek, Emily.  “Remittances and Reputations in Hawala Money- Transfer Systems: Self-Enforcing Exchange on an International Scale.” Journal of Private Enterprise, January 1, 2008.

 

Grading Rubric

Course will not grade on a scale. 

Attendance Policy

Your participation is essential for the course’s success and you are expected to attend all lectures. As a form of professional courtesy, I expect that you will inform me about medical contingencies and scheduling conflicts (related to sports, debate events etc) ahead of time, with a written note from your coach or concerned authority. As long as you inform me with a valid reason, you can miss classes. You are allowed three unexcused absences. Beyond three unexcused absences, I’m afraid that we will dock points.

Elementary Sanskrit - I [SAN-1001/ HIS-1101] [SAN-1001/ HIS-1101-1]

Faculty Name
Nirajan Kafle [nirajan.kafle@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Elementary Sanskrit I is the first of a set of three language courses meant to introduce the beginner to Sanskrit Grammar.  At the end of this intensive course, the student will have learnt about half of the major topics required to read and comprehend texts in Classical Sanskrit. We assume no prior knowledge on behalf of the student. 

Learning Outcomes
  • A basic understanding of the grammar of classical Sanskrit, with a specific focus on declension and conjugation paradigms.
  • Familiarity with the relevant terminology used in the study of Sanskrit Grammar.
  • Development of a foundational vocabulary in Sanskrit.
  • The ability to translate basic Sanskrit sentences into English.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

We will follow the ‘‘Samskrta-Subodhini: A Sanskrit Primer" by Madhav Deshpande. Additional handouts and worksheets will be shared over the AMS.  I am to cover at least the following topics: 

  • Sanskrit Alphabet
  • Verbs: 1st conjugation
  • Personal Pronouns
  • Masculine, Neuter Nouns and Prepositions 
  • Verbs: 4th, 6th, 10th conjugations
  • Negation and Some Connectives; Sandhi
  • The Case System
  • Active Verbs: Past Imperfect, Imperative, Potential 
  • Personal Pronouns I
  • Use of Indeclinables 
  • Masculine Nouns in i and u, Sandhi visarga, vowels
  • Middle Verbs: Past Imperfect, Imperative, Potential
  • Personal pronouns II
  • Pronouns: kim, yad, etad
  • Masculine Nouns in i and u, Sandhi: visarga, vowels
  • Feminine Nouns in ā, ī, ū
Grading Rubric

Attendance and Class Quizzes 10%

Weekly assignments: 20%

Midterm Exam: 30%

Final Exam: 40%

Attendance Policy

This is a language course, and its success entirely depends upon your participation and preparation. Please be committed to doing the weekly quizzes and assignments. You need a minimum attendance of 70% to be eligible to take the exams. You are expected to turn up in time for the classes. If you need extra help with any topic, I am willing to help. But you have to take the first step – speak to me and schedule a tutorial. Take language courses seriously!

CourseTitle: From Mantras to Magic :Exploring South Asian Tantra through Gnosis, Ritual and the Mystic Arts
description:
From Mantras to Magic :Exploring South Asian Tantra through Gnosis, Ritual and the Mystic Arts [SAN-3002] [SAN-3002-1]

Faculty Name
Nirajan Kafle [nirajan.kafle@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In this course, we will examine a strand of the South Asian religious traditions that has eluded outsiders – Tantra.  It is a complex domain of ritual and mystical praxis that is only partially accessible through texts. We will study the various regional and historical instantiations of Tantric thought and practice, as it permeates and transforms the other ‘mainstream’ sectarian systems. 

Learning Outcomes

Throughout this course, students will gain a strong foundational understanding and a well-rounded knowledge of South Asian Tantric traditions. By the end, they will possess the tools to seamlessly integrate new information into their existing knowledge base. Additionally, they will develop the capacity to critically analyze and interpret the intricate interplay of cultural, religious, and intellectual factors that shape these traditions.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)
  • This course is designed to accommodate students from diverse academic backgrounds and those with a general interest in exploring the world of tantric traditions in South Asia. Therefore, the course does not assume any prior knowledge of Sanskrit. However, students should have some exposure to academic English. 

  • There is no single designated textbook. Relevant sources will be uploaded to the AMS.

  • We will cover the following topics during the thirteen weeks of the term: 

    Week 1:  Exploring Religious Practices in South Asia

     Week 2:  Tracing the Emergence of Tantric Traditions in South Asia

     Week 3:  Tantric Goals: Embracing Divine Enjoyment and Liberation

     Week 4:  Divine Intervention in Tantric Practices

     Week 5: The Inclusion of Yoga in Tantra 

     Week 6: The Role of Spiritual Knowledge in Tantra

     Week 7: Enchantment and Mantras across the Tantric Traditions 

     Week 8: Revealing the Mystique of Magic

     Week 9: The Transmutation of Body, Mind and Spirit

     Week 10: Shared Ritual Practices across Tantric Traditions

     Week 11: Navigating the Cosmic Symbolism through Mystical Mandalas

     Week 12: Influence of Tantric Art on the Temple Culture of South Asia

     Week 13: Revision and Final Discussion

Grading Rubric

1. Class participation, classrooms presentations: 50%

2. Final Paper + Presentation: 50%

Attendance Policy

Students should come to class on time. Students cannot ask to cancel the class with same-day notice. They should notify the teacher in case of an emergency at least a day before.  If students fail to come to the class, 5 marks will be reduced for each dropped class. If a student comes to the class after 10 minutes, they will be marked absent.

CourseTitle: Gender and Land, Rivers, and Livelihoods
description:
Gender and Land, Rivers, and Livelihoods [SOA-2220/ ES-2292] [SOA-2220/ ES-2292-1]

Faculty Name
Smita Tewari Jassal [smita.jassal@ashoka.edu.in] ;

Key Issues in Gender Analysis [SOA-2237] [SOA-2237-1]

Faculty Name
Smita Tewari Jassal [smita.jassal@ashoka.edu.in] ;

Law and Society [SOA-3127] [SOA-3127-1]

Faculty Name
Deepak Mehta [deepak.mehta@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Law and Society (SOA 3127-1)

How do we understand the institution of law, if by institution we mean a way of doing? What is the relationship of this institution to the social and what is the yield of doing an ethnography of law? In addressing these questions, the course will be organised on three overlapping registers of enquiry and a coda. In the first, we will discuss the foundational violence that lies at the heart of law. Particular emphasis will be directed on the making of Constitutional law in India in the backdrop of the partition. The second register will detail comparative ethnographies of the relation of law to gender and sexuality. The third register will provide a reading of the vexed relation of law and religion.

The course will close with discussing the relation between the rule of law and the law of rules. Particular attention will be directed to how the 'state of exception' puts into crisis legal regimes.

This is a reading intensive course. If the class decides, we can pick up themes that address specific interests. The last ten minutes of each class will end with a prompt that the students must respond to before the end of class. The prompts will be graded.Attendance is in compliance with university policy.

Concepts, Contemporaneity and the Social [SOA-6101] [SOA-6101-1]

Faculty Name
Deepak Mehta [deepak.mehta@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The course does not start with a list of ready made concepts that are applied to questions concerned with ethnography. Rather, the course will concentrate on how concepts emerge in their granular detail while doing ethnographic fieldwork. To achieve this analytic we will focus on one main text on method and a series of ethnographic investigations. In putting method and ethnography on the same register our aim will be to show that in anthropology concepts are not abstractions - they are embedded in the material and social world. The text on method is Michel Foucault's The Archaeology of Knowledge, while ethnographic readings centre around the making of files, genres of writing, both bureaucratic and poetic and the power of the archive.

This is a reading intensive course. Students will be expected to make weekly presentations of the readings assigned to them. 

The readings will be based on students' academic interests.

The course outcome is to show how ethnographic texts are made.

Grading Rubric

The grading is as follows: seminar evaluations 20%; mid-term essay 40%; end-term essay 40%.

Faculty Name
Deepak Asthana [deepak.asthana@ashoka.edu.in] ,Munmun Ghosh [munmun.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

List of Experiments:

For the General Chemistry, Laboratory II, Following twelve experiments are planned:

1.  Synthesis of benzilic acid from benzil (Solid-State Synthesis)

2. Productiom of bio-diesel by performing transesterification of vegetable oil

3. Spectroscopic study of DNA-ligand interaction and performing the binding constant analysis

4. Preparation of Ni-DMG complex

5. Estimation of ferrous and ferric ions in a given mixture

6. Rate constant determination of saponification reaction

7. Separation of Co, Zn and Ni ions present in a mixture (Chromatography)

8. Preparation of aspirin

9. Gravimetric analysis of Al and Zn

10. Detection of organic functional groups-1

11. Detection of organic functional groups-2

12. Determination of partition coefficient for benzoic acid between water and benzene solvents

Learning Outcomes

The experiments are designed to provide basic practical knowledge about organic & inorganic syntheses, and physical chemistry-based analytical investigations.

Students, those who have done General Chemistry Laboratory-I, will get introduced to next level of experimental techniques required for synthesis and characterization of new molecules.

Those students who does not have any previous experience of working in a chemistry lab will have a great opprtunity to learn some basic organic & inoganic synthesis techniques and characterization methods. Studets will learn safe handelling of hazardous chemicals, will learn about planning a synthesis reaction, and performing various analytical measurements to identify the unnown compounds.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prerequisite: None

This course is recommended for both who have studied chemistry, and also to those who does not have chemistry background but wants to leran about chemicals andchemical synthesis.

Mid Term Exam (Viva): 20%

Final term Exam (Experimental): 40%

Final term exam (Viva): 30%

Faculty Name

Overview

Students should complete “Introduction to Creative Writing” before enrolling in this course. This workshop will focus on fiction.

English Graduate Pro-Seminar: Thesis Preparation [ENG-4001] [ENG-4001-1]

Faculty Name
Alexander Robert Phillips [alexander.phillips@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The Masters Pro-Seminar is a weekly symposium that runs through the second year of the Masters program. The monsoon semester will feature a series of guests who will circulate a piece of writing and discuss the process with the participants. The discussion will focus primarily on the processes of research and writing that went into making the paper, although its subject and arguments will also receive attention. Additional sessions will focus on aspects of producing a lengthier research paper. We will talk about research methods, accurately representing and responding to the arguments of others, and making original contributions to scholarly conversations even when it seems everything has been said already.

Venture Planning and Strategy [ENT-2005] [ENT-2005-1]

Faculty Name
Ekanto Ghosh [ekanto.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Mukesh Sud [mukesh.sud@ashoka.edu.in] ,Priyank Narayan [priyank.narayan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sagar Singhal [sagar.singhal@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What tools do entrepreneurs need to successfully launch new ventures? How do entrepreneurs raise funds, create a team and get their venture off the ground? Are there any key ingredients of a successful start-up?

These, and other similar questions, will be a part of Venture Planning & Strategy. The course is organized around modules. After introducing the case study method (that forms the basis of course instruction through the term) the first two sessions will engage with personal dilemmas that entrepreneurs confront in the initial phases of their start-up. The role of entrepreneurial vision and the hopes & aspirations of first-generation entrepreneurs will be debated. Sessions 3 & 4 introduce the business model canvas (BMC) and the lean start-up methodology to understand the importance of rapid prototyping and the need of a minimum viable product (MVP). The key learning is the ability to rapidly prototype and has an MVP at the lowest cost and in the quickest time so that entrepreneurs can pivot on their initial ideas. In sessions 5 & 6 students will engage with industry analysis. They will learn a variety of frameworks and learn how to conduct an external industry analysis like strengths-weaknesses-opportunities-threats (SWOT), examine political, economic, social, technological, environmental and legal factors (PESTEL) and use Porter Five Force to evaluate the attractiveness of an industry. Sessions 7 & 8 introduce the concept of a Blue Ocean Strategy. Firms traditionally compete in red oceans which are crowded marketplaces where new entrants take market share from existing players. Over a period, this ends up being a zero-sum game. However, some entrepreneurial firms are able to create new opportunities by differentiating themselves and offering customers a new value innovation. How do they do it and what can we learn from it? Sessions 9&10 will analyze the financial and legal aspects of a startup. Financing options include bank loans, social media campaigns, venture funding, crowdfunding etc.. We will also discuss the advantages and pitfalls accompanying each of them. Sessions 11 will be devoted to understanding the entrepreneurial context in large firms where firms want their employees to be ‘intrapreneurs’. Firms increasingly seek to disrupt themselves through corporate innovation rather than wait for smaller start-ups to upend their business model. This will also introduce the concept of a hackathon where teams work on collaborative projects to produce a working prototype. The final sessions 12 & 13 will be devoted to student presentations on a business plan that they have been working on in groups through the term.

Attachment
Venture Planning _ Strategy - Mukesh Sud (2).pdf

CourseTitle: Technology Law and Policy: A New Frontier for Business and Society
description:
Technology Law and Policy: A New Frontier for Business and Society [ENT-2032] [ENT-2032-1]

Faculty Name
Ekanto Ghosh [ekanto.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Priyank Narayan [priyank.narayan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sagar Singhal [sagar.singhal@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will explore emerging law and policy issues in the realm of technology – in India and key foreign contexts including the U.S. and Europe. Given the increasingly pervasive nature of technology, these issues bring new and critical implications for a wide variety of professionals and businesses including but not only startups and other entrepreneurial initiatives; for society at large; and for the roles that businesses can play in society. These issues also transcend national boundaries, and routinely reflect and influence complex interactions between different nations. The course will address issues including data privacy; free speech and content moderation; competition; and others – and also distill practical skills and insights that cut across the various substantive issues discussed in the course. In doing so, the course will help prepare students to understand, navigate, and shape tech law and policy as part of the business world and more broadly – in India and globally.

Attachment
Technology Law and Policy - A New Frontier for Business and Society.docx

Decoding Generative AI [ENT-2033] [ENT-2033-1]

Faculty Name
Ekanto Ghosh [ekanto.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Jaspreet Bindra [jaspreet.bindra@ashoka.edu.in] ,Priyank Narayan [priyank.narayan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sagar Singhal [sagar.singhal@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The wheel, fire, the printing press, electricity, the computer, the smart phone, the Internet – these were some of the epochal technologies that changed everything about business, society and life; both for the better and for the worse. The latest to be added on this list is AI, specifically Generative AI, which ChatGPT and Bard have made household words. ChatGPT racked up a 100mn users in just 2 months; even Tiktok took nine. From banking to media to the arts, there is not a single industry that can escape its disruptive potential. Given the speed and scale at which Generative AI is advancing, it is imperative to understand what this technology is, how it works and what it means for you, business, the country, larger society, and the planet. This course will aim to involve you in conversations around Generative AI, giving you the tools and knowledge you will need to actively construct a more equitable AI-powered future. Featuring sessions by global thought leaders and industry-stalwarts, we will cover everything from core tech, to the ethics surrounding it and the future of jobs, work, and humanity itself.

Attachment
Decoding Generative AI_Monsoon 2023 .pdf

Strategies for Market Access [ENT-3011] [ENT-3011-1]

Faculty Name
Ekanto Ghosh [ekanto.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Priyank Narayan [priyank.narayan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sagar Singhal [sagar.singhal@ashoka.edu.in] ,Shantanu Bhanja [shantanu.bhanja@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Whether you are a start-up founder, product manager, the marketing manager or a sales head, this introductory course will provide you with real world knowledge and the tools you will need to build a successful business. Students will get a strong foundation and practical understanding with actual techniques and solutions for identifying a market landscape, building a value proposition, understanding the buying process and the role of different stakeholders in the decision making process, and create winning strategies over competition. Explorers on this journey will get exposed to different types of business models and their respective Go-to-Market strategies as well as success models for e-commerce and modern trade. They will get a hands-on experience of building pricing models and experience real in-market situations to appreciate the role of the various levers of business. Some of the other themes that will run through the course will be KPIs for success, Influencer marketing and Lifetime value of a customer.

CourseTitle: SIL: Startup Readiness and Grand Challenge
description:
SIL: Startup Readiness and Grand Challenge [ENT-4011] [ENT-4011-1]

Faculty Name
Ekanto Ghosh [ekanto.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Priyank Narayan [priyank.narayan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sagar Singhal [sagar.singhal@ashoka.edu.in] ,Srikant Sastri [srikant.sastri@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

A revised & enhanced version of the Spring 2023 course, Startup Incubation Lab (SIL).

The booming startup eco-system in India reflects the surge in entrepreneurship, but bigger companies in corporate sector are also embracing innovation and intrapreneurship to succeed in a fast-changing world. For students who are considering becoming entrepreneurs in the very near-future, this course would be like a ‘finishing school’. Whereas, students who want to work in the corporate sector or at startups, will acquire the foundational skills to be successful intrapreneurs driving innovation in these companies.

It would be a fast-paced and immersive experience of the entire entrepreneurial journey from Idea to MVP. Besides the product and commercial aspects that are important while creating new ventures, several classes will be devoted to helping students become ‘Contemplative Entrepreneurs’ and ‘Doing it Right’. ‘Contemplative entrepreneurs’ are trained to ask critical questions on a timely basis, rather than take decisions on the fly. This ensures that they make fewer mistakes. ‘Doing it Right’ means not giving a short shrift to the ethics and governance aspects of business leadership. The world around is replete with examples of high-profile entrepreneurs who have gone astray on this count.

I will begin by helping students sharpen their ‘Problem Statement’, and then do disruptive ideation that will be validated through ‘Voice of the Customer’. Thereafter, developing a product strategy (incl. designing and executing a MVP) will be a big part of the learning. Students will also learn key business concepts (e.g. business models, moats, go-to-market frameworks & performance metrics) and incorporate them into their own venture. At a mid-point of the course, students will do field visits to meet a set of startup founders in NCR, and also meet some domain mentors.

Finally, students will develop their investor pitches using structured frameworks as well as compelling storytelling techniques. The culmination of this Startup Grand Challenge will be a ‘Demo Day’ where students will pitch to a panel of investors and mentors.

This hands-on bootcamp-style course  intertwines theory & practice so that students learn key concepts of new venture creation while simultaneously putting them in practice. It also aims to prepare students with the right balance of hard & soft skills.

Learning Outcomes
  1. Become well-versed in key concepts like problem identification, ideation, customer development, MVP, business models, defensibility, and go-to-market strategy.
  2. Gain hands-on experience of venture development all the way through to creating and testing a MVP.
  3. Learn life-skills like teamwork, real-time iterations, overcoming roadblocks, and storytelling.
  4. Students begin to appreciate the need to take a contemplative and well-balanced approach to their journey as an entrepreneur or intrapreneur, rather than get carried away by hype.
  5. Appreciate the importance of Purpose & Culture, as well as developing the right temperament.
  6. Being able to make conscious choices by thinking deeply about the rapidly-changing environment as well as personal aspirations, ethics and values.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Required Readings:

Books: How to be a Founder (Bloomsbury); The Storyteller’s Secret (Macmillan); The Ventilator Project (Pan Macmillan)

Case studies (all HBSP): (i) Negotiating equity splits at UpDown;  (ii) Rent The Runway; (iii) Facebook: monetization; (iv) Patagonia: Earth is now our only shareholder; (v) Fighting corruption at Siemens; (vi) Facebook: Hard questions; (vii) Apple: Privacy VS Safety

Other readings (all HBSP): Identifying & exploiting the right entrepreneurial opportunity for you; How VCs evaluate potential venture opportunities; Ethics in the age of AI; Ethical analysis: Situation VS Character

Team formation:

It would be ideal if students register for the course in groups of 2-3 (ideally), or individually (in exceptional cases).

Each team must comprise a set of people with complementary skill sets. A team must have at least one person who’s able to build a website & one person with digital marketing skills. Alternatively, the team must be able to access these resources from their wider network

Grading Rubric

One mid-semester submission (25% weightage); ‘Demo Day’ presentation & ‘pitch deck’ (25%); Class participation & attendance (25%); Final exam (25%)

Attendance Policy

As per University policy. That said, regular attendance and class participation will result in a richer course experience as well venture creation outcomes. And, as stated above, there is a 25% weightage for class participation & attendance.

Attachment
Startup Readiness and Grand Challenge_for catalog-July 2023.pdf

SpaceName: AC02-104 (TR), Media Lab 111, AC02-104 (TR), Media Lab 111
description:
Art and Craft of Sound [MS-2041] [MS-2041-1]

Overview

MS 2041 Art & Craft of Sound Gaurav Chintamani  ( https://www.gauravchintamani.com/) MEDIA PRODUCTION

Course cap: 20

Timetable: Thursday 10.10 am - 1.20 pm

No prerequisite. 

Overview: Of all the senses we possess, hearing cannot be turned off voluntarily. One of the strongest tools in the arsenal of media professionals, sound has the ability to construct, amplify and create more dynamic narratives, while engaging subliminally. Whether it is in the form of music or sound design, sound art or spoken word. This course is an audio literacy primer.

In this course over three months, we will deconstruct sound and explore the building blocks of audio from the lens of its Nature, Behaviour and Interaction. We will break it down to its key components of physics, its interaction with space and different mediums, its translation and the listener’s interpretation of this engagement. This will guide us through the levels of intervention that can be done in pre and post production through Digital Audio Workstations (DAW) to construct and curate the steps in the processing of sound. These techniques of bending sound can be applied to all forms of sound in various media; be it podcasting, audiobooks, music production, sound design and sound art. A course which introduces nature, behaviour and our interaction with sound through multiple audio forms and ways of listening.

Learning Outcomes

Learning Outcome: A strong foundation in understanding the key components of sound. Including developing the ability to visualise and interpret how sound interacts with different acoustic environments.

Identify the skills to record and manipulate this, applying post production techniques of processing audio, assessing the contrast and tweaking the audio. Both while capturing it and in post-production; to narrow the differences for more coherence and continuity in the program material.

The students will be able to assess the merits between different microphones, make informed choices on equipment and techniques of recording.

Get a firm grasp on navigating DAWs and be able to work with multitrack audio. They will be able to tweak multitrack audio with regard to the final delivery medium.

Engage with sound using processing tools with a focus on the sound’s emotional contour and context. They will develop the foundation for the skills needed to ensure that the program material translates and sounds as intended across different playback systems.

Compile in the form of an audio story / podcast (fiction or nonfiction) with stock music and SFX and render it for release with industry standard audio specs.

Introduction to Counseling Psychology [PSY-3042] [PSY-3042-1]

Faculty Name
Soumya Madabhushi [soumya.madabhushi@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Description:

This course is designed to provide the students with an overview of Counseling Psychology as a profession and define the subject matter of this field. The history, philosophy, values, and organization of counseling psychology both as an academic discipline and as a helping profession are explored. The course will provide students with an introduction to the major therapeutic approaches and an exploration of issues associated with values, ethics, research design, and more. Discussions, demonstrations, and exercises give students an opportunity to explore counseling psychology as a career path.

 

Learning Outcomes

By the end of the semester students will be able to:

  • distinguish counseling psychology as a profession from other areas of contemporary applied psychology and define its subject matter;
  • recognize the ethical issues associated with the field of counseling psychology;
  • describe and evaluate the theories and research pertaining to a range of topics in counseling psychology;
  • compare and contrast different psychotherapy orientations;
  • reflect on the role of social issues, privilege and oppression, and multicultural issues related to psychotherapy and mental health
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Required Readings:

Gelso, C. J., Nutt Williams, E., & Fretz, B. R. (2014). Counseling psychology (3rd ed.). Washington, DC: American Psychological Association. https://doi.org/10.1037/14378-000 (ISBN: 978-1-4338-1711-3)

Recommended Readings:

American Psychological Association [APA] (2020). Publication Manual of the American Psychological Association (7th ed.). Washington, DC: APA. https://doi.org/10.1037/0000165-000 (ISBN: 978-1-4338-3217-8)

APA Style Tutorials & Webinars: https://apastyle.apa.org/instructional-aids/tutorials-webinars/

**Please note that I may change/add readings to those mentioned in the syllabus. I’ll announce changes in readings (if any) during our class at least two weeks prior to when I expect you to read them**

Grading Rubric

Attendance - 5% of final grade

Participation and Class Citizenship – 5% of final grade

Learning Checks – 20% of final grade

Cultural Event Paper- 15% of final grade

Conceptualization Paper - 20% of final grade

Group Outreach Project– 30% of final grade

Self-Reflection Paper – 5% 0f final grade

Attendance Policy

Attendance Policy
Research has shown that students who attend class regularly tend to receive better grades than students with sporadic attendance. This is likely to also be true in this class. Class participation will account for 5% of your final grade. The evaluation of class participation will rest primarily on (a) attendance (3 “free” absences allowed), (b) the synthesis of the readings and the presented material, as communicated during classroom discussion, and (c) Discussion boards. You are also required to attend weekly DS sessions led by the TF (2 “free” absences allowed).

CourseTitle: Applied Behaviour Science: Norms, Nudges and Law
description:
Applied Behaviour Science: Norms, Nudges and Law [PSY-4061] [PSY-4061-1]

Faculty Name
Pavan Mamidi [pavan.mamidi@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Development professionals and policymakers are increasingly adopting behavioural insights to tackle profound challenges. While traditional policy tools focus on financial resources, laws and incentives, a behavioural approach focuses on human biases, heuristics, social norms, and choice architecture. Borrowing from various long standing disciplines, including economics, psychology, sociology, and neuroscience, behavioural insights has helped tackle complex development challenges, such as improving education outcomes by enhancing student learning, raising savings rates, promoting energy and water conservation, improving sanitation practices, improving health and nutrition outcomes for women and children and strengthening institutions, among others.

The course initiates students to solve complex social problems with a keen understanding of human behaviour. In this course, participants will learn the fundamental principles of applied behavioural and experimental economics and explore how these principles can be applied towards creating impact in the broader social ecosystem.

Grading Rubric
  • Attendance and Participation – 15% of final grade
  • Midterm Paper - 40% of final grade
  • Group Research Project and Presentation – 45% of final grade
Attendance Policy

Ideally, I would like students to actively participate in class and have at least 80% attendance.
Class participation will account for 10% of your final grade. The evaluation of class participation will rest primarily on (a) attendance, and (b) the synthesis of the readings and the presented material, as communicated during classroom discussion. Attendance therefore is strongly encouraged.

CourseTitle: Arts of our Times 1(Mediums and Media in Contemporary)
description:
Arts of our Times 1(Mediums and Media in Contemporary) [VA-2400] [VA-2400-1]

Faculty Name
Rakhi Peswani [rakhi.peswani@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Description:

This course will enable the fundamentals of contemporary artistic practices through the structures of Materiality, Space, Place, Time and (Im)materiality. Students will be urged to develop questions and expressions through a basis in practice of visual and other media forms. The course will engage experimentation in 2Dimensional, 3 Dimensional and time based media to arrive at ideas and concepts through experiments in various forms of media like drawing, clay, scanvenged and found images, graffiti,

architectural sites, outdoor spaces, site specific aspects of other spaces will be explored. The course will culminate into a public exhibition/display as per the students capacity/ambition.

 

Framework and Objectives:

The objective of this course is to enable students with foundational clarity in contemporary artistic practices and its possibilities. The course is designed to provide students certain potentiality in observing or asking difficult/complex concerns or reflections with and through varying media of artistic practices.

The course will be based on certain guidelines of media specificity and expansion of concepts/messages through medium.

Since it is a studio based course, certain introductions to histories of abstraction and installation art will be provided through the framework of revisionist art practices after 1960s as well as introductions to affective possibilities of artistic languages. Both these realms will be expanded through making of artistic forms, referring histories of art practices and artists, students presentations and classroom discussions

The overarching objective of the course is to provide students with faith and confidence in visual/aural/verbal languages that amalgamate other sense perceptions and to provide certain foundational understanding of language and affect in artistic forms.

 

Details of Course Modules 

(Each module will run for 6 weeks. The course is divided into two modules.) 

The course will enable the fundamentals of contemporary artistic practices through various tropes and themes. Students will be urged to develop questions and expressions through a basis in practice of visual and other media forms. The course will engage experimentation in 2-Dimensional, 3-Dimensional and time based media to arrive at ideas and concepts through experiments in forms.

The objective of this course is to enable students with foundational clarity in contemporary artistic practices and its possibilities. Since it is a studio based course, certain introductions to histories of abstraction and installation art will be provided through the framework of revisionist art practices after the 1960s as well as provide introductions to affective possibilities of artistic languages. Both these realms will be expanded through making of artistic form and references towards art practices.

The course has extensive references to research in art practice.

Each area will be discussed in class and reference points will be provided. Exercises will be shared in class along with classwork.

Each module will end with a class discussion and submission.

Module 2:

Genomics & next generation sequencing [BIO-4206/ BIO-6206] [BIO-4206/ BIO-6206-1]

Faculty Name
Balaji Chattopadhyay [balaji.chattopadhyay@ashoka.edu.in] ,Kritika Garg [kritika.garg@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is application oriented with a focus on understanding and making use of data in biology. The systematic acquisition of data made possible by advances in genomics and proteomics technologies has created a gap between the available data and its analysis leading to insights from the data. In addition, the data from multiple sources can be used to generate hypothesis and answer important questions. Computational and theoretical approaches to understanding biological systems are an essential step in closing this gap. Since statistics plays, an important role in data analysis lectures on relevant topics of statistics are part of the course.  The major emphasis of the course is to be able to solve some of common problems using the approaches being taught in the class.

Learning Outcomes

Students will learn about different forms of biological data including next generation sequencing data generation and how it has revolutionized our current understanding of biology. Further, students will learn to about data handling, analysis and interpretation. They will be able to answer simple biological questions using data analysis. The biostatistics part of the course will introduce students to application of statistical theory to biological data. Students will learn the concept of various test and their application use real data.

Grading Rubric

Relative grading system

Assignments: 30% (three assignments 10 marks each)

Mid-sem exam: 30%

End-Sem exam: 40%

General Chemistry Laboratory [CHM-2402] [CHM-2402-1]

Faculty Name
Santu Bera [santu.bera@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Chemistry plays a crucial part of our everyday life for creating new molecules endow with usage in foods, cosmetics, technologies to medicines. The lab course has been designed to provide you a comprehensive hands-on experience in chemistry and covers all aspects of the discipline including organic, inorganic and physical chemistry. These are a total of 12 laboratory practicals listed below:

1. Oxidation Reaction: Preparation of benzil from benzoin

2. Rearrangement Reaction: Benzoin to benzilic acid

3. Cadmium Sulfide Nanoparticles: Synthesis, optical characterization and determination of band gap using UV-VIS spectroscopy-Day 1.

4. Cadmium Sulfide Nanoparticles: Synthesis, optical characterization and determination of band gap using UV-VIS spectroscopy-Day 2.

5. Determination of E value of Ag/AgCl electrode and hence f+ by Potentiometric Method.

6. Nylon synthesis.

7. Detection by complexation with iron (III) salt and optical absorbance spectroscopy and determination of reaction stoichiometry by applying the method of continuous variation (Jobs’ method).

8. Assignment of d-d transitions in [Ni(OH2)6]SO4 and FeCl3.6H2O coordination complexes. Evaluation of 10Dq parameter and inter-electronic repulsion parameters (B) for [Ni(OH2)6]SO4 by using UV-VIS spectroscopy.

9. Cis and Trans-isomers: Synthesis of geometrical isomers cis and trans-dichloro bis (ethylenediamine) cobalt (III) Chloride.

10. Characterization of geometrical isomer (synthesised in exp 7) by UV-VIS and IR spectroscopy.

11. Synthesis of paracetamol (Step-I).

12. Synthesis of paracetamol (Step-II)

Learning Outcomes

Students will receive basic understanding and hands-on chemistry:

1.  Students will learn how to handle chemicals, carry out small scale synthesis in the lab and their identification and characterization.

2. After completing this course, students will be able to do organic synthesis, oxidation, rearrangement reactions.

 3. Students will learn to synthesize and characterize nanoparticles.

4. Students will learn how to use different spectroscopic instruments like absorption, emission, IR spectrometers and determination of important parameters using these instrumental techniques.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Procedures will be provided to each student before every experiment.

Grading Rubric

Experimental exam: 60%

Oral: 10%

Notebook: 20%

Class engagement: 10%

Attendance Policy

70% Attendance

Data Structures [CS-1203] [CS-1203-2]

Faculty Name
Subhamoy Maitra [subhamoy.maitra@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will introduce students to a wide array of data structures, mechanisms of analysis, along with when and how to use them. This will involve some heavy implentation work. Students will:

  • Learn about the wide variety of data structures available and how they can completely change how we approach problems.
  • Design and analyze nontrivial algorithms using these structures.
  • Solve recurrences and learn standard graph and sequence algorithms; they will also apply their knowledge of how to write simple proofs of correctness from prior courses.
Learning Outcomes

Outline:

  1. Algorithmic Thinking, Peak Finding
  2. Asymptotics and a crash course in complexity, including competetive analysis
  3. Insertion Sort, Selection Sort, Merge Sort, Sorting Lower Bounds, Counting Sort, Radix Sort
  4. Arrays and Lists, Stacks and Queues
  5. Heaps, Heap Sort, Fibonacci heaps
  6. Binary Search Trees, BST Sort, dynamic optimality
  7. AVL Trees, AVL Sort
  8. (Optional) Red-Black trees, Zip-trees
  9. Direct access array, Hashing (including both SUHA and Universal hashing)
  10. Quadtrees
  11. Breadth-First Search (BFS), Depth-First Search (DFS), Topological Sort
  12. Single-Source Shortest Paths Problem, Relaxation Algorithms
  13. Bellman-Ford, Dijkstra, dynamic graphs
  14. Union Find, self-organizing lists
  15. Optimizing for the memory hierarchy
  16. Persistent structures
  17. Geometry (maps, database tables)
  18. Strings
  19. Integers
  20. Succinct and sublinear structures
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

I will provide links and other reading materials in class. Students do not need to buy any textbooks.

Grading Rubric

There will be 6 homework assignments (with the best 5 out of 6 being counted), along with 2 exams.

  • 40% homework
  • 30% first exam
  • 30% second exam

Homework assignments must be submitted on time. Late submissions will not be accepted.

Attendance Policy

I do not take attendance in class - you snooze, you lose! Missing an exam for any reason will result in a zero.

CourseTitle: Demystifying Investments: Private Equity and Venture Capital
description:
Demystifying Investments: Private Equity and Venture Capital [ENT-2034/ FIN-3016] [ENT-2034/ FIN-3016-1]

Faculty Name
Ekanto Ghosh [ekanto.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Priyank Narayan [priyank.narayan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sagar Singhal [sagar.singhal@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sridhar Sethuraman [sridhar.sethuraman@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The rapid growth of Institutional Capital deployed within emerging markets, incl India, has created significant opportunities for entrepreneurs across a variety of sectors, incl the social impact sector. Institutional Capital denotes all types of capital including Grants, Angel, Seed Venture Capital Private Equity, and long-term Hedge Funds. This course will offer students the opportunity to hear of, and participate in, the opportunities and challenges facing institutional
investors. The course will include India specific case studies and sharing of experiences of successful investors and entrepreneurs. It covers several industries incl Real Estate, Fin Tech, Social enterprises, and Ecommerce.
The course is based on the fundamental premise that the personal life & career of every individual is also one of an investor and entrepreneur (everyone has to have an entrepreneur mindset whether salaried or an entrepreneur). Students can apply the same investment principles when taking decisions in professional life – incl. when they decide their career choices (where to invest the time capital of life). And that their professional journey post-graduation on the 4 pillars of any investment: Risk-Return –Investment-Mindset will mirror the life cycle of any enterprise from a startup (risk seeking) to VC to PE (more conservative) to finally being a Listed company where employers will sell and exit if they do not perform (with multiple turnarounds on the journey).
While this course uses the field of unlisted investments as an anchor, the paramount learning outcome it seeks to deliver to help the participant build a muscle of identifying and having courage to a) admitting about matters we think we don’t know b) identify the matters which are important for you and your success in life and c) building a mental process to go out and understand them and learn. You will also experience the stultifying power of fear of failure and helplessness that inhibits success in any investment decision (incl. your decision to invest time and credits in this course)

CourseTitle: Deconstructing Social Sector Systems in India
description:
Deconstructing Social Sector Systems in India [ENT-2035] [ENT-2035-1]

Faculty Name
Ekanto Ghosh [ekanto.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Priyank Narayan [priyank.narayan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sagar Singhal [sagar.singhal@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The development sector in India today is a vibrant space especially for young professionals. There is an increasing openness of governments to civil society, not-for-profit grassroot organisations, social ventures, and professional services/external experts. This has been equally matched by shifting young adult preferences, especially from socially conscious and economically secure backgrounds, who are looking for opportunities to enhance their social contribution through their professional lives. The opportunities to affect social change have therefore grown exponentially – in the form of public sector fellowships, lateral entries into government, social sector/not for profit roles, research and think-tanks, entrepreneurship and start-ups, as well areas like social sector consulting and impact investing.

However, even as the inputs (people as well as money) increase manifold into this space, the improvement in outcomes is much slower. The quality of public-sector school education remains poor and successive NAS/ASER reports do not indicate a secular upward trend; even over decades. Public health systems still provide for only 30% of India’s population with 70% people paying out of pocket for healthcare needs. Metrics like IMR/MMR/immunization rates or stunting are barely moving. Despite increasing subsidies and numerous programs, agriculture that engages 45% of India’s workforce, it is not remunerative and holds limited attraction for youth as a talent pool. The average monthly income per agricultural household is just ₹10,218 with just 4-5% annual growth.

Where does this dichotomy of increased inputs and yet stagnant outcomes come from? Why do entrepreneurial innovations typically not scale and lead to transformative outcomes? What structural factors lie at the heart of it? How can those who are looking to enter this space understand and begin to tackle this dichotomy from day 1? We hope that this course will help you answer some of these essential questions and better prepare you for a professional career that interacts with this space in any shape or form.

Deconstructing Social Sector Systems.pdf

Entrepreneurial Strategies for Climate Action [ENT-2037] [ENT-2037-1]

Faculty Name
Dvr Seshadri [dvr.seshadri@ashoka.edu.in] ,Ekanto Ghosh [ekanto.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Priyank Narayan [priyank.narayan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sagar Singhal [sagar.singhal@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is offered as an elective for Ashoka University students. It brings the perspective, “People + Planet = Profit” [often referred to as the triple bottom line] to the centerstage, which is a refreshing contrast to the predominant view imbibed by students, especially in business schools that the purpose of a business is profit maximization; all else only facilitates this pursuit.

The world is in a state that can best be described as “PLANETARY EMERGENCY.” Signals pointing to this are visible to all of us everywhere, to see. Each of us is witnessing the tragic fallout of this perspective, with climate change set to disrupt all known goal posts. For example, typically, Delhi during end of March each year records peak temperatures in the mid-30 degrees Celsius. The year, 2022 was the hottest in 121 years of the history of recorded temperatures in India, with temperatures exceeding 41 degrees Celsius by March 27!

Even in ‘advanced countries’ such as the USA, companies and the public typically give "lip service" to environmental issues.  Everyone is in favor of it until they have to pay for it.  On the ground however, we do not see much progress on these issues until it's economically beneficial to save the environment. It appears to be all about the money! 

So, when it comes to advocating these issues, one must emphasize the cost savings first and then double back and talk about how it will save the environment (i.e., economics before environment).  Hence, to succeed in the efforts to address the looming challenges, one should start by talking about economic "Customer Value Assessment" before one tackles specific environmental issues.  That's the winning formula. This is where the marketing angle of the issue of fostering a sustainable planet takes precedence. However, as can be recognized, it is not just about marketing!

The course, ‘Entrepreneurship and Climate Change’ [EACC] discusses the issues relating to sustainability from the perspective of businesses and the firm, and hence touches all aspects of the functioning of a firm, including its business, strategy, finance, operations, and much more. It thus takes an integrative approach, and fits in well with an elective course offering provided towards the final terms of any good undergraduate program. The course will equip students to prepare for the world that is fast unfolding before us, and help their companies to prosper, while doing good to the planet earth.

CourseTitle: Methods in Ecology and Conservation Science
description:
Methods in Ecology and Conservation Science [ES-3302/ BIO-3023/ BIO-4023] [ES-3302/ BIO-3023/ BIO-4023-1]

Faculty Name
Divya Karnad [divya.karnad@ashoka.edu.in] ,Manvi Sharma [manvi.sharma@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Description and Objectives:

The goal of this course is to introduce students to field methods in ecology and conservation science by involving both ecological fieldwork, lab work, and social science research methods. The course will also have open ended exercises, wherein students will be encouraged to come up with small questions and seek answers by experimentation. 

Course structure:

Week 1 - Orientation to asking research questions in social science

Week 2 - Social science methods: Quantitative

Week 3 - Orientation to asking research questions in ecology

Week 4 - Social science methods: Qualitative

Week 5 - Social science methods: Trials and refinements

Week 6 - Social science methods: Data transcription and basic analysis

Week 7 - Ecological Methods: Abundance and distribution (Sampling natural insect populations in the field)

Week 8 - Ecological Methods: Behavioural Ecology (Predator-prey interaction experiments)

Week 9 - Ecological Methods: Camera-trapping methods

Week 10 - Ecological Methods: Data Analysis and Writing

Week 11 - Independent work

Week 12 - Independent work

Week 13 - Independent work

Week 14 - Student presentations

Please note that the schedule or structure is subject to change depending on logistical reasons associated with proposed experiments. 

Grading Rubric

Attendance and discussion (15%): Every week, there will be one class, where activities include field visits, lab exercises and discussion. Students will be evaluated on their participation in these, where participation grades will be based on quality of participation. 

Weekly lab reports (50%): Students will also have to submit weekly lab reports on their experiment (see weekly handout for instructions). However, we will drop the lowest assignment score during final evaluation. You will be evaluated based on how structured and meticulous you are, not the experimental results. We will also consider your critical abilities (e.g. strength and weakness of experimental methods, future direction) while writing the report.

Final project (35%): Students will formulate a hypothesis that tests a natural law of their choice, devise an experiment to test the hypothesis, conduct the experiment, analyse the data and write a final report. They will also present their project in the last week of class. 10% of the grade will depend on peer grading by fellow students. Grades depend on originality, critical thinking, thoroughness and implications of research. 

Attendance Policy

Attendance is mandatory. Not more than three unexcused absences will be allowed.

This is an advanced course in Corporate Finance.  It provides the analytical tools and their application to specific corporate investment and financing decisions.

The basic analytical tools are:

These tools are applied to investment and financing decisions in the following context:

Migration and Media [MS-3831] [MS-3831-1]

Faculty Name
Priti Ashoka [priti.david@ashoka.edu.in] ,Seeta Sharma [seeta.sharma@ashoka.edu.in] ,Yashika Pawan Singla [yashika.singla_ug24@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview
Faculty: Priti David and Seeta Sharma [priti.david@ashoka.edu.in, seeta.sharma@ashoka.edu.in]

Course cap 15  | Timetable: Friday 2:50 - 6:00 pm | TA: yashika.singla_ug24@ashoka.edu.in | Office Hours: Friday 11am to 1pm

Overview

Hundred of millions of Indians are on the move, seeking work as migrant labourers: building our cities, cleaning our homes and growing our food, sending money back home. Migration is not a choice they make, it is a necessity, the only way to eat, to repay debts, to fund schooling and more. How do we tell their stories, and how are they represented in the media? Learning how to report on migration will lay the ground for future reporting on the dispossessed, the disenfranchised and the marginalised. We will be bringing in P. Sainath, Founder Editor of PARI who has written extensively on migration, to do a masterclass on migration journalism. 

This course will open a conversation on migrant labour, identifying the issues they face, the policies that help or fail them, the stories of their lives and livelihoods. We will be unpacking migration stories, examining their intersection with gender, occupation, skills, education, healthcare, losses and re-configured communities, festivals and more.

This course will be co-taught by two industry professionals: Priti David is a journalist and Executive Editor, People’s Archive of Rural India (PARI), and has reported extensively on displacement; Seeta Sharma is an international migration specialist, ex-ILO and current GOI consultant negotiator. 

Learning Outcomes

Writing, documenting stories of marginalised people calls for a empathy, observation and detail of a level not seen in other kids of journalistic storytelling.

Students will learn the basic skills of PARI’s style of reporting, how to research, interview and photograph using mobile devices.

You will get an insight into the process of journalistic storytelling, background researching, interviewing and photographing. 

Gain a ringside view of Indian migrant labour.

Understand how to use both of the above when working on pitching and publishing stories with a journalistic organisation.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

We will be reading across internal and international migration books and papers to better understand the landscape.

We will have a Guest Lecture by P. Sainat to learn how migration reporting has evolved over the last 30 years. 

We will have a Masterclass in Photojournalism by Photo Editor, PARI, Binaifer Bharucha.  

Pre-requisite terms & conditions:

This is an advanced Journalism course. You should be able to meet one of the following conditions

a. If you are enrolling for MS 1101 Introduction to News Writing & Reporting course in the Monsoon Semester of AY 2023-2024, you are qualified to apply for this course. If you have not already done the MS 1101 course and enrol in the Monsoon semester, then, please know that if you drop the Prerequisite course, you will also be dropped from being eligible for this course.

b. Have already done the prerequisite course

c. For any exceptions, write to Tisha Srivastav, MS Student Rep team and course professors in a common email with evidence of experience in journalistic/news writing. Please note: All three should be marked on this mail. The email IDs of the course professors is given on top. 

Grading Rubric

This course is geared towards journalistic writing, so the final submission will be critical to high grades. Students will be graded on critical thinking, application of the elements of researching, reporting and journalistic storytelling taught in the course.  

Total marks = 70 (Part 1)

Final Submission of story (marked for choice of / finding relevant subject, larger issues covered through the narrative, details, inputs followed through and photographs) = 40

FACES submission (a micro journalism project, will be judged for speed, accuracy relevance) = 10

Attendance, Class Participation and in-Class Assignments = 10

Attendance Policy

One  absence is permitted, but not for the field visit. Grading will be based on continuous assessment through the course and any absences will result in a reduction in the overall grade.

Helping Skills [PSY-4140] [PSY-4140-1]

Faculty Name
Soumya Madabhushi [soumya.madabhushi@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is designed to provide an introduction to psychotherapy skills. Students will be able to understand elements of ethical and effective counseling practice. They will be able to identify and use a variety of helping Skills at a beginner level with an appreciation of personal and sociocultural factors. The course also aims to enhance student understanding of self as a tool and increase self-awareness and self-reflective abilities. Students will practice helping skills with each other and attendance is mandatory and contributes to the course grade. Note that the course will involve discussing and working with emotionally charged content. Students should also be prepared to reflect on, and talk about (not mandated) some personal/emotional issues in class.

Learning Outcomes

At the completion of this course, students will be able to…

  • Identify helping skills, analyze their function, and evaluate their usefulness
  • Demonstrate a working knowledge of the Hill three-stage model of helping.
  • Use helping skills at a beginner level
  • Articulate ways their & others’ use of helping skills are influenced by personal and larger sociocultural characteristics

Note: Completion of this course does not qualify students to practice as counselors or therapists.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Required Reading:

Textbook: Hill, C. E. (2014). Helping skills: Facilitating exploration, insight, and action (4 ed.). Washington DC: American Psychological Association. ISBN: 978-1-4338-1678-9

Recommended Readings:

  • APA Ethical Code can be found online at: http://www.apa.org/ethics/code/index.aspx
  • Multicultural Guidelines can be found online at http://www.apa.org/pi/oema/resources/policy/multicultural-guidelines.aspx
  • Guidelines for practice with LGB clients can be found at: http://www.apa.org/pi/lgbt/resources/guidelines.aspx

**Please note that I may change/add readings to those mentioned in the syllabus. I’ll announce changes in readings (if any) during our class at least two weeks prior to when I expect you to read the articles**

Lab Score: Helping Sessions, Review, and Final Report – 35%

    • Helping Session  2: 15%              Review 2: 10%

*The standard Ashoka grading rubric for letter grades will be followed.

Attendance Policy

Student’s participation is essential in this course and is graded.

Lecture participation grades - will be based on your attendance and active engagement in the class discussion (e.g, asking questions, sharing a thought or opinion to generate discussion among classmates).

Lab participation grades - will consider your attendance, bility to stay on task, engage actively in the roleplays (as either a helper, client, or observer), to provide both positive and constructive feedback to your classmates on their skills, and to come into lab with concerns or problems to talk about.
